column2: Mayor Beame announced yesterday that his administration was rejecting an application by real-estate interests to remove from rent control all controlled apartments in New York City renting for $300 a month or more.
TRENTON, July 27 New jobs in New Jersey increased by 47,000 in May, and the number of people working in June was near a record high, the State Department of Labor and Industry Department said today.
The dollar held firm yesterday in foreign-exchange trading in Europe and, later, in New York, the Associated Press reported.

A union official, once linked by the Senate Labor Rackets Commitee with such Mafia figures as John DioGuardi and Anthony "Tony Ducks" Corrallo, was indicted yesterday along with five other persons and three companies on charges of extortion and labor racketeering.
CAIRO, July 27 Progress toward a peace agreement between Libya and Egypt was announced tonight, but the basic differences between the two countries clearly remain.
Some events of interest for enthusiasts of the house and home. Long Island Estate Auction, Old westbury, L.I.

DENVILLE, N.J., July 27 Martin Vybihal of Clinton, N.J., who has just returned from playing in the world junior golf championships in California, today led the way into the semifinal round of the 60th Metropolitan Golf Association junior tournament at the Rockaway River Country Club.
"we fully expect this advertising will bring us some grief and it could have a reverse marketing effect. But we have ultimate faith that the good will overshadow that."

P/E refers to price-earnings ratio, the number of times the company's latest 12-month earnings can be divided into the stock's closing price. All prices are in dollars. The letter u-stands for new annual high and d-indicates new low.
There will be free Shakespeare in the park this summer, after all.

ELON MOREH, Israeli-Occupied West Bank July 28 For 18 months bright red Israeli postal vans serving towns and villages in occupied Jordan whisked pest a large highway signpost proclaiming in large Hebrew letters the location of Elon Moreh.
Thinking of moving? How about a restored manor in the Blue Ridge Mountains? It's a steal at $2 million.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) The House Banking Committee today approved a bill designed to bring the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board into a somewhat closer relationship with the President and Congress.

AS A BOY, James Thomas Hooper was tireless in his quest of the art and artifacts of primitive peoples. He began his collection when he was 12 with an African spear, a gift from his father. Then, in pursuit of other weapons and crafts, he traveled by bus and bicycle from one junk shop to another throughout London.
Mayor Beame signed into law yesterday a bill creating a new city department to handle records of the city's business dating back to the l7th century.

WASHINGTON, July 28 A new urbanrural coalition in the House of Representatives succeeded today in winning passage of a four-year farm bill estimated to cost $10.5 billion to $11.5 billion annually, including $5.6 billion for a revised food stamp program.

Fair to partly cloudy skies will cover the Northeast today. Showers and thundershowers will be scattered through most of the rest of the Eastern Board, the lake region, Ohio Valley and lower Mississippi Valley; scattered showers and thundershowers may also develop in Illinois, southeastern Missouri and the eastern sections of Oklahoma and Texas. Three men were arrested yesterday and charged with kidnapping a man they said had stolen eight mopeds from a Brooklyn store, the police said.

Judge Jacob D. Fuchsberg of the New York State Court of Appeals said yesterday that he and his wife had such "substantial investments" in New York City notes that he had to disqualify himself from hearing a crucial case ow the city's finances or divest himself and face a loss of more than $500,000 on their investment.

When Elizabeth Ellery Bailey of Rumson, N. J., takes office next month as the first woman to serve on the Civil Aeronautics Board in its 38-year history, she will be much more concerned with the pricing policies that set air
Corn and wheat futures prices plunged to contract lows again yesterday in Chicago as improving weather kept many commercial buyers on the sidelines.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 28-Enterprise today had to give back one of her victories over Independence at the America's Cup trials, which concluded the second of three series here yesterday.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 28 Pass. To the Jets' defense last year, it was the worst four-letter word.

WASHINGTON, July 28 President Carter is personally involved in diplomatic efforts to persuade the South Korean Government to get Park Tong Sun to return to the United States to testify in the investigation of alleged Korean influence buying, Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today.

Such is the grace of Daniel Patrick Moynihan's style, and so refreshing his many insights, that even my brother Bill, who devoted three columns to the Senator's recent position paper on the problems of New York, was beguiled into acquiescing in Mr. Moynihan's central thrust, to wit: "I have reached the conclusion that our decline has come about as the... direct and palpable consequence of the policies of the Federal Government."
Thinking of moving? How about a restored manor in the Blue Ridge Mountains? It's a steal at 32 million.

HE IS BIG and hulking, whitehaired and pale. She is tiny, a wisp, 90 pounds. He acts as though nothing would faze him, an unflappable Englishman who has lived long and learned a great deal. She smiles readily, a perky Chinese woman who makes light of her learning.

Six months into his term of office, President Carter still enjoys strong general approval from the American people, but there has been a marked decline in public confidence that he can achieve such targets as significantly reducing unemployment or balancing the Federal budget.

THE VILLAGE GREEN is a blur of activity.It is an hour before the main event. Picnickers dot the lawn, others grab a ham burger at the grill, but the nucleus of the crowd is over at the gazebo listening to an early band concert.

Dennis Russell Davies will make his debut tonight at the Mostly Mozart Festival at Avery Fisher Hall, and what's surprising about that is there are still a few orchestras in New York that the 33-year-old conductor has not yet led.

WASHINGTON, July 28 After an open display of disagreement with President Carter's opposition to Federal funding for elective abortions, high-level women in the administration have muted their dissent and are quietly preparing a memorandum to the President taking issue with his position.

Citing a Saudi Arabian Prince's apartment-hunting problem here, the chief of the country's United Nations delegation asserted yesterday that New York was unfit to be the site of the U.N. headquarters.

WASHINGTON, July 28-President Carter said today that Prime Minister Menaiem Begins decision to legalize three existing Jewish settlements on the Israelioccupied West Bank of the Jordan River was an obstacle but not an insurmountable barrier to a Middle East peace.

WASHINGTON, July 28 In what was described by the Carter Administration as a major legal victory, the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today overturned a lower Customs Court ruling that would have required the Treasury to impose special duties on imports of Japanese television sets.

Nassau County political leaders have vowed to fight an integration suit asking that black students from Andrew Jackson High School in Queens be mixed with white suburban students from across the county line.

FOR SEVERAL years, Jimmy Giuffre has been leading a trio in which his various instruments (flutes, saxophones and clarinet) have been joined by bass and percussion in low-keyed, impressionistic sketches-frequently of animals, birds and insects all his own compositions. Although many of them were charming cameos, they had a dry, miniaturistic quality that became repetitive and, eventually, restricting over a program of any length.

A Federal district judge in Brooklyn told the Department of Health, Education and Welfare yesterday to continue making Medicaid funds available to states that wanted to use them for elective abortions.
The New York Times-CBS News survey is based on telephone interviews conducted from July 19 to July 25 with 1,447 adult men and women around the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 28 Despite opposition by the Carter Administration, the Senate Finance Committee today approved Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's plan for a one-year increase of $1 billion in Federal spending on welfare.

Fluctuation in the housing market has not deterred Robert Little. Steadily since 1970 he has been "gutting" townhouses and renovating them in Manhattan, first on the West Side and then on the East Side, one at a time. He creates six or seven duplex or triplex apartments per building.

NEWARK, July 28 Roger Lowenstein is returning to private law practice after four years as New Jersey's first Federal public defender and the eighth in the country's 92 Federal Court districts. He has mixed emotions about leaving his post.

New York State tax agents have started an investigation into possible tax cheating and avoidance by up to 300 officials and employees of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Tax Commissioner James H. Tully Jr. announced yesterday.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 28 The house at 469 Barker Pass Road is gone. So are its 30 avocado trees and dozens of apple and apricot trees. Also gone is Lorenzo Dall'Armi's brand new tuxedo, the first he had ever owned.

MIAMI, July 28 (UPI) The police sought today a band of gunmen who ransacked a home, lined up the eight occupants and shot them "execution style," apparently in an attempt to erase all witnesses to their crime. Two of the victims survived.

After Hye Young Choi made her Carnegie Recital Hall debut last February, a reviewer wrote in The New York Times that "the sweet ardor of the 'Song to the Moon' from Dvorak's 'Rusalka' seemed a perfect vehicle for Miss Choi's artistry." So it seemed perfectly natural to her when she auditioned for a part in the Broadway production of "The King and I" that she sing that same song.

TOKYO, July 28 Evidence is mounting that the United States and Japan, the two largest economic powers of the non-Communist world, are entering a new period of increasing trade tension, full of potentially serious misunderstandings.

Getaway day became runaway day at Yankee Stadium yesterday as the Yankees walloped the first-place Baltimore Orioles, 14-2. The one-sided victory captured the series for New York, two games to one, and moved the Yankees two games behind the Orioles as they heeded for nine games on the West Coast.

LOS ANGELES, July 28 A furnace-hot, desert-dry wind blows fiendishly, sometimes steadily for minutes or hours, sometimes in intermittent but endless gusts, as if some invisible giant were trying to drive you crazy.
WASHINGTON, July 28 More than at any other time since entering the White House, Jimmy Carter gave the public impression today of a President being crowded by tough, intractable issues.

LOUISVILLE July 28 (Reuters)-Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal said today that a strong dollar was vital to the world economy and the United States would not be indifferent to a continuing large trade deficit.

A. T. C. Bone, one of the last of the great breed of British eccentrics who remained behind in what was once the Empire, died in an auto accident in Burma on June 18, according to word received here yesterday. He was 56 years old.

The dollar showed strong improvement in foreign-exchange trading yesterday for the second consecutive day, posting gains against most foreign currencies in New York and abroad, The Associated Press reported.
The board of trustees of Kirkland College, an innovative school for women in Clinton, N.Y., voted Wednesday night to accept consolidation with Hamilton College.
If you get a letter from Louis Travers this month, you may be in for some money.

WASHINGTON, July 28 The Federal Bureau of Investigation is pursuing allegations that organized crime figures and teamsters' union officials might have paid large sums to Nixon Administration officials to insure that James R. Hoffa could not regain control of the union after his release from prison, a source familiar with the investigation said today.

WASHINGTON, July 28-President Carter portrayed himself and Congress today as the last hope of America's poor and charged that critics damaged the optimism of the underprivileged by suggesting that national leaders did not care about their welfare.

WASHINGTON, July 28 President Carter bowed today to a tide of Congressional opposition and agreed to put off until September his Controversial offer to sell a modern airborne radar warning system to Iran.

Delta Air Lines Inc., the nation's fifthlargest carrier, and one of the most successful, reported yesterday in an unaudited statement for the fiscal year ended June 30 net earnings of $92.4 million, equal to $4.65 a share. This sets a new airline industry record and represents a 32 percent rise from $70.2 million, or $3.53 a share earned in fiscal 1976.
John W. Harder, an American who held a permanent commission as a Royal Air Force fighter pilot is World War II, died Monday at Swedish Hospital in Seattle. He was 53 years old.
PARIS, July 28 (AP) Four bandits believed acting on inside information seized a truck carrying $3.54 million in newly minted coins today in one of the world's biggest robberies.
What is President Carter trying to tell Vernon Jordan and the black community? It sounds suspiciously like "Be quiet I know what's best for you." Or maybe "Don't call me, I'll call you."

GUATEMALA CITY, July 28 British and Guatemalan officials are looking to the United States to help them settle the potentially explosive dispute over the tiny British colony of Belize, which is claimed by Guatemala.

President Carter yesterday reiterated his concern for the poor, suggesting that they need help and hope. Most Americans are willing to believe in his sincerity. At the same time, it must be observed that the poor have grounds for being skeptical.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 28 (AP) Hans Gildemeister of Chile unleashed a flurry of passing shots today and posted a 6-2, 7-6 upset victory over fourth-seeded Wojtek Fibak of Poland in a second-round match in the $125,000 Louisville international tennis classic.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 28 Rambling Willie, the aged son of Rambling Fury, who spent his first and second years competing on the Indiana Fairground circuit, demonstrated again tonight why he is now a big-time campaigner.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) The Senate Judiciary jcommittee adopted today two amendments to a bill designed to restrict court-ordered busing for school desegregation.
Under the title "Bella Means Business," a series of economic development goals was sketched yesterday by Bella S. Abzug.

WASHINGTON, July 28 Internal White House documents released today by Representative Paul N. McCloskey, a California Republican, suggest that President Carter was influenced by a political campaign commitment to maritime unions and the industryi ssupporting controversial legislation that means inincreased revenues for the American maritime industry.

IN "One More July," George Plimpton has returned to the world of professional football, and one's first inclination is to protest that we had enough of it in "Paper Tiger" and more than enough in "Mad Ducks and Bears." But what has drawn Mr. Plimpton back this time is not another inglorious opportunity to get himself pasted to the turf at the quarterback position. It is the beguiling intelligence
ROME,July 28 (Reuters) The Somali Republic said today that it had shot down three Ethiopian jets and a planeload of paratroops over its territory in the widening war on the Horn of Africa.

WASHINGTON, July 28 President Carter bowed today to a tide of Congressional opposition and agreed to put off until September his controversial offer to sell a modern airborne radar warning system to Iran.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 28 (AP) Prime Minister Ian D. Smith has challenged an eviction order against a family of mixed race that has owned a house in a white Salisbury suburb for two years. Mr. Smith said he has asked for a report with "full facts" on the order by the city council.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 28 (AP) More than half a million acres of Alaska land were burning today as hot, dry conditions continued to hamper efforts to bring the flames under control, the Bureau of Land Management reported.
WASHINGTON, July 28 President Carter said today that oil conservation was the key to reducing the nation's yawning trade deficit, which is expected to reach an unprecedented $25 billion this year.

WASHINGTON, July 28 President Carter portrayed himself and Congress today as the last hope of America's poor and charged that critics damaged the optimism of the underprivileged by suggesting that national leaders did not care about their welfare.

DENVILLE, N.J., July 28 Jon Saxton, a tow-headed, 16-year-old golfer from Greenwich, Conn., said, "If I continue to improve I'd like to go South and play with a good college golf team. If I don't improve too much, I want to go to Dartmouth."

MOSCOW, July 28 (UPI) Overall exports of American products to the Soviet Union fell 22.6 percent for the first five months of 1977, led by a sharp drop in farm products, the United States Trade Office in Moscow reported today.

VALDEZ, Alaska, July 28 With its welding problems resolved by replacement of a three-foot piece of new pipe, the trans-Alaska pipeline system began moving oil again today toward Valdez and a tanker fleet.

ALBANY, July 28 The following is the text of the new general provisions of professional conduct that apply to all 29 professions regulated by the New York State Board of Regents, including broadened regulations on professional advertising.

Six months into his term of office, President Carter still enjoys strong general approval from the American people, but there has been a marked decline in public confidence that he can achieve such targets as significantly reducing unemployment or balancing the Federal budget.
OTTAWA, July 28-A proposed gas pipeline from Northern Alaska into Canada, known as the Alcan Route, cleared a Government environmental hurdle today with recommendations for only minor changes.

Max I. Arons, president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, said yesterday that "it now appears" that the orchestra of the Metropolitan Opera will be locked out on Sept. 9, because of failure to reach agreement on a new contract.

LIMA, Peru, July 28-Peru's military rregime, in power for nine years, an nounced through President Francisco Morales Bermudez today that a constitutional assembly will be elected next year to prepare for a return to elected, civil gov ernment in l980.

NEWPORT in summer is a resort of many attractions. Sailing regattas and tennis matches are lures for sportsmen, a be guiling mix of 18th 19th and 20thcentury dwellings and public buildings set amid magnificent trees, appeals to architecture and history buffs, and the extravagant Bellevue Avenue residences of past and present rich are a source of wonder and amazement for all.
Jon Matlack, the Mets' left-hander who took himself out of Wednesday night's game against San Francisco in the sixth inning suffered a strained left shoulder, the team physician said yesterday.
Two weeks after the blackout, the Citizens Committee for New York City is within $800,000 of its goal of raising $3.5 million to give to small-business men whose stores were damaged or destroyed.

The LTV Corporation, the Dallas-based conglomerate, reported yesterday an 83 percent plunge in second-quarter earnings and a loss for the half year because of the continuing poor results of its steel and food subsidiaries.

NEWARK, July 28 Opponents of nuclear energy as a source of power demonstrated today, with pickets, speeches and songs, at Military Park across the street from the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, the state's largest energy supplier.

Thanks partly to two events only one of them planned the powdered drink mix business is exploding.

A former director of a poverty program was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on a charge of having diverted more than $50,000 of the program's funds for his own use, including $13,500 for a Mercedes-Benz car.

If you wanted to buy a seemingly solid New York City bank, the place to be yesterday was the American City Squire Inn. That's when, for $8.2 million, and where, the Century National Bank and Trust Company went under the auctioneer's hammer.

SATORU SHIMAZAKI's dances float along in a self-contained, preoccupied manner that doesn't give the slightest nod to thea trical tension. They hardly even have any dynamic relationship to the music that accompanies them, except to bathe in the changing aural background. None of this, would be detrimental if the movement itself were highly inventive, but It tends to be quite repetitious, for the most part.

WASHINGTON, July 28 In what was described by the Carter Administration as a major legal victory, the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today overturned a lower Customs Court ruling that would have required the Treasury to impose special duties on imports of Japanese television sets.

An esoteric organization relatively unknown to many corporate managements may have an important impact on company policy. The organization, the National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws, begins an eight-day annual meeting in Vail, Colo., today.

WASHINGTON-Criminal sentencing today is a national scandal. Every day different judges mete out vastly different sentences to similar defendants convicted of similar crimes. One offender may receive probation while another-convicted of the very same crime is sentenced to a lengthy term of imprisonment. This glaring disparity can be traced directly to the unfettered discretion we confer on our judges. They act without any statutory guidelines or review procedures.
Pan American World Airways will formally put before the Civil Aeronautics Board today its keep-the-frills answer to Laker Airways' no-frills $135 New Yorkto London travel bargain.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 25 (AP)President Anastasio Somoza Debayle was flown to the Miami Heart Institute in a United States Air Force ambulance plane today for treatment of a heart condition, a presidential spokesman announced.
DETROIT, July 28 The Ford Motor Company reported today a 20 percent gain in second-quarter earnings, and the Chrysler Corporation reported a 33.1 percent drop in earnings.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) The House Rules Committee cleared President Carter's energy program legislation tonight for House floor action.

Lenny Randle of the Mets pleaded no contest yesterday to a charge of battery for punching Frank Lucchesi, former manager of the Texas Rangers on March 28 and was fined $1,050 by Circuit Court Judge Maurice Paul in Orlando, Fla.

WASHINGTON, July 28 President Carter said today that Prime Minister Menahem Begins decision to legalize three existing Jewish settlements on the Israelioccupied West Bank of the Jordan River was an obstacle but not an insurmountable barrier to a Middle East peace.

One has the impression that if it were not for the seemingly unending stream of bluefish cruising the shores from southern New Jersey to Cape Cod, light-tackle marine sport fishing in the Northeast would fall into a disastrous decline.
Nancy Ann Block, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cy Block of Lake Success, L.I., was married yesterday evening to Les Howard Perlson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Perlson of Brooklyn.

TEL AVIV, July 29-Twenty-nine persons were injured today in the vegetable market of Beersheba, the desert town, when a time bomb exploded under a stall. It was the third terrorist bombing in two days.
The stock market failed to put together even a halfhearted rally yesterday as prices ended mixed following Wednesday's jolting drop of 19.75 points in the Dow Jones industrial average.
A salvaged windmill known as the easternmost house on Long Island burned to the ground in Montauk on Wednesday night in a spectacular fire that flashed through the frame cliffside dwelling.

WASHINGTON, July 28-The United States, the Soviet Union and Britain announced today, after two weeks of preliminary talks in Geneva, that the way had been cleared for formal negotiations in October on a treaty banning all underground nuclear explosions.

Mayor Beame signed into law yesterday an antipornography bill that provides for strict civil penalties and court injunctions. In conjunction with criminal penalties, the Mayor said the bill would serve "as a strong deterrent to the nuisance of pornography and prostitution."

Joseph D. Duffey, an assistant secretary of state for Educational and Cultural Affairs, will be named on Tuesday by President Carter to head the National Endowment for the Humanities, according to cultural sources in Washington. The endowment allocated nearly $111 million in 2,045 grants in education and research in the 50 states in its last fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, July 28 The Securities and Exchange Commission has formally charged A-T-O Inc., an Ohio-based automatic bottle-processing company, with making more than $1 million in secret bribes and kickbacks to agents in Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Central America.

For the first time, and perhaps the last, Long Island enthusiasts have a mid summer opportunity to compete in a major tournament in their own backyard. The Nassau-Suffolk Regional Championships, replacing a tournament usually played in Manhattan, begins today at the Nassau-Suffolk Coliseum.

ALBANY, July 28 The New York State Board of Regents, considerably broadening its earlier position, voted unanimously today to permit physicians, dentists and other professionals to advertise not only their services but also their prices in newspapers and magazines.

WASHINGTON, July 28-The Carter Administration, wary of the financial pitfalls involved in taking over the United States Postal Service, is turning away from legislative proposals that would put the huge agency back under political control.

BOSTON, July 28 (AP) A DC-10 jetliner headed for Los Angeles with 292 passengers and a crew of 12 aborted its takeoff today when an explosion and fire erupted in its tail engine as it gathered speed on the runway at Logan International Airport.

A National Cancer Institute study has found that a small percentage of women with ovarian cancer who were treated with drugs called alkylating agents later developed leukemia. This second cancer, the study said, apparently developed as a result of taking the drugs.

Roy Wilkins turned over the leadership of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to Benjamin L. Hooks yesterday as 200 supporters, well-wishers, friends and people who have benefitted from the organization's civil-rights battles watched teary-eyed and solemnly.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 28 (AP) Duane Bobick, in his first fight since his 58-second knockout by Ken Norton, bounced back tonight with a knockout of Scott LeDoux in the eighth round of a scheduled 10-round fight.

KENT, Ohio, Friday, July 29 About 50 demonstrators defied a court order early this morning and reoccupied a construction site at Kent State University near the point where four students died in a hail of National Gunfire in 1970

One important argument of those who believe that Allan Bakke should lose his United States Supreme Court case against the Regents of the University of California is that universities and professional schools must retain the autonomy to select their students as they see fit, within of course certain limits.
PHILADELPHIA, July 29 The proportion is a matter of opinion 8020, 75-25, 60-40 but golf professionals unanimously agree that competition golf is more a mental enterprise than physical.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) The Master Lock Company is recalling 32,000 Master smoke alarms, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today. Officials said the Milwaukee concern was recalling No. 2551 battery-operated alarms and No. 2553 dual-powered alarms made in 1975 and part of 1976.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil (AP) A popular Brazilian senator has become the first civilian to announce his candidacy to succeed Gen. Ernesto Geisel as president. If elected by the Congress in the October 1978 election, the Senator, Jose de Magahlaes Pinto, would become the first civilian president since Joao Goulart was overthrown in a military coup in 1964.

Two weeks ago, Ellen Jane Hover disappeared. And to her friends and family, who find nothing missing from the small, walk-up apartment where she lived alone at 686 Third Avenue, her absence is extraordinary and alarming.

Edward W. Bourne, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Alexander Green and a life member of the board of governors for New York Hospital, died Wednesday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in West Cornwall.
VALDEZ, Alaska, July 29 Despite sabotage, explosion, fire, bad welds and clumsy accidents, oil from the Alaska Arctic was pouring into the terminal storage tanks here today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) The Congressional Black Caucus today unanimously endorsed Vemon E. Jordan's Jr.'s criticisms of President Carter and warned Mr. Carter that he was starting to lose black support.

HARVEST TIME "A Salute to Movie Musicals" seems an apt program for Joe Franklin, host of a special event tomorrow and Monday nights at the downtown Ballroom in Soho. Mr. Franklin, as many television watchers know, is the star of a popular nocturnal talk session that often has a fascinating array of guests and just as often is the salvation of the home-screen when the Late Late Shows are impossible.

WASHINGTON, July 29 President Carter intervened personally in the Panama Canal treaty talks for the first time today by calling the chief negotiators for both sides to a morning session at the White House.

WINNEMUCCA, Nev., July 29 Hot in the day and cold at night, the Owyhee Desert northeast of here is stingy with the things that support life even in the best years. Though it often seems empty, the 600,000-acre desert can suddenly explode with herds of wild horses, deer, antelopes, groups of rabbits, snakes, ravens, sage hens, and field mice and individual badgers, coyotes and mountain lions.

WASHINGTON, July 29 Representative Morris K. Udall, chairman of the House Interior Committee, said today he had asked President Carter to determine whether the Federal Government had covered up the theft of a large amount of nuclear material that could have been converted to atomic bombs.

Is money management a loser's game that is won by cautiously concentrating first on avoiding mistakes rather than by swinging from the heels for some hot growth company whose stock is bound to go from 3 to 30 overnight?

MOSCOW, July 29 (AP) The Sovietpress agency Tass said today that United States policy on the Middle East was hypocritical and that President Carter reflected this in his Washington news conference yesterday.

ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J., July 29 (UPI) Volkswagen of America today became the sixth foreign auto company in the last two weeks to raise auto prices to offset the decline in the value of the dollar against the West German mark and Japanese yen.

WASHINGTON, July 29 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that he would present specific American proposals to Israeli and Arab leaders during his forthcoming Middle East trip in an effort to overcome the obstacles to a new Geneva peace conference.
The Aetna Life and Casualty Company reported yesterday its highest earnings for any quarter or half-year period in its 124-year history.

Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan charged yesterday that the looting and disorders of the July 13-14 blackout in New York City had been "generally misperceived" as racial rather than criminal.

KENT, Ohio, July 29 Protesters fighting construction of a gymnasium near the site where four students were slain by National Guardsmen on the Kent State University campus in 1970 won a temporary stay today that will halt work until their case can be heard in Federal District Court.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., July 29 Mayor Beame, seeking votes among New York City's Jewish residents vacationing in the Catskill Mountains, was, for the most part, greeted warmly here today, but he encountered an undertone of dissastisfaction and worry over his handling of the looting and arson during the, July 13-14 blackout.
Joseph M. Giglio, who was appointed last May by Governor Carey to head a new cabinet-level Office of Health Systems Management, has resigned to take a higher-paying job in private industry.

WASHINGTON, July 29 The Senate refused decisively today to cut off debate on a proposal backed by President Carter to provide Federal campaign subsidies for Congressional candidates and limit the amount they can spend in a political race.

David Allen, a 23-year-old second-year medical student from Roxbury, Mass., remembered how helpless he felt when his great-grandmother was sent to a nursing home. He believes now, as he did then, that she could have received adequate care at home if medical attention had been available.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 29 A Federal District judge today rejected plans submitted by the city and state boards of education for desegregation of Columbus schools.

ST. LOUIS, July 29 (AP) A Federal District Court jury has convicted Richard J. Rabbitt, former Speaker of the Missouri House, on all 15 counts of an indictment charging that he accepted kickbacks and peddled his influence from 1967 to 1976.
CHATTANOOGA, Ten., July 29 (AP) An explosion that rained debris over a square block area destroyed a synagogue tonight about an hour after evening services had ended, the police said.

WASHINGTON, July 29 Conrail, the Northeast rail giant, is diverting freight traffic from New York City and urging rail shippers to move out of the city and relocate in New Jersey and elsewhere, a spokesman for the city charged at a Senate transportation hearing today.

DETROIT, July 29 (AP) John J. Riccardo, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said today that he was convinced Congress would settle on new pollution standards in time to avert a threatened shutdown of automobile plants in two weeks.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) The Conservative Caucus and its "Citizens Cabinet" have opened a campaign to oust Andrew Young as United States delegate to the United Nations. They say response so far has been "very heavy."
A two-count Federal indictment was filed in Manhattan yesterday against Peter Ottley, the president of Local 144 of the Hotel, Hospital, Nursing Home and Allied Health Service Union.
VALDEZ, Alaska, July 29 Despite sabotage, explosion, fire, bad welds and clumsy accidents, oil from the Alaska Arctic was pouring into the terminal storage tanks here today.
WASHINGTON Researchers at the RCA Laboratories in Princeton, N.J., have succeeded in keeping solar cells automatically pointed directly at the sun for maximum production of power.
The Union Oil Company of California announced yesterday that it was withdrawing from participation in the proposed Louisiana offshore oil port known as LOOP.

MOUNT POCONO, Pa., July 29 Amy Alcott has a touch of the pixie and a bright sparkle in her brown eyes. A 21-year-old professional golfer from California, she was having difficulty being serious today trying to describe the West Course at Pocono Manor.
Frozen orange juice futures prices spurted yesterday, with the September delivery closing at a contract high of $1.15 a pound, up the 3-cents-a-pound limit on the New York Cotton Exchange.

WASHINGTON, July 29 The Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Arthur F. Burns, said today that the economy would grow somewhat less rapidly in the second half of this year, but that activity would still be strong enough to produce some further reductions in unemployment.

A late rally in sharply depressed steel shares enabled the Dow Jones industrial average to post a token gain yesterday after a price slump in the morning. The Dow, down nearly 8 points at 11 A.M., finished 0.08 higher at 890.07.
The first radio or television station to broadcast from a transmitter atop the World Trade Center will be WKCR, the Columbia University-owned FM radio outlet.

WHITE PLAINS, July 29 A sunken car that contained two human skulls and numerous bones was pulled out of an Orange County lake yesterday by the New York state police and with it emerged the possibility that a 15-year-old mystery had been solved.

About a month has passed since Steve Cauthen, the 17-year-old riding sensation from Kentucky, lost his apprentice allowance of five pounds. The taciturn teen-ager, however, seems to have lost little of his appeal among trainers.
Beginners are taught that if both members of a partnership have an opening bid a game should be bid, and that conversely if neither player has a full opening a part score should be sufficient.
George D. Batson, a playwright specializing in comedies and farces died Monday at the age of 61. He lived at 245 East 21st Street.
CHICAGO, July 29 Federal District Judge John F. Grady issued an injunction today against the City of Milwaukee, ordering it to stop polluting Lake Michigan.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 29 (AP) Mackinac College, the island property where the television evangelist Rex Humbard once hoped to establish a Christian university like that of Oral Roberts, has been sold.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 29 (Reuters) Winnie Mandela, a black militant, was arrested yesterday and charged with having violated a Government order barring her fromp olitics and banishing her to the remote settlement of Brandfort. She is the wife of Nelson Mandela, a black nationalist leader serving a life sentence in Robben Island Prison.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) Prices farmers receive for raw products as they enter the consumer pipeline dropped 2 percent between June 15 and July 15, the second consecutive monthly decline, the Agriculture Department said today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 The Commerce Department reported today that its index of leading economic indicators, which is designed to show which way the economy is headed, declined in June for the second consecutive month.

Nassau County began action yesterday to try to collect $50 million in damages that it says it will lose as a result of the Nets' move from the Nassau Coliseum to New Jersey. The Coliseum is county-owned and countyoperated.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) The Federal Reserve Board approved today the application of Banco Central, the second largest bank in Spain, to take over control of Banco Economias of San German, Puerto Rico.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 29 Where did winter go? The question is a frequent one these days.

At the request of former Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller, the New York State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, is "looking into" the rejection of an application by a Saudi Arabian prince to buy an apartment on Park Avenue.

With all categories of construction showing substantial gains, building contract awards in June totaling $15.4 billion were 41 percent ahead of the $10.9 billion awarded in June of 1976, the F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company said yesterday.
PARIS, July 29 Hundreds of policemen fanned out across Paris and its suburbs today in search of three or four men and the truck they hijacked last night containing $3.65 million in 10-franc coins.

The most turbulent art auction season in 200 years will end next week, and preliminary reports issued in London yesterday show that both Sotheby's and Christie's will have surpassed all previous totals. Since the beginning of the season last September, they will also have eclipsed more records, if less spectacular ones, than in any season in memory.

There had to be a way to get Arthur Mitchell's company on stage in its hometown. After the spring season was canceled because of a serious fiscal problem, things appeared bleak, but on Thursday Dance Theater of Harlem began a two-week series of performances at Wollman Auditorium on the Columbia University campus.
GREENVALE, L.I., July 29 A 42-yearold bank teller, the mother of four children, was shot to death here this morning during a bank holdup.
WASHINGTON, July 29 After marathon negotiations, House and Senate conferees moved today toward agreement on controversial amendments to the Clean Air Act.
The victim of a revenge killing in Brooklyn Tuesday who had been described as a holdup man may have been involved in the drug trade in his neighborhood, the police said yesterday.
CLEVELAND, July 29 A declaration of war against all forms of pornography and all persons who peddle it was made here at a national conference that ended today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 29 After six weeks of efforts to reach agreement on an agenda, the Belgrade Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe remained deadlocked today, with mounting pressure for adjournment in the next few days.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., July 29 (UPI) Patricia Roberts Harris, United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, flew here today to survey flood damage and recovery efforts under the threat of more showers and a flash flood watch issued by the National Weather Service.

CORONA, Calif., July 29 (UPI) A brush fire that turned the sky "a mass of reddish brown" swept into this rural town 40 miles southeast of Los Angeles today but was driven off at the doorsteps of a fashionable, 100-home development on the town's outskirts.

ALBANY, July 29 The Federal Highway Administration has approved the design of the Westway, the controversial $1.16 billion replacement for the West Side Highway, the State Transportation Department announced today.

A 44-year-old nursing supervisor at St. Luke's Hospital was fatally wounded yesterday when she was caught in an exchange of shots on the upper West Side a few blocks from the hospital, the police reported.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) A Soviet deployment of submarines in the Atlantic three months ago was part of an annual exercise dating back several years, the Pentagon said today.

MONTE CARLO, July 29 Three weeks late and what seem like three million words later, Carlos Monzon will defend his world middleweight boxing championship here tomorrow night against Rodrigo Valdes in what Monzon insists will be his farewell fight.

WASHINGTON, July 29 With enthusiastic backing from the Carter Administration, the House Democratic leadership has worked out a compromise in its energy package, calling for a 5-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax increase instead of the 4-cent plan proposed by a special House committee.

MOSCOW, July 29 The Russian shopper looked with anticipation at the Christian Dior cosmetics tidily arrayed behind the counter, but before she could inquire the saleswoman cut her short "This is not our store," said the clerk, emphasizing the possessive. "This is only for foreigners."
A man charged with the 1972 murder of Carlo A. Lombardi, a reputed mobster, was arrested yesterday in Atlantic City by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the bureau announced.

WASHINGTON, July 29 Participants in the Arctic Gas consortium seeking to build a cross-Canada pipeline to carry Alaskan natural gas announced today that they were abandoning their project and would support instead a cross-Canada plan advanced by the Alcan Pipeline Company.

WASHINGTON, July 29 With enthusiastic backing from the Carter Administration, the House Democratic leadership has worked out a compromise in its energy package, calling for a 5-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax increase instead of the 4-cent plan proposed by a special House committee.

UNIONDALE, L.I., July 29 In a strange World Team Tennis match tonight at Nassau Coliseum, the New York Apples took advantage of two injuries to the Phoenix Racquets but still needed a game in overtime in posting a 22-16 triumph. A crow of 7,284 attended.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 29 (UPI) Rhodesia and Mozambique traded fire across their border today and the military command in Salisbury said seven black nationalist guerrillas had been killed in the last 24 hours.
TRENTON, July 29 The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled 6 to 0 today that candidates for Governor might not accept more than $600 from an individual in the general election this year.

PARIS, July 29 The Paris couture is not for you and me. To begin with, the clothes are too expensive. Typically, they'll run around $3,000 or $4,000 for a relatively simple style. More elaborate ones can go into five figures. Then, the collections are divided between hopelessly conservative and incredibly fantastic styles.

Mayor Lawrence F. Kramer of Paterson said yesterday that his city was dropping Blue Cross-Blue Shield health coverage for 1,400 city employees and would save half a million dollars over two years as a result.

In the Garden of the Southern Vermont Art Center in Manchester, yesterday evening, Kerry Elizabeth O'Sullivan, daughter of Mrs. Gerald Patrick O'Sullivan of Sydney, Australia, and the late Mr. O'Sullivan, became the bride of Sydney Nelson Stokes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stokes of Arlington, Vt., formerly of Plainfield, N.J.

ATLANTA, July 29 (AP) Illnesses resembling dengue fever, which has not appeared in epidemic proportions in the United States since the 1940's, are being investigated in nine states and the District of Columbia, the national Center for Disease Control said today. All cases involve persons returning from Jamaica.

MOSCOW, July 29 Soviet foreign policy in the Middle East, already battered in recent years by Moscow's estrangement from Cairo and the civil war in Lebanon, appears to be suffering a further setback as a result of the latest hostilities in northeastern Africa.
TEHERAN, Iran More and more women are seen on the streets of this Middle Eastern capital wearing the chaddour, a long enveloping veil, in what looks like a women's backlash.
TRENTON, July 29 The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled 6 to 0 today that candidates for Governor might not accept more than $600 from an individual in the general election this year.
HARTFORD, July 29 (AP) Connecticut has accused 13 major paper companies of conspiring to limit competition, rig bids and divide up territory, Attorney General Carl Ajello said today.
Peter A. Levine of White Plains, a commercial credit executive, died suddenly Wednesday while playing tennis near his home. He was 44 years old.

A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan yesterday ordered New York City to continue subsidy payments to a Harlem antipoverty agency that city officials sought to cut off because of the criminal record of its recently reinstated executive director.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 29 (AP) Former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, making his first public appearance since being freed from military detention, said today that martial law was not the answer to Pakistan's problems.

WASHINGTON, July 29 Officials of the Federal Power Commission said today that the Consolidated Edison Company had not been properly prepared to avert the July 13-14 blackout of New York City and Westchester County. But they also had praise for the utility's efforts to restore service.

ALBANY, July 29 Harry J. O'Donnell, who resigned last month as Governor Carey's director of communications to "reshape my life and find new areas of professional satisfaction and personal fulfillment," today joined the staff of Perry B. Duryea, the Assembly minority leader and a likely opponent for Mr. Carey in the race for Governor next year.

Dave Kingman led the pathetic San Diego Padres into Shea Stadium last night to play the equally pathetic Mets. The big slugger, who was traded by New York June 15 when he refused the Mets' contract offer and the Mets refused his terms, was probably the leading interest in a meaningless game.

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) Jazzman Milt Buckner, 62 years old, long the pianist and organist of the Lionel Hampton band, died Wednesday night after collapsing while setting up instruments for an appearance at a Chicago night spot.

Dave Bing has been given permission by the Washington Bullets' general manager, Bob Ferry, to make a deal for himself if he can with another National Basketball Association team. But the rapidity of change influences our sense of time, and in this quick-moving city the good old days of only a half-dozen years ago can evoke nostalgia that small towns reserve for events of decades back.

ANCHORAGE, July 29 (AP) A Federal appeals court in New Orleans upheld today an effort by the Interstate Commerce Commission to reduce the price that oil companies will receive for shipping oil through their trans-Alaska pipeline.

Ferber Jr. of Washington and Greensboro, and the late Mr. Ferber of Hackensack, N.J., to Spencer Wood Potter, son of Mrs. John Howard Nott Potter of Jamestown, R.I., and the late Mr. Potter.

The astronomical June trade deficit announced last week is a worrisome preview of the financial problems that lie ahead for the nation as it consumes increasing amounts of imported oil. Some of the record $2.8 billion trade gap can be blamed on the failure of West Germany and Japan to spur their economies and thus absorb more of our exports. But the major reason for the whopping deficit is our whopping appetite for imported oil.

HARTFORD, July 30--Gov. Elia T. Grasso has sent to a new Judicial Review Council a barrage of complaints against a 68-year-old Superior Court Judge who has stirred controversy with his decision and conduct in a number of recent, widely publicized criminal cases.
MOHTE CARLO, July 30--Going out a champion, Carlos Monzon of Argentina retained his world middleweight boxing title here tonight by scoring a unanimous decision over Rodrigo Valdes in 15 rounds.
Many amateur photographers are so conditioned to shooting in color that they almost completely ignore the potentials of serious black-and-white photography.

Moreland's Golden Tonka, U.D., is the first obedience trial champion in the United States. Tonka was shown in the east and on July 23 won more than the required 100 points at the Nita Nee show in Centre Hall, Pa.

LONG POND, Pa., July 30--Darrell Waltrip, quickly losing his image as one of the promising youngsters in Grand National stock-car racing, captured the pole position today for the Coca-Cola 500 at Pocono International Raceway.

CANTON, Ohio, July 30--The New York Jets finally made it to a Hall of Fame Game today, and discovered that they were not quite ready for election. Still, this young team had fun for a while as it opened the National Football League's exhibition season by taking a 6-0 lead before losing to the Chicago Bears, 20-6.

MONTREAL, July 30--The Quebec government has paid a political debt to labor --but has further alienated management --with legislation that would forbid companies from using strikebreakers to continue operations during strikes or lockouts.
MONMOUTH BEACH, July 31 Owners of high-rise condominium complexes along the northern part of the shore report that sales are slowly picking up after several seasons of stagnation.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, July 31 Special antiterrorist units of the West German police were alerted today in a nationwide search for four young women whom officials termed prime suspects in the killing of an internationally known banker, Jurgen Ponto, near here yesterday.

NEW DELHI, July 31 (Reuters) Indian pulishers are flooding the market with books "exposing" the 21 months of tough emergency rule by former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi that ended with her shattering election defeat in March.

James B. Skidmore, the former Mayor of the Village of East Hampton, L.I., died Saturday after a long illness at his home at 35 Dunemere Lane in East Hampton. He was 77 years old.

NEWARK, July 31 The task of rebuilding America's cities is not only the job of government but also the responsibility of its citizens. That was the message this weekend as several hundred people heard Federal state and municipal officials speak at the second annual Community Advisory Board convention at the Holiday Inn near Newark International Airport.

VALDEZ, Alaska, July 31 It was somewhat difficult to ascertain in this port village today which event was more eagerly anticipated: The first gush of North Slope crude oil into the bowels of an oil tanker bound for the "lower 48" or the first blush of the comely entrants in an oily-T-shirt contest.

Although Congress seems sympathetic toward the idea of abolishing mandatory retirement at age 65, businessmen have given this traditional practice a rousing endorsement. In a survey of executives released last week, 65 percent of the respondents said they still favored compulsory retirement at age 65.

HOUSTON, July 31 Harry Birdwell, manager of the Oklahoma City Chamber of Commerce, was ecstatic last year when the General Motors Corporation announced plans to build a big automobile assembly plant in his city because it would create 5,000 jobs and bring a badly needed economic lift.
UPLAND, Calif., July 30 Donald Jensen sat in his workplace surrounded by motorcycle parts and his own tools and said: "Fixing a motorcycle is a lot of fun. I love my job."

HOCKENHEIM, West Germany, July 31 (UPI) Niki Lauda, the former world champion driver from Austria who crashed in last year's West German Formula 1 Grand Prix, took the lead in his Ferrari on the 12th lap of this year's race and won the 1977 Grand Prix today at Hockenheimring.

BETHANY, Conn., July 31 Ch. Salgray's Market Wise, a striking deep red fawn boxer with white markings owned by Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Hamilburg of Brookline, Mass., took his fourth best-in-show award and second in two days today at the Elm City Kennel Club's 67th all-breed dog show at Bethany Airport. There were 1,379 dogs in competition.

TEHERAN, July 31 (UPI) Iran indicated today that it was withdrawing its request to buy an advanced airborne radar system from the United States, apparently in anger over a delay in Congressional approval of the $1.2 billion sale.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 31 Renee Richards was not overly impressive today, but she did not have to be. She easily won her singles match as play started in the $85,000 Mutual Benefit Life open at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

The three concerts attracted 35,685 people, and they found Mr. Tennstedt at his best to be a superb Beethoven conductor, if perhaps a slightly erractic one.

Obscurity is now their portion, lost causes their tradition.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31 "Who Cares?" was New York City Ballet's only hum-along ballet until the appearance of the deliriously successful "Vienna Waltzes" this spring. On the last day of its now traditional Saratoga Performing Arts Center season, the company presented both ballets, the first in the afternoon and the second for its closing evening performance. Audiences could be heard softly echoing their tuneful cadences on both occasions.

Givenchy is the only couturier who makes an effort at starting close to post time and he's usually thwarted by a mass of late comers.

Clarence W. Benedict, president of the United States Golf Association in 1964 and 1965, died Sunday while visiting Nantucket, Mass. A former resident of Armonk, N.Y., he had been living in Stuart, Fla. He was 74 years old.

WHEN Harry Torczyner spotted a T-shirt adorned with a picture of a giant gull skimming the water, he got right down to business. He wrote to the manufacturer, asking why it had copied a painting by the late Belgian artist Rene Magritte without permission. And he made an arrangement with the company to pay royalties on the sale of the 4,900 shirts it had produced to Georgette Magritte, the artist's widow.

A swim at the Hotel Paris is joining the Automat, the glass arches of Pennsylvania Station and opentopped buses in the memorial arcade of New York's absent amenities. Its saunas unplugged, its gym empty, its showers with the cascading tiles turned off, it shut, on Sunday, ending 25 years of its current inoarnation as the Olympic Swim School and Health Club, at 97th Street and West End Avenue.

Wallace circulated in the offices of newspapers, wire services and radio and television stations. ATHENS Archbishop Makarios's great lifework was an attempt to create a new nation out of a small island the size of St. Louis, and history will probably record that he failed. Johnson denied attending a meeting at which a Texas political leader allegedly proposed altering vote totals to insure Mr. Johnson's victory in the 1948 runoff for the Democratic nomination to the United States Senate. The text was among papers made public today at the Johnson Library here.
Trenton, Aug. 3 The rate increases granted earlier this week to automobile insurance companies covering 1.6 million drivers, the first in almost a year, may soon be followed by others.
The Dow Jones industrial average declined yesterday largely in response to disappointment over a dividend at General Motors and a prime-rate increase by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.
"It is easy to tell Alfred Lunt from other American actors," Alexander Woollcott, the Broadway critic and gadfly, once said. "He is the one who is always working."

An organized ring of South Koreans, with American help, systematically exploited a United States computer to steal up to $17 million a year in American food, uniforms, vehicle parts, gasoline and other goods from Army installations in Korea during the early 1970's, according to a retired Army lieutenant colonel who served there as a provost marshal.

ALBANY, Aug. 3 Governor Carey today signed into law three measures intended to improve conditions for labor and business in New York State, proclaiming the legislation "one of the highlights of the 1977 Legislature."

THE Queensboro Bridge, completed in 1909, is best known for the enormously intricate cantiliver steelwork that supports it a web of metal so overpower ing that the bridge's own architect, Henry Hornbostel, is said to have exclaimed upon seeing the completed bridge for the first time, "My God it's a blacksmith's shop!"
CLEMATIS, now there's a plant! In all of nature's flowering vines, none is as noble as the clematis.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 3 Prime Minister, Menahem Begin today endorsed the proposal by President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and Secretary Cyrus R. Vance that Arab and Israeli foreign ministers meet in the United States next month.
Archie R. McCardell, the 50-year-old president and chief operating officer of the Xerox Corporation, yesterday was named to the same post at the International Harvester Company.
The dollar continued its long-term tumble on overseas money markets yesterday, although it rose in New York trading, The Associated Press reported.

ONE OF SEVERAL surprises at the recent Consumer Electronics show in Chicago was the emergence of a new breed of sound equipment quality stereo for cars. Only recently, high-fidelity car stereo would have seemed a contradiction in terms. But the gap has narrowed between the performance of acceptable components for the home and the best available in car stereo.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3(AP) The California Fair Political Practices Commission is investigating past political campaigns of Robert Mendelsohn, President Carter's nominee as Assistant Secretary of the Interior.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 3 While Thurman Munson seemed to be heating up the next Yankee problem with his 6-day-old beard, Ron Guidry and Nolan Ryan displayed some heat of their own tonight with their fast balls.

For about seven years in the 1950's a number of officials of the American Civil Liberties Union gave the Federal Bureau of Investigation on a continuing basis information about the organization, its activities and some of its members, according to materials obtained from the bureau's files.
WASHINGTON There is a character in one of the Disraeli novels described as a man distinguished for ignorance, as he had but one idea and that was wrong.

Franklin Lamb, former president of the Reynolds Pen Company, where he helped pioneer promotion of the ballpoint pen, died early yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital, West Palm Beach, Fla., after a short illness. He lived in Palm Beach, was 78 years old, and formerly lived in Allenhurst, N.J.
NEWARK, Aug. 3 (UPI) a baboon was destroyed with a tranquilizer dart yesterday after escaping from a crate at Newark International Airport and running loose for eight hours.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3-A House-Senate conference committee reached a compromise agreement early today on new air pollution restrictions that ended the threat of an auto industry shutdown but produced mixed feelings among manufacturers and environmentalists.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) An insurance executive, John Hoeven of Omaha, and his family toured the White House today and were greeted personalty by the First Lady.

But American solitude seems to be associated always with bookish ideals, even if not directly with books, from Emerson and Thoreau to the present moment. Emerson, in his essay "The Transcendentalist," prophesied that his disciples would choose solitude:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) The Senate tonight approved Federal election law legislation stripped of most of its reform items, including a provision backed by the Carter Administration for public financing of Senate campaigns. The vote was 88 to 1, with Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, voting against the bill.

The first new office building to be developed here in five years without a specific corporate tenant as an anchor is planned for the southeast corner of Park Avenue and 59th Street. Such buildings are known as "speculative" projects and are undertaken by developers who are confident of potential marketability.

In Blair House, across the street from the White House where, a century ago, Robert E. Lee turned down Abraham Lincoln's offer of the command of the Union Army another man of principle, Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, recently turned down opportunities offered by the superpowers of the media to enter into negotiations with the terrorists of the P.L.O.

ALBANY, Aug. 3 The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation today banned all sport and commercial fishing for American eels in the Harlem and East Rivers because of unsafe levels of PCB's (polychlorinated biphenyls), a chemical that is believed to cause cancer. The order also prohibits the sale of any eels caught in the two rivers.

Terrorist bombs exploded in two midtown Manhattan office buildings yesterday morning, killing one man and injuring seven other persons, while dozens of bomb threats forced more than 100,000 people to vacate their offices.
A Milgram supermarket in a small shopping complex in a middle-class neighborhood of Kansas City, Mo., is well on its way to becoming a historic site in the annals of marketing research.

WASHINGTON Senator Frank Church and his staff on the Foreign economic policy subcommittee have come up with a strategy for tipping the balance of petroleum power in the world against the 13-country oil cartel, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission announced today an investigation of the insulation industry to determine whether there are barriers to competition. Earlier this year the F.T.C. created a special task force to determine if fraud or deception existed in the advertising and marketing of home insulation and other energy-saving materials and devices.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) Women are "over-represented among the mentally ill and underserved by the mental health system," a Presidential commission says.

Stansfield Turner more authority than any other Director of Central Intelligence in history by granting him explicit control over the entire national intelligence budget, including funding of the Defense Department's National Security Agency and the National Reconnaissance Office.

While statewide election campaigns in New Jersey no longer depend exclusively on courtng a few political bosses, Hudson County remains a vital base for Democrats as does Bergen County for Republicans.

The Puerto Rican terrrorists who took responsibility for yesterday's blasts are an elusive band who have bombed scores of buildings in four American cities, killing five persons in recent years in the name of independence for their Caribbean homeland.

Investors who are wondering whether the California savings and loan stocks can be cheap after 12-month gains of more than 50 percent and the highest prices for the group since February 1973 will get an affirmative answer from some bullish Wall Street houses.

THE first impression is of a woman of boundless energy the firm, ample body bronzed by the sun, the hazel eyes crin kled with lines and laughter, the strong hands choreographing conversation, the unrouged lips gustily sucking in pasta and caviar.

WHERE IS IT written that Oriental rugs belong on the floor? Bloomingdale's may revive a centuries old trend Orientals as table coverings or bedspreads. The store's 59th Street and Lexington Avenue window recently featured a new 9-by-12-foot Indian wool rug ($2,955) in traditional maroon coloring as a bedspread on a queensized bed. The rug buyer said that Persian, Indian and Iranian rugs are soft enough to be used in this way.
Alfred Lunt, who with his wife, Lynn Fontanne, reigned for nearly 40 years as the leading couple of the American stage, died early yesterday in a Chicago hospital. He was 84 years old.

An application to provide pay television onlyw ithout full cable service to parts of Queens and most of the Bronx occupied the bulk of a crowded calendar before the City Planning Commission yesterday.
Tens of thousands of New Yorkers, obliged to leave their offices abruptly yesterday morning, did so with dispatch, calm and even touches of good humor.
DETROIT, Aug. 3 Domestic automobile sales during the final 10-day period of July rose 6 percent above sales for the same period a year ago, the major automobile producers reported here today.

TOKYO, Aug. 3 The decision by Japan's Toyota Motor Company to lease a 30-acre site at Port Newark, a decision cited by officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey as proof of the value of their expensive lobbying trips overseas, had nothing to do with the recent visits here by authority executives, Toyota officials said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 House and Senate conferees on the 1977 farm bill agreed today on a compromise plan for wheat and corn subsidies that President Carter indicated he would accept.

DETROIT, Aug 3 Auto industry executives today issued brief and cautiously worded statements of praise of a HouseSenate conference committee's decision to again extend the 1975 auto emission control standards of the Clean Air Act to cover 1978 and 1979 model cars.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 3 (UPI)-Somalia's radio station said today that Somali guerrillas had launched an offensive against Ethiopia's last line of defense in the Ogaden region, attacking the military headquarters and major airstrip at Diredawa.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 President Carter climaxed a 10-year struggle over the strip mining of coal by signing into law today the first uniform Federal controls on strip mining, until now a prerogative of coal-state governments often dominated by mining interests.
The New York City Police Department appealed to the public yesterday for information on the person or persons who may have placed bombs that exploded at two midtown Manhattan office buildings.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Aug. 3 Five patients at Suburban General Hospital near here may have died in recent months because they received nitrous oxide instead of oxygen by mistake, the Allegheny County coroner said today.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 3 (AP)-Greek Cypriots began 40 days of mourning for the President of Cyprus, Archbishop Makarios, who died early today. Turkish Cypriots immediately stepped up their demands for autonomy.
A Federal judge in Chicago has dismissed a suit filed against Cenco Inc. by the Securities and Exchange Commission, charging the diversified company with securities fraud.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 3 The Soviet Union offered concessions today at the preliminary phase of the Belgrade conference on East-West cooperation, which has been deadlocked for weeks. The concessions are expected to clear the way for the main meeting to begin here Sept. 27.

JIMMY BUFFETT, who appeared on Tuesday at the Dr. Pepper Music Festival in Central Park (the concert had been scheduled for Monday, but was rained out), combines serveral divergent trends in present-day popular music in a most engaging way. He can be a jolly, rowdy, good old boy (he comes from Alabama, after all, and several of his most popular songs glorify alcohol in a manner akin to Ray Davies of the Kinks).
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3 Mayor George Moscone won a personal and political victory in a special election here yesterday, even though his name was not on the ballot.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 President Carter's lower-priced postage rate for consumers, recently put forward by the United States Postal Service, has encountered opposition from a surprising quarter the consumer.

Mayor Beame said yesterday that the hiring of 600 new firemen announced last week would bring the New York City department up to the level for which financing is provided by the budget, but his statement was directly contradicted by figures provided by his own Budget Bureau.

New disclosures about the Central Intelligence Agency's now defunct program to conduct experiments on human beings in a search for methods of controlling their thought and behavior have raise a a storm of ethical questions.
No major new initiative will be begun this year against pornography, which was a pressing issue at City Hall just a few months ago.
The only fatality in yesterday's midtown bombings was sitting with his partner at the Mobil Oil Corporation's personnel office on the ground floor at 150 East 42d Street when a bomb exploded.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Adm. Stansfield Turner, the Director of Central Intelligence, testified today that the C.I.A. had secretly supported human behavior control research at 80 institutions, including 44 colleges or universities as well as hospitals, prisons and pharmaceutical companies.

NEWPORT, R.I, Aug. 3 America's Cup yachting resumed tomorrow with the foreign yachts battling each other and the elements on Rhode Island Sound. The four foreign entrants will begin a month of racing to determine which is best qualified to try to wrest the 126-year-old Cup from the Americans in September.

New York City, which should be happy to take all the good publicity it can get, should be overjoyed with a 31-page section about our fair city that will run in the August issue of Ford Times magazine. It is a publication with a circulation of two million that is distributed to Ford owners by Ford dealers.

WHERE TO STAY in Europe was once no problem at all. Favored names were handed down from father to son, like preferential stock in a company that could only do better and better. Fundamental to romance, they were exchanged on betrothal day as auguries of bliss without end. Through long winter evenings they were dreamed of with atlas and timetable in hand.

At least 250 police officers have volunteered to patrol sections of the city on their own time as part of the hunt for the .44-caliber revolver killer, Mayor Beame announced last night.

THIS IS the season of jet lag, American Express-card-plastic fatigue and decorating dissatisfaction. Vacationers are beginning to return from faraway places with caftans, sarongs and straw bags. Their picture postcards will follow shortly, as will their color slides.

The Coca-Cola Company, the world's largest maker of soft drinks, reported a second-quarter net profit of $95.9 million, or 79 cents a share, up 12.9 percent from $85.5 million, or 70 cents a share, a year ago. This lifted the half-year net by 11.9 percent to $161.6 million, or $1.32 a share, from $144.5 million, or $1.18 a share, for the first six months of 1976.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Lloyd McBride, the new president of the United Steelworkers of America, said today that the steelworkers' strike in seven states "should properly be settled at the local level."
ONE OF LIFE'S minor mysteries is how that breed of specialist, the public insurance adjuster, often manages to arrive at the scene of a fire day or night almost at the same time as the firemen.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 In a hypothetical Soviet surprise attack, the UnitedStates is contemplating a strategic plan that calls for strikes against Soviet assets outside Europe to force Moscow to surrender any territorial gains in West Germany, a senior White House official said today.

The high point in the backgammon year was the recently completed Philip Morris International European Backgammon Championship at Monte Carlo. The former President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz of Mexico, who presented his credentials as Ambassador to Spain only two weeks ago, resigned suddenly yesterday "for health reasons." His appointment to Madrid led to the resignation of Carlos Fuentes as Mexican Ambassador to France. Mr. Fuentes said he was protesting the repression of student riots in Mexico City in 1968, when Mr. Diaz Ordaz was president.

Marion Clyde McCarroll, who for 21 years wrote the nationally syndicated King Features column "Advice to the Lovelorn" under the name Beatrice Fairfax, died Monday in the Allendale Nursing Home, Allendale, N.J., where she had lived since 1970. Over the years, the city's Board of Standards and Appeals has grown accustomed to attacks by planners for its role in the zoning process. As the body with authority to grant exceptions to zoning and building laws, it has been criticized as too lenient in giving such "variances." Planning officials, especially those in the administration of former Mayor John V. Lindsay, sought to curb the board's discretionary authority.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 4 (AP)--Mexico has signed a letter of intent to sell large quantities of natural gas to a consortium of six United States companies, it was announced yesterday. The accord should eventually help relieve winter gas shortages in the United States.

Last May 25 the Mets played their annual game against their Tidewater farm club and won easily. Afterward, some of the Met players said they were appalled at the lack of talent on the club that was supposed to feed the Mets for the future.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--President Carter asked Congress today to provide legal status for millions of aliens whose presence in the United States violates current immigration statutes.

A Federal district judge in Brooklyn yesterday withdrew his order requiring Federal reimbursement for elective abortions for the poor, and Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, acted immediately to ban all Federal subsidies for abortions except when a woman's life was in danger.

Every night after the curtain comes down on the hit musical "Annie," a brown-haired woman in a sweatshirt, smelly sneakers and Levi's hops into a Volkswagen and drives off to Brooklyn Heights. Sometimes the crowds at the stage door ask if she's a dancer in the show, but usually they ignore her. They never mistake her for Grace Farrell, Daddy Warbucks's coolly elegant, blond, color-coordinated secretary.
This weekend may well be the last chance for New Yorkers to see the vibrant Dance Theater of Harlem in Manhattan for at least a year.

TEL AVIV, Aug 4--Israeli forces killed three Arab guerrillas and took two prisoners today, destroying a band that paralyzed life in Jordan Valley settlements for several hours, military headquarters here said.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--The House resoundingly defeated today two proposals to increase the Federal gasoline tax but put off a final vote on President Carter's energy package.

ON AUG. 23, Katherine Anne Porter's "The Never-Ending Wrong" will be published. Why that day? Because on Aug. 23, just 50 years ago, Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti were executed by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. Miss Porter was there.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--Some 142 "sexual psychopaths" at the Iona State Hospital in Michigan were given LSD and a marijuana derivative to see whether the substances would unlock their most secret thoughts in an experiment soonsored by the Central Intelligence Agency, according to documents reviewed today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)--The median salary that United States Senators pay women employees is 56 percent of the median salary paid to male employees, a wider gap than three years ago, according to a new survey.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4-- What a Summer, favored at 8-5 and top-weighted with 125 pounds, easily won the $25,000 feature race, a handicap for fillies and mares, at the Saratoga track today. Artfully was second, 3 lengths behind.

A few weeks ago, it looked as though the quaint little village of Nyack in Rockland County would go through another summer with a "closed" sign on a landmark in the center of town, the Tappan Zee Playhouse. Then the local government suddenly approved a $20,000 restoration loan, touching off round-the-clock activity to get the theater ready for a five-week summer season, which opened this week.
Almost 75 percent of the estimated 2,000 stores that were looted or vandalized during the recent blackout have reopened for business, many at the same spot, Mayor Beame reported yesterday.

The number of people collecting welfare in New York City fell by 36,119 in the year ended June 30 to 966,728, which was the lowest monthly total in nearly three years, the Human Resources Administrator, J, Henry Smith, announced yesterday.

The beleaguered stock market finally showed a touch of bouyancy yesterday as oil shares and a broad list of issues moved higher.

Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc., the beleaguered Los Angeles-based brokerage house with heavy positions in the Vernitron Corporation and the Frigitonics Cor poration, took steps yesterday to sell some of these holdings. Stocks of the two companies have recently declined sharply in price.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 4 (AP)--The leaders of the four major Greek Cypriot political parties, including the acting President, Spiros Kyprianou, met today to discuss the future of this divided island in the aftermath of President Makarios's death.
The country's major chain Store organizations chalked up impressive sales gains in July with increases ranging from 8.7 percent to more than 21 percent over the level of July 1976.

Nothing quite captured the essence of the youthful 1960's--with its mixture of anger and love, cynicism and hope--like the musical "Hair."

The current market weakness that has carried leading stock averages down more than 5 percent in two and a half weeks has had almost no effect on the Johns-Manville Company, the nation's largest producer of asbestos fibers.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 4-- While Coach John McVay was finally announcing today that Dennis Shaw would be the starting quarterback for the Giants' preseason opener Saturday night, Shaw was doing his laundry.

In an effort to curb scofflaws, the Parking Violations Bureau plans to begin next week immobilizing the vehicles of motorists who repeatedly violate parking laws, according to Harry W. Voccola, the director of the bureau.
