MEXICO CITY, Aug. 4--Just hours after breaking a two-week strike of academic and administrative staff at the National University last month, Mexican policemen raided and closed a church-related information center here dedicated to defending human rights.

The dollar ended a two-day slide yesterday with gains against most currencies on the world money markets, The Associated Press reported. Observers were at a loss, however, to explain the rise in the dollar's value.

Would I mind lending her same, china and glassware? Jeff, her husband, is thinking of setting up bridge tables with checkered table cloths and candles in Chianti bottles--the bistro touch, you know.

LONG ISLAND reaches out into the Atlantic Ocean and forms a land mass that many liken to the claw of a lobster. But the two ends of that single claw--the North Fork and the South Fork--are as different from one another as are the green country and the sandy beach.

WASHINGTON--The Carter Administration has finally produced a compromise plan to stem the flow of illegal aliens into the United States, but it lacks the two elements essential to an effective solution to this increasingly serious problem.

The mass evacuation of more than a dozen skyscraper office buildings in Manhattan as a result of terrorist's bomb threats will apparently cost millions of dollars in lost worker time, overtime pay- ments, added security expenses and forfeited commissions and profits.

The Consolidated Rail Corporation, the Government-chartered successor to six bankrupt Northeastern railroads, yesterday reported a loss of $27.6 million for the second quarter. This was 19.7 percent less than the $34.4 million loss in the year-earlier quarter, which was the railroad's first quarter of operation.

Alice Caddy Burman, artist and illustrator of a series of popular books by her husband, Ben Lucien Barman, died Wednesday night in St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness. She was 80 years old and lived at 24 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--The Carter Administration, wary of political criticism of its plan to revise the nation's welfare system, has decided to withhold public disclosure of the plan until after the House of Representatives completes action this week on the President's energy legislation.

Settling for Central Park on the odd Sunday, they dream of coursing down sunny, sleepy lanes in a restorative silence, the wind ruffling their hair, with a hot bath at the end of the ride and drinks with congenial but undemanding friends.

SEATTLE, Aug. 4--Ken Holtzman laughed. One does not often see Ken Holtzman laugh. At this moment, though, he could have fallen off the bench laughing. It is that funny.

The New York Shakespeare Festival Mobile Theater is ready for its 22-performance, five-borough tour of city parks. The season opens on the East River Park athletic field at Sixth Street and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. The genentor truck hums, providing power for the outdoor theater's light and sound. The bleachers are erected. The trailer trucks that are dressing rooms and control booth are in place. Actors and musicians are on the stage.

An ephemeral particle 10 times heavier than the proton and neutron of the atomic nucleus, heaviest of the stable particles, appears to have been discovered, suggesting the existence of six rather than four quarks as basic building blocks of matter.

STOCKHOLM--The lack of incentive to earn more under Sweden's high tax rates and generous social-security arrangements is vividly illustrated by a new study prepared by the Central Statistical Office at the request of the Employers Association. SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 31--In the apprehensive lives of white Rhodesians, there are few more poignant occasions than an auction. WASHINGTON, Aug 5 The Comptroller of the Currency questioned Bert Lance today about a secret memorandum that seemed to tie Mr. Lance's $2.6 million personal loan from the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company to the opening of an arrangement between that bank and the National Bank of Georgia, which Mr. Lance formerly headed.

Sentences of up to life in prison for two women convicted under New York State's drug laws were declared unconstitutional yesterday by a Federal judge who said the sentences were "disproportionately severe" for relatively minor offenses.

Leo Boivin returned as coach of the St. Louis Blues of the National Hockey League yesterday, and the Buffalo Braves of the National Basketball Association made it official that Lowell (Cotton) Fitzsimmons is their new coach. Some of the things the two men said upon assuming their posts tended to reinforce the feeling that a coach is a coach is a coach, no matter what the sport.

ATLANTA, Aug. 5 Leaders of a number of black churches around the country, spurred in part by the rising influence of young, politically oriented ministers, are seeking to open a drive to increase goods, services and human rights for the poor.

Shipping lobbyists helped elect Jimmy Carter, raising over $150,000 for his campaign. Now they have asked for and received a little help from their friend. The White House has chosen to support "cargo preference" legislation, a new way for ship owners and the maritime unions to get rich at public expense.

Cook Industries Inc., one of the nation's largest grain and cotton conglomerates, continued to suffer severe reverses in its financial position, yesterday reporting a loss of $53 million for its fourth fiscal quarter ended May 31, in contrast to a profit of $20.2 million, or $5.41 a share, cleared in the final quarter of its preceding fiscal year.

Mayor Beame yesterday ordered the police to chase away couples parked in isolated areas of the city and to record the license-plate numbers of their cars "as long as the .44-caliber killer case remains open."

Warm Breeze, the fastest harness horse under race conditions in the 171 year history of the sport, has been syndicated and will begin stallion Service in 1978, the United States Trotting Association was told Friday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 After a week of intensive debate, the House today passed energy taxes and regulatory measures designed to reduce the nation's reliance on natural gas and imported oil, leaving President Carter's sweeping package largely intact.

A fairly new idea in dance probably, at least in effect, the now venerable Dance Theater Workshop was the granddaddy of them all is the "dance collective." This is simply a group of dancers and choreographers gathered together under one name and usualy one roof, who experiment on one another, with one another and for one another. They are their own raw material, their awn first critics and their own best friends.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) The Senate adopted a $7.1 billion foreign aid bill today after removing a restriction that would have barred World Bank loans to Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia and Uganda. The Senate also restored an overall 5 percent cut imposed by the House.

At the Martinique Hotel in midtown Manhattan, Maria Jiminez sat in a dimly lighted room studying a lease she had signed that day for a new apartment for herself and her two children.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug 5 Middle East hopes sank today after Syria announced its rejection of the proposed formation of a "working group" of Arab and Israeli foreign ministers under American auspices to break the Arab-Israeli deadlock.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 5 Satisfied with having at least disposed of the mountain of procedural obstacles they themselves created during the past two months, delegates of 34 nations and the Vatican have declared themselves ready

NEWPORT, R.I, Aug. 5 Baron Marcel Bich, the 64-year-old Frenchman who for seven years at considerable expense and effort has been in pursuit of the America's Cup without any success whatsoever, came close to a small reward today. The Baron's vessel, France I, held the lead against the Swedish yacht, Sverige, for all but the last half mile of a 13.5-mile course, only to lose out at the end by 42 seconds.

The Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center may be shut down for as long as one or two years after "The Cherry Orchard" ends its run there tomorrow afternoon, John W. Mazzola, the center's president, said yesterday. The New York Shakespeare Festival's production of the Chekhov play is closing more than four weeks earlier than anticipated; when it began its run last June 28, the center's management had hoped it would last into the fall.

St. Edward the Confessor Roman Catholic Church in Syosset, L.I., was the setting last evening for the marriage of Patti-Ann McKenna, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. McKenna of Syosset, to Ens. Arthur Stephen Olsen, U.S.C.G., son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Olsen of Farmingdale, L.I. The Rev. Harry J. Palmer performed the ceremony.

A four-day auction of the $110-million in inventories of the defunct 367-store Robert Hall retail chain, concluded yesterday at the Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden, brought in nearly $35 million, or about 32 cents on the dollar.

The New York Mets, the giddiest lastplace team in baseball, treated themselves to more of their newly found "joy of rebuilding" at Shea Stadium last night when they concocted one run in the last half of the eighth inning and defeated the San Francisco Giants, 3-2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 Under the welfare program to be proposed tomorrow by President Carter, New York State would receive well over $400 million in additional funds, members of the state's Congressional delegation reported today. CHERRY POINT, Wash., Aug. 5 The first oil from Alaska's North Slope arrived here today, commencing deliveries of crude from the trans-Alaska pipeline. The deliveries are expected to temporarily ease, but not reverse, the nation's growing dependence on imported oil.

Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday that the police had no suspects in the investigation of last Wednesday's terrorist bombings in midtown Manhattan. One person died and seven were injured in the two incidents.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) A national campaign to encourage women's ownership of businesses through programs of the Small Business Administration has been announced by the White House.

Fan Yuan-Yen, the MIG-19 pilot who defected from the Chinese Air Force to Taiwan last month, has turned down an invitation to visit the United States. Eight conservative Congressmen extended the invitation, but Mr. Fan turned it down for fear of embarassing the United States Government before Secretary State Cyrus R. Vance visits Peking later this month.

These experimental works which had, at least, the advantage of novelty must now stand or fall on their intrinsic merits. Against such a standard, "Myths," seen Thursday evening at 61 Crosby Street, was a poor entry in a flagging field.

Andrew Tsanas, a discharged employee of the J.C. Penney Company, was sentenced to three years in prison and fined $15,000 yesterday following his conviction in Brooklyn Federal Court on charges of failing to report to the Internal Revenue Service $1.4 million in kickbacks on which a tax of $880,000 was evaded.

METULLA Israel, Aug. 5 A Lebanese major, Saad Haddad, crossed the border this morning after a night of heavy fighting between his almost encircled forces of Christian villagers and Palestinian troops on neighboring hills.
ALBANY, Aug. 5 Governor Carey has signed a package of bills intended to improve conditions in private, profit-making homes for adults, his office announced today.
For almost as long as he can remember, Al Fierstein has been captivated by sound. "Sound is my life," he says.

Of the scores of reform movements that flourished in the United States in the last half of the 19th century, few generated the passion and the moral fervor of sex reform. Its explicit history, peopled with men and women of high purpose and fought around issues fundamental to an enlightened society, has lain neglected for almost 100 years, so that Hal D. Sears's "The Sex Radicals" is a pathfinding study of great interest and significance.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 5 Israel today refrained from commenting on Syria's rejection of the Vance proposal.
SEATTLE, Aug. 5 The Yankees, who didn't have much success playing in the proximity of Disneyland earlier this week, had trouble again tonight playing indoor baseball.

Two militant Israeli settlers on the Israeli-occupied West Bank of the Jordan River held a news conference in New York yesterday to announce plans for 12 more Jewish settlements in the disputed territory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 By canceling contracts on the B-1 bomber and the Minuteman III missile before notifying Congress, the Carter Administration violated at least the spirit of the Budget Control and Impoundment Act of 1974, the General Accounting Office said today.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 5 The leaders of the five non-Communist countries of Southeast Asia concluded their two-day conference today with a series of economic agreements and a broad communique pledging renewed efforts to create a "strong, viable and cohesive regional organization."

Doctors at the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey are seeking people who have undergone X-ray or radium treatment for ear, nose and throat ailments to determine if they ran a higher risk of developing cancer, Dr. Myron J. Shapiro, acting chairman of the division of otolaryngology, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 President Carter said today that he and President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania had reached "almost complete agreement" about the diplomatic course to be followed in trying to bring majority rule and legal independence to Rhodesia and South-West Africa, or Namibia.

He would also have curbed that petrified instinct which has featured his policy since U.D.I. (unilateral declaration of independence) in 1965.

Daniel Tange, a retired New York City Police Department captain, pleaded guilty yesterday to perjury in connection with his sworn statements regarding a bribery investigation that had been conducted by John F. Keenan, the special state anti-corruption prosecutor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 When doctors organize a "health maintenance organization," other physicians in the community seldom fight the competition by cutting fees but they do react in other ways that may help to control rising health-care costs, according to a Federal study published today.

Geography Jamaica is a 4,400square mile island in the heart of the Caribbean. Kingston, the capital, is 90 miles south of Cuba and 100 miles west of Haiti. Largely a limestone plateau, the island has volcanic hills, with Blue Mountain on the eastern end reaching 7,400 feet. Rainfall is heavy along this mountainous region, where there are extensive timber reserves. The plateau is a rugged area deeply dissected by streams and undermined by subterranean rivers.

The long fall from grace that began for the Chicago Cubs on May 27 ended last night. Betty Thompson Tuckerman, who was chairman from 1946 to 1949 of the committee for the Junior Assemblies, New York City's subscription dances for debutantes, died yesterday in Hartford (Conn.) Hospital. The widow of Roger Tuckerman, a New York broker, she was 76 years old and lived in Farmington, Conn.

ISLAND BEACH, Aug. 7 At a time when the New Jersey shore is apparently having its busiest summer in five years, Governor Byrne today dedicated an experimental shuttle-bus system that has been operating since June to make it easier for swimmers and sunbathers to get to Island Beach State Park on the state-owned barrier reef between the Atlantic and Barngat Bay.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7 Homosexual organizations in southern California, stung by the antihomosexual vote last June in Dade County, Fla., are preparing to fight a statewide initiative that would allow local school boards to dismiss or to deny employment to teachers who are "open and notorious" homosexuals.

Boris Spassky, a former world champion of the Soviet Union, has struggled to hold even at 5 all in his semifinal candidates' match with Lajos Portisch, a Hungarian grandmaster, in Geneva. But Viktor Korchnoi, a Russian emigree, ran away with the other semifinal, defeating Lev Polugaevsky, a Soviet grandmaster, 8 to 4 in Evian, France.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 The nation is experiencing a new form of inflation that cannot be curbed by the "conventional economic policies" being pursued by the Carter Administration, concludes a report issued today by a Washington-based economic research group.

ROBERT MOSES STATE PARK, L.I. At about 5 o'clock in the evening on every nice Sunday during the summer, thousands of people get the idea to leave this park at the same time, and their cars jam up bumper to bumper on the roads and bridges that lead back to their Long Island and New York City homes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 More than 1,000 fires have ravaged the West in recent days and nearly two million acres of forest and grasslands were still ablaze today in every state west of the Rockies from Alaska south.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 7 In a performance that could be compared to Babe Ruth's famous "called" home run, Gordon Ingate belted one today in the America's Cup yachting trials.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 7 Ch. Alekai Aphrodite, a magnificently-coated white standard poodle owned by Mr. and Mrs. Terence Levy of Huntington, L.I., was judged the best in an all-breed field of 1,495 tonight at the 21st Hunterdon Hills show at the Flemington Fair Grounds.
EDISON, Aug. 7 Intervals of heavy rain failed to dampen the enthusiasm of several hundred people who attended the 10th anniversary celebration of the John F. Kennedy Medical Center here today.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 7 Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel, on a visit to the occupied Golan Heights today, appealed to the leaders of Syria and Jordan to reconsider their rejection of a proposed working group of Arab and Israeli foreign ministers that would hold discussions in the United Sates as an interim step to ward a Geneva peace conference.

SEATTLE, Aug. 7 (UPI) Jerry Bangs, an unlimited-hydroplane driver, was killed today when he was tossed from his speeding boat as it spun during the $30,000 Seafair Trophy race, won by Bill Muncey aboard Atlas Van Lines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 Brooklyn-born James L. Larocca, scheduled for formal designation Thursday as the New York State Energy Commissioner, plans to emphasize conservation, conversion to coal and "the carrot approach."

The 2-1 loss to the Diplomats in Washington on Saturday night was nothing more than a "tuneup match for the playoffs," according to Eddie Firmani, the coach of the Cosmos who had rested four regulars, including Franz Beckenbauer and Giorgio Chinaglia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 In his new production of Ferruccio Busoni's "Dr. Faust," which had its premiere last night at Wolf Trap, Frank Corsaro has outdone himself. He has produced a super-colossal Ken Russell type of interpretive musical psychology, using poor Busoni as a takeoff point. Banners bravely aloft, all systems go, the Corsaro army has once again marched down the wrong road.

PARIS The new production of Rossini's "La Cenerentola" at the Theatre National de l'Opera continues Rolf Liebermann's policy of rebuilding the company's repertory of 18th and l9th century staples in productions that might most charitably be described as "unusual."

TAIF, Saudi Arabia; Aug. 7 (AP) American reporters accompanying Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance on his Middle East peace mission were presented on arrival here today with hotel registration cards with "Christian" filled in as their religion.

WEST BERLIN, Aug. 7 (AP) Fred Metasch and his fellow Radebeul Indians have pitched wigwams near Dresden, East Germany, for their annual festival of war dances, knife throwing and solidarity with the real native Americans.

Connie Joy Baum, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Baum of Passaic, N.J., was married yesterday to Jay Hartley Newman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Newman of Westfield, N.J. Rabbi Leon Katz performed the ceremony at the Patrician in Livingston, N.J.

OTTAWA, Aug. 7 A nationwide strike of air traffic controllers, the result of a wage dispute with the Government, began early today and before nightfall paralyzed regular airline service throughout the nation and forced 40,000 travelers to change their plans.
TAIF, Saudi Arabia, Aug. 7 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance arrived in this Saudi summer capital today after receiving an encouraging sendoff in Amman, the Jordanian capital, from King Hussein.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 An American soldier of fortune says the South Korean Central Intelligence Agency recruited him for espionage in Zaire and Canada last year and tried to persuade him to gather intelligence in the United States.

Five persons were struck by lightning in Central Park yesterday afternoon and a sixth person was struck on the beach in Jacob Riis Park in queens. Five of them were reported to be in serious condition.
William L. Phinney, a prominent New Hampshire lawyer who prosecuted one of the nation's first cases of alleged euthanasia, died Saturday at his home in Manchester, N.H. He was 68 years old.

Suffering their first serious slump of the season during the last eight days, the Chicago White Sox have helped create the most interesting pennant race in the major leagues. The American League West Division leaders for most of the season now have lost seven of their last eight games and have given new hope to the Minnesota
WANKIE, Rhodesia, Aug. 1 The bull elephant, the grandest of animals, is pitiful in death.

ROME, Aug. 7 (AP) Roman Catholic church sources said today that the Vatican forbids vasectomies for the purpose of birth control despite its new decree allowing men with vasectomies to contract valid marriages.

TRENTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) Angelo Bruno, said to be the Mafia boss of Philadelphia and southern New Jersey, will be the star witness tomorrow when the State Commission of Investigation begins a series of hearings on casino gambling in Atlantic City.

WASHINGTON The terms of the proposed new Panama Canal treaty are about to surface, and already an orchestrated campaign has begun to sell it without amendment to Congress and the public. In the process, two crucial and interrelated considerations are likely to be glossed over:

Even in this age of conspicuous consumption, having eight television sets in the living room seems a little much. Kenneth R. Betters apartment at 303 East 57th Street is so equipped not for pleasure and not for torture but for business.

PRINCETON, Aug. 7 The New Jersey Federation of Democratic Women gave a garden reception at Morven today to introduce the 15 woman candidates for the State Legislature and to publicize the progress of the three-month-old federation.

At Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I., yesterday, Donna Nancy Field, a student at the Emory University School of Nursing, was married to Michael Barry Krasnoff, a law student at Emory. Rabbi Fred Dworkin performed the ceremony.
Tillie, Tallulah, Buttons and George, Ginny, Pat, Buddy and Sam. Harvey, Miss X, Ugly and It. Not to mention Turkey.

Speaking of corn, we have noted before that there is almost no food or indulgence that one medical man or survey cannot prove is harmful in one way or another. Sugar rots teeth, salt clogs up the arteries, dairy products are deadly, and clams give you hepatitis.

As a preschooler, Frank Sullivan's I.Q. was under 70, and he was diagnosed as mentally retarded. His parents, Kathleen and Charles Sullivan of Philadelphia, sent him to special schools from the age of 6, and he ultimately completed a work-training program run by the Philadelphia Association for Retarded Citizens. (Sullivan is not their name.)

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Aug. 7 Manuel Orantes of Spain presided over the resurrection of John Alexander of Australia today in the finals of the $125,000 Volvo International tennis tournament in this tiny village deep in the heart of New Hampshire's White Mountains.

TIJUANA, Mexico, Aug. 7 Destitute migrants from the Mexican interior, estimated by the police here to number 200,000 to 250,000, are massed around this border city determined to reach the United States before Congress acts on an amnesty plan for illegal aliens that President Carter proposed last week.

Ellen Sue Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Cohen of Old Westbury, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Barry Steven Turkanis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Turkanis of Swampscott, Mass. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman performed the ceremony in Temple Israel in Great Neck, L.I.
SEATTLE, Aug. 7 Although they didn't hear their owner call them "the team that choked," the Yankees restored some spirit and spark to their sagging lives today by crushing the Seattle Mariners, 7-1.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 8 (UPI) Mark Moseley, who missed an extra point try and field goal attempts of 38 and 42 yards earlier in the game, booted a 29-yard field goal with 20 seconds left tonight that gave the Washington Redskins a 16-14 victory over the Cleveland Browns in their first National Football League preseason game.
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose slightly yesterday despite the widespread belief that the Federal Reserve is likely to push interest rates higher in the near future.

Despite a beautifully executed upset of Martina Navratilova by Billie Jean King, the New York Apples fell again to the Boston Lobsters in a World Team Tennis match last night before a crowd of 7,387 at Madison Square Garden.
In speaking out against capital punishment, Mario M. Cuomo was acting as "a buffer for his boss, the Governor," Mayor Beame said yesterday.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 8 When he finally loses a tennis match and gets a chance to take a day off, Guillermo Vilas will work on his movie screenplay, edit a new poetry collection, mail month-old letters to friends and stock up on his stereo cassettes from a list already one-page long in his diary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 A former official in the National Security Agency has charged that he was dismissed from the highly secretive agency after raising questions about possible conflict of interest in its equipment purchases and not because there were valid objections to his work.

CIUDAD OBREGON, Mexico, Aug. 8 (AP) The drought that is parching large areas of the United States has moved south into Mexico, sharply reducing water supplies in the northwest farmlands and threatening to bring nationwide food shortages.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 8 (UPI) C. Peter Magrath, president of the University of Minnesota, says the school will not declare three basketball players ineligible as a means of avoiding the probation placed on men's sports at the school by the Naitonal Collegiate Athletic Association.

Mrs. Sherman Post Haight, author, rare book collector, aviation enthusiast and a student of Indian cultures, died yesterday in her home in Litchfield, Conn., after a short illness. She was 88 years old.

TAIF, Saudi Arabia, Aug. 8 (AP) A spokesman for Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance expressed regret today that all American reporters traveling with him were identified as Christians on hotel registration forms.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 Should illegal aliens be granted amnesty by the United States?

TAIF, Saudi Arabia, Aug. 8 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that Saudi Arabian officials had advised him to expect an imminent change in the Palestine Liberation Organization's attitude toward a key United Nations resolution that recognizes Israel's right to exist and has been opposed by the P.L.O. for a decade.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 8 The jury in the Federal conspiracy and corruption trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland heard the final arguments of defense lawyers for his five co-defendants today and prepared for the showdown in the nine-week case tomorrow the summations of the chief prosecutor and the 57-year-old Governor's defense counsel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 Students at Harvard University, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Emerson College were among some 200 persons who received LSD in experiments secretly financed by the Central Intelligence Agency at the Boston Psychopathic Hospital in the early 1950's, researchers who worked on the studies said today.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. S (UPI) The Ethiopian radio said today that fighting in the Ogaden desert between Government troops and Somali guerrillas had turned into "full-scale war" with Somalia.

A throng estimated at 8,000 to 10,000 people jammed New York City's regional manpower offices yesterday, seeking applications for 2,000 jobs to assist in the federally financed blackout cleanup project. The scene was one of confusion over who was to apply, when and where.

BARDSTOWN, Ky., Aug. 8 (AP) Ray Hilbert, a widely traveled Associated Press executive whose last assignment was as chief of communications in Milwaukee, died Saturday after a long illness. He was 38 years old.

JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 8 Less than 45 miles separate the somber Cabinet room in Pretoria's Union Buildings and the smoke-clogged streets of Soweto, but for all the communication between them South Africa's white rulers and the black leaders of Soweto might as well be at opposite ends of the globe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 Highly placed United States Government sources said today that Cambodian or Vietnamese rebels operating from bases in Cambodia had been harassing Vietnamese border areas with artillery, rocket and mortar fire, forcing the temporary evacuation of two towns.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 The Carter Administration called on the Senate today to strengthen its energy program by tightening the tax on automobiles that get poor gasoline mileage and the taxes on the use of oil and natural gas by industry.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 8 Governor Carey said today that he would support an increase of $300 a student in the maximum grant available under the state's Tuition Assistance Program next year. The increase is similar to a plan Mr. Carey declined to support when it was proposed by Republicans in the State Senate during the last legislative session.

LA CANADA, Calif., Aug. 8 Sin, a black cat owned by John Weyl, a La Canada lawyer, disappeared the other day. And Mr. Weyl is sure that Sin Suffered the same fate as Erin, his 9-year-old Shetland sheepdog.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) The Central Intelligence Agency is forecasting a slowdown in the Soviet Union's economic growth in the 1980's, partly because of a predicted oil shortage.

ROANOKE RAPIDS, N.C., Aug. 8 This quiet, green, Southern textile town of 14,000 people is the test locale for the value of a labor law reform bill that organized labor regards as the key to sewing the union label on the booming and still largely nonunion South.

Mayor Beame, in a major shift from his proposal that the New York City Board of Education be abolished, recommended yesterday that it be retained, but with the Mayor appointing its members, and that its chairman serve as a salaried Schools Chancellor.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 8 (AP) Saboteurs blew up a section of track on a railway bridge outside Salisbury today, halting trains to points north and west of the capital, the police said. No injuries were reported.
Polygraph tests arranged by Playboy magazine indicate that James Earl Ray Jr. acted alone in slaying the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

PARIS In record time and with practically, no publicity, a new museum has been born in Paris. Its bombastic, nouveau riche name, Palais de L'Alma, gives no indication of the nature and quality of its contents: the art of the period from 1884 to 1904.

OTTAWA, Aug. 8 Canadian airlines continued today to reroute thousands of passengers through United States airports in border cities, sometimes with long and arduous delays, in the second day of a strike by Canadian air controllers.

NAPANOCH, N.Y., Aug. 8 About 150 inmates armed with clubs and other makeshift weapons seized 14 hostages and a wing of the Eastern Correctional Facility here this morning, but the rebels released the last of their hostages and surrendered peacefully tonight after a 12-hour siege:

WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 8 (AP) A man who filed suit earlier this year to prevent doctors from removing his stepdaughter from a respirator has been sentenced to five years to life for fatally beating the child.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 8 (AP) Ross Lewis, retired editorial cartoonist for The Milwaukee Journal who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1935, died Saturday in a hospital. He was 74 years old.

OTTAWA, Aug. 8 Canada and the United States will hold negotiations looking toward an early agreement on a pipeline to bring natural gas from northern Alaska, and eventually from the Canadian Arctic as well, to American and Canadian consumers by the Alaska Highway Route, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau announced today.

An unexploded bomb was discovered yesterday in one of the buildings mentioned as a target last Wednesday by telephone callers who said they were speaking for the Puerto Rican terrorist group known as the F.A.L.N. Two bombs exploded that day, killing one man and injuring seven other persons, and dozens of bomb threats led to massive evacuations of office workers.
LONDON Sixteen-year-old Kim Ryan of Rye, N.Y., paused for a moment in the crowded shop and eyed a long, blue cotton dress, printed with small white flowers.

Mayor Beame, in a major shift from his proposal that the New York City Board of Education be abolished, recommended yesterday that it be retained, but with the Mayor appointing its members, and that its chairman serve as a salaried Schools Chancellor.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 Vice President Mondale said today that a new set of regulations for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency being prepared by the Carter Administration would require warrants for all wiretaps, searches and mail opening.

The Loews Corporation, engaged in tobacco, theater and hotels, insurance and investments, more than tripled its second-quarter net income, after including capital and investment gains, it was reported yesterday. Earnings from operations were up 42.6 percent for the quarter.

O.J. Simpson got some reassuring news yesterday about his blurred vision from the Wilmer Eye Institute of Johns Hopkins University hospital in Baltimore. After being examined by two specialists, Dr. Walter Stark and the institute's director, Dr. A. Edward Muamenee, Simpson's vision was described as nearly perfect.
Altonell Hines Matthews, a member of the original cast of "Porgy and Bess" and "Four Saints in Three Acts," died Saturday at her home at 400 West 154th Street. She was 72 years old.
Babcock Wilcox's temporary reprieve from the United Technologies corporation takeover, granted last Friday by an Ohio court, has proved indeed to be temporary.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 (AP) A Philaprevent a syndicate from shifting the Puprevent a syndicate fro mshifting the Pulitzer Prize-winning comic strip "Doonesbury" to a competing newspaper.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. Enter here the opinion that Christianity has nothing to do with denying homosexuals their civil rights.

The Beame administration, until yesterday a supporter of the problemplagued B'nai Torah Institute of Brooklyn, has decided to give no "new funds" to the institute until the city receives "proper clearance" from the United States Department of Labor.

MORAINE STATE PARK, Pa., Aug. 8 (AP) Neither mud nor rain nor makeshift addresses can stop the mail at the National Boy Scout Jamboree, which was hit by three inches of rain over the weekend. Some of the Scouts had to move to higher camping sites.

The Crown Central Petroleum Corporation and the Hamilton Brothers Petroleum Corporation, which have been seeking to acquire a controlling interest in Kewanee Industries Inc., have proposed a new plan to purchase under certain conditions all of Kewanee's outstanding shares at $46.50 each.
CLINTON, Ill., Aug. 8 (AP) An accident at a nuclear power plant being built outside Clinton exposed several workers to direct radiation, the Nuclear Regulatory Agency said today.
MOSCOW, Aug. 8 (AP) The Soviet Union said today that South Africa was on the verge of creating a nuclear bomb and called for urgent international efforts to block such a development.

The Syntex Corporation said that an Internal Revenue Service Claim for the company's fiscal years 1970 and 1971 had been settled for $986,000. Originally, the I.R.S. had proposed deficiencies in Syntex's United States's taxes of $8.5 million for the two years.

Louis Clark Brock stole into town yesterday in pursuit of the sprinting ghost of Tyrus Raymond Cobb, and gaining fast. In his illustrious career, which began in 1905 and ended in 1928, Cobb stole a record total of 892 bases. In his illustrious career, which began in 1961, Brock has stolen 886 bases just six fewer.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Aug. 8( AP) An estimated 2,000 families are still living with relatives and friends three weeks after they were forced to flee their homes in the area's third Killer flood in a century.

JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 8 (UPI) Three blacks were wounded by police gunfire in Soweto today as youths tried to enforce a boycott of all-black schools. The police said 12 black youths were arrested.

Vance, that it would be futile to prepare a role for the Palestine Liberation Organization in Middle East peace talks by trying to make the P.L.O. recognize Israel.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 Vice President Mondale said today that a new set of regulations for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency being prepared by the Carter Administration would require warrants for all wiretaps, searches and mail opening.

Two more Wall Street firms, Shearson Hayden Stone Inc. and Faulkner Dawkins Sullivan Inc., announced merger plans yesterday continuing a securities industry trend that has become particularly pronounced this year.

Muriel S. Webb, director since 1974 of the Commission on Interchurch Aid, Refugees and World Service of the World Council of Churches in Geneva, died of cancer on Sunday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. She was 64 years old and lived at 5 Mill Pond, Cos Cob, Conn.

National Airlines, whose former "Fly Me" advertising campaign won it enormous attention, as well as enormous animosity from many feminist organizations, will begin a new campaign next week that is strictly non-controversial. In fact, it's downright homey.
The dollar made good gains against West European currencies in foreign exchange trading yesterday and a moderate gain against the Japanese yen, The Associated Press reported.

WASHINTGON, Aug. 8 A House investigator said today that United States intelligence officials had "strong suspicions" that highly enriched uranium, a type that could be used in bombs, was stolen from a Pennsylvania nuclear facility more than a decade ago.

Five businessmen were indicted in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday on charges of defrauding Citibank of $1.6 million through the use of forged savings bank passbooks that were submitted as collateral to obtain corporate loans.

First, let us clear the record. In recent months we have sharply criticized President Carter for his pinched approach to welfare reform. When he said he was determined to achieve reform, but without any increase in spending, we were left wondering "about either his sincerity or his arithmetic."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 The Securities and Exchange Commission has charged a New York-based concern that offers amateur inventors an "invention-development program" with violating registration and anti-fraud provisions of the Federal securities laws.

New York City has managed to get foreign diplomats and governments to pay more than $750,000 in unpaid bills that New York businessmen had been dunning them for, a municipal official disclosed this week.

DETROIT Like Kubla Khan is Xanadu, Lawrence P. Fisher had a pleasure palace built in 1929. However, the automobile magnate's place with its gardens and fountains, its huge pseudo-Moorish rooms with painted ceilings and pillars inlaid with gold (not to mention a swimming pool, bowling alley, miniature golf course and boat dock for his 100-foot yacht) was setin East Detroit, an area that began to deteriorate after the Depression.

TOKYO, Aug. 8 Nagataka Murayama, an owner and former president of Asahi Shimbun, Japan's largest and most prestigious newspaper, died yesterday in a hospital in a suburb of Osaka. He was 83 years old.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 8 Prime Minister Menahem Begin served notice today, on the eve of the arrival in Jerusalem of Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, that it would be futile to prepare a role for the Palestine Liberation Organization in Middle East peace talks by trying to make the P.L.O. recognize Israel.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 The Carter Administration, Vice President Mondale told the American Bar Association today, "has rejected absolutely the doctrine that any government official, including the President, is above the law. President Carter has made it clear that he and everyone else who serves under him has a duty to obey the law just like everyone else in America."

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) The Senate committee investigating possible involvement by Senators in alleged Congressional influence-buying by the South Korean Government may name a special counsel in the next two weeks, its chairman said today.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass. Originally written as a movie musical, Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart's "I Married an Angel" was rejected by Louis B. Mayer. In 1938, the team converted the script into a hit Broadway musical, and several years later it was filmed by M-GM.

Rio Rancho Estates lost another legal battle yesterday when a Federal appeals court affirmed the company's conviction in a major fraud case involving a scheme to sell $200 million of land in New Mexico.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Sam Peckinpah sits in a canvas chair in the middle of an empty highway licking the peanuts off a packaged ice cream cone. Except for a half-glass of beer with each meal, the 52-year-old director of the Wild Bunch," "The Getaway," and "Straw Dogs" has been a teetotaler for the last eight months.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 A substantial shift is under way at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in effect, moving thousands of jobs from the East to the Sunbelt states.
Because of good job prospects for graduates, accounting has become higher education's most popular subject.

AFTON, Okla., Aug. 8 Eleven Middle Western Governors, who have long favored deregulation of natural gas, today attacked President Carter's energy program and the recently passed House bill embodying it and began mapping strategy to fight in the Senate for increased production incentives.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 8 A surprisingly youthful-looking Ernie Banks, who spent all his 19 major league seasons with the Chicago Cubs, was one of six players inducted this morning into the Baseball Hall of Fame.

The Carter Administration reversing its previous stand, has decided not to supersede local rent laws at the large Lincoln Towers apartment complex in Manhattan and not to authorize rent rises of up to 20 percent for a single year's renewal lease.

The General Motors Corporation apparently disappointed shareholders late last Tuesday by declaring its usual 85-cent dividend after reporting second-quarter profits of $1 billion; the largest quarterly result ever for an industrial manufacturing company.

Ramblin' Jack Elliott, who has been rambling longer than many of today's folk singers have been alive, rescued a sodden, lugubrious late show at the Bottom Line Sunday morning with a warm, funny absolutely captivating monologue. MONTREAL, Aug. 8 In a city that has worked hard to be modern by transforming much of its center into characterless high-rises, a blow for conservation is struck every once in a while. After another long hard fight, conservationists have just found something to cheer about.

PANAMA, Aug. 8 United States and Panamanian negotiators held long sessions today in an attempt to bridge the remaining gaps and conclude a treaty that would provide for transfer of the Panama Canal and the Canal Zone to Panamanian control by the year 2000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) Consumers borrowed more money on the installment plan in June, but they paid off their past debts in record amounts, the Federal Reserve reported today.

The Kaiser Industries Corporation said it would make its second liquidating distribution of corporate assets on Oct. 3 to shareholders of record Sept. 2. The distribution will be $1 per Kaiser Industries share.

EMI Ltd., a British concern that was instrumental in the development of X-ray scanners, said it had filed suit against Pfizer Inc. and its subsidiary, Pfizer Medical System Inc. in Federal court in Wilmington, Del.

TRENTON, Aug. 8 Angelo Bruno, regarded by law-enforcement officials as the head of organized crime in Philadelphia and South Jersey, insisted today that he wanted to "stay away" from Atlantic City with the approach of legalized gambling there.

Remo Bolognini, an assistant concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic in the 1930's under Toscanini, died Monday in Roosevelt Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 78 years old. He had been playing as a substitute in the violin section of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra for the last five years.

City officials who have been sifting since Saturday through President Carter's welfare proposals say they cannot be sure whether the revisions would actually save the city the $173 million that the White House said would be saved.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 Attorney General Griffin B. Bell today urged foreign governments to cooperate with the antitrust investigations by the United States of the oil and uranium industries. Otherwise he suggested, the United States may be less willing to cooperate with investigations of these countries.

Arnold (Red) Auerbach, president and general manager of the Boston Celtics, will be coaching one of the teams for the 19th straight year tonight in the Maurice Stokes Memorial Game at Kutsher's Country Club in Monticello.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 8 Rich Sowells, a starting cornerback for three of his six seasons with the Jets, was one of 10 players cut today as the squad got down to tomorrow's 60player National Football League roster limit.

SEATTLE, Aug. 8 (AP) A group of friends gathered today at Lake Washington's hydroplane pit area in a memorial to Jerry Bangs, 42 years old, who was killed yesterday when his thunderboat cartwheeled and threw him into the water.
A bearish crop survey issued over the weekend by Conrad Leslie, the leading private forecaster, sent soybean and grain futures prices tumbling in Chicago yesterday.

TAIF, Saudi Arabia, Aug. 8 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that Saudi Arabian officials had advised him to expect an imminent change in the Palestine Liberation Organization's attitude toward a key United Nations resolution that recognizes Israel's right to exist and has been opposed by the P.L.O. for a decade.

PLAINS, Ga., Aug. 8 President Carter briefly interrupted his vacation here today to sign two bills into law, one allowing the manufacturing of cars under relaxed Federal emission standards, the other appropriating millions of dollars in Federal funds for several water development projects he had vigorously opposed.

The mutiny on the Island Queen, unlike the more celebrated insurrection on the Bounty, may not be the stuff of which best-selling books or movies are made, but it will probably be remembered for a long time by 23 city sanitationmen, a boat captain and his crew and law enforcement officers.

An accounting firm whose opinion had been sought on two controversial items in New York City's budget has concluded that Mayor Beame was wrong in balancing the budget with them and that Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin was right in opposing them.

LONDON, Aug. 8 The first hints of the huge purchases by the Russians in their 1972 grain-buying coup came not from the boisterous Chicago futures pits but from a relatively obscure exchange here that provides no public record of its transactions.

JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 8 (UPI) South African officials said today that a mine rescue team had found bodies but no survivors in a Mozambique coal mine where 70 black miners are believed to have died in an explosion last week.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug 8 Andrew Young, the United States delegate to the United Nations, was given a warm and friendly welcome here today and joined Costa Rican leaders in emphasizing that mutual concern for human rights would be the overriding theme of his visit.

TRENTON, Aug. 9 Dr. T. Edward Hollander, former deputy commissioner for higher and professional education in New York State, was sworn in today as Chancellor of Higher Education in New Jersey.

HAVANA, Aug. 9 (Reuters) President Fidel Castro gave Senator Frank Church a particularly warm welcome to Cuba today, talking to him for several hours and driving him on a sightseeing tour of Havana in his jeep.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) Admiral Turner said today that American intelligence agents never bugged or taped conversations of top South Korean officials in the Blue House, the Presidential mansion in Seoul.

ROANOKE RAPIDS, N.C., Aug. 9 A succession of more than 30 witnesses paraded before a Congressional panel in this Southern textile town today to tell Congressmen that without a tightening of the nation's labor laws, unions would remain unable to breach the wall of "economic terrorism" set up by what several witnesses referred to as "the Southern antilabor conspiracy."

STROUDSBERG, Pa., Aug. 9 As the time approaches for the first spin of the roulette wheels in Atlantic City, competing resorts in New Jersey's neighboring states of Pennsylvania and New York are growing increasingly nervous.

Maxwell Balfour, who began his career as an airplane pilot in World War I and ended it with his retirement in 1961 as director of the aviation division of the Spartan Aircraft Company, died Monday in Tulsa, Okla. He was 82 years old.

NASHVILLE, Aug. 9 (AP) Delegates to the Tennessee Constitutional Convention approved their first proposed amendment to the state constitution last night, voting 85 to 3 to delete an 1870 ban as marriages between blacks and whites.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 9 Israeli leaders told Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance today that they remained strongly opposed to giving up any territory on the occupied West Bank of the Jordan and in the Gaza Strip, to the creation of any Palestinian homeland on Israel's borders and to any part for the Palestine Liberation Organization in an eventual negotiation at Geneva.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 Adm. Stansfield Turner, the Director of Central Intelligence, said today that he would make all the records of the Central Intelligence Agency's drug-testing activities available to the Department of Justice if it decided that "an investigation into any aspect of the matter is warranted."

AUGUSTA, N.J., Aug. Sundance, owned and ridden by Sharon Busch of Holmdel, N.J., scored 16 points and won the Large-pony hunter championship today at the Sussex County horse show held at the Sussex County Fair and Horse Show Grounds.

OTTAWA, Wednesday Aug.10 (Reuters) The Canadian House of Commons early this morning passed a bill ordering 2,200 air-traffic controllers to end a strike that has brought the country's air services to a virtual halt.

TRENTON, Aug. 9 A bag of $40,000 in currency hidden in a cellar part of a "friend to friend" loan of $50,000 unsecured by any formally signed papers figured in tangled financial arrangements that led to the purchase early this year of a bar and discotheque in Atlantic City.
DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 9 At least 11 families lost their homes today as three major fires spread uncontrolled while striking Dayton firefighters watched from their picket lines.

HISTORY It was Columbus who in 1502 gave Costa Rica its name, which means rich coast. The name apparently came from the lush forests covering more than half the country, rather than from any great quantities of gold and silver, which attracted the Conquistadors' to other parts of Latin America. As a result, the country was virtually ignored by early Spanish empire builders.

Late in the afternoon of Saturday, July 30, Donald Byrne was struck and killed by a Long Island Rail Road train, Eight days later the woman he loved, Lorraine Scheele, died. She was killed by a train driven by the same engineer, at the same time on a fading summer day and practically on the same spot at the Massapequa Park station.

Compact, high-voltage, direct-current terminals being installed in Astoria, Queens, for operation next year are considered likely to open the way to import large blocks of electricity into power-pinched New York, and possibly other major cities.
ONE SATURDAY EVENING, according to Ceil Waldrip, as attractive red-haired woman stood on the corner of Broadway and 90th Street, trying futilely to hail a cab.
Computer stocks and selected issues moved higher yesterday in an indecisive market. The Dow Jones industrial average, as if underscoring the market's uncertainty, finished without change at 879.42.

It's been almost two months since Tom Seaver was traded by the New York Mets to the Cincinnati Reds. And last night Manager Joe Torre enjoyed a fringe benefit of that deal, something other than the acquisition of Steve Henderson, the left fielder Mets' fans have been growing to love.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 Bob Bergland, the Secretary of Agriculture, demanded today to know what legal justification the General Services Administration had for removing the dedication plaque from the department's grill, newly named in honor of Alferd Packer, who was convicted of killing and eating five Colorado prospectors in 1874.
I have a friend who repeatedly refers to her husband as a cordon bleu cook. I am under the distinct impression that a cordon bleu is properly applied to women only. Am I correct?

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 The American Bar Association urged Congress and the states today to adopt a broad program of grand jury changes aimed at curbing abuses by prosecutors and providing more protection for witnesses.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 9 Andrew Young upheld the Carter Administration's strong advocacy of human rights here today, insisting national boundaries and sovereignty become less important "when human need cries out."

WHILE most restaurants are content to do very little about wine other than overcharge for it a small but growing number of alert restaurateurs are going out of their way to bring their customers and wine closer together.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 9 Israeli leaders told Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance today that they remained strongly opposed to giving up any territory on the occupied West Bank of the Jordan, and in the Gaza Strip, to the creation of any Palestinian homeland on Israel's borders and to any part for the Palestine Liberation Organization in an eventual negotiation at Geneva.

DAWSON, Ga., Aug. 9 (UPI) A former policeman repeated under cross-examination today his charges that officers used threats and coercion to obtain confessions from five black youths accused of murdering a white man.

MOSCOW, Aug. 9 The Soviet press agency Tass today mounted a sharp personal attack on President Carter, accusing him of yielding to the Pentagon by approval to the neutron bomb. Tass apmanufacture a new neutron warhead.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug, 9 Running six or seven feet in a football game isn't hard the trick is doing it when everyone in the stadium knows that's what you're trying to do.

John L. Hanigan, chairman of Genesco Inc., one of the largest manufacturers and retailers of apparel, confirmed yesterday that his company will sell or liquidate its women's and children's apparelproducing divisions because, as a group, they have been "bleeding" the company of profits.

OTTAWA, Aug. 8 The announcement of a new rise in unemployment, the latest in a series of gloomy reports on Canada's faltering economy, was followed today by a drop in the international value of the Canadian dollar to the lowest point in more than seven years.

A New York State Supreme Court justice has been asked to settle a dispute involving a fat-rendering plant in Queens, residents of Long Island City and eastern Manhattan, New York City's Environmental Control Board and a smell that the board believes is so foul that it is seeking to shut down the entire plant.

One of the fastest-growing segments of the magazine business these days is the in-flight magazine. It shouldn't be surprising therefore to find that a new marketing concept for some of these publications has been developed.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 Invited by the bar to offer their views of lawyers, several prominent Chicago businessmen today acted as a blue-ribbon grand jury, handing up what amounted to an indictment of the profession. They found lawyers overpriced, pedantic, too talkative too combative and not adequately concerned with the goals of their clients.

The introduction of new products in July fell below June's recordsetting pace, but nevertheless surpassed the level of July 1976 by 26 percent. That's the word from New Products News, the DancerFitzgerald-Sample Inc. publication

China, the Bronx, Paris and Montana figure prominently in the movie news. EMI films has acquired "The Chinese Bandit," the best-selling novel by Stephen Becker. Mitch Brower and Robert Lovenheim are to produce the picture early next year. It's a "big-scale action adventure drama set in China."

Governor Byrne yesterday called the Federal Highway Administrator "correct on principle" in upholding the $1.50 toll for Hudson River bridges and tunnels, but the New Jersey Governor said the ruling would not change his demand for a rollback of the toll to $1 or for a new mass-transit aid plan.

AFTON, Okla., Aug. 10 A high official of the Agriculture Department told Middle Western governors today that the income of farmers would continue to decline this year, taking them "in real terms back where we were in 1971."

Backgammon is in part a blocking game and in part a racing game. In many positions, however, one strategy may predominate. Distinguishing between these two strategies and selecting the appropriate one is essential.

The American Museum of Natural History will celebrate the 75th birthday of Dr. Margaret Mead with a five-day festival of new and classical anthropological films. The festival, which begins Sept. 14, will feature more than 80 hours of continuous weekend screenings in eight museum halls. Also included are a three-evening retrospective of the works of film ethnographer Jean Rouch, a family-folklore workshop, informal talks by experts, displays and a special student screening area.

Comic Relief THE surest sign of the success of a Broadway show is the settling in of the actors as they begin decorating their dressing rooms. Now that the good reviews are behind them, the stars of "Annie," this year's Tony-award-winning musical, are turning their attention to wallpaper and carpet and sofas.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 10 Talks were nearing completion today on a plan to transfer the curriculum of Bennett College to the campus of Briarcliff College. Both colleges closed earlier this summer, but Briarcliff's campus facilities have been taken over by Pace University.

HAVE YOU ever wondered how television stars on the way up live? Take Stanley Slegel. Mr. Siegel is the "exhilarating and affable host" of ABC-TV's Stanley Siegel Show, the 9 A.M. talk program that in less than two years has overtaken NBC's popular "Not for Women Only."

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. "THERE IS A considerable risk in what I'm doing," says Ali MacGraw. "There's everything to be lost by this the possibility that my children will think I'm deserting them, and the possibility that I'll be atrocious in this movie. But if I'm atrocious, I think I can handle that better than I did five years ago."

FORT LEE, Aug. 10 Growing apprehension that the psychopathic killer known as "Son of Sam" might strike in North Jersey is discouraging teen-agers and sightseers from making nighttime stops in lovers lanes throughout the area and at viewing sites on the bluffs above the Hudson River.

TEL AVIV, Aug 10 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance told West Bank Arab public figures today that the United States considered a transition period under United Nations trusteeship as the most reasonable solution of the issue of a Palestinian homeland, members of the group reported.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 10 The long, complex Federal conspiracy and corruption case against Gov. Marvin Mandel and five business associates went to the jury today after the judge denied an unusual motion by the prosecutor to hold alternate jurors on standby to guard against a mistrial.

Tom Underwood, the St. Louis Cardinals' starting pitcher, gained credit for a 3-1 victory over the New York Mets at Shea Stadium yesterday, and although he is glad to be a starter again, he still longs to be a finisher.

TWO YEARS AGO Maggie and Terre Roche, two sisters from Park Ridge, N.J., then living in Manhattan, put out a record on Columbia. It was received with warmth in some critical quarters for its fresh variants on folk harmonizing and its songs, mostly composed by Maggie.

IMAGINE an icecap moving into Madison Square Garden yesterday while most of us were trying to cope with heat and humidity and the dog days of August. Yet, there it was, with the most astounding people, all marvelous showoffs, revelling on it, leaping and spinning and gliding with energy enough to make a tennis champ look lethargic.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., Aug. 10 The operators of private nursing homes in Suffolk County complained today that the bad reputation of their industry generally was responsible for state Medicaid fund cuts that, they said, might force the closing of several homes soon and leave the county with a shortage of more than 400 beds for the elderly.

SAN FRANCISCO Two years ago, Quentin Breen was one of the most promising young tax lawyers in the country. A recognized specialist in the intricate field of offshore tax havens, he had built his law firm, Breen, Kantor Wolfe, from scratch into a bustling office of 17 persons in only six years.

DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 10 After two days of standing by while homes or apartments burned, Dayton firefighters reached an agreement with city officials on a new contract late this afternoon, ended their strike and jumped on their engines to answer another fire call.
A Brooklyn grocer, his son and a family friend have been cleared of murder charges in the killing of a man believed to have murdered the grocer's wife during a robbery several weeks ago.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 10 Inspired partly by the crowd of 57,828 that packed Giants Stadium but mostly by his thirst for victory and his unfriendly attitude toward the Tampa Bay Rowdies, Pele scored two goals tonight and led the Cosmos to a 3-0 victory over a team that had never lost a playoff game to the Cosmos.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif. More than a mile above sea level amid the extravagant natural beauty of the Sierra Nevada Mountains, a major battle has begun in the ideological conflict between capitalistic and socialistic life styles.

Dr. Grete Lehner Bibring, professor of clinical psychiatry emeritus at Harvard University and a student and colleague of Sigmund Freud, died at her home in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday. She was 78 years old.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 10 (AP) A Federal judge said today that Rhode Island's maximum-security prison "presents an imminent public health, fire and safety hazard" and ordered the prison closed within a year.

ALBANY, Aug. 10 Loan agreements, apartment leases and other consumer contracts will have to be written in clear, understandable language beginning next June under the provisions of a bill signed today by Governor Carey.

PANAMA, Aug. 10 The United States and Panama announced today that they had reached "agreement in principle" on "the basic elements" of a new treaty that will call for transfer of the Panama Canal and the Canal Zone to Panamanian control by the year 2000.

MIAMI, Aug. 10 (AP) Two former Miami Dolphins players today were sentenced to a year in jail for selling cocaine, but were left some hope of returning to pro football once they were free.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10 State and Federal firefighters expressed cautious optimism today about controlling the big fires plaguing California and began to turn their attention to the problems that follow such natural disasters.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 10 (AP) Jimmy Connors, almost toying with an outclassed Matt Mitchell, scored repeatedly with his patented back to-thenet overhead slam tonight and crushed the defending National Collegiate champion, 6-2, 6-0, in the second round of the $160,000 United States claycourt tennis tournament.

The usually quiet futures markets in lumber and plywood broke out yesterday with a number of daily limit advances. Brokers said the price gains reflected the widespread forest fires in California.

Bond prices, behaving like a roller coaster, dropped and climbed yesterday, closing very little changed from their Tuesday levels as dealers and investors tried to figure out whether the Federal Reserve was in the process of nudging short-term interest rates upward.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 10 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, at the end of his Middle East mission, said today that although Israel and the Arabs seemed to want peace, wide gaps had to be bridged before a Geneva conference could be convened.

DETROIT, Aug. 10 (AP) A magazine says that the Ford Motor Company sold Pinto cars for six years even though company officials knew that the car's fuel tank could easily rupture in rear-end crashes and cause fires.

CHARLESTON, W.Va., Aug.10 (AP) Striking coal miners in southern West Virginia refused to join a back-to-work movement today, voting not to return to the mines.

MIAMI, Aug. 10 (AP) Gen. George Churchill Kenney, who served as Gen. Douglas MacArthur's air commander in the Pacific in World War II, died yesterday of an apparent heart attack. He was 88 years old and lived at Bay Harbor Islands, a community near here.

The Rev. William Sloane Coffin, former chaplain of Yale, has been nominated as senior minister of the Riverside Church on Morningside Heights. The nomination will be presented to the congregation at a special meeting this Sunday. It is expected to be approved.

Members of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association have voted 8,361 to 3,706 to accept a new two-year contract that will provide pay increases of about $1,200, improved duty charts and a gradual phase-in of one-man police cars.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) The United States has exchanged information about political dissidents with foreign governments and may do so in the future in an effort to check terrorism, the State Department reported today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) The legal defense of Nazis by the American Civil Liberties Union has set off a wave of resignations among members of the A.C.L.U., an official of the organization says.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation yesterday reported declines of 17.2 percent in net income for the second quarter and 3.5 percent for the first half, following a large extraordinary gain that swelled the 1976 results.

MONTREAL, Aug. 10 A flurry of borrowing in various parts of the world in the last few weeks by Hydro-Quebec has apparently demonstrated that Quebec's big public utility has not lost its attraction in money markets in spite of the various uncertainties facing the province.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 10 (AP) The Minnesota Department of Public Welfare said today that it would continue to reimburse welfare recipients for elective abortions.

For the last two weeks it has been possible to trade put options in the shares of 25 different companies, and to all appearances the new vehicle is on its way to becoming almost as popular as calls.

HAVANA, Aug. 10 Fidel Castro, a relentless host who for two days led Senator Frank Church of Idaho on a nonstop convivial tour of Cuban social progress under his revolution, settled down this evening with the Idaho Democrat for a discussion of Cuba's economic problems.

THE NEW YORK Philharmonic's second week of parks concerts, which got under way Tuesday night in Central Park's Sheep Meadow (with repeats last night in the Bronx, tomorrow at Eisenhower Park in Nassau County and Saturday at Crocheron Park in Queens, (all at 8:30 P.M.), was supposed to have been led by Sarah Caldwell.

Paint, over the centuries, has been the poor man's medium for fancy decoration, as well as the rich man's status symbol. The many approaches to paint as a decorative element on American furniture, from the end of the 17th century to the present, is the theme of a current show that ranges from small boxes to large cupboards.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 10 (Reuters) Two missionaries were shot dead by black nationalist guerrillas who attacked a Roman Catholic mission station in southwestern Rhodesia, a Rhodesian Government spokesman said today.

China's foreign trade, which recently has declined, can be expected to expand in coming years because of a "more pragmatic stance" on the need for foreign technology ana equipment by the new Government of Premier Hua Kuo-feng, according to a study by the United States Department of Commerce.
"I've never liked opera, but this is all right," said Joanne Moore, a secretary who spent yesterday's lunch hour watching an outdoor performance by the Harlem Opera Society.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 The Labor Department is preparing regulations to require Federal contractors to set goals and timetables for hiring women for bricklaying, carpentry and other construction jobs, much as they do now for blacks and members of other minority groups.

The Yankees, who have endured enough of their own problems this season, returned to the friendly surroundings of Yankee Stadium last night and immediately dropped some additional problems on the heads of the Oakland A's, especially Vida Blue.

CAPE TOWN, Aug. 10 (Reuters) Tear gas mingled with the smoke from smouldering shanties today as bulldozers and policemen destroyed an illegal black squatter camp near here and evicted its inhabitants.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 10 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, at the end of his Middle East mission, said today that al- though Israel and the Arabs seemed to want peace, wide gaps had to be bridged before a Geneva conference could be con- vened.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 The Securities and Exchange Commission is pursuing an inquiry into the securities activities of a bank that Bert Lance headed in Georgia, sources close to the commission inquiry said today.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 10 John McVay today pointed a finger toward the skies, as if trying to catch a falling quarterback, and explained the Giants' search for a passer.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 10 Queen Elizabeth II began her Silver Jubilee visit to Northern Ireland today in a setting of bucolic beauty that contrasted sharply with the battle-scarred, heavily guarded streets of Belfast.
GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Aug. 10 Andrew Young broke away from his talks with Guyanese leaders late last night for a meeting with Joshua Nkomo, the black Rhodesian nationalist leader.
BETHESDA, Md., Aug. 10 Federal medical researchers reported today the first successful use of an antivirus drug against a disease that is usually fatal.

EVERY WORLD-CLASS symphony orchestra has its own identifiable personality and characteristic tone of voice, which conductors quickly learn to exploit. The velvety strings of the Philadelphia, for instance, becamt a cliche of musical commentary under Leopold Stokowiski, and the chamber-music sonorities of the Cleveland became a benchmark of that orchestra under George Szell.

MID-AUGUST is when gardeners pay for corners cut in past months. Nowhere is this more true than in city gardens, where the midsummer heat, particularly this year, is apt to have joined forces with vacation-induced neglect to wreak havoc with the greenery. But a little puttering will set things right and raise a splendid show for a couple of months yet, before cold weather drives you and the plants in doors.

In an unusual three-page letter to village residents, Mayor Dominick M. Minerva of Valley Stream, L.I., has sought to assuage widespread anguish touched off in parts of western Nassau County by the comment of a Federal judge who, in hearing a New York City school-integration case, said that the county line between Queens and Nassau was "a coincidence of high political irrelevancy."

LONDON, Aug. 10 Just as the longsuffering British people find themselves suddenly feasting on good economic news, the Government launched a major drive today to persuade them that only continued wage restraint could keep them healthy.
Glamour stocks shared honors with blue chips yesterday as the market, shedding its recent sluggish air, produced a sharp rally late in the season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) The Federal Energy Administrator, John F.O'Leary, said today that a proposed pipeline from California to Texas could transport Alaskan oil cheaply and efficiently to Eastern and Midwestern states. However, he stopped short of telling a House energy subcommittee that he endorsed the terminal planned for the Port of Long Beach in California.

PANAMA, Aug. 10 Seventy-four years after the United States sponsored Panama's independence in exchange for permission to build a canal across the isthmus, Panama is still a ccuntry trying to become a nation.

Uncontrolled fires burned out the homes of citizens in Dayton while striking firemen watched from a picket line. The horror of that image, with the firefighters holding back except where lives are directly threatened, is enough to turn the firmest friend of unionism into a raging foe. It also revives the hard question of which public employees, if any, should have the right to strike.

For allowing the bat to leave his hands and sail in the direction of a Cincinnati pitcher in a game last week Frank Taveras has been suspended for five games and fined an undisclosed sum by the National League.

Gilbert Kalish is no newcomer to Ives. Mr. Kalish's performance of the "Concord" Sonata, while not a pathbreaking effort by any means, shows that his Ivesian sympathies have not diminished over the years.

A French woman who died in New York recently has left $300 to the city as a way of saying thanks for her treatment in the United States, Finance Commissioner Harry Tishelman said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) Law firms that do $250,000 or more in annual business are subject to union organizing efforts and other matters under the jurisdiction of the National Labor Relations Board, the board ruled today.
LA PAZ, Bolivia Peru's erratic economic policy has thrown the Andean Common Market into a new crisis over failure to reach agreement on an integrated automotive industry program.

In an apparent effort to compel Sunshine Mining Company to hasten a decision on its takeover offer, the Great Western United Corporation of Denver yesterday reduced its bid for 2 million shares of Sunshine to $14.75 a share from $15.75.

The Boston Red Sox, rallying for three runs in the eighth inning on a two-run, pinch-hit homes by Bernie Carbo and Carl Yastrzemski's runproducing single, beat the California Angels, 11-10, and extended their winning streak to 11 games last night in Fenway Park.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) As a precaution, all whipped butter manufactured at the Sugar Creek plant of the Beatrice Food Company in Louisville, Ky., has bee recalled, the company said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 The American Bar Association adopted tonight a 50-page code of guidelines for lawyers who wish to take advantage of their new freedom to advertise their services to the public.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 The chairman of the beleaguered House ethics committee, Representative John J. Flynt Jr., has begun a secret effort to question Park Tong Sun, considered to be a vital witness in the investigation of the Korean scandal here, Congressional sources disclosed today.

Dr. Isidore Daichman, former director of obstetrics and gynecology at the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn died Monday in his summer home in Fort Salonga, L.I., after a brief illness. Dr. Daichman, who also had a residence at 10 Plaza Street, Brooklyn, retired in 1975 and was 76 years old.

The Municipal Assistance Corporation announced plans yesterday to increase the size of a forthcoming public bond offering from $75 million to $190 million. The offering is part of a proposed refinancing of $2.5 billion in city and M.A.C. debt held by the city's sinking funds and major banks and pension funds.
Mayor Beame ordered the contract for the city's new outside auditors to be delayed after they gave an opinion that he was balancing his budget with gimmicks, according to city officials.
Russell A. Bufalino, the reputed Mafia leader of northeastern Pennsylvania, was convicted yesterday of extortion involving efforts to collect $25,000 owed to a New York jeweler.

WEST BERLIN, Aug. 10 Concern over mounting unemployment and a persistently sluggish economy is apparently forcing the West German Government to apply more direct stimulatory measures, mainly increased Government spending.
SYBARITES who dream of luxurious bathrooms would envy the Florida woman who had a bath and shower built outdoors on a patio, surrounded by plants and flowers, with an area for sunbathing.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) Retail sales increased by five-tenths of 1 percent in July on technical adjustments to end three consecutive months of decline, the Department of Commerce reported today.

MIZ LILLIAN,"78-year-old mother of President Carter, will receive the Covenant of Peace Award from the Synagogue Council of America. Mrs. Carter will be the first woman to receive the award for Americans "making outstanding contributions to the cause of peace." She will be honored in New York Sept. 25. Previous recipients of the award were John F. Kennedy, Martin Luther King Jr. and Chief Justice Earl Warren.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 11--Richard J. Herrin, 23-year-old graduate of Yale University, was indicted today on a second-degree murder charge in the hammer slaying of Bonnie Jean Garland, his for-mar girlfriend. He was released on $50,-000 bail.

LONDON, Aug. 11-Jimmy Carter's carefully cultivated identification with the common man suffered a blue-blooded setback today as a leading directody of British mobility said that the President not only was a descendant of the family that produced the first American milllonaire but was also related to both George Washington and the Queen of England.

WASHINGTON, Aug.11--Ralph Nader's consumer organization charged today that a quirk in the Medicare law had had the effect of having the Federal Government authorize and in part subsidize enormous incomes for 6,500 doctors.

The Connecticut General Insurance Corporation, the nation's third-largest publicly owned insurance enterprise, after Aetna and Travelers, yesterday reported increases of 32.6 percent in second-quarter net income and 33.6 percent in its half-year net.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 11 (AP)-Judge William F. Thetford of Circuit Court, who prosecuted the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and his followers in connection with the 1955 Montgomery bus boycott, died at a local hospital today. He was 64 years old.

Hans J. Hoffman, a retired shore manufacturer, died suddenly Tuesday in Belle-vue Hospital at the age of 67. He had homes at 520 Park Avenue, and in Little-ton, N.H., where he was the co-founder of Connors Hoffmann Inc., shoe manufacturers.

DETROIT. Aug. 11-American auto plants are scheduled to build 98,484 cars this week, off 8 percent from 107,058 last week and 3 percent below the 101,496 cars produced in the corresponding week a year ago, according to Ward's automotive reports.
