The Penn Central Transportation Company, languishing in bankruptcy since June 1970 and unable to pay its debts, now wants to pay its back taxes. But it's not easy, the company is discovering.

The Rev. Billy Graham, attempting to quell any doubt about the fiscal integrity of his evangelistic organization, has issued a six-page statement defending a controversial $23 million fund that the vast majority of his supporters knew nothing about until recently.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 12 The space shuttle Enterprise, the first of a fleet of re-usable vehicles for making space travel a more workaday experience, passed its first flight test today by making a smooth glide landing on a dry lake bed in the Mojave Desert.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 12 Prime Minister Menahem Begin's administration has made a basic, if informal, alliance with the Lebanese Christians that may lead to an important policy divergence with the United States, according to an authoritative Israeli source.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 12 (AP) Stung by a first-set loss, the top-seeded Jimmy Connors withstood a strong challenge by Dick Stockton tonight and won a three-hour quarterfinal match, 2-6, 6-4, 10-8, in the 67th United States clay court tennis championships.

Lawsuits have been a potent weapon in the struggle for civil rights, from opening the voting booth for all to insuring fair hiring practices and equal educational opportunity. J. Ray McDermott Company, a dark horse in the race to acquire control of the Babcock Wilcox Company, has suddenly come to life with a tentative bid of $55 a share for an additional 35 percent of Babcock Wilcox stock. McDermott already owns 9.9 percent of Babcock's shares.

WASHINGTON A doctor of physical chemistry at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia has devised a reversible, nonsurgical method of birth control. A man who the police said had robbed about 15 banks since April 1976, was arrested yesterday outside a Greenwich Village bank that had just been robbed of $5,870.

The American Bridge Association, which has a primarily black membership, regularly welcomes nonmembers at its tournaments. A result of this hospitable policy was that a major title at the association's 44th Summer Nationals in Los Angeles this week was won by a visiting sextet.

A Cabinet committee meets this week to decide whether the United States will leave the International Labor Organization. Departure would give some moral satisfaction to some Americans. But it would be a mistake.

Travelers in Italy (and people in this country who have Italian money stashed away in a drawer) should examine their 5,000-lira (about $6) bills very carefully. There are two kinds of 5,000-lira notes, both the same size, both light green on one side, blue on the other, but one of the two has ceased to be legal tender. And Italian officials say that there's still an enormous number of this version in circulation.

IN Chinese restaurants, the menus go on for pages. At Dynasty in Roslyn, the menu goes on for menus. Upon being seated, you are handed a small black folder containing eight attractive minimenus: cocktails and wines, appetizers and soups, seafood, poultry, beef and pork, chop suey and chow mein, low-calorie and vegetarian, desserts. Each is a different color, decorated with an example of Chinese ink-brush drawing. It's an interesting and pleasant presentation.

POMONA MEMBERS of the Golden Knights, the United States Army's parachute demonstration team, will fall from the skies over Pomona on Wednesday afternoon to inaugurate the first transportation fair to be held in New Jersey. ATHENS--When the Greek junta crumbled during the Cyprus crisis three years ago, Constantine Caramanlis returned from exile and took control of a highly volatile situation. Within a few months he had pulled the country back from the edge of war, held elections, drafted a new constitution and conducted a referendum that ended a disabling dispute over the monarchy.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14--Pamela Gray was having a fantastic, fabulous time, although every time she swung around on the dance floor, the flowers pinned to her shoulder bag would whirl and hit someone, usually in some strategic spot. But a swat with a handbag is minor league, when one considers that some of the colony's best and near best were being stepped on, kicked in the shins, and cracked in the elbows.
LONDON, Aug. 14--Russian bankers, it seems, are no different from their gimlet-eyed capitalist counterparts, the ones so prominent in Soviet propaganda.

"I'm starting to move, I'm dancing!" an exuberant Billie Jean King said yesterday after working out with the New York Apples in preparation for tonight's opening-round World Team Tennis playoff match against the Indiana Loves in Felt Forum.

HOLTSVILLE, L.I. Cruz Albert and Esperanza Negron lived for many years in a Brooklyn apartment, working hard and saving their money. On June 4, 1976, they moved into their first house, a four-bedroom, cedar-shingled structure large enough for them, their daughter and son-in-law and their two grandchildren.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 The Central Intelligence Agency sponsored a six-year search for a "knockout" drug during which scientists were supposed to analyze spinal and other vital fluids from comatose and delirious patients hospitalized with terminal cancer, liver failure, uremia and severe infections, newly declassified records show.

DETROIT, Aug. 15 The General Motors Corporation, in an effort to reduce the number of unhappy car buyers, said today its 1978 model cars and light trucks would be covered by a new, expanded and simplified warranty.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) Leon Jaworski, warning against jumping to conclusions, took charge today of the House investigation into alleged South Korean influence-buying in Congress.

WASHINGTON, Aug. P5 (UPI) Environmental groups applaud the United States tuna fleet, which this season reduced accidental killing of porpoises by almost 500 per cent. But the industry is not exactly taking a bow, according to an Environmental Defense Fund lawyer, William Butler.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, calling the trans-Alaska oil pipeline a pipeline to nowhere, today urged President Carter to approve an overland route through Canada to bring Alaskan natural gas to the Middle West.

YONKERS, Aug. 15 A chance telephone encounter last Tuesday between a New York City detective and a police dispatcher here who is the daughter of Sam Carr believed to be the "Sam" in "Son of Sam" appears to have played the pivotal role in the search that led to the arrest the following day of David R. Berkowitz as the so-called .44-caliber killer.

DETROIT, Aug. 15 (AP) The pace of domestic new-car sales in early August matched the industry's record of 1976, although the American Motors Corporation today reported its lowest sales for a 10-day period in at least a decade.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 15 The Giants, who had been down to "zero" fullbacks, as Coach John McVay said yesterday, added two today J. J. Jennings and Larry Csonka.

LOS ANGELES A group of Los Angeles airline stewardnesses, alarmed by a rising number of assaults on flight attendants, have formed a self-defense organization whose members hope eventually to alert most of the nation's 38,000 stewardesses about would-be rapists.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 15 Amnesty International said today that there had been widespread abduction, torture and killing of peasants by the National Guard in Nicaragua last year, although church and diplomatic sources there said the human fights situation had improved in recent months.

MULHOUSE, France, Aug. 10 Fritz and Hans Schlumpf arrived in this Alsatian town on the eve of World War II, built a textile factory that prospered under the German Occupation and emerged in the postwar era as the largest woolen textile producers in Alsace.
Hugo Perls, an art dealer who was well known in New York and abroad, died Sunday in New York Hospital. He lived at 128 Central Park South. He was 91 years old. He retired several years ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 Senator Edward M. Kennedy called today for the ending of diplomatic relations with Taiwan to pave the way for full-scale ties with China.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) Joint United States and European production of the F-16 lightweight fighter may drive the price above the agreed ceiling of $6.09 million a plane and this could have a "grave political impact," the General Accounting Office said today.

The newest statistics on those arrested during the blackout last month show that judges and prosecutors who were under pressure to handle their cases strictly did, in fact, treat suspects more severely than they treat those seized normally for similar crimes.
LONDON, Aug. 15 The H. J. Heinz Company has come under 57 varieties of pressure to cancel a wage increase granted workers far in excess of the Government's target for avoiding a new wage explosion.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 (AP) Vestiges of Hurricane Doreen lashed the southern California deserts with rain and 60-mile-an-hour winds today, flooding four highways and washing away a large section of Interstate 15, the major artery linking Los Angeles and Las Vegas.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 15 The House of Representatives worked late today as it edged toward reluctant passage of a state budget that would end Pennyslvania's funding crisis.

DAWSON, Ga. The Rev. M.W. Merritt, pastor of the Sardis Baptist Church here, took the witness stand the other day during pretrial hearings in the case of the "Dawson Five." He told how a local pharmacist had recently refused to allow the Reverend Mr. Merritt's 5-year-old daughter to use the toilet in a downtown drug store.
GARLAND, Tex., Aug. 15 (AP) Clifford Wells, the former Tulane basketball coach, died at his home early today of an apparent heart attack. He was 81 years old.
LONDON, Aug. 15 Members of the Socialist Workers' Party clashed with the police in Birmingham tonight as they tried to break up a meeting of the rightwing National Front.

SAN ANTONIO, Aug. 15 (AP) A Dallas lawyer testified today that T. O. Gravitt, a former executive of Southwestern Bell, told him a few days before he committed suicide that company employees had been used as "pimps" to secure women for high officials of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

First-half job placements for advertising and marketing people rose 25 percent over the year-ago period, according to the tabulation of its results made by Judd-Falk Inc., an executive recruitment concern that specializes in these fields.

Lou Walters, one of the nation's leading, supper-club entrepreneurs in the 1940's and 50's, owner and operator of the famed Latin Quarter in midtown Manhattan, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Miami. He was 81 years old.

YONKERS, Aug. 15 By the end of the third race at Yorkers Raceway tonight, Tim Rooney, the track president, knew that the $100,000 facelift at the track, the darkness at the New Jersey Meadowlands or his old rule of thumb was working.
PARIS Almost every morning, lovers of classical music here have switched on their radios to hear Yehudi Menuhin's violin strings soar through the "Adelaide" Concerto.

New works by film makers from France, Italy, West Germany, Algeria and the United States, as well as an animation festival and a retrospective of 10 important American films will be seen at the 15th New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center, from Sept. 23 to Oct. 9, it was announced yesterday by Martin E. Segal, president of the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

An off-duty policeman from the Englewood, N.J., force shot and slightly wounded a Port of Authority of New York and New Jersey police officer outside St. Clare's Hospital in midtown Manhattan Sunday night, the police said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) President Carter today nominated ambassadors to Honduras, Burma and the Bahamas. Also announced were selections of the second ranking officials at the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and the National Science Foundation and the new head of the Agriculture Department's Agricultural Marketing Service.

MIAMI, Aug. 15 (AP) Federal and state agents frustrated the plans of Cuban exiles to raid their former homeland today, seizing three boats, an antitank cannon and other weapons, a federal spokesman said.

Gimbel Brothers Inc., which is continuing its program of phasing out lowmargin, hard goods lines in its department stores, reported yesterday that it had a loss of $2.2 million in the third fiscal quarter ended July 2. In the corresponding period last year the loss was $718,000.

The New York Stock Exchange fined Hornblower Weeks Noyes Trask Inc. $5,000 yesterday for alleged short-tendering violations during the tender offer for Marcor Inc. by the Mobil Oil Corporation in August 1974.

After a hard day at the office and an evening making campaign speeches, Mayor Beame often comes home to Gracie Mansion to find a living room full of visitors munching his potato chips, sipping diet soda and chewing over politics.

Jimmy's Music World, a chain of discount record stores that touched off a price war when it opened in New York City in 1974, has filed bankruptcy proceedings in Federal Court along with its parent company, Sutton Distributors of Rahway, N. J.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) The Church of Scientology filed today a $1 million damage suit against the Federal Bureau of Investigation and asked that it be protected against any more search and seizures by the agency.

C. A. Brenninckmeyer, the large Netherlands-based holding company, which in 1962 bought the Ohrbach's stores, has reportedly made a bid of $160 million to purchase the Miller-Wohl Company, a chain of 142 women's apparel shops, mainly in the Middle West and South.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 Conservatives will open a campaign against approval of the new Panama Canal Treaty next Sunday with newspaper advertisements aimed at Southern Democratic Senators and a television appearance by the current leader of their fight, Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina.

A court order that barred Federal community-development funds last year for several relatively affluent suburbs of Hartford was overturned yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

PINEHURST, N.C., Aug. 15 (AP) Cathy Reynolds of Springfield, Mo., and Noreen Uihlein of Hershey, Pa., tied for medalist honors today, the opening day of the Women's Trans National golf championship. Each shot a 73 at the Mid Pines Country Club.
LONDON, Aug. 15 (AP) An Associated Press correspondent who was held in prison for a month in the Central African Empire arrived here late today after his release.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 15 (Reuters) Somalia said today that the three-weekold war on its borders had spilled into Somali territory, and President Mohamed Siad Barre warned his people to prepare for an invasion by Ethiopia.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 15 (AP) A cache of irreplaceable historical documents, including some bearing George Washington's signature, is missing and presumed stolen from his Revolutionary War headquarters here, the site curator says.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 Thirdseeded Tracy Austin of Rolling Hills, Calif., and Kathy Jordan, seeded 14th, from King of Prussia, Pa., each showed adept volley work in gaining the final of the United States girls 18-and-under tennis championship today. The tour ney is being played on the grass courts of the Philadelphia Cricket Club.
GENEVA, Aug. 15 (Reuters) Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union took the lead today in his World Championship Candidate's Match with Lajos Portisch of Hungary with a 40-move victory in the 13th game.

Yielding to a bid of $55 a share, the directors of Babcock Wilcox have recommended to its shareholders that they accept the offer of J. Ray McDermott Company of New Orleans to buy virtual control of B. W.

Joseph J. Pinola, 52 years old, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the Western Bancorporation, Los Angeles, the nation's 10thlargest bank holding company, effective Jan. 1. He is now president and chief operating officer of the United California Bank, Western's largest affiliate.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 14 Birmingham relived part of its past last week when a state grand jury began taking testimony on a series of racially motivated bombings of the 1960's, including the 1963 dynamiting of a church that killed four young girls attending Sunday School.

WASHINGTON (AP) The United States Civil Rights Commission said today that television was marked by racial and sexual stereotyping and that the Federal Communications Commission appeared unwilling to push hard to end such discrimination.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) Adm. Stansfield Turner, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, has told Congress that the United States is "well ahead" of the Soviet Union in military technology while China is 15 to 20 years behind the Russians.

FRANKLIN LAKES, Aug. 15 For five years, Don Roehrs, a prize-winning landscape architect, has been fighting the Bergen County government and the Town Council over the fate of greenery in his front yard, a hedgerow, laurel, rhododendron bushes and three pines that date to near the turn of the century.

Many key commodity futures fell to contract lows yesterday as prices retreated on a broad front, much to the gain of holders of short positions in the market.

HAVANA It looked like a scene from "Jaws." Hundreds of bathers, mostly skinny young kids, broke from the surf at Santa Maria Beach in a frenzy of churning legs and shrieks, clawing their way out of the water to reach the hot sand and the tall bearded figure in military fatigues and cap standing there with another man.

The Federal Reserve continued yesterday to encourage short-term interest rates to rise, and the Treasury incurred the highest rates since late 1975 as it sold $5.7 billion of bills at its weekly auction.

BRICK TOWNSHIP, N.J., Aug. 15 (UPI) An electrical storm yesterday killed a motorist and knocked out power in several shore communities.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 15 (UPI) A teen-age newspaper boy was critically wounded today by a young sniper who stationed himself on the roof of an abandoned building. The sniper then shot a man who tried to aid the boy, the police said.

TRENTON, Aug. 15 The president of Lawn King Inc., Joseph Sandler, was sentenced today to six months in jail and fined $43,120, the equivalent of his annual salary, for criminal violation of New Jersey's antitrust laws. It was the first conviction of its kind in the state.
Billy Graham, the evangelist, has accepted an invitation to visit Hungary from Sept. 3 to 10 for religious meetings. He is the first Western religious leader invited by Hungary since World War II.
OBERAMMERGAU, West Germany, Aug. 15 (UPI) It is mankind's sins and not the Jews that kill Christ in a new version of the centuries-old Oberammergau passion play that opened Saturday night.

ALBANY, Aug. 15 (UPI) Governor Carey has designated Msgr. James Healy of Buffalo as chairman of the State Mediation Board, it was announced today.

NASHVILLE, Aug. 15 A Congressional subcommittee investigating an international uranium cartel, which says it has disbanded, failed today in its efforts to determine what impact the price-fixing plan has had upon domestic electricity prices.

LONDON, Aug. 15 The Amnesty investigators were Kurt Madlener, Director of the Department of Hispanoamerican Penal Law of the Max Planck Institute in West Germany and Michael McClintock of Amnesty's research staff here.

TOKYO, Aug. 15 These are the days for the dead in Japan. Through religious and historic coincidence, the times for remembering deceased ancestors and those who died in Japan's most recent battles fall together in the middle of August. The accompanying mixture of prayers and tears and festivals and dances makes for some bittersweet midsummer moments in this homogeneous nation, which,although it is the size of California, often seems more like a giant small town.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 15 The jury in the Federal corruption trial of Gov. TIJUANA, Mexico, Aug. 15 (AP) The United States Export-Import Bank may lend Mexico up to $400 million of the $1.2 billion it needs to build a pipeline to carry natural gas from Mexico to the United States, according to the United States Ambassador to Mexico.

New York City said yesterday that it had hired 2,000 workers to clean up debris from looting during last month's blackout.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 15 As any gambler can tell you, when it comes to losing streaks, you either go broke or finally win one. Against the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, the Mets, losers of six games in a row, went for broke by using a pitcher who had also lost six games in a row to the Cards.

Katherine Mather McLean, a former president of the Women's Board of Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, died yesterday of cancer in Coatesville Hospital, Coatesville, Pa. She was 64 years old.

WALNUT CREEK Calif., Aug. 15 (AP) Patients at a hospital here who listen to the taped voice of a comforting doctor the night before an operation require less medication and recover more quickly, officials report.

Nixon and Attorney General Griffin B. Beli, asking that the pardon granted to Mr. Nixon in September 1974 be declared null and void.
LONDON, Aug. 15 (AP) The dollar rose in very quiet dealing today, while the price of gold fell.

Berkowitz, the accused .44-caliber killer, to two newspapers asked a Criminal Court judge yesterday to relieve him as Mr. Berkowitz's attorney. But the judge told him to take his request to State Supreme Court, where the murder case is now being heard.

PHILDELPHIA, Aug. 15 As the Philadelphia Company performs classical theater in the southeast corner of the City Hall courtyard these steamy summer nights, the play's the thing, but not the whole thing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) The women in the Carter Administration who spoke out against the President's opposition to using Federal funding for abortions were praised today by 27 women's and public interest groups.

Commander Cody and the Lost Planet Airmen formed one of the great bar bands and cult bands of recent years. They had a passel of colorful, vibrant personalities, and they could knock out a set of boogie-woogie, rhythm-and-blues, rockabilly and novelty numbers that would have a crowd cheering deliriously. But the same hippie fervor that informed their performances undermined their discipline, and they were never able to make successful records.

The company will present seven premieres, including its first full-length ballet, "Romeo and Juliet," by Oscar Araiz. The ballet will first be performed at a gala benefit Oct. 12, the night preceding the company's official opening.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16 The America's Cup yachting competition today presented a tripleheader, three contests, from which Ted Turner emerged as one hero and Pelle Petterson and his gallant Swedes as 11 more. Also there was one large argument.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 A woman whose husband died of lung cancer after 18 months of treatment with laetrile has filed a $2.5 million suit against the doctor who administered the drug.

Dr. John G. Lexa, an adjunct associate professor of comparative constitutional law at New York University, died Sunday in his home, 74-19 43d Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens, after suffering a heart attack. He was 62 years old.

ALBANY, Aug. 16 Governor Carey today announced his veto of a bill that would have increased penalties for crimes against the elderly or disabled. He asserted that its provisions were "inconsistent" with the state's criminal laws and that it "would not be effective in achieving its stated goals."

If you believe what happened in Yankee Stadium last night, you would believe almost anything but here goes: The Yankees scored four runs in the eighth inning to grab a 9-4 lead, blew it in the top of the ninth when the Chicago White Sox scored six times, then won it by 11-10 in the bottom of the ninth on a home run by Chris Chambliss.
It has been a good year for the Bally Manufacturing Corporation of Chicago: New Jersey legalized casino gambling and New York City lifted a 35-year ban on pinball machines.
WASHINGTON Every city has its own conceits. New York's is that it is incurably romantic. Washington's is that it is inexpressibly important. Chicago's is that it is a big city.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Administration officials said today that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance during his trip to China next week would explore with Peking's leaders the possibility of finding a formula that would allow the United States to establish formal relations with China while being assured that Taiwan would not have to fear an armed attack from the mainland.

BRUNSWICK, GA. "THERE was simply no work for black people down here during the Depression years except a little share-crop ping," Dorothy Cook English said, "so many of us left for the North. There was just no way to improve your life down here at that time."
ROME, Aug. 16 Sorrow, skepticism and anger marked a demonstration here today to protest the escape of a convicted Nazi war criminal, Col. Herbert Kappler, from a Rome military prison Sunday night.
David E. Schimmel, a director and former president of the Dayco Corporation, plastics manufacturers of Dayton, Ohio, died Saturday an West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 70 years old.

Every player should experiment from time to time with formations foreign to his style for the sake of gaining broader experience and introducing freshness into his play. But a semifinal Candidate's Match is hardly the place for such an edifying exercise, as a former world champion, Boris Spassky, discovered in the eighth game of his series with the Hungarian grandmaster Lajos Portisch in Geneva.

Willis Reed, a former All-Star center, will make his National Basketball Association coaching debut with the New York Knicks on the first night of the 1977-78 campaign, according to the N.B.A. schedule released yesterday.
MADRID, Spain, Aug. 16 (UPI) The Government imposed heavy fines today on leaders of the bakery industry, arrested four of them and warned that army bakers might take over the ovens.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16, (AP) The White House says it has asked the Justice Department to determine whether President Carter has the authority to review the case of Antoinette Slovik, widow of the only American soldier shot for desertion since the Civil War.

New York State's Crime Victims Compensation Board yesterday notified lawyers for David R. Berkowitz that "any moneys owing" him or his representatives "as a result of crimes he is accused of committing" must go to his victims if he is convicted in the so-called .44-caliber shootings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 The Administration is anxious for early ratification of the Panama treaty, but Democratic leaders in the Senate are recommending that the formal debate be postponed until next January or February.

DETROIT, Aug. 16 (UPI) The Ford Motor Company announced today the recall of 741,000 1976 and 1977 model standard-size Fords and Mercurys and 1977 model Lincolns that may have a safely defect in the engine-cooling fan assemblies.
The nation's coal industry, readying itself to meet sharply rising demand, has hung up a giant-sized "Help Wanted" sign.
ANDERSON, Ind., Aug. 16 (UPI) Twenty factories ceased production yesterday and remained closed today in a strike by United Auto Workers Local 662 against Delco-Remy.

VAIL, Colo., Aug. 16 Former President Gerald R. Ford today threw his support behind the Panama Canal agreement announced by the Carter Administration. Mr. Food labeled the pact "an important step forward" and called for prompt Senate approval.

WHEN it comes to what might be called cooking a la minute, the virtues of ground meat are immediately apparent. Chief among them is their cooking nature. Toss a quarter-pound of first-quality ground beef on a hot grill or into a lightly oiled (or even unoiled) skillet, a touch of salt, a sprinkilng of pepper and a dollop of butter and the results are almost foolproof.
The nation's coal industry, readying itself to meet sharply rising demand, has hung up a giant-sized "Help Wanted" sign.
ANDERSON, Ind., Aug. 16 (UPI) Twenty factories ceased production yesterday and remained closed today in a strike by United Auto Workers Local 662 against Delco-Remy.

Abe Beame is "tough." Bella Abzug is a "fighter." Mario Cuomo is "angry." Edward I. Koch is "competent." Three other Democratic mayoral candidates are financially strapped, so they have not so far been able to use television advertising to promote their personal and poltical assets.

NEWPORT, R.I. Aug. 17 What will it take for one of the three United States yachts, Courageous, Enterprise or Independence, to be chosen soon as the defender of the America's Cup next month against the foreign challenger? The vague requirement is about a dozen victories in these final selection trials, which got under way yesterday, and Courageous chalked up her third victory today. The others have none.

Twenty-five policemen, including Deputy Inspector Timothy J. Dowd, commander of the special homicide task force set up to catch the 44-caliber killer, will be promoted for their work on the "Son of Sam" case.

The conventional wisdom is that recruitment by corporations on college campuses will increase in the next academic year as a result of a step-up in business activity. A rise in recruitment advertising would be likely to accompany this increase, according to the same conventional wise men.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 17 If Frank M. Johnson Jr., President Carter's choice to be director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has time in his prospective job to delve...

TRENTON, Aug. 17 Stanley C. VanNess, New Jersey's Public Advocate, called today for a "total moratorium" on the use of psychosurgery, such as frontal lobotomies of the brain, whether for corrective purposes or research.

These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fast-selling record.
Another cut in copper prices, this one a substantial 7.7 percent drop, was announced yesterday by Asarco Inc. and the Duval Corporation.

TWO OF AMERICA'S best young pianists joined forces for two of the greatest pieces of the duet literature Tuesday night in Avery Fisher Hall. Because the third soloist was the redoubtable American soprano Jessye Norman, the Mostly Mozart program received a sturdy assist from the New World.
"ANYTHING WORTH doing is worth doing to excess," says Clem Labine, a single-minded gentleman from Brooklyn, who on first meeting seems singularly free of obsessions.

NEWPORT, R.I. NEWPORT IS A great town for vicarious decorating thrills. Contrary to its exclusive image, it's one of the few great resort towns where you don't have to know anyone to get into the best houses. From Cornelius Vanderbilt's The Breakers to Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs's Rosecliff, where "The Great Gatsby" was filmed, the mansions are all open to the public for a few dollars a head from April to October.

THE THIRD and final week of the New York Philharmonic's concerts in the parks opened at the Sheep Meadow in Central Park on Tuesday night. The program announced for the concert, which was led by Erich Leinsdorf, consisted of three works that brought out an enormous audience Beethoven's Symphony No. 1, Haydn's Trumpet Concerto (with Gerard Schwarz as soloist) and Dvorak's "New World" Symphony.

PARIS WHO SAID the French had no eye for design? Surely, this does not hold true for the handful of citizens in Grenoble and Paris they have chosen to remain incognito who recently set fire to about 75 electricity lit, plastic and aluminum billboards designed and erected in the streets by the firm of Jean-Claude Decaux.

OTTAWA, Aug. 17 Canadian labor leaders, in a move bringing further uncertainty into this country's troubled economy, today rejected all the conditions proposed by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau for an early end to wage and price controls here.

DENVER, Aug. 17 (AP) The American National Cattlemen's Association says average retail beef prices in mid-August were vitually unchanged from the preceding month, but predicts they will start going up before too long.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) A coalition of union, civic and religious organizations announced today plans to sponsor a "Full Employment Week" Sept. 4 to 10.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 17 (AP) Harbor View Farm's Affirmed, ridden by Steve Cauthen, handed Bertram R. Firestone's Tilt Up his first defeat at Saratoga today when he scored by 2 lengths in the $37,150 Sanford. It was his fourth victory in five starts.

On the way to dinner with Grant Smith, deputy chief of mission at the United States Embassy in Bangui, capital of the Central African Empire, I stopped off first at my hotel. Smith stayed in his car outside waiting for me.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 Governor Carey announced today that he had signed a bill to phase out the effects of the New York City stock transfer tax over the next four years. The measure is intended to halt the drift of the securities industry from the city.

PARIS THE DEATH of Elvis Presley is being treated as a major event in Western Europe. Most newspapers splashed it across their front pages, and carried long obituaries and detailed accounts of highlights of his career. Radios in Brit ain, France, Italy and West Germany have been playing his top hits spanning a generation for more than 24 hours. Television programs are showing excerpts from his films and stage performances.

LONDON, Aug. 17 (AP) The Financial Times, London's leading financial newspaper, today failed to appear for the 11th consecutive day because of a labor dispute, and management announced it was locking out 232 union production workers and suspending their salaries.
ALBANY, Aug. 17 One of the bills Governor Carey said today that he had signed would allow the records of those arrested for marijuana violations to be wiped clean after three years.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (UP) The MidAmerica Commodity Exchange has agreed to pay a $50,000 penalty imposed by the Commodities Futures Trading Commission for failure to exercise "due diligence" in enforcing its own rules.

POMONA, Aug. 17 A Hollywood stunt pilot flipped his little DeHavilland Chipmunk upside down today and, hanging by his seatbelt and crabbing into the wind 20 feet off the ground, flashed between two green poles and cut red, white and blue crepe ribbons with his propeller to open Transfair '77.
The crime of stealing from stores. The epidemic of looting during last month's blackout may have been its most dramatic expression, but day in and day out, shoplifting eats away at merchants.

MOST of the characters in "Blood Tie" are expatriates not the wide-eyed, excited expatriate of the 20's, but the culture dropout of the 70's, someone who puts an ocean between himself and his past, who visits a foreign country and as a crasher enters a party. Traveling light, unburdened by a social role, this expatriate is a voyeur. He sees the life of the natives as theater or burlesque.

FAMILIES shopping for older homes in New York State may be able to get by with much lower down payments than in the past, thanks to revisions the Legislature has made in the rules governing private mortgage-guarantee insurance.

BONN, Aug. 17-Authorities confirmed today that Lieut. Col. Herbert Kappler, the 70-year-old Nazi war criminal whose escape from detention in a military hospital in Rome has caused tension between Italy and West Germany, was back in his native country for the first time since World War II.

The nearby deliveries of lumber and plywood futures advanced their daily price limits yesterday, with the more dis- tant months closing with strong gains. And all deliveries set contract highs as well.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 17 The Giants signed today two free agents Willie Spencer, a fullback, and Ken Helms, a rookie offensive lineman recently put on waivers by other National Football League team.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 President Carter, as expected, today nominated as the next director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation Frank M. Johnson Jr. of Alabama, a Federal district judge who was offered but refused the position eight months ago.
Beatrice Wiggs, a past president of the Queens chapter of the American Jewish Congress, died yesterday. She was 70 years old and lived at 425 East 58th Street in Manhattan.

Following are excerpts from the testimony of Mayor Beame before the Securities and Exchange Commission in New York City on Sept. 1, 1976. The questions were asked by Edward Boyle, an attorney for the S.E.C.:
President Carter's welfare-revision package would have given New York City $182 million last year toward the $471 million it spent, First Deputy Mayor Donald D. Kummerfeld said yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 17 (Reuters) Dozens of valuable paintings and frescoes were badly damaged today when rainwater poured through a roof at London's Victoria and Albert Museum. As freak rainstorms lashed central and southern England, part of the museum's roof, which was under repair, collapsed and water cascaded into two storerooms.

ANDREI SERBAN'S production of "Agamemnon" last spring at Lincoln Center perhaps revealed more about the Vivian Beaumont Theater than it did about Aeschylus. Exposing this theater to its rib cage and plunging his company into an abyss under the stage, Mr. Serban demonstrated that in the hands of an imaginative director such as himself, this white mastodon of a theater could have a future life.
The Soviet Union announced yesterday that its nuclear icebreaker Arktika had reached the North Pole, the first surface ship to break through the Arctic ice pack to the top of the world.

AT LAST the Carnegie Hill section of Manhattan has a shop pers' area in keeping with the elegant traditions of the neigh- borhood. This past year 10 new stores, offering everything from Victorian wicker to maize-meal soap, have opened on that stretch of Madison Avenue that runs from 86th Street to 93d Street. The area's fading shoe-repair shops and tired delicatessens are being replaced with lively, original boutiques.
Mayor Beame yesterday ordered the closing of Flushing Airport in Queens following a forced landing of a commercial plane on Monday in an empty lot nearby.
While scattered strength appeared in some glamour issues, the Dow Jones industrial and transportation indexes fell again yesterday to new lows for 1977.
KEARNY The Garden State Harmonica Club, 130 harmonica players ranging in age from 15 to 79, brings countless hours of pleasure to New Jersey listeners.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 17 (AP)-Ninety-seven fragmentation hand grenades, 26 sticks of dynamite and 17,000 rounds of ammunition were found at a dump today in the course of a Federal Bureau of Investigation inquiry into a radical antibusing group.

Secretary of State Vance leaves Sunday for Peking to initiate high-level contacts between the United States and China. He goes representing a President who is on record as wishing to "normalize" relations with the People's Republic, with its 800 million Chinese on the mainland, and at the same time not "abandon" the 17 million Chinese on the island of Taiwan commendable if seemingly contradictory objectives.

JERUSALEM From the strongest supporters of the Begin Government to its sharpest critics, Israelis are even more deeply worried over Israel's relations with the United States than its relations with the Arab states.

TOKYO, Aug. 17 The family of the late Nobel Prize-winning author Yasunari Kawabata has reached a compromise settlement with the publisher of a controversial "novel" allegedly detailing the reasons behind the author's suicide in 1972.

Crime, a subject that seems to permeate the New York City mayoral campaign, was addressed by two candidates yesterday Bella S. Abzug in a statement she read on the steps of the Criminal Court Building and Mayor Beame in a talk to old people who applauded, nodded and interjected murmurs of "right... right" when he called for touch tactics.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 17 After six days of deliberations, the jury in the Federal corruption case against Maryland Gov. Marvin Mandel and five co-defendants reported today that it was deadlocked.

Beatrice Straight, winner of the 1977 Academy Award for supporting actress for her performance in "Network," will return to the stage in a new production of Harold Pinter's "Old Times" at the Academy Festival Theater in Lake Forest, Ill. The production, which will open Sept. 1 for three weeks, will have as co-stars Irene Worth and Raul Julia, recently the leading actors of "The Cherry Orchard" at Lincoln Center.

The struggle for acceptance finally ended for Dr. Renee Richards yesterday when the United States Tennis Association approved her entry into the main draw for women's singles at the United States Open championships.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 17 (AP)-Assistant Secretary of State Terence Todman arrived here tonight after discussing human rights with Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, President of Paraguay.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP)-Despite a surgical effort to save the lives of Siamese twin sisters, one of the threemonth-old twins died Saturday of an infection, the Children's Hospital National Medical Center said today. The center said the surviving twin was in "stable condition."

A Federal Judge ruled yesterday that the 17 month ban on Concorde flights using Kennedy International Airport was illegal because of an "excessive and unjustified" delay in setting sound-level standards for the noisy supersonic jetliner.
VALDEZ, Alaska, Aug. 17 (AP) Loading at the trans-Alaska pipeline port of Valdez was halted early today, about 40 hours after an oil leak forced shutdown of the trouble-plagued pipeline.

J. Edward Shugrue, former national director of the American Heritage Foundation, sponsors of the American Freedom Train in the 1940's, died Tuesday in a Pearl River, N.Y., hospital after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

Abe Beame is "tough." Bella Abzug is a "fighter." Mario Cuomo is "angry." Edward I. Koch is "competent." Three other Democratic mayoral candidates are financially strapped, so they have not so far been able to use television advertising to promote their personal and poltical assets.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) Five Republican Senators are suing the Senate on ground that it cannot legally limit the fees they get for their speeches.

This week's Federal court decision permitting New Jersey students opposed to reciting the pledge of allegiance to the flag to remain seated will not change the tradition for the state's 1.5 million students of opening each class day with the flag salute and pledge, the State Education Department said yesterday.

In the first decision growing out of the Central Intelligence Agency's domestic mail-monitoring, Judge Jack B. Weinstein yesterday ordered the Government to pay $1,000 and court costs--and to write an apology--to each of three plaintiffs whose mail had been opened during the undercover program.

ATLANTA, Aug. 17 Bert Lance said today he was confident that a "complete and a fair" report on the Comptroller of the Currency's investigation of his finances would show that he had done nothing wrong. He said that he had no plan to resign.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 17 In this goingnowhere year, the Mets have had few, if any, wishes granted them. Tonight, still another wish was shot to smithereens when the St. Louis Cardinals beat them, 2-0, and prevented the Mets from gaining their first three-game sweep since last May.

While the youth market has for many years been the object of marketers' attention, the pre- and post-retirement market has not received as much notice. In an effort to rectify this discrepancy, a private organization named the National Retirement Council is trying to get companies to adjust their marketing strategies.

MADRID, Aug. 17 (UPI) An assassination attempt against King Juan Carlos, Queen Sofia and Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez was foiled today when the police discovered a bomb under an overpass only moments before the King's car was due, the national news agency Cifra reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 Common Cause, the public affairs lobby, said today that Representative John M. Murphy, chairman of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, received large campaign contributions from maritime interests at a time that his panel had reported out bills favorable to shipping companies and marine unions.

GENEVA, Aug. 17 (AP) Unless capital investments expand more rapidly in the United States, West Germany and Japan, a new economic downturn could begin in the second half of 1978, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development warned today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 A gunman apparently bent on revenge surrendered to the police late tonight less than six hours after hijacking a Santa Cruz city bus and holding a number of hostages at a religious retreat about 70 south of here.
Harriet S. Edmunds, a pioneer in the development of visual graphics for use in advertising, died Aug. 11. She was 85 years and lived in Clinton, Conn.

ENTERING the new television season in stages, WNET-13 will introduce two new series next month, "In Pursuit of Liberty," consisting of four one-hour documentaries on the American freedoms, and a 14-week series of domestic and foreign motion pictures that were created as entertainment, but for the purpose of conveying propaganda.
LA JOLLA, Calif., Aug. 17 (AP) Delmer Lawrence Daves, a retired motionpicture producer and director who was part of 80 films in a 40-year career, died today at Scripps Hospital. He was 73 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI) Largely because of an increase in Social Security distributions, personal income climbed 0.8 percent in July, for the 24th consecutive monthly gain, the Commerce Department said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The Carter Administration is considering introducing legislation before the end of the year to institute what it calls a coordinated family and youth program to prevent unwanted pregnancies.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 Southern California, which along with most of the West is in the second year of its worst drought of the century, finally got some rain yesterday and today. And when the rain came, it came in buckets.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The State Department criticized today, the Israeli decision to go ahead with construction of additional West Bank settlements.

A rush by the public to insulate homes and production bottlenecks in two key industries have created a shortage of insulation materials and higher prices for them that industry and consumer leaders expect to worsen if Congress passes the Carter Administration's energy conservation tax incentive program.

HACKENSACK, Aug. 17 The trickle of Medicaid beds available to the elderly in need of long-term care in New Jersey has virtually dried up over the summer months, with Bergen County particularly hard hit.
DETROIT, Aug. 17 (UPI) The wildcat strike that stranded 30,000 Detroit metropolitan area commuters for 48 hours appeared to be over today as the 300 striking bus drivers started back to work.
TEL AVIV,- Aug. 17 The Government today approved construction of three new Israeli settlements in territory captured from Jordan in the 1967 war.
CAIRO, Aug. 17 Egypt accused Moscow today of failing to live up to its trade agreements and suspended its commitments to the Soviet Union.

Eugene H. Nickerson, former Nassau County Executive, and Charles P. Sifton, a former Federal prosecutor, have been nominated by President Carter to be Federal trial judges in the Eastern District of New York. The district takes in Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and Long Island.

Although he lived in a state with one of the toughest gun control laws in the nation, David R. Berkowitz, the accused Son of Sam killer, had little difficulty assembling an arsenal of weapons. When captured he had a pistol, a semi-automatic rifle, a shotgun, and another disassembled rifle: quite an array of firepower to be in the hands of one willing to plead insanity.

TORONTO, Aug. 17 (AP) John McEnroe, the Wimbledon sensation from Douglaston, Queens, advanced today to the second round of the Canadian open tennis tournament by defeating Werner Zirngibl of West Germany, 6-4, 2-6, 6-3.
Sometimes a single roll radically alters the course of the game particularly when one player rolls doubles while on the bar.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The State Department today welcomed Leonid I. Brezhnev's pledge to respond in a positive way to new American efforts to improve relations.

When Madderlake Florists in the West Village caters its next little dinner party for ten ($125 a person is the slightly breathtaking tab) the table will be set with terra cotta dinnerware by Kitty Bright.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) The United States Ambassador to the Central African Empire, Anthony Quainton, is being recalled for consultations over the recent imprisonment of two journalists, one American and one British.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) Deaths from overdoses of heroin and morphine decreased sharply in Detroit, Los Angeles and San Francisco in the first three months of this year, the Drug Enforcement Administration reported today.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 17 The important Ethiopian city of Diredawa came under sustained mortar attack yesterday in what some diplomatic observers here viewed as a possible prelude to an all-out Somali assault on the city, the fourth largest in the country.
The dollar fell on world currency markets yesterday after three days of advances, while gold ended its slide on major bullion markets, The Associated Press reported.
EL PASO, Aug. 17 Around McAllen, Tex., and Monterrey, Mexico, he was known simply as "Oscar," an ingenious Peruvian with a magic touch for turning illegal aliens into United States citizens.

The European championships played in Elsinore, Denmark, ended last week in a victory for Sweden, with Italy in second position. This means that the Italians, who have dominated world bridge for more than two decades, will be missing from the world team championships in Manila in October.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 17 In a more that may have long-range significance but little current interest to fans, baseball's major leagues voted today to increase their Executive Council from seven to 11 members and require it to meet every two months.

Mark Schorer, the novelist, literary critic and biographer, died in an Oakland, Calif., hospital last Thursday evening at the age of 69. His family said that the cause of death was a blood infection following an operation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) Labor Secretary Ray Marshall announced today a $661,170 agreement with the Chicago and North Western Transportation Company to train 432 Vietnam veterans in railroad jobs.
COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Aug. 17 (Reuters) A night-time curfew has been imposed on two districts in Sri Lanka following outbreaks of looting, a Government communique said today.
Cook Industries Inc., the financially troubled grain and cotton merchandiser whose shares were suspended from the American Stock Exchange at its own request on May 25, will begin trading again today.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 17 The Indiana Loves beat the New York Apples tonight, 27-25, to force the World Team Tennis playoffs to the rubber match.

President Carter, going against the recommendation of the Interior Department, is planning to name Patrick J. Delaney, son of the House Rules Committee Chairman, James J. Delaney, Democrat of Queens, to a $47,500-a-year post as a commissioner of the Susquehanna River Basin Commission.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 17 If Frank M. Johnson Jr., President Carter's choice to be director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has time in his prospective job to delve...
JONKOPING, Sweden, Aug. 17 (AP) Gerald Moerken of West Germany and Petra Thuemer of East Germany set world records today at the 14th European swimming championships.

The Procter Gamble Company, the nation's leading maker of soaps and detergents, reported yesterday profit increases of 10 percent for the final quarter and 15 percent for the fiscal year ended June 30.

"Mistakes. Fundamentals. What has happened to us?" asked Manager Sparky Anderson of the world champion Cincinnati Reds recently. "I'm putting it all down, every night in a book I'm keeping. Then next spring we will correct it, all of it. But there is so much. We are totally ashamed of 1977."

Charging that the Securities and Exchange Commission was injecting itself into the mayoral campaign, Mayor Beame yesterday released the transcript of his sworn testimony before the commission last year and angrily denied that he had failed to disclose New York City's fiscal plight in 1974 and 1975.
MOGADISHU, Somalia, Aug. 17 (AP) The Soviet Union has signed an economic aid agreement with Somalia, the Government-controlled newspaper October Star reported today.

A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the 17-month ban on Concorde flights using Kennedy International Airport was illegal because of an "excessive and unjustified" delay in setting noise standards for the supersonic jetliner.

They vowed to protest yesterday's court decision concerning the Concorde, to continue to fight against the plane's ever landing at John F. Kennedy International Ariport even to carry the battle back to the streets as they did not too long ago.

A recent survey by Michael Knight of The Times showed that control of suburban schools is passing from parents and local school boards to agencies of state and Federal governments and the teachers unions. The conclusions of this significant report need not be confined to suburban schools. The loss of local power affects cities as well as suburbs. The trend is widely regarded as inevitable and therefore passively accepted. Must it be?
DETROIT, Aug. 17 In a move that may be followed in small school districts nationwide, a dozen small teacher associations in Wayne County have formed a single bargaining unit.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 Governor Carey today announced his veto of a measure that would have liberalized rules for "Las Vegas Nights" events at which religious and charitable organizations cam raise money through games of chance.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17-In a rare admission of its own espionage activity abroad, the K.G.B. contended through the Soviet press today that the Central Intelligence Agency was responsible for the disappearance of a Russian-born double agent, Nicholas Shadrin, in Vienna in late 1975.

LONDON, Aug. 17 British and French aviation officials, guardedly hailing the decision permitting the Concorde to land at Kennedy International Airport, said today they planned to make the first of half a dozen test flights in about 10 days without waiting for the outcome of an appeal.
TEL AVIV, Aug 17 The Government today approved construction of three new Israeli settlements in territory captured from Jordan in the 1967 war.

Samuel Levine, who retired in 1966 as general director of the Jewish Community Centers in Chicago, died Monday in SloanKettering Memorial Hospital in New York City after a brief illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Sarasota, Fla.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 17 Once it was unthinkable; a Jets-Steelers game playing before 50,000 empty seats.
"I LIKE TO GO to movies. I like to be recognized. And I enjoy burning my hair with my cigarette, like I just did," said Richard Pryor, calmly patting out the accidental blaze without missing a beat.

FIRST, the good news. Avocado is no longer the most popular color nationwide in kitchen and laundry appliances. The bad news, reports that Maytag Company, (which doesn't realize that it's bad news) is that "gold has replaced avocado as the most popular color, other than white, asked for on laundry appliances." Gold has also gained at the expense of copper, the Maytag report said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI) The number of persons living alone in the United States more than doubled from 1960, and the number of couples without children increased 50 percent, new census figures show.

LENOX, MASS. WHEN THE NAME of George Antheil comes up nowadays, and that is not often, it is likely to trigger one im- mediate associative response: airplane propeller. His use of that instrument in his "Ballet Mecanique," one of the most celebrated pieces of the 1920's, is about all that remains of the American composer's once shiny reputation as an inspired Dadaist and shocker of the middle class.

THERE WAS a time when what I knew I knew with great clarity. Then there was another time when what I didn't know poked its foot from behind the curtain and demanded to be integrated all at once. I was on a train.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 17 (AP) A 58-year-old farmer from St. Mary's, Ohio, Norbert Liette, won the clay-target championship of America tonight in the 78th annual Grand American trapshooting tournament.
Thirty-one persons, most of whom were full-time public employees, were arrested yesterday on charges of defrauding the city of about $250,000 in illegal welfare payments over the last seven years.

PARIS, Aug. 17 The 50,000th passenger has just flown with a French Concorde, and so, tomorrow night, there will be a champagne ceremony at Charles de Gaulle Airport at Roissy-en-France, due north of here.

DETROIT, Aug. 17 Somewhere in the ninth inning of the game the Yankees played against the Detroit Tigers tonight, Manager Billy Martin noticed that the proceedings had a familiar look. Camera in hand, he is also a traveler concerned with the natural culture and everyday activities of other countries.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 17 Since winning the Professional Golfers' Association championship Sunday at Pebble Beach, Calif., Lanny Wadkins has been quite busy and pretty much alone. He also has been rather numb. With no friends or relatives to celebrate with and talk to, "I don't think all of it has hit me yet."

Rival advocates of statehood and independence for Puerto Rico lobbied before a United Nations committee yesterday for a Cuban resolution condemning the island's present commonwealth relationship with the United States, United Press International reported.

Count on this upbeat little show to be resolutely affirmative. The fact is that this is a skein of songs, innocent and amiable, but stretched porously thin as an evening's entertainment.

Billie Jean King and Virginia Wade were convulsed with laughter last night as they sat on the bench watching two of their teammates, Sandy Mayer and Ray Ruffels, complete a 31-15 laugher against the Indiana Loves at Felt Forum. The victory advanced the New York Apples to the second round of the World Team Tennis playoffs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 A White House spokesman said today that President Carter made five trips in 1975 and 1976 in an airplane owned by the National Bank of Georgia, of which Budget Director Bert Lance was then president, but that it was not clear whether the trips were a part of his campaign activities and if so whether the bank had been reimbursed for the use of the plane.

Picabia drove to impress, and he liked his cars to be fast, open and spectacular.

The tonnage was considerable.
The Dance Theater of Harlem will perform tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M., and the Don Redlich Dance Company will perform Sunday, also at 8, in Newport, R.I., as part of the American Dance Festival.

MANILA, Aug. 18, 1977 Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda of Japan ended his 10day tour of Southeast Asia here today with a speech outlining Japan's new doctrine of peaceful cooperation with its neighbors based on mutual trust.

THE THREE-WAY partnership between Martha Schlamme, Alvin Epstein and Kurt Weill is still growing and developing after a decade together. Because their professional careers have taken separate paths, Miss Schlamme and Mr. Epstein have been able to come together in their programs of Weill songs for only brief periods in those 10 years, but the very infrequency of their gettogethers seems to add a freshness and a constantly probing quality to their performances.

HOLBROOK, L.I., Aug. 18 (AP) A 16-year-old girl was critically shocked, and burned, and her dog was killed when the dog urinated on the wiring of an electrified sign here, the Suffolk County police reported.

United States industry will spend $22.4 billion on overseas capital investment this year, the economics department of the McGraw-Hill Publications Company reported yesterday.

Aficionados of bocce a form of lawn bowling for the steely nerved from all over the metropolitan area will compete for cash prizes and medallions this weekend in the fourth annual Sambuca Romana bocce tournament. It will be in Cunningham Park. Union Turnpike and 196th Street in Queens, tomorrow and Sunday from 10 A.M. to dusk. The final matches are scheduled for 1 P.M. on Sunday. Admission is free.

Hospital after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 26 South Farragut Avenue, Manasquan, N.J.

THE 1960's continue to exert their spell in mysterious ways. The 1970's aren't so much a contradiction of the previous free-swinging decade as they are a subtler, more pervasive extension of it. The music and the life style may have lost some of their radical intensity, but they have permeated ever more broadly through the population at large.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (AP) Flames from a ruptured underground fuel line blanketed a city block today, injuring two passersby and threatening homes and businesses before it was extinguished, firemen said.

Determined to stay in the running in the battle for the Babcock Wilcox Company, the United Technologies Corporation yesterday raised its bid for all shares of Babcock to $55 a share.

PEKING, Aug. 19--A mass meeting, apparently the 11th Congress of the Chinese Communist Party, was under way in the Great Hall of the People late tonight amid reports that a major shift in the official ideology from revolutionary radicalism to more down-to-earth policies would be announced within 24 hours.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 19 -- A powerful earthquake, possibly the strongest ever recorded, struck the eastern Indian Ocean between Australia and Indonesia today, rattling tall buildings as far away as Perth, Australia, 1,000 miles to the south.

The Criminal Justice Agency showed extraordinary bureaucratic mindlessness in preparing a report that seemed to recommend release without bail for David R. Berkowitz, the accused .44-caliber killer. The agency did not in fact really make such a sweeping recommendation; it had no authority to do so; and there was never any likelihood that the accused killer would be released.

The gross national product rose 6.1 percent and inflation increased 7.1 percent in the second quarter, the Commerce Department reported. Both measures were higher than had been forecast by the agency. Page 31.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)--The Federal Maritime Commission announced today that it had accepted a $340,000 fine from Japan's Sony Corporation and its United States subsidiary to settle a case in which the company had been accused of accepting illegal rebates.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI)--The Consumer Product Safety Commission, has issued a new warning to retailers who are still selling children's sleepwear treated with the banned flame retardant Tris.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)--The Justice Department said today that a proposed Agriculture Department subsidy for sugar producers would be illegal.

Dr. Donald Cooksey, a physicist who helped organize and direct the Radiation Laboratory of the University of California at Berkeley, died yesterday in Berkeley. He was 85 years old.

PARIS--After gracing the Paris skyline for 88 years, Alexandre Gustave Eiffel's creation is under attack again. No one is proposing to tear down this city's best-known landmark, as Guy de Maupassant and other aesthetes of the 1890's urged. But the business life of the Eiffel Tower has been thrown into question: Should Mr. Eiffel's corporate successor be allowed to continue operating the tower concession?

A CONTINUING decline in the number of commercial farms in Connecticut is reported in a new national census of agricul ture, just released. In the five years from 1969 to 1974, the number of farms in the state that sold more than $2,500 of products annually dropped 15.3 percent, from 2,903 to 2,360. In the same period the number of acres in farms fell 11 percent, from 424,000 to 376,000 acres.

INSPIRED by the example of the pioneering ethologist Konrad Lorenz, students of animal and human behavior have fashioned ethograms: de tailed descriptions of behaviors that are displayed by all members of a species. Most fascinating are fixed action patterns--complex sequences of acts that appear almost from birth in fully developed form, provided only that a stimulus of certain type has been perceived, usually during a critical period of the creature's development.

Robert Irving, born, reared and educated in Winchester, England, is now in his 20th year as musical director of New York City Ballet, the longest period anyone has ever occupied the post.
