The Santa Fe Opera's answer to this question has remained pretty much the same since the company's first season 21 years ago, and on the whole it has worked well: Revive at least one interesting opera from the past, balance that with a contemporary novelty and fill out the bill of fare with important repertory staples, all restudied and rehearsed under optimum performing conditions.

A clear signal of the decline of the Democratic organization in New York City is that district leaders will be elected in next month's primary in Manhattan but that very few voters and even politicians say they care.

MANILA, Monday, Aug. 22 President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced today that he would ease his five-year martial law restrictions by calling for National Assembly elections next year and lifting the 1 A.M.-to-4 A.M. curfew and the ban on foreign travel by Filipino.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 Senator William Proxmire, citing some of the activities of Budget Director Bert Lance before he joined the Government, announced today that the Senate Banking Committee would conduct a broad investigation of the "ethics and soundness" of American banking.

Michele Mandelbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Mandelbaum of Woodmere, L. I., was married last evening to William C. Bursten, an assistant attorney general in New York. Rabbi Morris S. Friedman performed the ceremony in Temple Hillel in North Woodmere.

PRINCETON, N.J. The country's second-most popular public-affairs radio program is prepared and produced here each week by a bunch of college kids who think nothing of putting famous people on the spot.

The Central Intelligence Agency is bearish on the Soviet economy. Moscow, says the C.I.A., will feel increasing strain in the years ahead; sharply reduced rates of economic growth will pose excruciating choices for the Kremlin leaders. Gone are the C.I.A's cries of alarm of twenty years ago that the Soviet Union might soon surpass the United States economically.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 21 Two American rabbis lobbied in the Israeli Parliament and said today that they were assured of sufficient votes to block a move by Prime Minister Menahem Begin that would deny the privileges normally accorded Jews to converts to Conservative or Reform Judaism who immigrate to Israel.
History has been unkind to Mayors of New York City, and the world of politics has been unreceptive even to those who have survived the job.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 21 After the Cosmos rallied and defeated the Lancers, 2-1, today, Coach Eddie Firmani of the Cosmos wanted to let the world know that his team could play defense and win away from home.

MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich., Aug. 21 (UPI) Recalling his inability to save a young boy's life six years ago, Don Schmidt frantically hacked through the hull of an overturned cabin cruiser Friday to save the lives of three boaters.

A pair of dramatic tiebreaker victories both involving Sandy Mayer, the consummate World Team Tennis player, pushed the New York Apples into the finals of the league championship last night as they beat the Boston Lobsters, 29-26. With his Apples teammates screaming on the sidelines Mayer defeated Tony Roche, 7-6, and then teamed with Ray Ruffels to defeat Roche and Mike Estep by the same score.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22(AP) The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today there were 368 banks on its "problem list" as of June 30, one more than a year earlier, but 18 less than the peak reached in November 1976.
The last of the old-crop soybean futures contracts, the spot August, expired at noon yesteday, but not before traders witnessed a nerve-fraying display of roller coaster price moves.
DETROIT As auto dealers clear their showrooms for this year's offering of smaller, more efficient models, William L. Mitchell has reason to reflect with pride. The majority are his designs.

In one of the sharpest exchanges of the New York City mayoral campaign, Mayor Beame and Mario M. Cuomo traded accusations yesterday over Mr. Beame's charge of possible conflict of interest by a Securities and Exchange Commission lawyer overseeing a commission study of the city's fiscal crisis.

Negotiators for the Metropolitan Opera and its orchestra musicians scheduled a meeting for tomorrow in hopes of breaking a deadlock in their attempt to reach a labor agreement before Sept. 9. If there is no agreement by that date, the Metropolitan has warned, the opera season will be canceled.

LOCUST GROVE, Okla., Aug. 22 People in this small northeastern Oklahoma town normally spend free August afternoons taking a dip in Spring Creek or fishing for bass with crawdads, but for the last two months the swimming holes have been deserted and the fishing poles have been tucked into closets.

Chester J. LaRoche, a leader in advertising who for 20 years headed the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame, died Sunday night, three days before his 85th birthday, at the Meadow Club in Southampton, L.I. He had been living in Palm Beach since 1972.

Setting the stage for a test case on a conflict between Federal education regulations and state tenure requirements, a Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday ordered the Brentwood, L.I., school district to rehire teachers for bilingual programs.

In one of the sharpest exchanges of the New York City mayoral campaign, Mayor Beame and Mario M. Cuomo traded accusations yesterday over Mr. Beame's charge of possible conflict of interest by a Securities and Exchange Commission lawyer overseeing a commission study of the city's fiscal crisis.
President Carter is to hold a news conference today, beginning at 2:30 P.M.

The current uproar about the SST by the folk who live near Kennedy Airport is but the latest chapter in the history of noise and New York City. Perhaps no one has yet written the book, the chronology of noise in the city, of which this is a chapter but the New York Story, from its start, has always been, according to those who have stopped and listened, unfit for human ears.

Steel production remained steady during the week ended Aug. 20, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesetrday. Production totaled 2,331,000 tons, up one-tenth of 1 percent from the 2,329,000 tons produced during the previous week.
Governor Carey announced his support for President Carter's welfare revision proposals yesterday and used the occasion to do a little pointing with pride at his own record on welfare.

Laura Dean, a dancer and choreographer who also composes her own music and directs an ensemble of musicians, gave a strictly musical performance at the old United States Customs House near Battery Park on Sunday.

LONDON, Aug. 22 Britain's assistant air-traffic controllers who for several days have disrupted air traffic with a work slowdown, voted overwhelmingly today to begin a four-day all-out strike at midnight Thursday that could affect more than one million travelers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 The White House said today that the Georgia bank formerly headed by Budget Director Bert Lance had not been paid for five flights that President Carter took on an airplane owned by the bank in 1975 and 1976, even though some of the flights were political campaign trips. The White House press secretary, Jody Powell, said that arrangements were being made to pay now.

BONN, Aug. 22 Justice Minister HansJochen Vogel announced today that the Government was considering new legislation that would enable courts to disqualify lawyer suspected of conspiracy and defendants in terrorism cases.

CRANBURY, Aug. 22 Years ago, Mahbubeh Stave recalls driving past farms on the outskirts of this picturesque village of tall arching trees and pristine white houses and seeing black migran workers in the fields.
PARIS, Aug. 22 The French Government said today it had received new information that South Africa was getting ready to set off an atomic test explosion.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 22 A wildcat strike by union coal miners, begun eight weeks ago to protest cutbacks in medical benefits provided by the United Mine Workers Health and Retirement Fund, appeared to have collapsed here today after a tumultuous meeting that involved miners and the union's international executive board.

The Soviet announcement the other day that its nuclear icebreaker Arktika had become the first surface ship to reach the North Pole, confirms, yet again, how rapidly man is conquering the inaccessible places on the planet. The question, yet again, is whether man's capacities in the political, legal and economic arenas can keep pace.

Last spring, Attorney General Griffin Bell made a painful, historic and correct decision: to authorize the first Federal indictment ever of an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The defendant was John J. Kearney, a squad supervisor, and the charges involved illegal wiretapping and mail-opening by the F.B.I. in connection with the Weather Underground.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 22 The Southampton "cat burglar" struck again last weekend, making off with at least $1,500 in jewels and cash, and a prescription for sleeping pills from two lavish summer homes here.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 22 Lisa Hansen and Liz Hills of Long Beach, Calif., won their repechage, or second-chance heat, today to qualify for Thursday's double sculls semifinals for women at the world rowing championships.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 22 The state's new Commissioner of Education today extended by one year the time that the Rockville Centre school district has to begin integrating its six elementary schools. The order, which affects 4,000 students, overruled one issued by former Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist as he left office last June.

MONROE, La., Aug. 22 (UPI) Funeral services were held Saturday for two teenage girls who drove more than 200 miles to Memphis, Tenn., to mourn the death of Elvis Presley and were killed by a car outside the late singer's mansion.
Magazine mailing labels will have to bear subscription expiration dates starting next year, under a New York State law enacted on the recommendation of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

NEWARK, Aug. 22 State Senator Raymond H. Bateman of Somerville and the man he beat by more than 64,000 votes in the Republican gubernatorial primary, Assemblyman Thomas H. Kean of Livingston, joined forces today in an atttmpt to unseat Governor Bryne in the November elections.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) The Interior Department announced today plans to restrict ownership of land irrigated with water from federal reclamation projects.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 22 (AP) Clancy Edwards of the United States edged Silvio Leonard of Cuba by 18hundredths of a second tonight and won the 200-meter dash at the World University Games.

MINEOLA, L.L, Aug. 22 The state's new Commissioner of Education today extended by one year the time that the Rockville Centre school district has to begin integrating its six elementary schools. The order, which affects 4,000 students, overruled one issued by former Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist as he left office last June.
The political news from Quebec often hits the front pages of the American press. But the economic developments in that French-speaking Canadian province are much less known in the United States.

CHICAGO A few months ago, I prepared some rough statistics on real, after-tax personal income by state that have been widely cited by people on both sides of the debate about whether or not Federal tax and spending programs benefit the Southern states at the expense of the North.

After all the complex circumstances are sifted surrounding the bizzare escape from a Rome prison hospital of a convicted Nazi war criminal, the fact remains that Col. Herbert Kappler sentenced to life imprisonment for the 1944 murder of 335 Italian civilians is now free, and the West German Government has taken a hands-off attitude that cannot but dismay its friends abroad.
JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 22 The South African Government's plan to offer a share of national political power to minority racial groups, but not to the black majority, has met a mixed reception.

In a step that speeds New York City toward the day it can issue its own securities to the public, the two major credit-rating agencies yesterday awarded long-sought "investment-grade" ratings to a forthcoming $200 million offering of new bonds by the Municipal Assistance Corporation.
A 19-year-old student shattered the world record for consecutive roller coaster rides yesterday on the cyclone roller coaster at Astroland Park in Coney Island.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 22Jerry Golsteyn, who has never played a National Football League regular-season game, will be the Giants' starting quarterback on opening day, it was NOT announced today.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 22 (UPI) Mexican troops and policemen blocked the path of a hijacked passenger bus early today and 10 persons were killed in a shoot-out and the explosion of a grenade held by one of the two hijackers. Ten persons were wounded.

A justice of New York State Supreme Court yesterday rejected a challenge to the nominating petitions of Barry Farber, thus setting up a mayoral primary in the Republican Party. The challenge had been mounted by Roy M. Goodman, the organization Republican candidate.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (AP) United States Naval Intelligence says that for 10 years Western assessments of the armament and purpose of the latest Soviet missile cruisers and destroyers have been totally wrong, according to a report by Britain's Foreign Affairs Research Institute.
MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Aug. 22 Sometimes, you can't tell the winners from the losers, even when the game is over.

John Hightower is beginning to get his sea legs in his new job as president of the South Street Seaport Museum, and he likes the feeling. The former executive director of the New York State Counci1 on the Arts and, for a relatively brief period, director of the ...
Buoyed by strength in some of the selected glamour and blue-chip issues, the stock market yesterday ended its foursession losing streak by posting a moderate advance in slower trading.

Three brothers were sent to jail by a Federal judge yesterday for refusing to provide their fingerprints, palm prints, handwriting samples and voice samples for an investigation into terrorist bombings attributed to a Puerto Rican nationalist group known as the F.A.L.N.

YONKERS, Aug. 22 Alexander's, which already has department stores in White Plains and central Westchester County and in Cortlandt in the northern part of the county, broadened its efforts today by opening another store in this city on the county's southern border.
NEW MADRID, Mo., Aug. 22 (AP) Inmates of the New Madrid county jail pitched in to help save case records and evidence today as the jail burned, the authorities said.

Msgr. Thomas Fee, a Gaelic scholar and authority on early Irish Christianity, was named yesterday by Pope Paul VI to be Roman Catholic Primate of all of Ireland. Monsignor Fee, who was born in Northern Ireland, is 53 years old and since 1974 has been president of St. Patrick's College, an major center for training priests in the Irish Republic.
Touche Ross Company and J.K. Lasser Company announced yesterday they had merged their practices, creating one of the largest accounting partnerships in the country.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) The Soviet Union has continued to improve its military forces in the last year, but at increasing expense, the Defense Intelligence Agency says.

Libby Howard was a construction worker, one of thousands who worked on the new Labor Department headquarters in Washington. Now she was back in that building, attesting to the ordeals of women hard hats.

Despite the raising of the prime interest rate by major United States commercial banks, the dollar dropped yesterday in foreign exchange trading on the strength of rumors about the United States trade deficit, The Associated Press reported.
PARIS, Aug. 22 The French Government said today it had received new information that South Africa was getting ready to set off an atomic test explosion.

In an extensive managerial shake-up believed to have been prompted by its television network's poor showing in the ratings last season, the National Broadcasting Company yesterday dismissed the network's president and appointed Robert E. Mulholland, a seasoned executive of NBC News, to succeed him.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 22 Princeton University's Center for Environmental Studies recommended today that New Jersey minimize adverse impacts of offshore drilling by limiting to the Atlantic City area any onshore bases built to support and supply oil rigs in the ocean.

HOUSTON, Aug. 22 (AP) Scientific instruments left on the moon by astronauts of the Apollo mission are still sending information to earth, but the data will not be monitored after this month because the national space agency cannot afford it, the Johnson Space Center announced today.

The publication of the Random House Encyclopedia on Sept. 30 is the culmination of a major international publishing venture that began almost 10 years ago. For the first time, 14 publishing houses in Europe, Africa, Asia and the Middle East will be using the basic information to produce their own editions between now and 1980.
Campaign workers for Mario M. Cuomo were routed from a Brooklyn office yesterday by a foul-smelling gas that someone sprayed in an adjacent hallway, the police reported.
MOSCOW, Aug. 22 (AP) A Soviet general has expressed concern about the quality of some draftees entering the armed forces from the Soviet Union's large military training program for school-age youths.

MEMPHIS, Aug. 22 Elvis Presley named his father, Vernon, executor of his fortune in a will probated this afternoon in Memphis. But the singer did not include his fiancee, Ginger Alben, one of three witnesses who signed the will March 3, or his wife, Priscilla, in the document.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Aug. 22 (AP) After traveling 25,833 miles throughout the continental United States, the "American Freedom Train" is to begin its last journey tomorrow under that name. The 15 red, white and blue cars are to be hauled northward from here to Buffalo, and then to Canada. The train is to become "Discovery Train," part of the National Museums of Canada.

The United States International Trade Commission has narrowed its inquiry into stainless steel pipe and tube imports from Japan. Last October, a group of United States specialty steel producers accused a number of Japanese companies of engaging in "predatory" export pricing practices.

OCEAN CITY, Md., Aug. 22 (UPI) Oil from a major spill yesterday smeared this resort city's beaches. Clean-up operations were under way today and the Coast Guard sought to determine the source of the oil.

Robert P. Tyler Jr., the president and chief operating officer of the Simmons Company, a large diversified home furnishing producer, has been discharged, the company announced yesterday in Atlanta, its home base.

The New York Shipping Association has threatened to withdraw from the Council of North Atlantic Shipping Association if the council is unable to negotiate a new agreement with the International Longshoremen's Association.

A private van that began regular commuter runs along the East Side was abruptly taken out of service by its owners yesterday after New York City threatened to serve them with a summons for operating without a license.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) The Agriculture Department is proposing new standards for the care and feeding of sea mammals in captivity. The category includes polar bears, sea otters, whales, porpoises, dolphins, seals, sea lions and walruses.

When a group of (mostly) New York liberals gathered in a good cause at East Hampton last week, not surprisingly one of the dominant subjects of conversation was President Carter's nomination of Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr. to be the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. What was surprising was that so much doubtshort of hostility was expressed about the nomination.

NEWPORT, R.L, Aug. 22 Two independent artists who might never have worked together without a combined music and dance grant from the National Endowment for the Arts collaborated successfully Sunday evening at the American Dance Festival here in Rogers High School Auditorium.
The credit markets, showing a solid but rather uninteresting sense of balance yesterday, remained stable as securities dealers got ready to handle today's larger volume of financing.

Marian Sulzberger Heiskell and Samuel J. Lefrak, both of New York City, were among four members of regional state park and recreation commissions named yesterday by Governor Carey. The nominations are subject to confirmation by the State Senate.

COVENTRY, Conn., Aug. 21 An elderly couple intent on fixing up and moving into a cottage on a tiny island they own on Lake Wanbumbaug is in serious conflict with this community over the tightening of zoning and sanitary codes, and because of the rising level of the lake.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (Reuters) Israel has used American-supplied military equipment to support Christian forces involved in the conflict in Lebanon, the State Department said today.

For a change, their were no adjustments in the standings in the American League's two torrid divisional races last night. The three top teams in each division stayed in exactly the same relationship to each other. The reason? Because the three Western Division leaders beat the three top teams in the East.

CAROLINA EVENING Theatergoers who missed the acclaimed revival of George Gershwin's "Porgy and Bess" last season on Broadway can hear musical highlights free tonight at 7:30 at Central Park's 72d Street Bandshell.

COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Aug. 22 (AP) A nighttime curfew was imposed on this island nation today in an attempt to quell a wave of violence between rival ethnic groups that has taken 25 lives, driven plantation workers from their jobs and produced hundreds of refugees.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Aug. 22 (Reuters) Secretary General Kurt Waldheim said today that the best way to solve South Africa's apartheid problem would be to hold a national convention composed of genuine representatives of all the people of the country.
BRIGHTON, Colo., Aug. 22 (UPI) Gerald Owens, a blind veteran, set off with his seeing-eye dog today on a walk to Washington to seek a pension from the Vterans Administration.

VALDEZ, Alaska Aug. 22 (AP) A tanker of the British Petroleum Company departed from the trans-Alaska pipeline terminal here today with the first load of North Slope crude to go south since a pump station oil leak forced the line to close down a week ago.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 22 (UPI) Representative Al Ullman, Democrat of Oregon, said today that the short-term financial problems of the Social Security System could and should be handled with minor, short-term adjustments in the payroll tax rate and the wage base.

A justice of New York State Supreme Court yesterday rejected a challenge to the nominating petitions of Barry Farber, thus setting up a mayoral primary in the Republican Party. The challenge had been mounted by Roy M. Goodman, the organization Republican candidate.

The right of a social-service agency and its workers to maintain a privileged, confidential relationship with a client has been upheld by the New York State Supreme Court. In a decision made public yesterday, the court quashed a subpoena by the state's Welfare Inspector General for information supplied to an agency by a client.

I find it reassuring to see a good writer occasionally at a loss for something to say. Literature should be difficult, like loving. An unbroken round of successes might take some of the romance, the mystery, out of writing.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 22 The head of the central council of the Palestine Liberation Organization said today that his group would not embrace Resolution 242 of the United Nations Security Council, which implicitly recognizes the right of Israel to exist.
JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 22(AP) South African security forces have killed three black nationalist guerrillas near the Angolan border in South-West Africa, the South African radio reported today.

The announced closing of the Wiltwyck School's Eleanor Roosevelt campus, in Yorktown, N.Y., is bad news for the 110 boys who live there. They are black and Hispanic youths, public charges between the ages of 10 and 17, many of them suffering from serious emotional and behavioral problems. It has been Wiltwyck's pride since its establishment in 1937 that it took in "the kids nobody else wants."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 A Federal Appellate Court has ruled that an employee's interest in a pension fund is a security, subject to the antifraud provisions of Federal securities laws.
These are a number of people on the Cosmos who believe the team has won its last two playoff games both away from home, because of Shep Messing, Shep Messing and Shep Messing.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 On the verge of taking over first place in the American League East, the New York Yankees lost a 3-0 lead in the seventh inning and then experienced a defensive collapse in the eighth, which let the Chicago White Sox wm tonight's game, 5-3.
For the badly mauled trust and pension equity accounts of leading banks and insurance companies, recovery from the bear market chat began in 1970 has been slow and hard.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 22 Working with the care of watchmakers, engineers removed the protective shroud from the Voyager 1 spacecraft today and began a detailed search for clues to what might have caused its twin to get off to such an uncertain start Saturday on its journey to the outer planets.

GUATEMALA Two decades after campaigns were launched to eradicate malaria from Central America, the disease is once again spreading through the region because of the resistance of mosquitoes to traditional insecticides.

George H. Walker, who served as president of the United States Golf Association in 1920, had an idea for an annual series of matches between the best United States amateur golfers and the best amateurs from Britain and Ire land.

MOSCOW, Aug. 22 (AP) An ill Jewish mathematician, his parents and his brother received permission today to leave the Soviet Union, Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and prominent dissident, said. Moscow dissidents had carried on a publicity campaign in their behalf.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 22 (UP) A flying instructor, Glen Shaw, was in two plane crashes on the same public golf course within three days, the second claiming the life of a woman and critically injuring Mr. Shaw and a second man.

The Parker-Hannifin Corporation, a supplier of fluid power components and automotive parts, had a 25 percent earnings jump in the quarter ended June 30 and a 42.3 percent increase for the full fiscal year, the company reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Consumers in the market for home insulation have no protection against unscrupulous or inexperienced merchants who may sell them flammable insulation or who may install it improperly, the Consumer Product Safety Commission was told today.

WASHINGTON A dancer dances, a musician plays and an artist paints or sculpts. But pity the poor humanist in America. Few people seem quite sure what he's supposed to do, or what it means once he's done it.

MAHWAH, Aug. 22 A small charter bus company here that is trying to branch into commuter operations is locked in a dispute with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey over space in the authority's bus terminal on Eighth Avenue in Manhattan.

Two bills that would guarantee rentincrease exemptions for qualified elderly people who move and that would prevent discrimination in housing and mortgages because of age were voted out yesterday by the New York City Councils General Welfare Committee.
CAIRO, Aug. 22 On these warm nights of Ramadan, the month of daytime fasting, Egyptians crowd the cafes and complain bitterly over rising prices and the failure of peace.

Today is the 50th anniversary of the execution in Boston of Sacco and Vanzetti, but passions endure and doubts persist. Was their murder conviction, which stirred demonstrations, strikes, riots and even bombings in many countries, justice or injustice? Were they criminals or martyrs?

PLYMOUTH, Mass. "Promenade left and do-si-do, hang on gents and don't be slow." In a rustic pavilion called C. Sharp in a country dance camp named Pinewoods, Jim Morrison was calling the figures for a class in Southern square-dancing, as a fiddler, a guitarist and a bass player from Berea College in Kentucky sawed away at the toe-tapping music.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) Louis Zahn, who built a multimillion-dollar pharmaceutical business out of a $225 investment, died of cancer yesterday. He was 67 year old.
Major banks across the nation raised their basic, or prime, lending rates yesterday to 7 percent from 6 percent Friday following the increase set in motion Friday by New York's Citibank.

Howard Baldwin, who spearheaded the unsuccessful drive for a merger of the World Hockey Association and the National Hockey League, was named president of the W.H.A. yesterday. The 35-year-old Baldwin succeeded Bill McFarland, who resigned "for personal reasons."

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois today rejected a demand for a special legislative session to deal with the issue of property tax increases of 40 to 300 percent that have been imposed on many home owners in the northern section of Cook County.

LORDSTOWN, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP) The sprawling General Motors Corporation passenger car assembly line moved sluggishly into life today as the rerooled operation began production of 1978 models based on the Vega style.

The L.B. Foster Company of Green Tree, Pa., one of the nation's largest distributors of pipe, tubular goods, rail and track accessories and steel sheet piling, was sold yesterday to a group of private investors and senior managers for a sum of about $106 million.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 22 (AP) Five black African presidents and two Rhodesian nationalist leaders will meet here this weekend to discuss a British-American proposal for ending white-minority rule in Rhodesia, diplomatic sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) President Carter will designate Friday a Women's Equality Day, the White House said today. Earlier a Carter aide had mistakenly announced that the President had decided against such a move.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 22 Syrian troops of the Arab League's peacekeeping force moved today into the mountain area near here where Christian-Moslem fighting yesterday left 17 persons dead, and Christian leaders warned that a new civil war could erupt if such clashes could not be prevented.

The District Director of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service said yesterday that he would be happy to grant a Peruvian girl living in Valley Stream, L.I., a 30-day leave during which she could return home to visit her sick father. Last week a judge turned down a Long Island couple's long effort to obtain permanent-resident status for the girl.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) New factory orders for durable goods fell 4.4 percent in July, the biggest decline in two and a half years, the Government said today.
LONDON, Aug. 22 (Reuters) The sudden visit to Britain today of the Israeli Foreign Minister, Moshe Dayan, brought denials that he would meet King Hussein of Jordan, who is also on a visit here.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 22 (UPI) The United States Army Chief of Staff told the Veterans of Foreign Wars convention today that the overriding goal of the armed service was to avoid war because no one would win a nuclear exchange.

COVENTRY, Conn., Aug. 21 An elderly couple intent on fixing up and moving into a cottage on a tiny island they own on Lake Wanbumbaug is in serious conflict with this community over the tightening of zoning and sanitary codes, and because of the rising level of the lake.

Alice Crimmins, the onetime Queens cocktail waitress who was convicted of manslaughter in the 1965 strangulation of her 4-year-old daughter, was married July 15 to Anthony, Grace, the contractor who had testified that he had been having an affair with her at the time her two young children were kidnapped and murdered.

MONTAUK, L.I., Aug. 22 (AP) The heaviest tuna caught in United States waters, 1,017 pounds, was reeled in 15 miles off Block Island yesterday.

Berkowitz, the man accused of being the 44caliber killer, to a literary agent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) The State Department is going to court Wednesday to ask permission to search some 200 packing crates left behind by Richard M. Nixon for valuable gifts presented to the former President and his family by foreign dignitaries.
Gilbert C. Tompkins, an artists' representative and a golf historian, died Sunday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 94 years old and lived in Matamoras, Pa.

Va., Aug. 22 A wildcat strike by union coal miners, begun eight weeks ago to protest cutbacks in medical benefits provided by the United Mine Workers Health and Retirement Fund, appeared to have collapsed here today after a tumultuous meeting that involved miners and the union's international executive board.

In a step that speeds New York City Toward the day it can issue its own securities to the public, the two major credit-rating agencies yesterday awarded long-sought "investment-grade" ratings to a forthcoming $200 million offering of new bonds by the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

TRENTON, Aug. 22 The State Assembly majority leader, Christopher J. Jacman, Democrat of West New York, pledged an all-out fight today against establishment of any kind of "theme" park or commercial amusement center on the site of Liberty State Park in Jersey City.

In an extensive managerial shake-up believed to have been prompted by its television network's poor showing in the ratings last season, the National Broadcasting Company yesterday dismissed the network's president and appointed Robert E. Mulholland, a seasoned executive of NBC News, to succeed him.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 22 Ethiopian forces relying heavily on air power repelled a full-scale Somali attack last week on the important Ethiopian city of Diredawa, according to official and diplomatic sources here.

While Tom Seaver was riding off into the sunset after his triumphal return home, the New York Mets turned back to less emotional pursuits last night and ended a five-game losing slide by edging the Houston Astros, 2-1.

Heir apparent to John Ferguson since being named assistant coach a year ago, Jean-Guy Talbot became head coach yesterday of the New York Rangers. The fiery Ferguson will devote full time to his work as general manager.

PEKING, Aug. 22 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance appealed today for mutual efforts by China and the United States to find ways to move toward normalization of relations as he began four days of talks with Chinese leaders.

The dollar meandered in slow trading on foreign exchange markets yesterday as traders awaited tomorrow's announcement of United States trade figures for July, which are expected to be poor, The Associated Press reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 Justice Department lawyers are expected to ask a Federal judge in New York to modify or dissolve a sweeping order that would require the Government to produce records of all warrantless wiretaps, mail openings and break-ins by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents between 1947 and 1972, sources said today.

BOSTON, Aug. 23 Today, the 50th anniversary of the execution here of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, was a time for the men and women of the heavily Italian North End section to recollect an event, not a cause, and then only if someone reminded them.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 23 Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and five of his wealthy business friends were convicted today of some 18 counts each of mail fraud and racketeering after what experts said was one of the longest Federal jury deliberations in history.
ANNETTE BIERINGER and a friend were at the Brooklyn Academy of Music not long ago when Mrs. Bieringer's friend encountered difficulty in operating a new pair of opera glasses.

The Securities and Exchange Commission began action yesterday against Tolchin Instruments Inc. and two officers of the company for allegedly filing false financial statements with the S.E.C. for the years 1969-75.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 23 Indira Gandhi's defense minister, who was one of the two or three most important people in her government, was arrested today on charges of having misappropriated political party funds.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 23 (AP) John Osborne hit a homer run, fired a three-hitter and struck out 15 today powering El Cajon, Calif., to a 3-1 Victory over Hattiesburg, Miss., in the opening round of the Little League world series.

United Airlines, whose "friendly skies" has long been the airliner industry's best-known slogan, will begin a $7-million-plus four-month advertising campaign immediately after Labor Day. "We're going to give the 'friendly skies' a new dimension in size and stature." said Fred W. Heckel the company's vice president-advertising promotion.
The chairmen of two of the nation's airlines strongly attacked yesterday a bill pending in Congress that would fundamentally alter the Government's regulation of the air carrier industry.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 3 (AP) Thousands of policemen using dogs and tear gas battled thousands of students shouting "Down with the military regime" today in San Paulo's downtown area.

GUSH-HALAV, Israel Ayoub Mtanes, his family and friends laughed with embarrassment when they were asked the first thing they would do if Prime Minister Menaham Begin went through with his plan to fulfill their hopes of 29 years.
The stock market's modest rally on Monday lost its impetus yesterday as prices finished slightly lower in accelerated trading.
HIGHER prices for meats and grains sent the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City to a record level last week, according to the City Department of Consumer Affairs.

BALTIMORE Doubtless there must be a better source for steamed crabs than Obrycki's Restaurant, but it would be difficult to find. Obrycki's is a cozy, casual, friendly place with an expertly staffed kitchen that turns out, in addition to mouth-tingling (if not to say mouthburning) steamed crabs, formidably good crab cakes and crab imperial baked in the shell.

"EVER SINCE that 'Star Is Born' picture, it's really been grou pie-time," said Kris Kristofferson's manager, on the morning when an unidentified flying fan very nearly forced her way into the singer and actor's bedroom at 10:30 A.M. At midafternoon, in their motel near a turnpike near Philadelphia, the performer and his wife of four years, Rita Coolidge, were still fuming over the incident.

The New York Stock Exchange and the Pacific Stock Exchange said yesterday that they had tentatively agreed to an electronic link between their trading floors that would enable members of either exchange to shop both markets simultaneously for the best prevailing price.
Maurice H. Nadjari, the controversial former special state prosecutor, was restored to the ballot as the Republican candidate for Queens District Attorney by an appellate court yesterday.
The stock market's modest rally on Monday lost its impetus yesterday as prices finished slightly lower in accelerated trading.
HIGHER prices for meats and grains sent the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City to a record level last week, according to the City Department of Consumer Affairs.

BALTIMORE Doubtless there must be a better source for steamed crabs than Obrycki's Restaurant, but it would be difficult to find. Obrycki's is a cozy, casual, friendly place with an expertly staffed kitchen that turns out, in addition to mouth-tingling (if not to say mouthburning) steamed crabs, formidably good crab cakes and crab imperial baked in the shell.

The current movement to reinstate the kitchen as a focal point of the home and a room in which one would welcome, and even serve, guests is a trend New Yorkers find difficult to follow. Since World War II, developers in the city have looked to the kitchen as a place to conserve space, resulting in perplexing, challenging layouts. An eatin kitchen is still a boon.

Officials of the National Council of Churches yesterday reached an agreement with representatives of the council's clerical staff that could result in the first successful unionizing effort within a national church body.

THE UNUSUAL instrumentation of the Ron Carter Quartet piccolo bass, regular acoustic bass, piano and drums immediately sets the group apart from other contemporary jazz groups. But the mere novelty of the quartet is quickly forgotten in the face of the vir tuosity and interplay of the four musicians who are performing through Saturday at Sweet Basil, Bleecker Street at Seventh Avenue. They will return for another five-day engagement Sept. 6.

IF BY FALL , you're still looking "natural" in light lipstick and a discreet touch of rouge, you may be dating yourself. Al though fashions in face painting are slower to change than those in clothes, change they do: Cupid's bow mouths and hairline eyebrows mean the 30's and 40's. Pale lipstick and false lashes were the rage with miniskirts in the 60's. Streaks of brown bluser place you in the early 70's.

Clarence (Bubber) Jonnard, a major league baseball scout for 40 years and the metropolitan area scout for the New York Mets for the last 15 years, died yesterday at his home here. He was 79 years old.

"It's the new frontier in licensing." The man making this definitive state ment certainly ought to know whereof he speaks, since his name is Allan Stone, president of Hamilton Projects Inc., and one of the heavyweights of licensing in the United States. And the subject of his definitiveness is the licensing of corporate names and logos to other companies for non-competing products.

The U.S. Labor Party's candidate for Mayor of East Orange, N.J., was arrested while campaigning at a busy intersection yesterday after a motorist accused him of stealing a $500 diamond ring as he shook his hand.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 The Internal Revenue Service is investigating an allegation that an official of the Atlanta office of the Comptroller of the Currency ordered a bank examiner to give Bert Lance's bank in Calhoun, Ga., a "clean bill of health" in a 1976 review, sources familiar with the investigation said today.

TOKYO, Aug. 24 (AP) President Tito of Yugoslavia was greeted with "firm handshakes and warm hugs" by President Kim Il Sung of North Korea today as he arrived in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, for an official visit, the North Korean press agency reported.
KOBE, Japan, Aug. 21 The three groups of Vietnamese refugees sheltered in a Roman Catholic home in this port city have been recovering from their arduous escapes by small boat since May.
One of the Mets' boys of summer is concerned that he no longer is a boy.

Many experts are convinced that the ideal system of bidding is one based on the relay principle: One player takes charge and makes a series of minimum bids, or relays, requiring partner to describe his hand. At the end of the proceedings which are usually lengthy, one player knows virtually everything, and makes the final decision, while his partner knows virtually nothing.
SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 24 Tongsun Park, breaking months of silence, denied today repeated allegations that he had been an agent of the Government of South Korea.
After a minor retreat early yesterday, the credit market resumed the moderately strong and to some dealers, mystifying advance that began a little more than a week ago.

As Gene Mauch watched a heavy rain pelt the blue tarpaulin covering the Yankee Stadium infield before last night's game with the Yankees, he noted that his Minnesota Twins had not been rained out in 126 games this season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Panamanian officials say that an 11th-hour espousal by President Carter of a sea-level Atlantic-to-Pacific canal project severely jeopardized the negotiations over two Panama Canal treaties as they were about to be concluded earlier this month.
Will the Boston Red Sox follow the Chicago Cubs into oblivion as this 1977 season runs its erratic course?

YONKERS, Aug. 24 The horses were on the track, trotting and pacing. Watchers, clocks in hand, were near the track, timing them. But inside Yonkers Raceway, away from today's morning workouts, was the real action.
Andrew J. Melton Jr. will become chairman and chief executive officer of Dean Witter Company, one of the nation's largest securities firms, effective Sept. 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) Richard M. Nixon lost a court fight today to prevent the Government from searching through boxes he left behind to see if they contain information on the whereabouts of valuable gifts from foreign dignitaries.

The ideological blur of the New York City mayoral primary election the inability of any of the seven Democratic candidates to find an issue to separate the individual from the pack is reflected in The New York Times/Channel 2 poll.

MOGADHISHU, Somalia, Aug. 24 (Agence France-Presse) The red and green banner of the Somali guerrillas flies over the towns of Ethiopia's southern Ogaden region these days, and charred buildings and wrecked equipment at military bases attest the heavy fighting that ended there last month.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 24 (AP) Five regional stock exchanges agreed to continue discussions on establishing the first computerized national stock exchange after meeting in Chicago today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) The Carter Administration plans to step up enforcement of civil rights laws under a $257.5 million program offering funds to help school systems desegregate during the upcoming school year.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 24 (AP) The National Collegiate Athletic Association will rejoin the United States Olympic Committee after a bill reorganizing the committee is approved by Congress, N.C.A.A. officials said today.

The Consolidated Edison Company yesterday attributed more of the blame for the blackout of July 13 and 14 to human and mechanical failures within its own system, and less to the lightning strikes that started the emergency.

PEKING, Thursday, Aug. 25 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance discussed normalization of relations between China and the United States with Teng Hsiaoping, China's third-ranking leader, for two and a half hours yesterday but apparently made no progress on the critical issue of Taiwan.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 24 (AP) The United States men's basketball team defeated Brazil, 103-81, today and scored its sixth straight victory in the World University Games.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 24 (UPI) With delegates shouting "keep this a fighting men's outfit," the Veterans of Foreign Wars today voted to bar membership to women veterans who served overseas.

J. Noel Macy, former publisher of the Macy chain of newspapers in Westchester and Rockland Counties, died yesterday is Doctors' Hospital in Washington after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived in Washington and Antigua in the West Indies.
Corporate executives of the 1970's are turning the tables on their counterparts of the 1960's at least in the desks they choose for their homes away from home the office.
Lieut. Col. Gustav M. Minton Jr. a retired Air Force officer, died Tuesday at Herman Hospital in Bremerton, Wash. He was 76 years old and a resident of Lewiston, Idaho.

The Central Intelligence Agency has informed Columbia and Princetown Universities that they are among 86 institutions where secret research is believed to have ben conducted in an attempt by the agency to develop ways to manipulate the behavior of human beings, spokesmen for the universities said yesterday.
ONE of the true delights of gardening is the resident wildlife population it encourages (excluding rabbits in the vege table patch and raccoons in the corn).

The first woman to have been a judge at the Tokyo all-breed dog show will judge the regular classes at the New Jersey Boxer Club's independent specialty, which features 76 entries and is scheduled for Sept. 2 at the 4-H Center in Bridgewater, Township N.J.
Chris Evert and the Phoenix Racquets are the formidable barrier standing between the New York Apples and their second consecutive World Team Tennis championship.

Continued buying of soybeans by commercial interests, a group that includes exporters, attracted speculators to the bean pit yesterday. As a result soybean futures rose 7 to 12 cents a bushel, with the near months strongest.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 24 India has quietly terminated an agreement with the Soviet Union and turned instead to the United States for technical help in the expansion of the Bokaro steel plant in the eastern state of Bihar.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 24 (AP) Jimmy Carter was the first President not invited to a national convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars in 27 years, and he will probably not be invited next year either, according to a top official of the organization.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 24 Bernie Traurig, a 32-year-old professional, has ridden the winners of hundreds of jumper classes in horse shows, and he even has handled the first and second finishers on rare occasions.

ON THE TOWN at today's 10th annual Lower East Side Festival from noon to midnight, the public is invited to sample drama, dance and music events, along with displays of crafts and food prepared by the multi-ethnic community. The place is Henry Street between Jackson and Montgomery Streets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 The Internal Revenue Service is investigating an allegation that an official of the Atlanta office of the Comptroller of the Currency ordered a bank examiner to give Bert Lance's bank in Calhoun, Ga., a "clean bill of health" in a 1976 review, sources familiar with the investigation said today.
CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Aug. 24 (AP) One of nine black marines facing a renewed series of courts-martial in an attack on white marines pleaded guilty today to specifications against him.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 The United States and Britain have developed a plan for Rhodesia that would eliminate Prime Minister Ian D. Smith from leadership and involve a large United Nations peacekeeping force, Administration officials said tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 24 The New Jersey Department of Transportation estimated today that by 1982 Atlantic City would have four operating casinos that would be attracting 4,000 more vehicles each day than now reach the resort city.

While most people these days are looking for ways to enlarge their kitchen, Michael Christiano, an interior designer, shrank his walk-in kitchen to a pullman kitchenette.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 24 The Cosmos are a game away from presenting Pele with a championship in his last year of an illustrious 22-year career.
John A. Masiello Sr., reportedly a major Mafia figure in Westchester County, was charged yesterday with conspiracy to sell $750,000 in stolen securities.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 A White House spokesman said today that there had been discussions within the Government about limited American efforts to help settle the sectarian conflict in Northern Ireland.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 24 (AP) Tsai Tsung-hien fired a no-hitter and Chiang Chen-jung drove in four runs with four hits, including a home run, to lead the Li-Teh Little League of Taiwan to a 19-0 victory over Alberta, Canada, today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) After more than a year's moratorium, the Postal Service announced today plans to resume the gradual closing of rural post offices that it considers uneconomical.

THE succes fou of the season at Design Research has been a humble, old-fashioned item called Duck Deck. Duck Deck is a trendy name for the slatted platform that used to be called a duckboard or a trenchboard something the dictionary describes as a boardwalk running lengthwise on the bottom of a trench to keep the occupants out of accumulated mud and water.

Six years ago, Treasury Secretary John Connally stopped the world and got off. The Nixon Administration unilaterally withdrew from the international monetary system that had been constructed, to United States specifications, in 1944. Henceforth, Secretary Connally declared, the United States would not defend the value of the dollar in exchange with other currencies.

PEKING, Thursday, Aug. 25 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance discussed normalization of relations between China and the United States with Teng Hsiaoping, China's third-ranking leader, for two and a half hours yesterday but apparently made no progress on the critical issue of Taiwan.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24 Courageous and Enterprise were unable to race again today in the America's Cup trials because of adverse weather. It was the third day in a row that the two candidates for the role of Cup defender were stymied by weather. The two 12-Meter yachts are scheduled to race again tomorrow.

Imports of crude oil were down sharply to 6.3 million barrels a day for the week ended Aug. 19 from 7.3 million barrels a day in the preceding week, according to the latest petroleum figures released by the American Petroleum Institute.

The ideological blur of the New York City mayoral primary election the inability of any of the seven Democratic candidates to find an issue to separate the individual from the pack is reflected in The New York Times/Channel 2 poll.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Leon Jaworski, the new special counsel to the House ethics committee, said today that he still intended to question Tongsun Park, the Korean businessman who is a key figure in the committee's investigation of alleged influence-buying in Congress.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today announced the appointment of Terry L. Claassen as head of the agency's division of trading and markets.

Bill Brock, chairman of the Republican National Committee, came to New York City yesterday and backed State Senator Roy M. Goodman in both the Republican primary for Mayor, should one be held, and the November general election.

Putting together a rare combination of political views, Representative Herman Badillo and Abraham Hirschfeld will link their respective campaigns for the Democratic mayoral and City Council President nominations in an effort to stimulate their faltering candidacies.

NEWARK, AUG. 24 With the New Jersey gubernatorial election less than 11 weeks away, the five Democrats who garnered more than 67 percent of the vote in the June primary sit at dockside like members of a bewildered varsity rowing...
MOSCOW, Aug. 24 (AP) As Chinese and American officials met in Peking, the Soviet Union declared today that new Chinese attempts to improve relations with the West were a threat to world peace.

The Consolidated Edison Company yesterday attributed more of the blame for the blackout of July 13 and 14 to human and mechanical failures within its own system, and less to the lightning strikes that started the emergency.

WASHINGTON Water, a commodity typically in great abundance, is suddenly scarce in the Western United States. Public officials have used the drought to impose more regulations and controls on the lives of many Americans. Indeed, what is taking place in the San Francisco area may foreshadow a future of growing bureaucratic control over all Americans, especially those who live in the West.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) Five senators and 26 House members, most of them liberals, asked President Carter today to halt plans to produce and deploy the neutron bomb.
David R. Berkowitz, who is accused of being the 44-caliber killer, refused to admit to his name at his arraignment yesterday on three murder charges in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) The staff of the Senate Rules Committee has been ordered to gather information about the outside business activities of Robert O. Tiernan, a member of the Federal Elections Commission.

A few of the nation's largest public accounting firms, under prodding from Washington to divest themselves of parts of their practice unrelated to financial auditing, are quietly folding up their executive search operations.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 24 (UPI) A Federal judge ruled today that the public schools in Benton Harbor were guilty of maintaining racially segregated classrooms, and ordered school officials to change discriminatory policies.

AGREEMENT is rare among audio aficionados. Something about an endeavor premised upon the perennial pursuit of some thing better seems to attract people who share, if nothing else, a certain cantankerous individualism. This in itself is one of the pleasures of audio; for those impervious to minor abrasions, it provides a bracing atmosphere.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation wiretapped the National Lawyers Guild and may have broken into guild members' offices in Washington and New Haven in the late 1940's and early 1950's, according to newly disclosed files of the bureau.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 24 India has quietly terminated an agreement with the Soviet Union and turned instead to the United States for technical help in the expansion of the Bokaro steel plant in the eastern state of Bihar.
HOUSES MEAN different things to different people a showcase or a sanctuary; a place to hang one's hat; and some times, when the boiler goes or the roof needs to be fixed, a real nuisance.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 (AP) Sweltering heat and high humidity are being blamed for the deaths of 700 to 1,000 cows in the rich dairy country of the Chino Valley.

WEST BERLIN, Aug. 24 East Germany disclosed today that it had arrested a dissident East Berlin party official who won sudden fame in both parts of Germany through his criticism of Communist bureaucracy.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 24 (AP) Artillery duels between right-wing Christian militiamen and Palestinian guerrillas went on today in southern Lebanon. Authorities said that five persons had been killed in the exchanges and 20 wounded.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 24 (Reu ters) The Australian Government gave the go-ahead today for an international consortium to spend $3.4 billion to develop large natural gas deposits off the northwest Australian coast.

The Rockettes, the precision dancing ensemble that has long been a major draw at Radio City Music Hall, will make a rare appearance away from their home stage when they take part in the New York Dance Festival at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park on Sept. 7 and 8. This will mark the first time they have taken part in a dance festival.

Despite higher sales, earnings of J.P. Stevens Company fell 26.9 percent in the second fiscal quarter ended July 30 and 20.1 percent for the nine-month period, according to the unaudited report released yesterday. J.P. Stevens is the second-largest publicly owned textile manufacturer.

BOSTON, Aug. 24 (AP) A new study has found that deaths from heart disease are almost twice as common among teetotalers as among men who down one or two beers a day. The report also found no link between coffee drinking and heart disease.
With the approach of September, the Yankees and the Mets now have come into focus, thanks to each other. The Yankees are fighting to finish in first place, the Mets are fighting to finish.
A delegation of Associated Press executives and directors will make a two-week visit to China beginning Aug. 30.
The Jets practiced without Shafer Suggs again yesterday, but Coach Walt Michaels said the hard-luck fellow would make his 1977 debut in the secondary Saturday night in New Orleans.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 24 (AP) Dorsie W. Willis, the last survivor of a company of black soldiers that the Army discharged without honor in the Brownsville Incident of 1906, died today. He was 91 years old.
LIMA, Aug. 24 (Reuters) The Peruvian Government has agreed to pay $1.54 compensation to the Gulf Oil Corporation, whose assets in Peru were nationalized two years ago.

CAMDEN, Aug. 24 A Camden County Court judge reduced the bail today of Roxanne Gay, accused of killing her husband, Blenda, a defensive lineman for the Philadelphia Eagles football team, after she was allegedly beaten by him.

LEEWOOD, W. Va., Aug. 24 About a dozen angry and bitter young coal miners blocked the fork in the road here early today, threatening violence to any miner who dared drive past them to work on the midnight shift at any of the several mines in this area, 35 miles of winding road south of Charleston.

FIRE ISLAND, L.I. IN LATE May, our routine weekend inspection of the garden revealed the "monster." It was tall, green and stately. It was also uninvited, unidentifiable and firmly entrenched among the peas, beans and corn.
Heirs to the long-defunct New York Herald Tribune sued in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday to prevent a planned tabloid's use of the name "The Trib."

With the official opening of the city's public schools only weeks away, Chancellor Irving Anker met yesterday with the president of the Community School Board Association to try to resolve a dispute over the date of the first day of classes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (Reuters) The 27-nation economic conference in Paris this June nearly broke up in disarray because of a threatened walkout by some of the industrialized countries, three United States delegates to the meeting reported today.

ROME, Aug. 24 Twenty-nine months of imprisonment without trial in Switzerland and Italy ended today for a woman terrorist suspect who was ordered released by a court in Naples after a campaign on her behalf in which the Italian Government played a part.
TULSA, Okla., Aug. 24 (AP) Twenty-six black football players at the University of Tulsa boycotted football practice today for the second day in a row and faced being dropped from the team.

"Tribeca isn't SoHo, but you'll notice there are fixture fees for even those 'loftments,'" said the apartment-hunting young artist, who was really not speaking in tongues. "From what I've seen, though, a lot of places down here will never get a C. of O. to qualify for a J-51 from the city."

As a pushcart peddler, John Zervas tells you, he did what he had to do and then some: wearing four pairs of socks on a winter day, upgrading his cart with wheels costing $30 each, conquering evolutionary stages beyond the pretzel and Cracker Jack beginnings with the addition of stove and dry-ice units that opened up new profit vistas in hot dogs, sodas and flavored ices.

THERE will be a royal wedding in Monaco soon. How soon isn't known, but Prince Rainier III and his wife, Princess Grace, announced yesterday that their daughter, Princess Caroline, will marry a 37year-old French insurance broker.
Ninety percent of the New York City Police Department's available personnel reported for duty during last month's blackout emergency, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday.
Stanley Rodman Noble, retired president of Noble Noble Publishers, died yesterday at his Point O'Woods summer home on Fire Island. He was 72 years old and lived at North Tarrytown, N.Y.

BOSTON, Aug. 24 In the spring of 1976 The Tennessean of Nashville discovered that one of its copy editors, Mrs. Jacque Srouji, had been playing an undercover role for the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The publisher of the paper, John Seigenthaler, decided after much discussion that her activities had been inappropriate for a journalist. On May 5 he dismissed her.

OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 24 (UPI) A design has been chosen for a $100 million solar power tower and mirror system to be constructed near Barstow, Calif., the Energy Research and Development Administration announced today. The design was developed by the McDonnell Douglas Astronautics Company, of Huntington Beach, Calif., Honeywell Inc. and the Martin Marietta Corporation had also submitted proposals.
The city's Health Department has issued a warning against picking mushrooms from the ground. Eating mushrooms, which grow wild in the city in the late summer and early fall, can be fatal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Leon Jaworski, the new special counsel to the House ethics committee, said today that he still intended to question Tongsun Park, the Korean businessman who is a key figure in the committee's investigation of alleged influence-buying in Congress.

"I've always wanted my name over the door," Terence Conran said yesterday after learning that he can't legally use the name Habitat for his new shop, which will open coon in Citicorp Center at 575 Lexington Avenue near 50th Street. Mr. Conran is the founder and head of Habitat International, a chain of home furnishings emporiums in Europe.

Inner-City Equestrians Show Their Skills Looking a bit starry-eyed, 13-year-old Francina Wallace of East Harlem smiled as she recalled her recent introduction to horseback riding through a 4-H program on Staten Island.

POCKFT calculators, digital watches, and C.B.'s, the trio of consumer items that recently made your local retailers' sales figures jump, are small potatoes compared to the latest entry in the electronic 70's the microcomputer. Within the next five years, it wouldn't be surprising if 90 percent of all American homes had computers.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 24 (AP) The Government, in the process of running CocaCola out of India, said it had chosen the name "77" for its state-produced substitute cola drink.

ON SEPT. 18, 1927, the second of the national radio networks went on the air, broadcasting to 16 stations reaching as far west as St. Louis. Owned by United Independent Broadcasters Inc., it was a frail competitor to the first of the networks, NBC, and went on the air as the Columbia Phonograph Broadcasting System.

LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP) The new edition of Jane's Fighting Ships says the all-volunteer United States Navy has the edge over conscript rivals. The book also has high praise for what it calls the Soviet Union's "very powerful and well-knit fleet" and for France's achievement of global sea power.

The American Stock Exchange fared better in the second quarter than in the opening quarter this year, but earnings continued their decline with the net of $238,000 off 5.9 percent from the $253,000 a year ago, according to the Exchange's report issued yesterday.
COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Aug. 24 (AP) The Government began airlifting refugees to safety today from areas of clashes between minority Tamils and majority Sinhalese.
In a surprise move, Babcock Wilcox yesterday declared a special dividend of $2.50 a share, payable Oct. 3 to holders of record on Sept. 15.

WASHINGTON Few Government agencies this side of the K.G.B. have stirred images more forbidding than the small (less than $200 million a year in budget), new (operational in 1971), Federal entity with the long name (Occupational Safety and Health Administration) and familiar acronym (OSHA).

With what is believed to be depressing United States trade figures in the offing, the dollar plummeted on foreign exchange markets yesterday, falling to a record low against the Swiss franc, The Associated Press reported.

New York City auditors say that the Board of Education stockpiled a "huge" amount of new desks and chairs as well as a 40-year supply of 8-cent postcards while failing to order needed art and other supplies.
Weakness in glamour issues helped depress the stock market yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at its lowest level in more than 19 months.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 24 The Moneda presidential palace, where President Salvador Allende Gossens died under fire during the military rebellion of 1973, is being reconstructed, and President Augusto Pinochet said after a recent inspection that he might move his offices there.

The five-year-contract held by John Zervas, the so-called peddler king of Central Park, was canceled by New York City yesterday after Mr. Zervas had been arrested for allegedly fighting with another hot-dog vendor and with a police officer who intervened.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 24 (UPI) The long-awaited confrontation between the world's best 800-meter runners ended today with a clear victory for Alberto Juantorena of Cuba. He beat Mike Boit of Kenya at an international track and field meet.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 24 The ceremony could have been a scene from the Great Depression of the 1930's, but the W.P.A. doing the hiring today in the public library here was called Westchester's Partners in the Arts not the Works Progress Administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) Federal researchers announced today a new effort to find out why lightning knocks out power lines despite protective devices, blacking out cities and causing damage that increases electric bills.
DETROIT, Aug. 24 The pace of domestic new-car sales continued at record levels in mid-August as industry analysts continued to predict that 1977 would be among the best sales years of the decade.
Four years ago, The New York Times polled New Yorkers after the mayoral election and some of the questions were identical to those asked in today's survey.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 24 Down to the last 36 games in their fading title defense, the Cincinnati Reds behaved like a team in a desperate hurry tonight when they pounded out 15 hits and mauled the New York Mets, 11-4.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 President Carter intends to sign two Panama Canal treaties here on Sept. 7 in the presence of a large number of Latin American heads of state and government, Administration officials said today.

JERUSALEM Prime Minister Menahem Begin has none of the physical attributes of an Old Testament Prophet, but he seems guided by a semimystical reliance on the force of his own logic and vision. Yet his messianic characteristics are almost visibly tempered by a hard political sense.
It was a lawn mower that delayed 30 Long Island Rail Road trains with perhaps 3,000 passengers up to three hours Tuesday night and early yesterday, according to the railroad.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland has advised President Carter to counter a growing national wheat surplus by approving a 25 percent acreage-reduction program for 1978.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland has advised President Carter to counter a growing national wheat surplus by approving a 25 percent acreage-reduction program for 1978.
QUEBEC, Aug. 24 The Quebec government today moved a step closer to a vote on independence by issuing an outline of rules by which a referendum campaign would be held.

LEE, MASS. THE AVIDITY with which German ballet companies scoop up young American dancers is flattering but also a little alarming. While preparing for his role as Davies, the destitute parasite in Harold Pinter's "The Caretaker," the actor Craig Smith found he could study for the part at close hand simply by walking around the Bouwerie Lane Theater's East Village neighborhood.

Bluegrass has made such admirable progress in the metropolitan area in the last 10 years that there is hardly any new ground to conquer. After all, bluegrass is now heard in Fifth Avenue cafes, student auditoriums, the South Street Seaport and indoor music halls in New Jersey, even air-conditioned shopping centers in the suburbs. What else is left?
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 25 Wanted Punter, Must be able to do light office work.
After being briefed on the new Panama Canal treaties here yesterday by the chief American negotiators, Ronald Reagan declared that the Senate should refuse to approve them.

PLAINS, Ga., Aug. 25 (UPI) A makeshift device that Federal explosive experts belive is a remote control bomb was found 125 feet from the Plains Baptist Church in President Carter's hometown, the authorities said today.
The Central Park "hot-dog war" got hotter on the legal front yesterday, but peace reigned in the park.

THERE ARE books that are written at great personal risk. An author or his family and friends can be threatened if spoken words are committed to writing. "A State of Blood" by Henry Kyemba, to be published in the United States early next month, is such a book.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 25 Authoritative sources said today that there was no prospect whatever that Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's Government would accept a British-American proposal providing for a United Nations peacekeeping force to maintain order during a transition to black majority rule.

Myrna Gail Sameth, daughter of Mrs. Herman Sameth of New York and the late Mr. Sameth, was married last evening to Kenneth William Juster, a widower and son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Juster of New York. Rabbis Edward E. Klein and Harvey M. Tattelbaum officiated at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Friday, Aug. 26 (AP) Federal Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr. selected last week by President Carter to become director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, is scheduled to undergo surgery today at Methodist Hospital in Houston for a suspected blocked blood vessel in the stomach.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 25 In an atmosphere of secrecy and stringent security, Israel's Prime Minister, Menahem Begin, arrived here today and opened four days of talks with leaders of Rumania, the only Communist country that recognizes Israel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (Reuters) President Carter today announced the initiation of a review of the Federal Government's economci analysis and policymaking machinery to try to improve ways in which economic decisions are made and carried out.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 25 (Reuters) The Minister for Religious Affairs, Aharon Abu-Hatzeira, today proposed public services for inhabitants of the occupied Golan Heights and Sinai equal to those provided to Israelis.
Mayor Beame's package of tax-incentive bills to spur business expansion in the city was passed by the City Council yesterday by a vote of 37 to 0.

Dr. Charles Murray Gratz, a retired orthopedic surgeon and a member of the staff of one of the earliest flying clinics, died Wednesday at the Northport (L.I.) Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 78 years old and a resident of Port Washington, L.I.

ANNAPOLIS Md., Aug. 25 The Attorney General of Maryland ruled today that Lieut, Gov. Blair Lee 3d could not assume the title of Governor when Marvin Mandel, who was convicted Tuesday on Federal corruption charges, is sentenced and removed from office on Oct. 7, because Mr. Mandel could reclaim the office if he is vindicated on appeal.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 25 (UPI) Andrew Young, the United States chief delegate to the United Nations, today rejected armed struggle as a means to end South Africa's racial segregation policies saying: "It is not necessary, to kill the patient to cure the disease."

IT'S NOT EVERY DAY that you can see a genuine authenticated fake in a reputable Manhattan gallery. But as of now and through Sept. 10 at the A.A.A. Gallery, 663 Fifth Avenue, at 53d Street, you can see a whole wall of them as part of an exhibition called "The Discerning Eye."
AMSTERDAM, Aug. 25 The United States had mixed results today in the semifinals of the women's and lightweight men's races at the world rowing championships.

BOSTON, Aug. 25 The computer revolution seems endless. Every six months, a new product comes along that outdates everything before it. The latest is the microcomputer, based on the same technology as the pocket calculator but capable of putting a powerful computer into homes and small businesses.

Col. Jacob M. Arvey, the Democratic boss of Chicago in the late 1940's who started the political careers of Paul H. Douglas and Adlai E. Stevenson Jr. and was instrumental in Harry S. Truman's narrow Presidential victory in 1948, died of heart failure yesterday in Weiss Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 81 years old.

The nation's chain stores moved massive quantities of merchandise in July and finished the month with a gain of 16.4 percent from July of 1976. For the January-through-July period the chains reported a gain of 11.9 percent over the comparable 1976 period.

The United Technologies Corporation withdrew yesterday from the battle to acquire control of the Babcock Wilcox Company, one of the nation's leading manufacturers of steam generating equipment and other industrial products. The apparent winner of the fight is J. Ray McDermott Company of New Orleans, a major producer of offshore oil rigs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) The State of Alaska is willing to guarantee up to $900 million in loans for construction and materials for the El Paso Alaska Company's proposed natural gas pipeline, it was learned today. The pipeline is one of two alternatives under consideration for bringing Alaska North Slope natural gas to American consumers.

The oil industry was elated by the surprise court decision yesterday to lift the injunction on Atlantic offshore drilling, but the ruling will not mean a sudden influx of oil dollars to the Northeast, industry sources said.

Commercial banks substantially increased their borrowing from the Federal Reserve during the week ended Wednesday, heightening speculation that the central bank would raise the discount rate this afternoon.
Frederick Tompkins, a retired manufacturer of building materials, died Wednesday at Orange Memorial Hospital in Orange, N.J. He was 82 years old and lived in East Orange.

TRENTON, Aug. 25 A brief sickout by nurses and other union members that began last midnight at Marlboro State Psychiatric Hospital appeared to have ended late today after a day of negotiations over work schedules and staffing arrangements.

Little-known players carried off the honors in the first day of play at the New York-New Jersey Regional Championships at McAfee, N.J., Wednesday. The women's team title went to a Connecticut foursome, Lisa Burke of Hamden, Myrna Lurie of Wallingford, Julia James of Rocky Hill and Frances Esposito of North Branford, who swept to victory with a 90 percent score.

MIDLAND, Mich., Aug. 25 (AP) The Dow Chemical Company announced today that it was trying to recall all stocks of a potent pesticide suspected of causing sterility in the company's employees and cancer in animals.

AREA A Ralph Stork of Captain Andy's Marina in Margate, N.J., says fishing is "at the peak for the year." He says the water temperature has dropped from 70 to 57 in a week, bringing out large schools of blues, fluke and weakfish. The blues and weakfish have been abundant in front of Ocean City and down to the Sea Isle Lump.

Three children of a woman killed by self-styled "Bishop" DeVernon LeGrand were removed yesterday by the police from his former Brooklyn "church" and put into the custody of their maternal grandmother, police officials reported.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 20 (Reuters) An apparent hard line on peace with Israel adopted by Palestinian leaders meeting in Damascus today was viewed with tacit official satisfaction here.

LONDON, Aug. 26(AP) A British television documentary in which a hidden police camera recorded a woman urging her aged mother to commit suicide has touched off a widespread row over the right to privacy and ethics in television and criminal justice.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 26,(AP) John Demjanjuk, a resident of the United States since 1952, has been accused by Federal officials of participating in the commission of World War II atrocities while he served as a guard at a German concentration camp in Poland.

HONG KONG, Aug. 26 (UPI) The Central Committee of Vietnam's Communist Party, facing serious nationwide food shortages and admitting "big mistakes in leadership," has begun a program to speed up agricultural development.
