WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP)-The Securities and Exchange Commission said that its report on New York City's finances was one of its most complex ever. It was also one of its most closely guarded.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 26 (AP) Tommy Kramer threw his first touchdown pass as a pro, and Duck White and Sammy White each scored touchdowns as the Minnesota Vikings overwhelmed Miami, 33-7, in a National Football League exhibition game tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 26 From the morning raising of the blue and white Quebec flag with its graceful fleur de lis until long after the sun had set last night, Quebec Day here celebrated a growing love affair between La Belle Province and the Jersey Shore.

Abraham Koppleman, the president of H.P. Koppleman, wholesale distributors of magazines, books and newspapers in Hartford, died yesterday at Hartford Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Hartford.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Patricia Roberts Harris, said today that she had asked the Council of Wage and Price Stability to investigate "an inexplicable but dramatic" rise in lumber prices, which have increased as much as 28 percent since July 1.

The Kansas City Royals, who won the American League's Western Division title a year ago, are making a run at the top, again, however belatedly.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 26 Angel Cordero, the meeting's leading jockey, was more ebullient than usual this afternoon after bringing home Townsend B. Martin's Sherry Peppers as the winner of the $53,900 Spinaway at Saratoga.

As the clock struck 11 P.M. on Dec. 31, 1981, President Carter's telephone rang in the Oval Office. Patrick Caddell, his polling authority, gave him the great news. At precisely 10:32 P.M., the American people had undergone a complete recovery of faith in their government.

As part of its investigation into the securities transactions of New York City, the Securities and Exchange Commission polled investors about how much they knew about the city's financial condition when they bought city notes. Of the more than 160,000 individual investors who owned the major portion of the city's outstanding long-term bonds, more than 500 of them were polled to determine the adeouacv of city's disclosure.

PINEHURST, N.C., Aug. 26 (AP) Grimly determined Hale Irwin responded today to what he called "a must-win situation" with a spectacular nineunder-par 62 in the second round of the $250,000 Hall of Fame Classic. That gave him the lead by five strokes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (Reuters) Senator Barry Goldwater said today that President Carter would be risking impeachment if he unilaterally tried to break off the defense treaty with Taiwan.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 26 In weather that sent the spectators running for shelter from torrential downpours and reappearing to gaze at rainbows, the semifinal rounds of the men's elite, or heavyweight, world championship races were rowed today on the Bosbaan course.

LAS VEGAS, Aug. 26 (AP) After four years of rumors, there was almost a sigh of relief today as officials at the University of Nevada-Las Vegas formally acknowledged that the school's basketball program had been placed on a two-year probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The N.C.A.A. issued the suspension yesterday.
A union dispute among television camera crews delayed Mayor Beame's news conference for 45 minutes yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26,(AP) Thou sands of commuters had to be switched from one route of Washington's new Metrorail subway system to buses today after dams at a subway construction project collapsed, flooding a partly completed station.
VAN, Turkey This area of Turkish Kurdistan once had its great moments in history but now it is a nowhere place and therefore eminently suited as a point from which to write about Cambodia.

Lawyers for the Crane Company said the company was prepared to divest itself of its welding-fittings business in St. Louis in order to allay objections by the Chemetron Corporation to a proposed tender offer.
HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Aug. 26 A sniper with a rifle killed six persons here today, firing into backyards as he walked along a railroad track, the police said.

Phyllis Gleitsman Gross, co-owner of Hayes Registry Inc., the city's largest theatrical telephone-answering service, died Tuesday of cancer at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. She was 44 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) Former President Richard M. Nixon was described today as angry and his wife, Pat, as deeply hurt by implications that they intentionally kept some valuable foreign gifts that belong to the Government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 The Securities and Exchange Commission's staff report that today charged New York City's underwriters with misleading the investing public, said some of them were reducing or eliminating their own holdings of the city's securities at the same time they were urging small investors to purchase the city's debt.

OTTAWA, Aug. 26 Six prominent op position members of the Canadian Parli ment have filed an action in the Ontario Supreme Court challenging the legality of a Government order prohibiting the disclosure of information on an international uranium cartel sponsored by Canada.

Winn-Dixie Stores Inc., the nation's fourth largest supermarket chain, yesterday reported a 6.4 percent drop in earnings for the fourth fiscal quarter ended June 25, but an 11.7 percent gain for the full year. The quarterly earnings decline was the first since the fourth quarter a year ago.
PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 6 (AP) A science boom aboard Voyager 2 is pretty much where it ought to be, scientists say, but they are not sure it will stay there.

The Community Services Administration, like the Office of Economic Opportunity which preceded it, represents an innovation in Federal efforts to help the poor. Most of its money $800 million this year goes to 850 local organizations where the poor or their representatives are to some extent entrusted with the responsibility of using it as they see fit. Houses have been renovated, minority businesses assisted, poor people involved in local politics.

TOKYO, Aug. 26 (AP) Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance briefed Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda on his China trip today, and Japanese sources said Mr. Fukuda extended an invitation to President Carter to pay an official visit to Japan.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug, 26 (UPI) Top-seeded Jimmy Connors, hitting deep the whole match, advanced to the quarterfinals of the $125,000 United States Pro tennis championship tonight with a 6-4, 6-3, victory over Stan Smith, seeded 10th.

Carol Bellamy must go begging for attention, trailing the Philharmonic on its summer park tour and working the crowds with her politician's fugue, looking for voters' hands in all sorts of groups, from the naked on Fire Island to the wizened in the city's sunset warrens.

TOKYO, Aug. 26, (Reuters) Japanese police said tody they suspected a large international crime syndicate of passing forged Bank of Tokyo travelerschecks totaling $127,547 in 15 countries in the last year.
ALBANY, Aug. 26 (AP) An American bald eagle found last month on the shore of Lake Ontario died of "a virtual potpourri of pesticides," according to a preliminary autopsy.

ROME, Aug. 26 The Italian Government today appealed publicly to West Germany to take measures against Lieut Col. Herbert Kappler, the Nazi war criminal who escaped from a Rome military hospital last week, that would express condemnation of "a past that cannot be forgotten."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 A White House spokesman today confirmed a disclosure that Budget Director Bert Lance used a single block of bank shares as collateral for two separate loans from two different banks at the same time. The spokesman called the action "an innocent mistake."

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 26 The United States Steel Corporation announced today an austerity program under which it is not filling jobs caused by retirement and keeping new employment of administrative personnel "at an absolute minimum."

CAPE TOWN, Aug. 26 (UPI) A diamond dealer, who suffered acid burns in the face and told the police last week that he had been robbed of $3.5 million wort hof diamonds, has been arrested as a suspect in the theft, the police said today.

TRENTON, Aug. 26 William F. Hyland, the State Attorney General, announced recommendations today for tightening state controls over mercantile and alcoholic-beverage licensing in Atlantic City in a further effort to "bar undesirable elements" attracted by the advent of legalized gambling there.

What entertainer of Nijinsky's and Pavlova's time, for instance, can match their legend?

BOSTON, Aug. 26 Sword-swallowers, clowns, office workers, mimes, families, tourists, area residents, marching bands, street musicians and a local dignitary or two turned out here today to celebrate the opening of the South Market in the Faneuil Hall Marketplace.

An encouraging armistice has been reached in the battle over plans to control automobile pollution in New York City. There will be no tolls on the East River bridges. There will be no ban on parking so draconian as to destroy the city's economy. There will be some modest steps taken to improve traffic flow and mass transit.

Moscow, Aug. 26 Tne historic voyage of the nuclear icebreaker Arktika to the North Pole last week was part of a continuing effort to develop a shorter shipping route across the northern Soviet coastline, the expedition's leader said today.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 26 (AP) The United States men's and women's basketball teams won their semifinals in the World University Games today. The men defeated Czechoslovakia, 85-69, and the women rallied to upset Bulgaria, 87-84. Both will face the Soviet Union in the finals tomorrow.

A Brooklyn administrative judge yesterday announced changes in the selection of receivers, guardians and other court-appointed officials to remove "any appearance of impropriety as well as any unjustifiable criticism" of court appointments.

Southampton, L.I, Aug. 26 Golf was a wonderland of green beauty and tradition spread over 18 magnificent holes in perfect weather at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club today as the 26th biennial Walker Cup matches opened with unexpectedly one-sided success for the United States.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 26 This city's welfare director plans to require able-bodied non-English-speaking welfare recipients to take English classes or lose their welfare checks, even thcugh the state's Social Services Commissioner has doubts about the project's legality.

The Bread and Puppet Theater, headed by Peter Schumann, will return to the New York scene from its home base in Glover, Vt., with a new production, "Masanielio." HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Saturday, Aug. 27 A sniper shot six persons to death yesterday as he wandered along the railroad tracks that run through this country town in North Jersey.

Martine Pr d'homme and Frederick Hendrik Dulles, a New York lawyer, were married yesterday at the American Cathedral in Paris. The Rev. Frederick B. Northup performed the ceremony.

In a tribute to Groucho Marx, who died last week, WNEW-TV, Channel 5, will pre-empt most of its afternoon and evening schedule tomorrow to telecast, in their entirety, four feature films starring the Marx Brothers.

How many young people squirmed through "The Sound of Music" in the 1960's, making faces as their dates or parents watched and listened in rapture? How many endured "Mary Poppins" dreaming of the Rolling Stones? One thing is certain. Those who loved these movies have not forgotten. One could sense their expectations this week at the Westchester Premiere Theater, where Julie Andrews, the star of both films, has been performing.

NEWARK, Aug. 26 Thousands of consumers who heat their homes with natural gas supplied by the New Jersey Natural Gas Company or who use gas for cooking purposes will get a onetime credit of about $32.50 as a result of an order by the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners.
The Indianapolis Fairgrounds and Yonkers Raceway are 732 miles apart, but Billy Haughton, his son Peter and Joe O'Brien will be at both harness racing sites today, hunting for prestige and money.

Suddenly the motor oil business is bubbling with activity. The Exxon Corporation this week announced a new motor oil that, the company asserts, will increase gasoline mileage by an average of 4.5 percent. In July, the Atlantic Richfield Company introduced a premium oil that promises similar gains, as well as less engine wear. And, last year, the Mobil Corporation came out with a motor oil that also raises gasoline mileage.

Clay Felker, who founded New York and New West magazines and then lost them to Rupert Murdoch in a financial imbroglio last winter, bought Esquire magazine yesterday with the help of one of Mr. Murdoch's British newspaper competitors.

Frank Langella, who was last on Broadway in Edward Albee's "Seascape," will return in the title role of "Dracula," the John BalderstonHamilton Dean dramatization of Bram Stoker's vampire story. When first produced on Broadway in 1927, "Dracula" starred Bela Lugosi, who went on to make a classic film version in 1931.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 26 The British Foreign Secretary, Dr. David Owen, and Andrew Young arrived here tonight to present a British-American plan for settling the conflict in Rhodesia before a skeptical assembly of Rhodesian black nationalists and key leaders of black African nations.
LONDON, Aug. 26 A strike by air traffic control assistants played havoc with travel plans throughout Britain today but numerous flight cancellations helped prevent congestion at airports.

Mayor Beame lashed out yesterday at the Securities and Exchange Commission's report as a "shameless, vicious po- litical document" and "a hatchet job," while his opponents in the Democratic mayoral primary took views ranging from condemnatory to sympathetic.

HOUSTON, Aug. 26 A Chicago businessman boards a Braniff Airways flight at Chicago's O'Hare Field late one afternoon and arrives at the sprawling Dallas-Fort Worth Airport two hours later. He rides a bus to downtown Dallas, meets clients for dinner, then takes a taxicab to Love Field, the smaller and older Dallas airport that is closer to the city's center.

After months of discussions, four regional stock exchanges the Boston, Cincinnati, Midwest, and Pacific Coast Stock Exchange agreed today to establish a common electronic linkup and trading system. The announcement follows by two days an agreement between the New York Stock Exchange and the Pacific Stock Exchange to link their trading floors electronically.

OTTAWA, Aug. 26 (Reuters) Canada had a seasonally adjusted trade surplus of $328 million in July after recording a revised $91 million surplus in June, Statistics Canada reported today.

President Carter's efforts to improve deteriorating Soviet-American relations seem to be achieving results. Personal attacks on Mr. Carter in the Soviet press have ceased. Both sides are muting public differences.

In an apparent publicity stunt for his latest literary effort, an aspiring playwright clad in a wetsuit and flotation gear placed his unpublished manuscript on a railing of the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday afternoon and plunged 130 feet into the East River. He was critically injured.

PEKING, Aug. 27. The scene is a packed movie theater with the audience intently watching "Woman Pilot," a film about female mliers in the Chinese Air Force. At a critical moment,` a male pilot, who has established "a close comradely relationship" with the heroine, dies in a training accident.
Walter Taylor can stop inking out his name on his wine bottles for the time being.

DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 29 (UPI) Allegations that Ford Pintos have faulty fuel tanks that make them firetraps and cause the death of 70 or more people each year is pure exaggeration, the auto maker said today.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 29 X-rays of Richard Todd's jammed right thumb were negative, the Jets announced today, and Coach Walt Michaels had already answer on the quarterback's availability against the Giants next Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29(AP) Every year some 7,000 immigrants abandon more than their homelands when they become American citizens. They leave behind their name as well.
Walter Taylor can stop inking out his name on his wine bottles for the time being.

The Mets recalled Jackson Todd from their Tidewater farm club in the International League yesterday. The rookie right-hander, who had won his first two games before losing his next three, was sent to Tidewater on July 29 after the Mets had reactivated Bob Myrick. Todd had a 2-3 won-lost record in nine games with the Tides.

GOTEBORG, Sweden, Aug. 29 (AP) The proposed merger of Sweden's two auto manufacturers, Volvo and SAAB, has been called off. The merger would have been the biggest in Swedish history and would have created one of Europe's largest auto manufacturing companies.
Paris, Aug. 29 The European currency "snake" is getting thinner and thinner, largely because West Germany's economy is getting fatter and fatter.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 29 The battle to protect and possibly enlarge the world's dwindling supply of fertile land reached a key stage today as politicians and scientists from more than 90 countries met here for the opening session of the United Nations Conference on Desertification.
HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Aug. 29 Emile Pierre Benoist, who killed himself after murdering six persons at random last Friday, was ordered 10 months ago to undergo psychiatric treatment, but he did not.
President Carter's decision yesterday to reimpose the old soil bank program now termed a set-aside plan came as no surprise to the grain trade.

The Rev. Louis R. Gigante, after testifying yesterday for several hours before a special grand jury investigating his relationship to organized crime figures, said he would go to prison rather than violate the right of priestly confidentiality. The jury is looking into reports of bribery, official misconduct and conspiracy relating to "favored treatment" for prisoners in the custody of the New York City Department of Correction.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 29 (AP) The Australian Government has ordered a thorough investigation into the allegation that Australian beef may have been responsible for an outbreak of salmonella food poisoning in the Northeastern United States.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 29 Joe Pisarcik, a 25-year-old National Football League rookie with a bad cold, was the unlikely hero tonight as the Giants returned to their home of champions and registered their first victory of the year and their first ever in an overtime game.

MOSCOW, Aug. 29 The most prominent Soviet scientist to apply to emigrate to Israel said today he feared that a recent newspaper article denouncing him might be only the beginning of an officially sanctioned campaign to discredit his reputation.

THETFORD CENTER, Vt. The ads show virile fellows swinging their soap-on-a-rope in a locker room, or standing explorer-like in a rural landscape. They give off almost visible waves of delicious scent: English Leather, or Eau Sauvage, or Acqua di Selva. An admiring and beautiful woman often stands a pace or two behind, though they ignore her.

The freewheeling lunacy of the Kat's Pajamas Sunday evening at the Cubiculo stemmed from the boisterous model of "Hellzapoppin" rather than the more decorous structure of traditional concert dance. Conceived and performed by Debra Zalkind and Cameron Burke, it was so outrageous in delineating character that the results were closer to caricature than portraiture.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 The Department of Health, Education and Welfare disclosed today that Federal auditors had begun checking the way Haward University spent about $200 million in Government grants and contracts over the last three years.
PEKING, Aug. 29 One of China's top leaders said today that "the Chinese people are quite unhappy" at the reluctance of President Carter to give up "his old friend" Taiwan.
MOSCOW, Aug 29 (UPI) China's new Ambassador to the Soviet Union, Wang Yo-ping, arrived by train from Peking today to fill a post that had been vacant for more than a year.

LONDON, Aug. 29 London's Notting Hill Carnival, the largest celebration for Caribbean immigrants in Europe, ended in violence tonight. More than 100 persons were injured, including 30 police officers. Twenty-seven others were hurt in a brief outbreak last night.

CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, Aug. 29 The Wildwood Beach Patrol, which was dismissed after ignoring a back-to-work order after a one-day sickout, rejected today an offer by the state to drop charges against 58 of the lifeguards if four others would plead guilty to contempt of court.

The Securities and Exchange Commission staff report that accused Mayor Beame and half a dozen of the city's largest banks of misleading the investing public also had critical words for Moody's and Standard Poor's, the nation's two largest bond rating agencies.

With the increasing loss of advertisers for ABC-TV's controversial new comedy, "Soap," officials of leading advertising agencies in New York have expressed concern about the effectiveness of recent campaigns by pressure groups to prevent companies from advertising on television programs.

The Securities and Exchange Commission report on New York City's financial dealings has set off a debate between the commission and city officials over who is telling the truth about what occurred ...

Trial by television, with the defendant watching on a screen at home or in a hospital, would deprive the defendant of his rights and would make him "in many respects a spectator at his own trial," a State Supreme Court justice in Queens ruled yesterday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission report on New York City's financial dealings has set off a debate between the commission and city officials over who is telling the truth about what occurred ...

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 29 A proposal to suspend and eventually deactivate the forces opposing each other in the Rhodesian guerrilla war continued to be the main sticking point today as British and American diplomats presented their settlement package to Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa, who holds the key to Rhodesian acceptance of the plan.

Another treatment for obesity is about to join the weighty list of painless remedies for shedding excess poundage. This treatment, while not yet tested on humans, appears to be the dieter's dream: It offers weight loss without a drastic reduction in food consumption. All this may someday be accomplished by simply swallowing a tablespoon or two of a colorless, tasteless liquid after each meal.

DAWSON, Ga., Aug. 29 Confessions and statements allegedly implicating five black youths in the murder of an elderly white ranch foreman were ruled inadmissible as evidence today by a judge who cited a technical error in procedure.

DETROIT, Aug. 29 There had been a quick look at the star of the show the night before. After the news conferences were over, and the out-of-town visitors and local television personalities had eaten cocktail-party hush puppies and quiche Lorraine, after, dinner was over, but before the dancing girls came onstage, someone flipped back a white sheet that covered one of the American Motors Corporation's new 1978 Concord automobiles.

State Senator Joseph Galiber and Robert Munoz, the former director of a Bronx drug rehabilitation program, along with three other persons, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiracy to defraud the United States through a real-estate scheme financed by antipoverty funds.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 29 (AP) President Mohammed Siad Barre of Somalia has flown to the Soviet Union, the major supplier of arms to both the Somalians and their Ethiopian rivals, at the invitation of the Soviet Government, the Mogadishu radio reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 An internal Pentagon analysis strongly criticizes the Navy for what it views as buying only one-third of the new planes it needs because it spends too much on the costly F-14 Tomcat fighter.

LONDON, Aug. 29 (Reuters) Filbert Bayi of Tanzania, late world-record holder in the 1,500-meter run, was beaten at a mile today, and then disclosed he might run a mile against the Olympic 1,500-meter champion John Walker of New Zealand in Vancouver, British Columbia, Sept. 17. Walker holds the mile world record of 3 minutes 49.4 seconds. Bayi's 1,500 record is 3:32.2.

For years Congressmen unable to get the truly vital news of their activities back to the home folks because of intransigent, stupid or vicious reporters have been solving the problem by writing their own newsletters to constituents. President Carter is now having their age-old problem with the press. You may receive his first newsletter any day now. It will read more or less as follows:

As a priest and a politician, Louis R.Gigante operates in two realms where substance and appearances can crosshatch and mystify. He handles water and wine and bread and claims there actually is a God somewhere. He also pockets and delivers the worldliest clubhouse contracts for City Hall disposition, hustling eye-on-the-sparrow favors and backslapped fealties for his followers in the impoverished South Bronx.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, making its first comment on a critical Securities and Exchange Commission report issued Friday, denied yesterday that it had "dumped" New York City securities in late 1974 and early 1975.
MEMPHIS, Aug. 29 (AP) Four men who the police say were plotting to steal Elvis Presley's body and hold it for ransom were arrested early today outside the cemetery where the singer is entombed.

Dr. Levester Cannon, director of New York State's often controversial Willowbrook Developmental Center on Staten Island for the last 13 months, said yesterday that he would leave the center to become Ohio's Commissioner of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities on Sept. 25.

DETROIT, Aug. 29 Federal and state courts were asked in two lawsuits today to strike down as unconstitutional a zoning ordinance in suburban Oak Park that bans posting of all signs on residential properties, on the ground that the ordinance violates the First Amendment's right to freedom of speech.
Buoyed by strength in many of the depressed blue-chip issues, the stock market posted a broad advance yesterday in the second slowest trading of the year.
The Federal Reserve Board voted yesterday to increase the discount rate, the interest rate the central bank charges on loans to commercial banks, to 5 percent from 5 percent.

"Exploration" was the word used by both Secretary of State Vance and Chinese Prime Minister Hua Kuo-feng to describe Mr. Vance's recent four-day visit to Peking. There were no agreements to sign, not even a communique to read, but the two seemed satisfied and so should Americans concerned that good relations be maintained with the People's Republic and that the future of Taiwan be settled peacefully.

It's now evident, if anyone ever doubted it, that deep and emotional hostility to the "giveaway" of the Panama Canal presents the Carter Administration and the Senate with a powerful challenge. Perhaps even more so than in the case of the Vietnam War, the test is whether the American people, governed as they are, can adapt themselves sensibly to a changing international order.

Representative John M. Murphy, Democrat of Staten Island, yesterday vehemently denounced charges by Republican National Chairman Bill Brock that Mr. Murphy had suppressed a General Accounting Office report because it was unfavorable to a bill he backed.

Nancy Hanks, retiring as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts after eight productive years, is not herself a practitioner of any of the arts. But there is one thing on which all are agreed. Miss Hanks has carried the techniques of political persuasion to a level that is itself high art.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) The National Labor Relations Board is making it costlier for employers and unions to discharge workers illegally or otherwise discriminate against them.
SAN DIEGO, Aug, 29 (AP) Inez Keller Fuite, who was in the first group of airline stewardesses to fly 47 years ago, died Friday. She was 71 years old.
Approximately 5,000 fans mobbed the Cosmos when the players arrived on a chartered plane at Kennedy International Airport last night from Portland, Ore., where they had won the soccer championship.
WEST BERLIN, Aug. 29 (AP) Sarah Kirsch, one of East Germany's most popular poets, has arrived in West Berlin as a self-exile, a spokesman for the Association of German Writers said today.
LONDON, Aug 29 (Reuters) The dowager Countess Alexander of Tunis, widow of Field Marshal Earl Alexander of Tunis, has died at the age of 72.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 29 (AP) Governor Carey took his first look today at construction for the 1980 Winter Olympics to be held in this Adirondack Mountain village.
HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Aug. 29 Emile Pierre Benoist, who killed himself after murdering six persons at random last Friday, was ordered 10 months ago to undergo psychiatric treatment, but he did not.
JOHANNESBURG, Aug 39 (Reuters) Justice Minister James Kruger said today that the police had smashed a guerrilla network plotting an invasion of South Africa.

Billy Martin, the Yankee manager, didn't want Whitey Herzog, the Kansas City manager, to go fishing in the pond they share in Kansas City. "He would have gotten ahead of me," Martin said, explaining why the Yankees made the Royals pay a one-day visit to Yankee Stadium yesterday to play a makeup game.

A 34-year-old policeman, responding to a 911 emergency call about a man with a gun was killed by a shotgun blast yesterday as he and his partner tried to enter a room in a shabby brownstone house in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. The partner killed one man in the room and wounded another.

DETROIT, Aug. 2 The Michigan Supreme Court today reinstated a city crminal court judge it demoted last week after the judge repeatedly refused to participate in a broad program to reduce court backlogs and operating expenses through greater use of plea bargaining.

DURBAN, South Africa, Aug. 23 Until the security police came for him on March 18 last year, Joseph Masobiya Mdluli was a minor player in the South African racial drama. A semieducated black, long in trouble over suspected activities on behalf of the African National Congress, he made his living hawking clothes in a black town outside this coastal city.

More magazine, a monthly review of journalism that started in 1971, is to be sold today to James Adler, president of Congressional Information Services Inc. of Washington, according to Michael S. Kramer, its publisher and editor.

The 100 biggest national advertisers spent $7.7 billion for advertising and promotion last year, up 20 percent from 1975. This increase to a new record was the largest in the last 22 years, according to an annual tabulation made by Advertising Age.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 28 Broad public school desegregation programs are expected to begin this school year or next in nearly every major city in this state, marking the end of decades of dual education systems. But, as implementation approaches, confusion, uneasiness and racial tension are growing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 George Meany, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and usually a hard-liner on international affairs, said today he supported President Carter's treaty ceding the Panama Canal to the Panamanian Government at the end of the century.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 29 (AP) Manuel Orantes defeated Jaime Fillol, 6-3, 6-0, 6-1, in the semifinals of the $125,000 United States Pro tennis championships today.
Permission for the Concorde to use Kennedy International Airport was delayed yesterday by a Federal appeals court that will hear arguments Sept. 19 in the long dispute over the supersonic jetliner.

Levi Strauss Company, the nation's largest apparel manufacturer and largest apparel advertiser, has a widelyknown brand name in Levi's. It probably would rank among the dozen most recognizable brands in America and its worldwide recognition may be almost as strong.
PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 29 (AP) The North American Soccer League announced at its meetings here today that it would increase its schedule to 30 games a team, from 26, next season.
PEKING, Aug. 29 One of China's top leaders said today that "the Chinese people are quite unhappy" at the reluctance of President Carter to give up "his old friend" Taiwan.
Dr. Robert Schatten, professor of mathematics at Hunter College since 1961, died last Friday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 29 (AP) President Nicolae Ceausescu and Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel ended talks today that the official Rumanian press agency said had furthered relations between the countries despite differing views on Middle East issues.

HOUSTON, Aug. 29 Dr. John Hill and his wife, Joan Robinson Hill, ranked among Houston's social leaders in the 1960's. He was a prominent plastic surgeon, she was a noted horsewoman. They lived in River Oaks, Houston's most exclusive neighborhood.

The Securities and Exchange Commission report charging that investors in New York City notes had been "misled" in 1974-75 is likely to delay the sale of new notes planned for October the first since the fiscal crisis broke and in general make it more difficult for the city to re-enter the credit markets this year, several financial experts said yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 29 Currency markets were thrown into confusion in Europe today and political tensions flared, following today's decision by Sweden to devalue its currency by 10 percent; Norway and Denmark then followed suit with 5 percent devaluations.

It could be argued that Flushing Airport in Queens doesn't make enough money for New York City and that by turning the 80-acre site over to property developers more revenue could be generated. But there are other less easily measured benefits derived from this piece of land that in more than 52 years of operation has cost nary one cent of taxpayer money.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 The stereotype of the old woman in this country depicts her as unintelligent, incompetent and unattractive. But at a symposium of the American Psychological Association being held here this week, the panelists while recognizing her present plight found themselves irrepressibly hopeful about her future.

A 34-year-old policeman, responding to a 911 emergency call about a man with a gun was killed by a shotgun blast yesterday as he and his partner tried to enter a room in a shabby brownstone house in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. The partner killed one man in the room and wounded another.
The Board of Higher Education ousted Edgar D. Draper last night as president of Borough of Manhattan Community College for what it called "the good of the college."

Capital appropriations by the nation's 1,000 largest manufacturers totaled $15.19 billion in the second quarter of 1977, the second highest amount in 24 years, the Conference Board reported yesterday.
Tenants at 35 Pine Street in Yonkers where the alleged "Son of Sam" killer, David R. Berkowitz, resided have been asked to tell everybody they live at 42 Pine Street.

Ted Turner is marketing his mouth. The outspoken, flamboyant Atlanta Braves' owner and America's Cup trials skipper has hired Ed Keating to negotiate with several companies considering Turner as a spokesman for their products. Keating is the man who negotiated a contract for the ex-free agent Gary Matthews, now a Braves' outfielder, whose case led to Turner's suspension from baseball.
Three Harvard researchers have found evidence of a reversal of the long-term trend to water down the reading levels of textbooks used in American elementary and secondary schools.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-The Pentagon has quietly urged the Carter Administration to sell 60 F-15 supersonic fighters to Saudi Arabia, according to Government sources.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 27 The Government of President Hafez al-Assad is plagued by sectarian tensions, corruption, economic difficulties and a series of assassinations and explosions.

HONG KONG, Aug. 30 President Tito of Yugoslavia received a huge official welcome when he arrived in Peking today for his first visit to China. The warmth of his reception reflected the importance China places on supporting allies against the Soviet Union and the new mood in Peking following the death last year of Mao Tse-tung.

LIBERTY, Miss., Aug. 30 Black students have overwhelmingly joined a boycott of Amite County's four public schools to protest a seven-year-old Federal court desegregation order that separat-, ed the schools by sex.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 30(AP) Andrew Young, the American delegate to the United Nations, and Foreign Secretary David Owen of Britain arrived here today after a stop in Dar es Salaam to seek support of their Rhodesia peace plan from Tanzania's influential President, Julius K. Nyerere.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 30 Dr. David A.W. Wilson has resigned as director of the division of surgery of United Hospital in an action that is part of a months-long dispute between the hospital's medical staff and its board of trustees.

The right of the Rev. Louis R. Gigante, a New York City Councilman and a Roman Catholic priest, not to divulge to a grand jury the nature of a conversation with a reputed Mafia chief was upheld yesterday.

President Carter's decision to seek a 20 percent cut in wheat acreage represents a victory for the Agriculture Department and wheat farmers, a loss for the Treasury Department and the Council of Economic Advisers and a bet against world hunger next year. WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 In the last few days, there has been a definite change in the White House attitude, not toward Bert Lance personally but toward the Lance "problem." Publicly, his Georgia colleagues are still supporting him, but privately and sadly they are now conceding that he is embarrassing the President and will probably have to go.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 30 Prime Minister Menahem Begin said today that the recent Syrian suggestion that the Arab League might represent the Palestine Liberation Organization in any reconvened Geneva conference would be "completely unacceptable" to Israel.

The heightened competition for shipping business among the Atlantic ports from Boston to Hampton Roads, Va., has stymied contract negotiations with the longshoremen, whose current contract expires on Sept. 30.

EVIDENCE abounds that for more than a million Cambodians the wake of the 1970-75 war in their country was worseo than the fighting. Some ad agencies that handle food or franchiser accounts have used field account executives to present their clients advertising and marketing programs to local managers and staffs. Lillian Graham Theiler, widow of Dr. Max Theiler, winner in 1951 of the Nobel Prize for physiology and medicine, died suddenly Monday in Briar Crest Nursing Home, Ossining, N.Y. She was 81 years old and formerly lived in Hastings-onHudson, N.Y., and New Haven.

TRENTON, Aug. 30 Faced by a growing "no smoking" movement in a state whose citizens last year smoked 18 billion cigarettes, a committee of the State Public Health Council proposed today sharp restrictions today on the use of tobacco in a wide variety of public places.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (Reuters) India will honor all agreements with foreign investors despite the Government's present problems with the Americanowned Coca-Cola Company, Commerce Minister Mohen Dharia said here today.

It was supposed to be Dullsville at Forest Hills yesterday. No Jimmy Connors. No Bjorn Borg. No Renee Richards. No sun.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 31 White Rhodesians gave the governing Rhodesian Front party an overwhelming election victory today. They granted Prime Minister Ian D. Smith the mandate he sought to negotiate a vaguely defined constitutional settlement outside the framework of the diplomatic efforts being pursued by Britain and the United States.

MY ADMIRATION for Waterside, the housing complex of four towers atop a platform in the East River at 25th Street, has always been tempered somewhat by the vast stretch of concrete in the towers' midst. It is a plaza, obviously, but it is not what Waterside needs, since its own harshness only exaggerates the similarly rough qualities of Davis, Brody Associates' otherwise handsome towers. What the place really needs is some landscaping.

An engine an a Trans World Airlines Boeing 747 jetliner bound for Rome with 240 passengers exploded over Valley Stream, L.I., shortly after it took off last night, and forced the plane to return to Kennedy International Airport.

LONDON, Aug. 31 British stock prices soared today to their highest levels since January 1973, with the widely followed Financial Times index piercing the 500 mark just before brokers began picking up their umbrellas to go home.
HOUSTON, Aug. 31 The New York Mets traded Jerry Grote to the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight for a nominal cash consideration and two minor leaguers to be named later.

Victor Korchnoi, a Soviet defector who is the world's No. 2 ranked chess player, showed up at the 100th birthday party of the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday and announced he would soon "go to California" to arrange a match with Bobby Fischer, who vanished from public view shortly after winning the world championship in 1972.

THE CELEBRATION OF Black Composers moved to Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday night, with Paul Freeman conducting the New York Philharmonic. This concert took a look at three composers, one active in the 18th century, one spanning the 18th and 19th, and one from the l9th.

EAST HARTFORD, Aug. 31 Frank Daniel DeCorleto, the convicted murderer who killed his wife and 4-year-old son and then committed suicide yesterday, had won custody of the child from a previous marriage because the child's mother was too afraid of him to fight for the boy, according to the lawyer who represented her in the custody fight.
A "dream mile" race between Filbert Bayi of Tanzania and John Walker of New Zealand, in the makings for three years, is now scheduled for Sept. 17 at Empire Stadium in Vancouver, British Columbia.

Arthur Levitt, the New York State Comptroller, yesterday questioned the need for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to hire its own auditors at an unspecified cost for a study of possible expense-account padding by officials.

PARIS, Aug. 31 Faced with rising unemployment and a crucial parliamentary election next spring, the French Government of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing announced today its second package of expansionary economic measures this year.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 Good, soil-soaking rains throughout most of the Middle West have brought relief to droughtstricken farms in the nation's major grain-growing region and have stored enough moisture in the subsoil to promise a good beginning for next year's crops.

One of the strange truths about the investment business is that Wall Street stockbrokers use both technical and fundamental analysts and that hardly anyone is surprised when they disagree as they often do.

The mayoral campaign veered pleasantly into metaphysics for a moment yesterday when Barry Farber owned up to his opponent's accusation of "blowing smoke" at the voters in the form of campaign rhetoric. Mr. Farber construed the accusation of State Senator Roy M. Goodman as a compliment and sought to state the question positively: What's wrong with blowing smoke?

Federated Department Stores and the Consumer Products Safety Commission announced yesterday that they have agreed on a consent order settling the commission's complaint against Federated involving Tris-treated children's garments. The chemical has been banned for use in clothing since a commission directive of last April.

July construction contracts at $11.2 billion were only 1 percent ahead of the value of contracts in July 1976 despite a 32 percent gain in residential building commitments, the F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

Leslie Manning Bergesch, a vice president of Calisch Associates, a New York public relations concern, was married yesterday afternoon in St. James' Episcopal Church to Richard Talmage. Perkin of New York, who is secretary/ treasurer of the Foundation for Art Education. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Raymond Webster, who was assisted by the Rev. George Ruggieri, a Roman Catholic priest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The Government banned today the export of bobcat pelts, and as a result the small predator now has the distinction of having one Government agency trying to protect it while another is trying to kill it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 President Carter intends to guarantee the independence of the news function of the Voice of Aemrica as part of a plan to create a new single agency to replace both the United States Information Agency and the state Department's Bureau of Cultural and Educational Affairs.

NOW'S THE TIME The fall music season is officially on, with the beginning of the New York City Opera's 11-week program. Tickets are gone for performances of "Die Fledermaus" tomorrow and Sunday nights. But seats are still available this first wek for a cluster of perennial favorites in the Italian repertory, with some new leading singers and a conductor who is making his American debut.

The Maddox Brothers and Rose rated less than a paragraph in Bill Malone's compendious "Country Music U.S.A.," but their importance should be reflected more adequately in books that follow the release of these records. Drawing on both commercial recordings and radio broadcast transcriptions, Rose Maddox and Arhoolie's Chris Strachwitz have assembled two impressive albums that document the uniquely wide-ranging music of the Maddox Brothers and Rose during their glory years, 1946-51.
After several years of study and effort, the American Hospital Association approved this week its first guidelines on the acceptable use of advertising.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (Reuters) The White House said today that President Carter was not studying possible voluntary wage and price standards. White House spokesman, Jody Powell, said: "There is absolutely no such proposal being considered by the White House. The President has given no instruction to develop such standards."

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 31 Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso, who has been criticized by his political opponents for what they consider the excessive cost of operating the county government, announced today that he expected to reduce the general county tax rate next year.

ALTAMONT, N.Y. It has become widely accepted that the violation of human rights in Brazil has greatly diminished; that in comparison with other Latin-American countries the problem in Brazil is mild and unworthy of exerted critical attention; that the Brazilian Government's pronouncement banning the use of torture, together with the renewal of friendly relations between the United States and Brazil, have provided a secure, normal climate for continued economic growth and corporate investment.

NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa., Aug. 31 (UPI) Bill Sander, the defending champion, scrambled back through the trees on the 18th hole to tie his match and then won the first sudden-death hole today to advance in the 77th United States Amateur golf championship.
HOUSTON, Aug. 31 The New York Mets completed a totally imperfect 0-7 road trip and the Houston Astros finished a perfect 7-0 home stand as Houston prevailed, 5-2, tonight in the Astrodome.

HONOLULU, Aug. 31 Special Prosecutor Grant B. Cooper said today that the Federal indictment of a key witness in the bribery trial of Mayor Frank F. Fasi would not further delay the Mayor's case, which is scheduled to go before a jury in late September or early October.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 31 An obscure 1909 map of the Thai-Cambodian border may hold at least part of the key to the increasingly violent clashes between troops of the two countries in the volatile frontier region.

Representative Al Ullman, the chairman of the House tax-writing committee, suggested yesterday that if the slow economic recovery faltered, the nation might need a tax cut "even more" in the forthcoming attempt to overhaul the basic tax laws.
Tom Seaver and Steve Carlton, who have earned four Cy Young Awards between them, may wind up in a battle for the National League's best pitcher this season. Both coasted to easy victories last night.

DESPITE THE FACT that Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy have worked together on stage for 35 years, they do not re gard themselves as an acting couple; they are actors who sometimes work in tandem. In fact, some of their greatest successes have been achieved separately, such as Miss Tandy's original Blanche DuBois in "A Streetcar Named Desire" and Mr. Cronyn's Polonius in Richard Burton's "Hamlet."

PATERSON, Aug. 31 Officials of this Passaic County community of 150,000 were elated today over a record $19.4 million bond sale yesterday at an interest rate of 5.65 percent. In the city's last bond sale in early 1974, the rate was 6.25 percent.
The Federal Reserve, for the fist time since money market rates began to rise late in July, gave a signal yesterday that it did not want short-term rates to climb any higher just now.
LONDON, Aug. 31 (UPI) The Soviet Union's trade with the West is still declining, official figures showed.
HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 31 (UPI) Jean Hagen, radio, Broadway and movie actress who played Danny Thomas's wife in the television series "Make Room For Daddy," died Monday of throat cancer at the age of 54.

Barry Farber accused State Senator Roy M. Goodman yesterday of "bribery," "theft" and "blackmail." Mr. Goodman accused Mr. Farber of being "reprehensible," "flaky" "totalitarian," and "slanderous." Each accused the other of being a blatant liar.

WHILE I am always surprised to discover how unsophisticated some writers can be hundreds of years after such examples as, say, Shakespeare or John Donne, there are, on the other side, many who behave as if no one ever had a profound thought or a complex feeling earlier than yesterday. What Rollo May calls "pseudo-innocence" guarantees the originality of such writers. One might say that they are guilty of innocence.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia Aug. 31 White Rhodesians gave the governing Rhodesian Front party an overwhelming election victory today. They granted Prime Minister Ian. D. Smith the mandate he sought to negotiate a vaguely defined constitutional settlement outside the framework of the diplomatic efforts being pursued by Britain and the United States.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 31 An international panel of scientists advising the United Nations Conference on Desertification here today criticized the proposed plan of action for combatting desert spread as underestimating the costs of achieving the goals, overestimating the adequacy of existing technology and being too optimistic on how quickly the job could be done.

"It's like Agatha Christie," said Pat Sasso, the detective working on the murder of "the birdman," who was found hanged in a dilapidated pet shop in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, his hands and feet tied with twine.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 31 (AP) The State Gaming Commission toughened its position on jai alai today, saying that one arena made too much money and that the names of prospective buyers of another must be made public.

Edward F. Huber, a public utility lawyer and the senior partner in the New York law firm of Huber Magill Lawrence Farrell, died yesterday in Hartford. He was 71 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y., at 11 South Drive.

"THE BEAUTIFUL BAIT" was clearly a prophetic title for a brief selection of Chinese dances that was more appetizer than main course. Four young women under the direction of Alan Chow, himself an impressive performer, conducted a mini-tour through Chinese regional and classic dance at the fountain, Lincoln Center Plaza, Tuesday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The United States and the Soviet Union today postponed for two weeks the resumption of Cabinet-level negotiations aimed at curbing the strategic weapons race.
PEKING, Aug. 31 (Reuters) President Tito of Yugoslavia, once branded a traitor to Communism by China, today became the first foreigner to visit the Mao Tse-tung Mausoleum.
SEPTEMBER will once again find college students hammering, painting, wiring and generally recreating all the comforts of home not to mention a bathtub in the bedroom or even a roller coaster.

HOUSTON, Aug. 31 The slow but relentless buildup of Hurricane Anita in the Gulf of Mexico sent thousands of Louisiana and Texas Gulf Coast residents fleeing to higher ground today in anticipation of the storm's assault on the coastline.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 31 (Reuters) Zambia said tonight that Rhodesian jets had bombed Zambian territory early today near the Zambian border town of Feira.

MOSCOW, Aug. 31 (AP) Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, today ended three days of talks with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko. A joint communique indirectly criticized United States mediation efforts in the Middle East.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 31 In an outbreak of intense fighting today in southern Lebanon, 10 persons were killed and 20 were wounded, according to official Lebanese sources.

Q. I have an old brick house and the north wall leaks in a heavy rain. A "water repellent" paint has been applied, but apparently has not solved the problem. What is the best way to treat this wall? Can aluminum siding be applied? Dr. J.C.S., Bayonne, N.J.

Mayor Beame demanded yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission release its findings on the 1975 default of New York State's Urban Development Corporation and threatened to go to court if the commission refused.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 31 The Long Island Lighting Company today released polls that it said indicated that people in the area it served strongly favored the construction of nuclear power plants on Long Island.

In the two and a half years since the New York State Urban Development Corporation collapsed financially providing a sort of curtain raiser for the New York City fiscal crisis the state agency has been quietly working to complete its unfinished projects while also seeking modest involvement in new undertakings.

James Porter Davis, who retired in 1953 as director of the Office of Territories in the Department of the Interior, died Monday on Nantucket Island, where he had a summer home. He also had a residence in McLean, Va. He was 87 years old.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Aug. 31 (Reuters) The new Prime Minister of Bermuda, David Gibbons, has named to his cabinet four members of his United Bermuda Party who had instigated the unseating of his predecessor.

Governor Carey, plunging into the Democratic mayoral primary campaign in New York City in support of his candidate, Mario M. Cuomo, portrayed Mayor Beame yesterday as a weak leader more interested in protecting the job of a "cohort" than in coping with the city's fiscal problems.
About two years ago, agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Miami obtained a court order to place a wiretap in the office of Joseph Teitelbaum, one of Miami's busiest shipping agents.

H.C. Potter, tile director whose urbane wit characterized major films as well as plays on the Broadway stage for nearly 30 years, died yesterday after a brief illness. He was 73 years old and lived in recent years in New York City and Southampton, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 A Congressional study of people receiving Medicaid benefits has found that surgery is performed on the needy and the near-poor at twice the rate of surgery on the general population. For some forms of elective surgery, for conditions that are not lifethreatening, the disparity was found to be even greater.

YONKERS, Aug. 31 The Yonkers City Council directed the city last night to bring a suit for damages against Mayor Beame, six New York City banks and others named in the recent Securities and Exchange Commission report cirticizing their actions in handling New York's fiscal crisis.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 27 Weakened and diminished by the civil war in Lebanon, the Palestine Liberation Organization is passing through a period of sharp testing, troubled in its ranks by a heavy dependence on Syria.

AL CARMINES, that last glowing ember of vaudeville, is taking a week off from his theatrical and ecclesiastical responsibilities to sing at the Ballroom while his latest musical, "Camp Meeting," prepares to reopen after a short engagement at the Greenwich Mews Theater, which ended last weekend.

The state's special anticorruption prosecutor is looking into a complaint from police union delegates that the Brooklyn surrogate, Bernard M. Bloom,threatened "to get" a police officer who wanted to arrest three relatives of the surrogate for allegedly assaulting him after he stopped their car for passing a red light.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) A late spurt of speculative selling erased substantial gains in soybean futures and dictated a slightly lower close on the Chicago Board of Trade today.

Barclay Cooke is widely respected as a senior member of the backgammon establishment expert player backgammon author, backgammon teacher. He has been a backgammon enthusiast for more than 30 years, and is a regular player at New York's Racquet Tennis Club. Although the game has, for some, become ruthlessly competitive in recent years, Cooke has remained an exemplary sportsman. He and his late son Walter once formed the most famous father-son team in backgammon.
Count Dracula may become the man theatergoers most love to hate this season.

WASHINGTON, Aug.31 (UPI) Unemployment has reached a record high among black youths, who were virtually excluded from a small summer hiring surge enjoyed by young whites, the Labor Department said today.

A few minutes before noon on a steamy day this week Mayor Beame walked from City Hall to the nearby Brooklyn Bridge subway station and got on the last car of a Woodlawn express. It was an air-conditioned car, one of the first two being introduced on the old IRT line.

A group of urban visionaries sees at some future date a river-to-river trolley service, a year-round farmers' market and a dance center among the amenities that they hope will restore some of the old elegance and excitement to West 42d Street.
The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest reports of changes in stock ownership by large stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies.
August sales of six of New York City's biggest department stores rose 11.5 percent over the 1976 month, the biggest monthly advance since May 1969.
The stock market closed mixed yesterday after a sharp upswing in the afternoon reduced most of its earlier losses.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 3l Venezuela's state oil monopoly, which ranks as one of the largest petroleum companies in the world, will invest $233 million in land and offshore exploration next year, the company's president said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Congress was told today that thousands of Filipinos who served in or with United States armed forces lived a life of luxury in the Philippines on Veterans Administration benefits.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall announced today that his department was investigating a number of cities, including New York, after finding that Chicago had illegally misused Federal public service employment funds.

MANY PEOPLE have found it necessary in these last weeks to say something profound about the death of Elvis Presley. RAG rugs are upwardly mobile. Like wicker furniture and oak floors, they're moving from country homes into chic urban and suburban settings. A few decorators are in the vanguard, appreciating the earthy, functional look of the homespun product, and using it in contemporary as well as traditional rooms.

WINCHESTER, Mass. Michael Holodnak was luckier than most corporate dissidents. An employee of the Avco-Lycoming Division of Avco Corporation in Stratford, Conn. Mr. Holodnak had the temerity to criticize management for hypocrisy in its labor relations. When he was fired summarily, he sued the company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The White House said today that the Carter campaign committee, through an oversight, failed to pay for rides by Jimmy Carter on corporate and state-owned planes on a campaign swing through the Carolinas in April 1975.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Amtrak, the national rail passenger system, announced today that it would make major cutbacks in its Northeast Corridor area, eliminating an average of 22 trains a day of the 120 now serving such centers as New York, New Haven, Boston and Washington. The changes are to become effective Oct 30.

New York Racing Association officials learaed again yesterday that attendance at Belmont Park can be made to mushroom if the price is right. They also discovered that a bigger turnout on a free-admission day (to the grandstand) does not automatically mean much bigger betting.
The dollar weakened in most foreign exchange trading yesterday, but gained slightly against the Japanese yen and the sturdy Swiss franc, the Associated Press reported.

THE ELDERLY and the young are age groups that make up television's most devoted audience, but while there are numerous programs designed for children on both commercial and public television, there have not in recent times been any, on an ambitious scale, directed expressly at the concerns and interests of the older population.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) A former high-ranking Navy official was indicted today on Federal charges involving his alleged efforts to steer a multimilliondollar contract to a private concern that hired him after his military retirement.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 31 President Carter's carefully worded call yesterday for a peaceful settlement between Northern Ireland's Protestant majority and Roman Catholic minority has received a generally favorable but muted reaction here.

John Santucci, the Queens District Attorney, will challenge a psychiatric report saying David R. Berkowitz is not competent to stand trial and ask in State Supreme Court in Queens today for further psychiaric evaluation of the man accused of being the Son of Sam, who killed six persons.

Historically the posture of the Federal Government has been passive once it has insured the loans that have built thousands of privately owned apartments around the country. It stands back while management runs the project and pays off the loan to the private, insured lender.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 1 (AP) Nassau County Executive, Ralph Caso, says the average cost of putting a youngster through one grade in a county grammar school matches the annual tuition of an Ivy League college. He says the cost per pupil is $3,100.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept.1 This year could "mark the beginning of the end of a national coal labor agreement" unless a way is found to eliminate wildcat strikes by miners, Joseph P. Brennan, the president of Bituminous Coal Operators Association, said today.

The name of Charles Merz was not well known to readers of this newspaper but his words were. For more than 30 years, from before the New Deal until the New Frontier, he was one of the small band who wrote the anonymous editorials on this page. From 1938 to 1961, he was the Editorial Page Editor, responsible for every word and every opinion that appeared here.
The leading Roman Catholic advocate of a liberalized attitude toward homosexuality on the part of the church has been ordered by the Vatican to keep silent on the subject.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 1 (UPI) Jane Blalock, Betsy Cullen, Sally Little and Hollis Stacy each fired 4-under-par 68's and shared the lead in the opening round of a $100,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament today. Two brief thunderstorms temporarily halted play in mid-afternoon.

HONG KONG, Sept. 1 Peking's new leaders have begun to reverse many of the late Mao Tse-tung's radical education reforms as part of a broad program to improve the quality of China's schools and provide a basis for the country's rapid economic modernization.
WASHINGTON, Sept.1-The Navy today selected the Sikorsky Aircraft division of the United Technologies Corporation at Stratford, Conn., to build 200 new helicopters for antisubmarine combat.

With unabashed pride and a touch of nostalgia, 300 fans, parents and dignitaries paid tribute yesterday to Brooklyn's first championship baseball team since the Dodgers copped the National League pennant in 1956 and two years later defected to the West.

CAIRO, Sept.1 An Egyptian who was a leader of the nation's principal conservative party before King Farouk was deposed in 1952 announced plans last week for a new political organization, and concern has been growing in official circles ever since.

A union representing the 900 Allstate Insurance Company's agents in New York State charged at a State Senate hearing yesterday that large insurance companies are forcing mny drivers with clean records into New York's assigned-risk pool; where they may pay 50 percent more in premiums for less coverage than they could get in the "voluntary insurance" market.

MONTREAL, Sept. 1 A new provincial law aimed at promoting the primacy of the French language in Quebec has touched off unrest in northern Eskimo communities and defiance by some school boards elsewhere in the province.

If you want to see a tiger in its natural setting, think twice before rushing off to India. The trip is expensive and arduous, and in the end you are far from likely to find one. There are now fewer than 2,000 tigers left in all that vast subcontinent and they are extremely hard to spot in a bamboo thicket. Go to the new Wild Asia exhibit in the Bronx Zoo instead.

The marriage of Barbara Symmers Wiedemann to Thomas Moore Bancroft Jr. took place at the River Club yesterday. The Rev. W. Raymond Webster, associate rector of St. James Episcopal Church, performed the ceremony.

George L. Shinn, 54 years old, chairman of the board of First Boston Inc. and its subsidiary, the First Boston Corporation, was elected yesterday to the board of directors of the New York Stock Exchange. He will be one of the 10 securities industry representatives on the 20-member board.

Ethel Waters, the singer and actress whose talents took her from honky-tonk night spots to Broadway, into motion pictures and on to radio and television, died yesterday, apparently of kidney and heart failure. She was 80 years old and lived in Chatsworth, Calif., with friends in whose home she died.

A number of Bert Lance's banking practices fell outside the limits of customary or even ethically acceptable behavior, according to bankers and financial executives who were asked in a spot check to assess the embattled budget director's performance as a Georgia banker.

The pursuit of the Chemetron Corporation quickened yesterday when the company announced that it had reached a tentative agreement to merge with Allegheny Ludlum Industries Inc. by exchanging securities. The Crane Company responded by increasing its cash offer for Chemetron's common from $40 to $48 per share.

Harold D. Vursell, a former vice president and managing editor at the publishing house of Farrar, Straus and Giroux, died Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 79 years old and lived at 24 Gramercy Park South.

Late-summer storms battered the Middle West once more yesterday, causing floods and power failures. Water from as much as 4 inches of rain washed over streets and highways on Chicago's South Side and southern suburbs, at a depth of 2 feet, slowing morning rush-hour traffic.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) The office of the Comptroller of the Currency, in light of the Bert Lance case, soon may take the "very unusual" action of asking the 4,700 national banks it regulates to spell out their policies on overdrafts, it was learned today.

About 20 pounds of metal debris fell over Valley Stream, L.I., late Wednesday night when an engine on a Trans World Airlines 747 jetliner disintegrated in midair shortly after the craft took off for Rome.

Some of the biggest names in pro basketball moved yesterday. The Nets sent Nate Archibald to Buffalo, and the Braves, in a surprising move, traded Adrian Dantley to the In- diana Pacers for Billy Knight. Dantley was last season's National Basketball Association rookie-of-the-year and Knight, the league's second leading scorer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) Leaders of women's organizations appealed to Congress today for more jobs for women in the armed forces, saying that economies and increased military effectiveness could result.
MELVILLE, L.I., Sept. 1 Garbage collection at thousands of Long Island businesses, mostly in Nassau County, was disrupted today as 300 employees of 80 private carting concerns went on strike.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 For the people who have to govern this country, and even for those who have to report and analyze the news, the events of the last day of August 1977 around here were almost enough to make you think that life is a little complicated. For example, on this one day:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1-Transportation Secretary Brock Adams today announced a new policy to encourage greater use of design and the arts to enhance the nation's transportation systems.

BRITAIN'S CELEBRATION of Queen Elizabeth II's silver jubilee, has spawned a number of art events, not the least of which is the Faberge exhibition on view (through Oct. 23) at London's Victoria and Albert Museum.

Close to 500 runners are expected to complete tomorrow at 5 P.M. in the first mini-marathon to be held on Fire Island, Registration for the race, which will cover 5.3 miles along the beach, ends at 8 P.M. tonight. There is an entry fee of $4.
The jury is still out on Bjorn Borg and Jimmy Connors, but the verdict was clear on Dr. Renee Richards and Chris Evert yesterday at the United States Open tennis championships.

HONOLULU, Sept. 1 (AP) The General Assembly of the World Psychiatric Association voted today to censure the Soviet Union on charges of abuse of psychiatry for political purposes and to establish a committee to review such practices in any country.

The supervisor of a state prison in the Bronx has been suspended on charges of permitting staff members to make longdistance telephone calls, allowing security to be lax and using inmates to print leaflets and perform other personal work.
WASHINGTON, Sept.1 (UPI) The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today it is to undertake a year-long study of state and Federal regulation of the nation's 14,700 commercial banks.

Continued strong consumer buying directed toward back-to-school apparel and the fall fashions, helped most of the nation's major retail chain stores post double-digit sales gains in August over the corresponding month a year ago.

Sweet are the uses of adversity. Marvin Schiller, a management consultant, believes that troubled times for big companies have produced a heightened sensitivity to the danger of being overtaken by business disaster.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 The United States and Cuba restored today a modest portion of the official relations that were broken off in anger 16 years and eight months ago.

The flames raged almost until dawn yesterday at 558 50th Street, in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. Sirens screamed, firemen fought the blaze, police officers held back the spectators and ambulances stood by to carry away the injured. But there was no panic and hardly any anxiety, and when some fiery debris fell from the four-story brick building there was even be a scattering of applause from the crowd.

TRENTON, Sept. 1-The head of a State Assembly committee said today that Alan Sagner, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, had agreed to meet with the panel to discuss the authority's "commitments" to public transportation in New Jersey.

HONG KONG, Sept. 1-Peking's new leaders have begun to reverse many of the late Mao Tse-tung's radical education reforms as part of a broad program to improve the quality of China's schools and provide a basis for the country's rapid economic modernization.

NBC has agreed to an affirmativeaction hiring program and will award $540,000 in back pay as part of the settlement of a discrimination suit by female employees. The back pay ranges from $1,336 to $35,174 for 16 women who originally brought suit, and either $1,000 or $500 each for 2,700 others as a result of the suit's having become a class action.

RICHMOND, Sept.1 (AP) The United States Labor Department said today that it had complied with the order of a Federal judge to certify the importation of 5,000 foreign workers to harvest the nation's apple crop.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1 (AP) A woman deputy city sheriff has won a St. Louis Cardinals contest by guessing the exact minute, as well as the exact inning and exact date, that Lou Brock stole his record 893d base.

FROM TAP TO TOE, the shape of this year's New York Dance Festival in Central Park promises more variety than ever. With tonight's opening at 8 P.M. at the open-air Delacorte Theater, the popular annual festival starts a 10-day run that will present dancers as different from one another as the Rockettes and soloists from the Joffrey Ballet.

Ken W. Clawson, who served as director of communications for former President Richard M. Nixon during his last year in office, has joined the mayoral campaign of Barry Farber, a spokesman for Mr. Farber said last night.

AMERICAN PUBLISHERS who will attend the first Moscow International Book Fair, which begins next Tuesday, will be there as exhibitors and observers and are hopeful that their presence will lead to a growing exchange of books and ideas.
BONN, Sept. 1 (Reuters) The West German Economics Ministry today issued a gloomy assessment of the country's economic performance so far this year.

THE CLASH of prime-time specials next Tuesday night, signaling the opening of the new television season, may have consequences beyond the issue of which of the three rivals will have the fastest start in this year's ratings contest.

HAYS, Kan., Sept. 1 (UPI) Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Weilert oppose the wedding of their daughter so strongly that they are filing a $10,000 suit to have their names removed from the wedding invitations. It is not likely, however, that the suit will come to court until after the wedding, scheduled for tomorrow.

AREA A "You can't miss, it's like fishing in an aquarium," said Ralph Stork of Capt. Andy's Marina about the healthy run of blufish and weakfish in the Avalon Shoals at Margate, N.J. Between Buoy 2 aad Sea Isle Lumps, the hot spot, one fisherman this week caught 42 weakfish and Tom Gallagher of Longport, N.J., pulled in a 23-pound blue. Tennis players will head for the courts this weekend, swimmers the beaches, fishermen the streams, dozers the shade of a tree. David R. Berkowitz, the man accused of being the 44-caliber killer, was described yesterday in a small section of a confidential psychiatric report as being "well aware" of the six murders and seven attempted-murder charges against him in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Sept.1 Hurricane Anita, generating winds of more than 150 miles an hour, veered away from this southernmost Texas city late tonight and headed for an early-morning landfall about a hundred miles to the south on Mexico's sparsely populated Gulf Coast.
The New York City Opera and, in effect, the fall music season opened at the State Theater on Wednesday evening, when the company presented the "Mefistofele" of Arrigo Boiti.

HISTORY IS its own reward in Flemington, N.J., though George Washington never slept there, and the major confrontation with history of this rural Hunterdon County crossroads was clothed in notoriety as the site of the crowded 1935 trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, the German-born carpenter from the Bronx, who was sentenced to death for the kidnap-murder of the Charles A. Lindbergh baby.

NEWARK, Sept. 1 Grumbling and repeated glances at watches gave way to smiles and even a brief cheer this morning when more than 100 people at the Penn Station stop of the Newark subway system learned the cause of the car's failure to arrive on time.

WASHINGTON, Sept.1 Amid reports that the Government may be weakening its support for affirmative action, Attorney General Griffin B. Bell delivered to the President today the first draft of a Government position on a landmark civil rights suit pending before the Supreme Court.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 Before dawn today, a flotilla of small boats left their shelter along the California coast and by sunup, hundreds of divers were scouring the sea in search of abalone, a delicate white shellfish that, to the despair of many Californians, has become increasingly scarce.
BOSTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) Flooding the St. John River in northern Maine to build a hydroelectric dam would cause great harm to the environment, a long-awaited study said today.

Main Street in Roxbury, N.Y., an upstate village with a population of 600, will be lined with paintings, sculptures, photographs and handcrafted items this weekend, and artisans will demonstrate wood sculpture and pot throwing at an outdoor art festival.

Miss O'Toole wrote that she did impressions, including one of a dead cockroach.

DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 1 Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, said today that because of a "regrettable" mistake, Ford failed for four years to recall 424,000 of its 1972-model cars that posed what proved to be a serious safety hazard. One death and 11 injuries were linked to the defect between the time it was discovered in 1973 and the recall was finally made last June.
In describing Lyle Lane, who opened Washington's first permanent diplomatic mission in Havana in 16 years yesterday, colleagues and friends spoke foremost of his discretion.

Former President Richard M. Nixon says in his last televised interview with David Frost that he believes Rosemary Woods' account of the 18 -minute gap in the Watergate tapes, Mr. Frost said in New York City last night.

Baseball turned into its final full month yesterday with everybody bracing for the homestretch of a season that began in April the sprinting Yankees en route to Minnesota and eight games on the road, the stumbling Mets back in New York for eight at home and Jerry Grote headed for Los-Angeles and somebody else's pennant race.

Pointing up the personality issue in the mayoral primary campaign, Democratic candidates attacked one another's integrity, honesty and qualifications yesterday in a debate that often slipped into finger-jabbing shouting matches.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 The Carter Administration is weighing the possibility of giving the Concorde supersonic airliner landing rights at 10 cities in addition to New York and Washington despite the controversy surrounding the noise of the craft, Government sources said today.
