RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 2 (AP) Princess Lalla Nouzha, 37-year-old sister of King Hassan II and the wife of Prime Minister Ahmed Osman, was killed in an automobile accident in northern Morocco early today, the Government announced.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) American membership in labor unions declined by 767,000 over a two-year period ending in 1976, with most of the losses among women, the Government said today on the eve of the Labor Day weekend.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 31-President Carter's decision last month to admit 15,000 more refugees from Indochina has already produced one important result, American diplomats report: Malaysia, where most of the Vietnamese fleeing in fishing boats run ashore, no longer pushes them back out to sea, as it frequently did.

New Yorkers, who have survived a summer of record high temperatures, which followed a winter of equally discomforting cold, began taking to the beaches, parks and resorts yesterday for a Labor Day weekend that the National Weather Service said would be plain old "normal."
Mary Isabel Bovee McAdoo, a prominent volunteer worker for the Salvation Army, died Thursday at her home in Vineyard Haven, Mass. She was in her late 80's.

A major break in steel pricing appears to have developed with a decision by the Armco Steel Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest producer, that it will not go along with tomorrow's scheduled 6 percent price increase for structural products, thus keeping its prices at present levels on a major portion of its structural products.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 2 Was that really Sir Garfield Sobers chasing a cricket ball across the artificial turf of Giants Stadium here in the Meadowlands this morning? And was that indeed Everton Weekes who had cracked out the small, red-leather ball with his gleaming bat?

He chuckled and thanked her.

LONDON, Sept. 2 (AP) Andre Previn will give up his post as principal conductor of the London Symphony Orchestra in 1979, an orchestra spokesman announced today. The Berlin-born American conductor has held the post since 1968, but in the last few years there has been dissension over him in the ranks of the self-governing orchestra.
Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned yesterday in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities.

Officials of the Bergen-Passaic Lung Association said yesterday that they were elated over the response from school officials across the state to a warning on the use of possible cancercausing chemicals in classroom science laboratories.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3--President Carter went off to Camp David for the Labor Day weekend with some distressing homework: the latest Labor Department figures--6,900,000 Americans out of work--7.1 percent over all; 14.5 for blacks, as high as any month since the last world war; and 40.4 for teen-age blacks as compared to 14.7 percent for teen-age whites.

ON several occasions in early childhood, Anthony Powell tells us he was conscious of approaching the brink of some discovery. One afternoon in about 1911, when he was 5 or 6, standing outside the door of his London home, "the truth came flooding in with the dust infested sunlight," he writes. "The revelation of self-identity was inescapable. There was no doubt about it. I was me."

How long can a jury properly take--or be held--to make up its collective mind about the guild or innocence of criminal defendants? That puzzling question was raised by the Federal mail fraud conviction, the week before last, of Maryland Governor Marvin Mandel and five friends. The jury deliberated for 12 days before returning the guilty verdict-- an extraordinary length of time even by the sometimes gargantuan standards of American trials.

SUBURBIA is in a pachysandra rut. This ubiquitous ground cover has everything going for it --price, ease in planting and quick growth. When the pachysandra has had a year or so to settle its roots, it provides a finished and ever-green trim to the property with a tone of elegance.

GENIUS AND LUST, edited by Norman Mailer. (Bantam, $3.50.) A bountiful anthology of the writing of Henry Miller assembled by one of his most enthusiastic admirers. Of the judgments Mailer offers in his commentary, Gass said they were "generally legitimate if not beyond dispute."

There is probably nothing quite like the Avery Fisher Artist Program among noncompetitive cultural prizes. Public discussion on the issue of human rights in the third world has generated more heat than light because it has failed to recognize the large-scale economic costs of more humane policies. There is no natural affinity among capitalist growth, political freedom and social justice. In the contemporary underdeveloped world, repression and poverty have become integral and essential parts of the dominant growth strategies.

THE picture of "thorough and efficient" education given by Dr. David E. Weischadle (Aug. 22) contained some major distor- tions of this new approach to education. While Dr. Weischadle's expertise in education cannot be faulted, certain statements made in his article question- ing the workability of "t and e" are based on inadequate information which, therefore, led to inaccurate conclusions.

Jane Chispa Gallagher and Bruce Alan Huber, graduate students at the University of Rhode Island, will be married in October. Mr. Gallagher is former president and general manager of The Associated Press.

Andrea Colton and Peter S. Britell, both of New York, were married last evening ,in Rochester, Minn. Rabbi Joseph Davidson performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. Jonathan and Dr. Catherine Britell, brother and sister-inlaw of the bridegroom.

In the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn., yesterday evening, Nancy Judson Stanger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rhys L. Stanger of Darien, became the bride of Robert Estes Stopher, son of Mr. and Mrs Joseph E. Stopher of Louisville, Ky.

FOR DEAF children, life is an exercise in frustration and isola- tion unless education begins early. While there is controversy over the best methods for teaching the deaf, many educators now believe in the total-communication philosophy, in which sign language and speaking are used simultaneously to help integrate children with a hearing handicap into a normal environment.

The racquet looks like a bad joke. If a madman had strung it, using pipe cleaners, noodles and macrame, it wouldn't surprise anybody. Sheathed in a cover, it looks like any other racquet, a Head Professional metal frame, the grip covered with green gauze.

The Art of Miss Hanks During her eight years as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, Nancy Hanks has turned the Federal Government into the country's pre-eminent benefactor of the performing arts. With a political adroitness that has earned Washington's respect, Miss Hanks built up the Endowment's annual grants from $11 million to over $100 million. She has demonstrated a knack for persuading legislators that appropriations for the arts can make good politics.

BY FEDERAL Census Bureau estimates, the average Con necticut resident ought to be getting an annual income of at least $5,348--and in towns like Darien and New Canaan as much as $11,404 and $10,964 respectively. For a family of four, this would mean a household average of $21,392 statewide--and for Darien,$45,616.

Leeds Pond Park in Plandome, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Bonnie Gail Sarnoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Sarnoff of Bethpage, L.I. to John Thomas Wark, son of Thomas Edison Wark of Philadelphia and Marie Jean Wark of Largo, Fla.

IN JUST a few months, the medicalliability crisis, which has been dormant this spring and summer, will resurface in the state. The stop-gap solutions offered by Public Law 1952 and the insurance company of the Medical Society of the State of New Jersey were temporary indeed. The malpractice monster that was swept under the rug after the crisis of November 1976 will come up again as a more formidable force in November 1977.

Marseille, with 3,000 fun-loving passengers aboard, diverted on its New York-to-Le Havre run by a well-organized cadre of shipnappers demanding $3 million in gold within 48 hours or they'll send the ship to the bottom.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Sept. 3--On a hot, humid afternoon on which even a smart race horse might be expected to prefer a day in the pasture under a spreading oak, Hambletonian history was made at this Midwestern harness racing track.

MOUNT VERNON MAYOR Thomas E.Sharpe says that he does not generally mix politics and government but that he will not take any vacation this year and will be "totally involved" in helping his Democratic Party win control of the City Council in the November election.

One to See Lamont Johnson's film "One on One" recently opened and is now playing around town in the wake of generally good reviews. Concerned with a high school basketball star's confrontation with the highpressure, big-business world of supposedly amateur athletics, the film, which might have become a cliche, instead gives an audience plenty of action--including a terrific basketball game as a finale--and, according to Vincent Canby, "characters of unexpected backbone." This Labor Day weekend finds the American labor movement proving anew the firmness of its adherence to George Meany's maxim that "ideology is baloney." To muster support for its most ambitious and controversial legislative goals in a quarter-century, organized labor is building coalitions of such divergence that its allies in one are its enemies in the other.

"And in view of developments of the last couple of years, I think we have to look forward to a real struggle against economic deterioration."

We wheeled the Chevy Blazer off Interstate 40 at Canoncito, N.M. A bright, round moon cast eerie shadows on the lonely rest area, with its leafless trees and pitted earth, as we quickly inflated air maftresses, locked the car and crawled into cold bed rolls. But my friends and I were not to sleep that night.

Opened in 1935, it has aged well.

AT the suggestion of his travel agent, Lawrence Durrell joins a two-week group tour through Sicily, appropriately called "the Carousel." Irving Penn is possibly a great photographer, though he, resisting superlatives, surely would not designate himself as such, and the term is still a tricky one in such a young medium (if Stieglitz is great, then how does one decide about Arbus, and so forth?). A FEW weeks ago Commissioner William Ratchford of the Connecticut Department on Aging described in these pages what the state was doing to provide services for the elderly. While I agree on the importance of this priority, I see a far less encouraging picture than the one he paints.

Evan (Big Cat) Williams, the defending champion, was down to his last chance in the National Long Driving Championship. His first three tries had missed the 40-yard fairway, and he needed to keep his final ball in play and move it at least 316 yards or he was out.

THE NATION'S unemployment rose to a seasonally adjusted 7.1 percent in August from 6.9 percent in July, the Labor Department reported. Solomon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max S. Solomon of Takoma Park, Md. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. John C. Laske, senior minister of the Overbrook Presbyterian Church is Columbus, Ohio.

The big red and white Sikorsky helicopter whirled away from the Warwick, N.Y., airport and roared off toward New York City at 115 miles an hour. About 40 minutes later, it swung nimbly to a touchdown at the 34th Street Heliport on the East River.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 Senators Abraham A. Ribicoff and Charles H. Percy told President Carter today that they had received "allegations of illegality" about Budget Director Bert Lance and had urged the President to ask Mr. Lance to resign.
ALBANY, Sept. 5 New York State has agreed to buy 9,311 acres in the eastern Adirondack Mountains, including 11 of their highest peaks, to add to the Adirondack Forest Preserve.

If President Carter had stayed with his original pre-inaugural plan for stimulating the economy, the effect of the stimulus would have been felt by Labor Day. But he didn't, opting instead for "business confidence"; that's one good reason why the economy now appears to be pausing, perhaps ready to head downward.

George Barnes, the jazz guitarist who teamed with Bucky Pizzarelli and with Carl Kress in guitar duos and who shared the leadership of a widely acclaimed quartet with Ruby Braff, the cornetist, died of a heart attack Sunday night at his home in Concord, Calif. Mr. Barnes, 56 years old, had been teaching and freelancing in Concord since he moved there from New York in 1975.

TOKYO, Sept. 5 (AP) A member of China's ruling Politburo, in one of the strongest signals of a new "pragmatic" course for the nation, has called on the Chinese people not to follow political theories dogmatically.
POINTE CLAIRE, Quebec At a recent one-day conference here on cancer and death, Dr. Eric Cassell, of New York Hospital, welcomed what he called "the new religion of truth."

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 5 (UPI) Two buildings next to the American Motor Company's main Jeep Division, one of which was packed with new tires, were destroyed today in a $1 million fire that filled the air with billowing, acrid smoke.

MADRID, Sept. 5 (Reuters) Felipe Gonzalez, leader of the Spanish Socialists, said tonight after a two-hour meeting with Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez that neither he nor Mr. Suarez favored forming a coalition government.

GLASSBORO, Sept. 5 The Farmworkers Rights Project of the American Civil Liberties Union will sue New Jersey tomorrow, challenging the constitutionality of the 1966 state law that excludes farm workers from provisions for overtime pay.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 5 (AP) Police officers clad in riot gear broke up a crowd of 300 to 400 busing protesters tonight after the demonstrators blocked traffic on a major highway.
Angel Cordero Jr. will go to the post at the Meadowlands tonight, and this time he will not be competing in one of those exotic promotions in which jockeys drive harness horses.

Encouraged by the success of an unpublicized federally financed experiment that resulted in a 59 percent increase in robbery arrests, the New York City Police Department has assembled a squad of 60 handpicked officers who will be sent into selected high-crime areas to strengthen precinct anticrime efforts.

EDINBURGH Recently,the Edinburgh Festival was forced to cancel one of two scheduled performances of Heinrich von Kleist's comedy, "Das Katchen von Hellbronn," by the Stuttgart State Theater. After a remodeling job that cost more than $l.1 million, the emergency lighting system in the Lyceum Theater failed to operate, so the city's building department refused to issue a license. Several hundred people were turned away at the last moment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 Alonzo L. McDonald Jr., fresh from being sworn in, takes up his post this weekend in Geneva as deputy special trade negotiator signifying a stepped-up American effort to get the long-stalled international trade negotiations into a decisive phase.

WASHINGTON There have been those who have said, "Look at Britain and beware." Parity of reasoning suggests that, as we pioneer new political and economic ideas for overcoming our problems, the moral will become, "Look at Britain and learn." This, at least, is my strong personal conviction.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 5 (AP) The Voyager 1 spacecraft was launched that is to take it by Jupiter and Sat urn ahead of its earlier-launched twin, Voyager 2. A project official termed the flight "absolutely flawless."

LONDON, Sept. 5 (AP) For the first time, the Tate Gallery will hold a public lottery in an effort to save two l8thcentury British paintings from being sold to someone else and perhaps leaving the country.

The conflict arising from the Federal Government's expanding influence over higher education occupies center stage as the academic year opens with Washington locked in battle with many of the nation's colleges and universities.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (UPI) The man accused of ramming his sports car into a crowd at a Ku Klux Klan rally in Plains, Ga., said that he was only trying to disrupt the rally, not hurt anyone. Buddy Cochran, 30 years old, gave this explanation yesterday at a rally of the National United Workers' Organization.
Girls and boys are apparently unequal in the eyes of the law.

Roy M. Goodman, the organization Republican candidate for May or of New York City, was endorsed by former President Gerald R. Ford yesterday as "a tough-minded leader with an outstanding record of accomplishment."

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 5 (AP) A white 17-year-old sniper wearing a swastika armband opened fire on a mostly black crowd at a church picnic today, killing a man and injuring at least three other persons before killing himself, the police said.

BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 5 Rankand-file trade unionists stepped up their attacks on the Government's restrictive pay policy as the annual Trades Union Congress got off to a tumultuous start here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 The Carter Administration is planning to resubmit to Congress its proposal to sell seven highly sophisticated airborne warning systems to Iran, but without the plane's most sensitive gear.
LONDON, Sept., 5 (AP) Some transAtlantic flights were delayed as long as 20 hours today by a nationwide strike of Britain's 850 assistant air traffic controllers.

George S. Schuyler, a major black author and the first black journalist to attain national prominence with the acidic bite of his ideas, died Aug. 31 at New York Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 270 Convent Avenue.

In the largely Jewish 48th Assembly District in Brooklyn, where the only Democratic primary contest for the State Assembly is taking place, there have been some traditional political issues during the campaign "bossism," for example, and which candidate is best qualified.

Barry Farber, the conservative contender in tomorrow's Republican primary, announced yesterday morning that he had won the primary endorsement of James L. Buckley, former Conservative-Republican United States Senator.

Arthur Smadbeck, a pioneer in the development of rural and suburban real estate and president of the New York Coliseum, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 90 years old and had homes at 52 Vanderbilt Avenue here and in Carmel, N.Y.
A gang of youths has been harassing residents of Washington Township in Bergen County for several months, vandalizing homes and threatening people with violence should they report them to the police.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 Following are the texts of the Panama Canal Treaty, the treaty on the neutrality of the Panama Canal and a protocol to the neutrality treaty that were initialed today in Washington by the United States and Panama. Also initialed today, but not reproduced here, were an "agreed minute" to the treaty and an annex on Procedures for the Cessation of Transfer of Activities Carried Out by the Panama Canal Company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 "I knew it was a mistake the moment I said it," Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff reflected today.

A dispute between New York City and the Federal Government over alleged discrimination against women and minority- group members, which had jeopardized milions of dollars in aid to the city's school system, was tentatively settled yesterday, just a day before the opening of the new school year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6 A Federal judge ruled here today that the Howard Hughes estate owes $71 million to the former stockholders of Air West.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI) Labor unrest among teachers is at its lowest ebb in years as most schools opened this week, the National Education Association said today, with only scattered teacher strikes or threats of walkouts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) Ninetyseven of 101 Haitian peasants who arrived at the United States Naval base at Guantanamo, Cuba, in a sinking boat on Aug. 10 have been flown back to their country, the State Department said today.
Carlton Fisk and the Boston Red Sox jumped all over the expansion Blue Jays in Toronto last night in order to keep pace in the American League East Division with the New York Yankees.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 6 Prime Minister Menahem Begin said today that Israel had prepared a proposal for a peace treaty in response to an American request for such a document.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 The Comptroller of the Currency has reffered Bert Lance's use of his bank's airplanes to the Department of Justice for possible criminal prosecution.

Edward K. Brass, who retired in 1962 as vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died last Wednesday in a nursing home in Cedar Grove, N.J. He was 79 years old and lived at 3 Windsor Place, Upper Montclair, N.J.

SAN SALVADOR, Sept. 6 (AP) Kidnappers armed with machine guns seized the wife of an American industrialist today after a shootout with her bodyguards in front of her husband's company offices, the police said.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 6 (UPI) Robert Dufala, a nursery school teacher who once ran for Congress, entered a surprise plea of guilty today to charges of threatening to kill former Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller.

The Stage Company, the nonprofit group that is attempting to maintain professional theater in Queens, will begin its second season at Flushing Town Hall with the popular Joseph Kesselring comedy, "Arsenic and Old Lace," was announced yesterday by Howard da Silva, associate director. Ron Roston has been signed to stage the play.

A special state court on judicial discipline will investigate Judge Jacob D. Fuchsberg's transaction in New York City securities while crucial cases on the city's finances were before the bench on which he sat, the New York State Court of Appeals.
Iris Brussels of Paterson, N.J., a pianist, composer and teacher, died there of pneumonia Monday in Barnert Memorial Hospital. She was 77 years old.

As schools across New Jersey prepared to reopen today for 1.4 million students, officials disclosed that tense, 11th-hour contract bargaining was under way in at least six districts, including two large ones in Monmouth County and two others in Morris County.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 The Justice Department unsealed an indictment today that charges Tongsun Park with 36 felony violations, all of them stemming from an alleged influence-buying operation here that was intended to benefit the South Korean Government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 Representatives of the three large lumber companies that would lose the most in a proposed expansion of Redwood National Park indicated today they did not expect to succeed in their efforts to block the addition of 48,000 acres of their timber land to the northern California park.

A mistrial was declared yesterday because of a prosecutor's statement in the trial of Irving Goldman, former New York City Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, who was charged with conspiracy and fraud in the sale of candy supplies for subway vending machines.

TRENTON, Sept. 6 The chairman and two other members of the Casino Control Commission, which will regulate gambling in Atlantic City, were sworn into office today before cheering Atlantic City residents.

"We're going to need a lot of help," Harvey Lichtenstein, president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, said yesterday as he looked over a sea of mud, five feet deep, in the academy's basement. Under the mud lay costumes, scenery, electrical equipment, props, tools and other paraphernalia.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 6 The establishment of a "green belt" tightened against the southern border of the Sahara a swath of planted trees and shrubs stretching from the Atlantic to the Red Sea has repeatedly been proposed for more than 20 years as the best way to hem in the apparent southward march of the desert.

Morgan Stanley Company, in its second move in less than two months to attract wealthy individual clients, disclosed here yesterday that the investment banking house would shortly begin recruiting brokers for a new "big ticket" retail office to be set up in New York.

If repair bills are any indication, the often-criticized automobiles made by American manufacturers are slowly becoming more reliable, according to the Hertz Corporation, the car-rental company that is the nation's largest nongovernmental purchaser of cars.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 "I knew it was a mistake the moment I said it," Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff reflected today.
A "dream mile" race between the world one-mile record-holder, John Walker of New Zealand, and Filbert Bayi of Tanzania has been canceled by the withdrawal today of Walker because of health problems.

Steve Henderson batted in three more runs yesterday as the New York Mets defeated the Montreal Expos, 5-3, but the deed was done in solitary splendor before only 4,702 cash customers the smallest "crowd" of the baseball season in Shea Stadium.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 6 (AP) Dr. Donald W. Hastings, an organizer of the transsexual program at the University of Minnesota Hospitals, died Sunday after suffering a heart attack. He was 61 years old.

CAIRO, Sept. 6 Foreign ministers of the Arab League countries ended a four day meeting here today determined to try to win a commitment from the UnitedStates and other countries to oppose any Israeli moves to annex any part of the occupied territories.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 6 The head of the military government said today that he had seen documentary evidence that he believed implicated former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto in a political murder.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 The Comptroller of the Currency had referred Bert Lance's use of his bank's airplanes to the Department of Justice for possible criminal prosecution.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 The 12 member's of the Hanafi Moslem sect who seized three buildings in downtown Washington last March and took 134 persons hostage at gunpoint for three days were given severe sentences in Superior Court today that may send at least two of them to prison for life.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 6 Ed Marinaro knew it was coming, but it still felt "like a slap in the face" today when the Jets placed him on recallable waivers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 There have been more heads of government in Washington this week all of them from the Western Hemisphere than at any time since the funeral of President Kennedy in 1963. They are here at the invitation of President Carter, who has a clear purpose in mind.
Dr. George L. Wolcott, a research specialist in preventive medicine, died Sunday at Riverview Hospital, Red Bank, N.J. He was 64 years old and lived in Franklin Lakes, N.J.

In the biggest shake-up of the Police Department's narcotics and vice enforcement divisions since 1971, about 40 of the most senior detectives in these units will soon be transferred to less prestigious jobs.

Three premieres, as well as revivals of plays by Shakespeare, George Kelly and Lillian Hellman, will mark the 1977-78 season of the McCarter Theater Company in Princeton, N.J., it was announced yesterday by Michael Kahn, producing director.

Ernie DiGregorio, an unhappy Buffalo Brave for several seasons, is now a happy Los Angeles Laker. The Lakers have called a news conference for today to announce the purchase of the 6-foot backcourt man from the wheeling and decline Braves.

DUBLIN THOSE IRISH who think about it at all are quietly delighted that some 70 treasures of early Irish art are to travel abroad. The collection, scheduled to go on display at New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art on Oct. 15, and later in San Francisco, Pittsburgh, Boston and Philadelphia, is the first of its kind ever to leave the country, and it is of major significance.

ROVING LEGACY The New York Kammermusiker, a group of instrumentalists specializing in vintage classics, really gets around. Returning last month from another concert tour of Central and South America, the young musicians are now back on the local scene, giving a performance this afternoon at 4 at the Lincoln Center branch of the New York Public Library, 111 Amsterdam Avenue. Admission is free.

DETROIT, Sept. 6 The nation's driving public continued to show a strong demand for new cars during August, and new-car sales, particularly those of the General Motors Corporation, broke records for both the final 10-day selling period and the month, posting some surprising gains, in the opinion of the industry and the investing public.

The Democratic mayoral primary, marked by a record number of candidates and few substantive issues, moved toward a climax in tomorrow's primary as testy and tired candidates exchanged personal charges and tried to shake as many hands and make as many speeches as possible in the final hours.

After having played in Trinidad and Venezuela last week, the Cosmos depart today on a trip to Japan, China and India with three players they may acquire for the next North American Soccer League season.

After surprisingly active trading last week in the normally quiet period before Labor Day, the credit markets briefly attempted to continue their advance yesterday and then settled back. At the close, most prices were unchanged for the day or down slightly.

Thomas R. Reid, who retired as executive director of civic and governmental affairs for the Ford Motor Company in 1975, died yesterday in Bon Secours Hospital, Grosse Pointe, Mich. He was 63 years old.

BRISTOL, R.I. WHEN YOU are a recent widower, actually a young senior citizen, with an 11year-old daughter to raise, you suddenly become much more than a father. You are mother, cook, dishwasher and dryer, cleaning man, grocery shopper, tutor, supervisor of homework, expert on clothing for a young girl, host to her friends. You are magistrate without portfolio of social and religious mores. This multifaceted job becomes a continuing career.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI) 4 firebomb was tossed into a crowded northwest Washington nightspot last night injuring at last 15 persons, the police reported. Three of the victims were listed in critical condition in hospitals, officials said, and several others were seriously burned.
LONDON, Sept. 6 The estate of Benjamin Britten, the composer, who died in December, was valued at the equivalent of $2.9 million in his will made public yesterday.

The four candidates for the Democratic nomination for Borough President of Manhattan found themselves sitting together before television cameras for the first time yesterday, and they agreed that even the limited exposure afforded by a daytime talk show and a cable TV forum was long overdue.

College classrooms opened yesterday in New Jersey with Rutgers University students providing the largest contingent. Rutgers has 47,860 students and most of them started classes yesterday.

More blue-chip players clashed yesterday at the United States Open tennis championships, but Blue Cross matters still dominated the seventh day of action at Forest Hills.

PEKING, Sept. 6 Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiao-ping said today that efforts to establish normal diplomatic relations between the United States and China had suffered a setback during the visit last month of Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance.

Reid A. Railton, a British designer of racing cars, sport cars and racing boats, died last Thursday in a hospital in Berkeley, Calif. He was 82 years old and had lived in Berkeley.

ADERDEEN, SCOTLAND Not too many years ago; Lord Lau rence Olivier, commuting between London and his home at Brighton on the Channel coast, was appalled to find that the dining car could not produce a kippered herring for his breakfast. The great actor complained, and soon he and his traveling companions on the Brighton Belle had their kippers once more.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6 A. Alan Post, an unusual figure in California politics and public administration, left the office of legislative analyst last week to go into retirement at age 63.
A late rally sent stock prices slightly higher yesterday as the stock market recorded its fourth gain in a row.

The rise in margin debt to record levels reflects in part successful efforts on the part of some brokerage firms to encourage customers to borrow money for purposes other than buying securities.

The state parole board granted the 6-foot-9-inch Barnes parole from the Rhode Island Correctional Institution in Cranston, where he has served four months of a one-year sentence. CHICAGO, Sept. 9 Even a patient man like Joe Torre couldn't grin or bear it after what happened to the Mets today in Wrigley Field.
The former Lady Ashley, who was the widow of Douglas Fairbanks Sr. and a former wife of Clark Gable, died of cancer June 30 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 73 years old.

ATLANTA, Sept. 9 (UPI) Federal health officials said today that an investigation was being conducted to determine whether an outbreak of legionnaires' disease in Columbus, Ohio, may be connected with excavation for a new building at a hospital where many of the cases have occurred.

The leading participant in what is the only close race left in the major leagues, the Yankees, have no time to laugh at rookie-laden, expansion clubs like the Toronto Blue Jays. That may have been all right early in the season, although it cost them when they lost four of the eight games with Toronto in April and June.
Amid talk of Russian interest in buying American grain as well as heavy buying in wheat and corn futures, prices of those commodities rose sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

PARAMUS, Sept. 9 No one likes the intersection of Routes 4 and 17 here not the thousands of motorists caught each week in its traffic jams or the government officials and bureaucrats who have been wringing their hands for years about finding the money to unsnarl the bottleneck.
Following is the text of Mayor Beame's statement of concession early yesterday morning, as recorded by The New York Times:

The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that it planned to file a complaint next week with the Treasury Department charging Japanese steelmakers with dumping steel products in this country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) The Department of Agriculture Friday announced a temporary ban on direct imports of most horses from Britain, Ireland and France because of an outbreak of contagious breeding disease, equine metritis.
The company of "The Merchant" was still in shock yesterday over the sudden death Thursday of Zero Mostel, its star.

During my recent Korean visit I called upon Whoopee Bag Blak, whose generous cash donations to Congressmen over the years have made him a notorious figure in Washington. Blakbag Whoopee, to give him the Americanized name by which all Washington knew him in those days, had been a neighbor of mine for several years in the nation's capital, and I found him hurt and astonished at the allegations now being leveled against him.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) The Communications Satellite Corporation said today the Federal Communications Commission is asking Comsat to say whether it is keeping an escrow account properly pending the outcome of a court appeal of an F.C.C. decision involving Comsat's rates.

Alice Crimmins Grace, freed on a controversial parole, dashed into a waiting car and presumably a new life yesterday after serving five years of a five-to-20year sentence for the strangulation of her 4 year-old daughter.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) The Senate approved a 1978 Federal budget of $459.2 billion today after rejecting Republican efforts to make room for an acrossthe-board tax cut.

Frederick William Irving Lundy, founder and owner of the seafood restaurant bearing his name, at 1901 Emmons Avenue, in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, died Tuesday at his apartment at that address after long illness. He was 82 years old.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 9 President Augusto Pinochet received a triumphal welcome in the streets of this capital today on his return from a visit to the United States.
A Brooklyn man and his wife, both in their 70's, were wounded yesterday by a single bullet fired during a robbery attempt, the police reported.

At 7:30 yesterday morning, having caught barely three hours of sleep, Edward I. Koch, bleary-eyed and wearylooking but freshly showered, was walking up and down the platform of an elevated subway station in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn urging commuters to vote for him again.

"Everybody felt that Bella Abzug was going to do a lot better," Mayor Beame said at a news conference yesterday. From the opening bell to the final pre-primary polls, she had been counted at least second, and thus destined for the mayoral runoff. But Mrs. Abzug garnered less than 17 percent of the vote, half her one-time strength.

If 3,476 people who voted for Mario Cuomo had voted for the Mayor instead, it would be Abe Beame who'd be out on the streets now, battling Edward Koch in the Democratic mayoral runoff campaign. But they didn't, and so, by a hair, after 31 years in municipal affairs, the Mayor is a loser and Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Koch are winners.
Auditors have uncovered new cases of apparent expense-account padding by officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, sources close to the widening investigation reported yesterday.

RULING IN TENNESSEE HITS LOAN COMPANIES NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 9 (UPI) Two major small-loan companies today announced cutbacks in branch operations in Tennessee and the state's largest bank said it would reduce consumer loans by 75 percent because of a Tennessee Supreme Court decision barring interest rates over 10 percent.
LONDON, Sept. 9 (AP) The Bank of England today announced a new bond issue of nearly $1.75 billion, maturing in 1995 and paying interest of 12 percent annually.

On a hot June night in 1964, a group of Mississippi men, all of them members of the White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, abducted and murdered three civil-rights workers, Michael Schwerner, James Chaney and Andrew Goodman. They then sought to bury their crime from the world beneath 20 feet of earth at a dam site.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) Recommendations to streamline the administration of the House are considered likely to win approval on the floor following their approval yesterday by the House Commission on Administrative Review.
"As I see it," said Percy E. Sutton, "We have three choices Cuomo, Koch or Going Fishing."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) The United States and Pakistan agreed today to trade information about possibly illegal sales activities by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and the Boeing Company in Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 Affidavits in an Internal Revenue Service investigation released today indicate that Bert Lance's banking problems disappeared into a bureaucratic haze between the time he was nominated and and the time he was confirmed as Director of the Office of Management and Budget.
KIMBERLEY, South Africa, Sept. 9 (AP) A magistrate ruled today that a black man who plunged to his death from a sixth-floor window of a police station July 7 committed suicide.

BOSTON, Sept. 9 Kenneth P. O'Donnell, former aide and close adviser to President John F. Kennedy, died at 3:15 A.M. today in the intensive care unit of Boston's Beth Israel Hospital. He was 53 years old.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 9 (UPI) The 12-Meter yacht courageous practiced against Independence today in preparation for her upcoming defense of the America's Cup against Australia on Tuesday.
The West Side Tennis Club announced the resignation yesterday of William J. McCullough as a member of the board of governors and chairman of the United States Open commitee.

Shirley Bassey returned to concert performing Thursday night at the Westchester Premiere Theater in Tarrytown, N.Y., after a fivemonth layoff. She will be appearing there through tomorrow and then again from Wednesday through Sept. 18. The theater was full except for the extreme side sections, and much of the crowd seemed to be in an adoring mood. That said, this reviewer finds himself at something of a loss as to what to add.

MOSCOW, Sept. 9 Leonid I. Brezhnev today received Chief Justice Warren E. Burger for a conversation dominated by Mr. Brezhnev's criticism of the Carter Administration's stand on strategic arms limitation.

BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 9 This year's long-awaited convention of Britain's union leadership slogged to an end here today, the last agenda item a vote of thanks to the press that, many speakers had complained, tends to pay too much attention to Britain's industrial disputes.

TONES AND TEAMS There is a rewarding cornucopia of vintage screen music over the weekend and into next week, some of it going back to the early days of the talkies in the exceptional array of Universal revivals now at the Museum of Modern Art.

In my role as master of ceremonies of the Miss America pageant for 23 years, I've been asked many questions by many interviewers about many aspects of the pageant: How has the pageant changed over the years? How much longer do I think that I will be the emcee of the pageant? Tell me some of the interesting or unusual events that have occurred in your years as emcee. And many other very unusual questions.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 The Jets' drive toward respectability narrowly missed a successful preseason finale tonight as the Redskins set up two touchdowns with pass interceptions and won, 14-7.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) The new natural gas pipeline from Alaska may cost $13 billion or $14 billion to build, a 37 percent increase over the current estimate of $9.6 billion, Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger predicted today.

ANCHORAGE, Sept. 9 (AP) All 13 persons aboard a twin-engine plane bound from Iliamna to Anchorage died when it crashed into 10,016-foot Mount Iliamna about 200 miles southeast of here, according to state troopers.

Ending his weeklong first series of religious meetings in a Soviet bloc country yesterday, Billy Graham said in Budapest that his visit to Hungary had changed his thinking about Communism, and said that he had found that in that officially atheist nation people can "freely worship God."
The Civil Aeronautics Board approved yesterday a $256 New York-London round-trip fare for "standby" passengers that will enable other airlines to compete with Laker Airways' $236 no-frills bargain.
SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 9 Tongsun Park, the South Korean businessman charged with illegal lobbying in the United States, said today that he had no intention of immediately returning to Washington.
MACON, Ga. A few days ago I pulled up to the drive-in window of a bank to cash a check and was mildly astonished when the teller blurted out, "Oh, you're Neva Jane, aren't you?"

Eight-year-old Ann, whose cerebral palsy kept her in a wheelchair, was known to have a severe hearing loss. She never responded to the other children at Wayne Multiple Handicapped Center, in Wayne, N.J., and the therapists wondered if she could hear anything softer than a loud noise.

A group of black leaders called upon President Carter yesterday to put his Administration on record as favoring "affirmative action" programs when it discloses its position on a major civil rights case pending before the United States Supreme Court.

Zero Mostel, the actor who became a legend on Broadway with his poignant portrayal of the woebegone dairyman Tevye in "Fiddler on the Roof," died of cardiac arrest Thursday night at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 62 years old.

MOSCOW, Sept. 9 (UPI) Trade between the United States and the Soviet Union dropped by 21.7 percent during the first half of 1977, reflecting cuts in both Soviet agricultural and nonagricultural purchases.

Motorists whose automobile insurance is up for renewal can demand that the company issue the new policy for the same length of time stated in the expiring one, the state's Insurance Commissioner, James J. Sheeran, said yesterday.

The New York City Opera's version of Bizet's "Carmen," given its first performance of the season Thursday night, has had a big facelift at the hands of the company's new stage director, Cynthia Auerbach. The results are exceptionally lively, with some brawls that would do justice to an old-style western saloon fight.
John Wummer, a retired flutist, died of cancer in a hospital in San Francisco last Tuesday. He was 78 years old and made his home in New York.

A 34-year-old Suffolk County man was arrested yesterday on charges of sexually molesting a 10-year-old girl at knifepoint in Glen Oaks, Queens. He was also being questioned by the police about the rapes of a dozen women in this middle-class community and in neighboring Fresh Meadows over the past year.

The state of American politics is a bit clearer on election night at the Kanawha Democratic Club in East Harlem, where Frank G. Rossetti sweats out votes to survive and Richard M. Nixon sweats out memoir money on the TV set that drones over in the clubhouse corner at the convergence of two walls of time-warped momentoes.

SAN JOSE, Calif., sept. 9 More than 1,000 women pledged to the goal of enlarging the political power of women began a three-day meeting here today amid an atmosphere of optimism for their cause. They cheered the news that more and more women were being elected to public office, jeered reports of bias in government, and thunderously encouraged passage of the Equal Rights Amendment.

Chris Evert has a painful pinched nerve in her left shoulder. Her biorhythms are changing for the worse. And today she plays Wendy Turnbull in the women's singles final of the United States Open tennis championships.

The Folger Coffee Company of Cincinnati, a Procter Gamble division, has reduced the wholesale price on vacuum-packed coffee by 10 cents a pound, to $3.38, effective immediately, it announced yesterday.
Robert W. Thibodeau, for 10 years treasurer of the Emhart Corporation of Farmington, Conn., machinery manufacturers, died Thursday night at his home, 57 Crocus Lane, Farmington. He was 59 years old.
NEWARK, Sept. 9 (AP) A Federal judge has cleared the way for the construction of a 1,000-ton-a-day garbage baler in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 In its drive for Congressional approval of the new Panama Canal agreements, the Carter Administration has made a decision to bypass the House of Representatives in a way that could cost it some support for the treaties.
WASHINGTON Many Republicans are talking about an off-year tune-up for their party, when what it needs is an overhaul.

The Metropolitan Opera Company and its musicians, after months of stormy bargaining, yesterday reached an agree ment on a new three-year contract, thus virtually assuring that the Met's 93d sea son will start on schedule next month.

Crime has always paid and paid handsomely for Pinkerton's Inc. and other suppliers of protection. Thanks partly to rising crime rates, Pinkerton's sales in the last five years have expanded to $214.4 million from $162.2 million while earnings have risen to $2.90 from $1.98 a share.

A woman with crimson lips and attired in a haute couture gypsy dress slunk through the scribbling crowd of journalists around Wendy Turnbull and stuck her face inches from the tennis player's. Startled, Miss Turnbull turned to stare at her.
Faced with a veritable mountain of copper that has caused prices to tumble, the nation's producers have begun to idle their workers and mines in an attempt to cut costs and whittle inventories.

For people who go regularly to concerts and operas, the debut that turns unexpectedly into a triumph is one of the rarer pleasures. To see a heretofore unknown artist start out confidently into a performance, to hear a new individuality and artistry fill out the lines of a work familiar in other interpretations and, above all, to know the excitement that comes with encountering something really superior all of this can be heady indeed.
HONG KONG, Sept. 9 China commemorated the first anniversary of the death of Mao Tse-tung today with a brief, solemn ceremony opening his white marble mausoleum in Peking's Tien An Men Square.

A woman and two men were killed, a dozen firemen were injured and four tenants were plucked to safety from fireescape balconies early yesterday when a fire believed set by an arsonist ravaged part of a six-story tenement on the Lower East Side.

ASSEN, The Netherlands, Sept. 9 After several days of tension and intermittent violence, a trial ended today for eight Moluccans involved in the June seizure of a train and elementary school that left six terrorists and two hostages dead.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 In a break with a policy of long standing, the Carter Administration decided today to allow four Soviet trade union representatives to visit the United States, despite the opposition of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

Hans Friderichs, the West German Finance Minister, announced yesterday in Bonn that he would resign to become head of the Dresdner Bank, one of West Germany's largest commercial banks. He will replace the late Jurgen Ponto, who was murdered by urban guerrillas in July.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 The Advisory Council of National Organizations, formed in 1969 as the public-participation arm of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, voted late last night to dissolve itself.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) Mortgage interest rates advanced again in August, but appear to have stabilized at about 9 percent, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.
ATLANTA, Sept. 9 (UPI) The longer that women use oral contraceptives the greater their risk of developing a rare but serious nonmalignant liver tumor, Federal health officials said today.

Hundreds of teen-agers and their parents lined up yesterday at the Board of Education headquarters in Brooklyn for what has become an annual event: the reshuffling of students to schools other than those to which they had been assigned.

Marie M. Lambert won her solid upset victory in the Democratic primary for Manhattan surrogate by waging a campaign that took advantage of the apparent trend toward women candidates below the top spot of the ticket in Thursday's voting.

United States and allied military analysts are concerned over Arab reaction to an expansion by Israel of settlements in occupied Arab territories, warning that this might result in an acceleration of military preparations and increased unity of Arab command.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 The House Republican leadership proposed today a comprehensive plan for curing the deficits in the Social Security System by a variety of means, including mandatory inclusion in Social Security of the 2.5 million civilian Government employees who now have a separate retirement system.
Roy M. Goodman yesterday challenged his three opponents in the New York mayoral race to discuss campaign issues in six televised debates.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 9 Chile has become a bazaar filled with foreign goods that are snapped up by the well-to-do while millions of workers and their families are living hand to mouth.

The Chet Baker Quartet that played at Stryker's, 86th Street at Columbus Avenue, Thursday evening, was a bit unusual. It consisted of six musicians, only three of whom were officially members of Mr. Baker's quartet. Two a drummer from Seattle and a tenor saxophonist were sitting in and the bassist was a substitute for the bassist Mr. Baker had planned to have.
Fifty years after the "Four Musketeers" of French tennis began a run of six straight years in which France won the Daivs Cup, the four players were honored yesterday in Paris.

BUCK HILI FALLS, Pa., Sept. 9 Warning that civil litigation has become so "painfully slow," so "prohibitively expensive" and so widespread, Judge Irving R. Kaufman said today that Federal courts faced two choices: "reform or disaster."

Melinda Kemp Smith, daughter of Mrs. George Douglas Lawrence of Bronxville, N.Y., and Renshaw Smith of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Steven Kenneth Porter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Porter of Old Westbury, L.I.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 10 (AP) Despite the fact that he wore a swastika armband, a 17-year-old gunman who opened fire on a group of blacks at a Labor Day church picnic here had no Nazi affiliations, the police say.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 10, (AP) A 47year-old South Euclid woman who was raped 2 years ago has been awarded $22,000 in damages from her attacker.

BLUEFISHING remains inconsistent along much of both the North and South Shores, but offshore the action is super, with Southern fish such as wahoo and sailfish reported within range. The Hudson Canyon is alive with gamefish and it is likely to stay that way for another few weeks until the first fall storm chases them away.

TRENTON THE placement of emotionally disturbed or socially malajusted youngsters in residential treatment centers as far away as Florida and Texas no longer will be permitted under a plan adopted by the state's Division for Youth and Family Services.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON BEFORE they paved over much of Westchester, some of the cheerier sounds of that bygone era were the greetings of wagonmen, those enterprising souls who brought their green groceries, eggs or even macaroons directly to the kitchen door.

THOMAS A. EDISON COLLEGE did not teach George Meisler a thing, but it awarded him a degree anyway. The college thought he deserved it.

The first "Boheme" of the New York City Opera's fall season at the New York State Theater Friday night offered no surprises. These were familiar singers in familiar roles, working with minimal rehearsal in a warhorse opera in an ancient production.

ASSEN, the Netherlands, Sept. 10 Using helicopters and armored personnel carriers, Dutch policemen and military units staged a predawn raid on the Moluccan quarter here today in another search for weapons.

WILTON AT FIRST blush visitors might think that it is another component of a movie set. HEMPSTEAD, L.I. "It beats going to a psychiatrist." That is how Joan Rubinstein, a Merrick housewife, explained her reasons for participating in Hofstra University's Gray Wig Alumni Repertory Theater Company.

Intent on erasing the popular perception of municipal hospitals as drab institutions used almost exclusively by the poor, the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation is initiating a series of changes aimed at enabling the 18 hospitals it runs to compete more effectively with private voluntary hospitals for the city's dwindling number of patients.
CONGRESS is inching toward a coherent Federal policy on adult education amid evidence that existing programs are not reaching those who seem to need them most.

Officials of British Airways said yesterday that they would make vigorous efforts at the White House to overrule a decision Friday by the Civil Aeronautics Board that the airline said puts severe limits on competition against Laker Airways' no-frills, $236 roundtrip bargain fare between New York and London.
PARIS, Sept. 10 UNESCO will not award its two annual prizes to outstanding contributors to the fight against illiteracy this year because the number of illiterates is still increasing.
BOSTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) Mayor Kevin White's campaign to collect $50 million in delinquent taxes will include the posting of pictures of offenders on billboards around the city.

COLOMBO, Sri Lanka Unlike most of its neighbors, this island republic in the Indian Ocean has made important progress in an area that many experts consider the key to the region's development birth control.

Tonight "60 Minutes" begins its 10th season on CBS, with another segment in its weekly magazine format that promises to cause a stir an interview with Idi Amin's former health minister, who discusses his ex-boss's "cannibalism," ...

EAST WINDSOR at first glance may not seem a very exciting spot. It is an area of nursery and tobacco farms and an incipient mushroom industry and is home for about 8,900 people. Surprisingly enough it also furnishes top stars and top shows to 1,325 people nightly at its two dinner theaters.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 President Hugo Banzer Suarez of Boliva brought his landlocked country a step closer to the seas this week by persuading the presidents of Chile and Peru to consider opening an access route for Bolivia to the Pacific.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Sept. 10 (UPI) Russian athletes will probably leave United States Olympic team members in the dust in 1980 as a result of the Soviet Union's use of hypnosis and "autogenic" training, according to a noted psychologist and expert in behavior modification.

BEDFORD ANDREW BURNS and Fred Ferriola are challenging the rules of the American Institute of Ar chitects. The two designers refuse to separate architecture from building, an issue that has divided the architectural profession for years.

EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa., Sept. 10 Kevin Burns strengthened his bid to become Columbia University's starting quarterback by completing seven of 12 passes for 118 yards and a touchdown in one half of play today to lead the Lions to a 10-7 scrimmage victory over East Stroudsburg (Pa.) State.

ONE of the best restaurants in France's wine capital, Bordeaux, is a place called Clavel. It's in a rundown section of town near the railroad station. Clavel started out as a workman's bar and, in fact, half of it still is. The other half, separated only by a door, is one of the most elegant dining rooms in the city.

OUR great "Ulysses" adventure which culminated in 1934, had really begun in 1932, when James Joyce's "Ulysses" was contraband in the United States, absolutely forbidden. The only way you could buy it was under-the-counter in an edition published by Miss Sylvia Beach in Paris under the colophon of Shakespeare and Company, the name of her very famous little bookstore on the Left Bank, where many American tourists found their way.

Women were holding their own as the second year of coeducation began at the nation's military academies last week. And at the Naval Academy at Annapolis, the Military Academy at West Point and the Coast Guard Academy at New London, Conn., fewer freshman women have dropped out during summer training this year than last.

People are never happy with their hair the way it is naturally. Those of us with fine straight hair dream about clusters of thick, glossy curls. But fine hair refuses to hold a set and has been risky to perm because it's so easily damaged.
Dorothea Langhorne, librarian for Community School District 6 before her retirement in 1972, died Thursday at her home, 555 Edgecombe Avenue. She was 70 years old.

New Yorkers have voted for a fresh start in their city politics. Often maligned for sloth and self-indulgence, they delivered a message in last week's primary that deserves to be heard by an often skeptical nation. This city is eager for renewal, and its citizens are doing their share to earn the help they require.

A skillful writer can get away with using the most conventional of materials, and Robert L. Duncan does so in TEMPLE DOGS (Morrow, $8.95). This is a novel of Big Business, and in it can be found our usual assortment of friends.

Today is the fourth anniversary of the military coup that overthrew the elected Government of Salvador Allende in Chile. The right-wing junta, led by General Augusto Pinochet Ugarte, has now held power more than a year longer than did President Allende. Whatever harm the left-wing Allende regime caused Chile by its catastrophic, ideologically motivated mismanagement of the economy, the brutal repression of the present Government has been even more harmful.

Perhaps the most frequently asked question on growing peonies is why don't my plants bloom? There may be a number of reasons: Plants too young and immature. Large clumps planted without proper division. Buds killed by late frost. Excessively hot weather and high humidity during early spring. Poor location. But the most common cause of most peony failures is improper planting.

CONCORD, N.H., Spt. 13 (AP) Eleanor Vinton, the last person to hold life tenure as New Hampshire's poet laureate, died yesterday. She was 78 Years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Panama invited the United Nations today to send observers to its Oct. 23 plebiscite on the Panama Canal treaties and welcomed a "first-hand" investigation of human rights in that country by an agency of the Organization of American States.
TROY, N.Y., Sept. 13 (AP) John J. Purcell, former Mayor of Troy and Democratic chairman of Rensselaer County, died Thursday at the age of 70 in St. Mary's Hospital here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) House tax writers voted tentatively today to include in the Social Security system all Federal, state and local government civilian employees.
Deep in Flushing the late Samuel Brunner started manufacturing a pouch to hold fishing flies in 1945, after he was discharged from the Army.

REGGIO NELL'EMILIA, Italy A foundry owner looked in vain for workers for months, so when Magd Kedr Megahed, an Egyptian, showed up asking for a job, the owner hired him immediately. Mr. Megahed had no papers, no place to live and no training in foundry work, but the factory here in northern Italy had been operating at only 30 percent capacity, so the owner took a chance.

TRENTON, Sept. 13 Governor Byrne today signed a new state law that provides for up to seven years in prison and $100,000 fines for officials who are convicted of corruption. The law takes effect immediately.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (UPI) Gov. James R. Thompson vetoed a bill today that would have banned welfare abortions in Illinois. The Republican Governor said that the bill was "more than unfair it is cruel."

New York State's Mental Hygiene Department yesterday reported "great difficulty" in finding small community places for retarded patients in its efforts to close one Manhattan residence, and said discussions were under way to phase out another.

DETROIT, Sept. 13 The General Motors Corporation today unveiled the first diesel-powered American passenger car as it began taking the wraps off the auto industry's biggest family so far of slimmed-down automobiles designed to meet stricter fuel-economy standards.

Leopold Stokowski, possibly the bestknown symphonic conductor of all time, died in England yesterday at the age of 95, in his house at Nether Wallop, a village in Hampshire, England. He had been suffering from a mild virus infection that had not been thought serious, and his death was attributed to a coronary attack.

BARBARANO ROMANO, Italy LEGEND has it that the finest food in all of Italy is not to be found in restaurants and trattorias but in private homes. A visit to the country residence of the Angelo Bettojas, a one-and-a-half-hour drive from Rome; in the province of Viterbo, is eloquent proof.

Mario M. Cuomo and Representative Edward I. Koch, entering the second half of their campaign for next Monday's Democratic mayoral primary runoff, unveiled major new television advertising campaigns yesterday. It was billed as the "Gala Opening Night Concert" of the Philharmonic's 1977-78 season, and it anticipated tonight's regular subscription concert. It also was a benefit concert for the Philharmonic, and it netted almost $45,000.

The New York State Department of Taxation and Finance will look into whether Governor Carey is legally re- quired to pay personal income tax on the value of flights his children made on state aircraft, James H. Tully Jr., the Tax Commissioner, said yesterday.

Stokes, the former United States Attorney in Atlanta, was pictured as having closed out an investigation of a bank headed by Bert Lance over the objections of his subordinates and at a time when he was hoping to save his job.

The New Jersey State Insurance Department went to court yesterday to prevent the cancellation of 20,000 automobile insurance policies by the financially troubled Empire Mutual Insurance Company and its subsidiary, Allcity. Koch, entering the second half of their campaign for next Monday's Democratic mayoral primary runoff, unveiled major new television advertising campaigns yesterday. American raisins are always seedless, which for the East Coast home grower usually means the white Interlaken variety. A relatively hardy (to 10 below zero) grape, the Interlaken bears at the end of August, filling the air with a heavy sweet aroma.

R.H. Macy Company, one of the nation's leading retailers, reported yesterday a 42.6 percent increase in earnings in the fourth fiscal quarter ended July 30. The 77-store chain had record sales and earnings not only for the quarter but also for the fiscal year ended July 30.

LONDON THERE ARE TWO Royal Ballets in Britain. One is based at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, and is about 90 dancers strong. Since 1949, this company has been a regular visitor to New York. "SAN FRANCISCO GOOD TIMES" is an hour-long black-and-white documentary about the underground newspaper Good Times, which was published between 1968 and 1972 by a staff that lived communally for part of that period. Delegates to the convention of the United Electrical Workers took a position yesterday that opposed forced retirement because of age but supported measures that would encourage workers to choose early retirement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15--The House of Representatives approved today an increase in the minimum wage in each of the next three years and, in a tense, dramatic roll-call, defeated by one vote a proposed subminimum wage for youths.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15--The United States, citing growing ties to Egypt, said today that it favored sending American technicians abroad to help rehabilitate Soviet-built planes of the Egyptian Air Force.
Mel Blount has patched up his salary differences with Dan Rooney and his personal dispute with his coach. Chuck Noll, and has rejoined the Pittsburgh Steelers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP)--The Senate today confirmed a series of ambassadorial nominations, including President Carter's choice of Gov. Raul H. Castro of Arizona to be ambassador to Argentina.

A state hearing officer, finding that the controversial Westway was likely to worsen air pollution despite assurances to the contrary, has recommended that a construction permit for the billion-dollar roadway be denied.

A businessman, his wife and their two daughters were indicted yesterday on charges that they carried out a fraudulent scheme to remove $300,000 from two family-owned fabric companies that were going bankrupt in Manhattan.

BECAUSE the number of capable young classical guitarists is increasing by leaps and bounds these days, it was hardly sur- prising that Robert Secrist qualified as one such in his recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night. But something about the playing of this 21year-old performer made him seem more than just competent.

The Rev. William J. Rogers, chief of chaplains at the Franklin D. Roosevelt Veterans Administration Hospital in Montrose, N.Y., died yesterday at the Rosary Hill Home in Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 48 years old and lived in Tarrytown, N.Y.

At a meeting of the trustees of the Jean Cocteau Repertory, one member of the board approached Craig Smith, an actor in the company and a spokesman for it, and asked what the first effort of the new season would be.

A few years ago, when the argument over how children acquire language was at its peak--whether they learn the complex rules of speech primarily from people around them or come already equipped with an innate mental structure for language--there was at least one productive result of the debate: Researchers around the country set out in droves to see just how much children did learn from their parents.

The New York State Board of Regents and the State Education Commissioner, Gordon M. Amlach, who said recently that they wanted to become more involved with urban school problems, formed a Regents Advisory Council yesterday to deal with New York City school issues.

THE ANGRY YOUNG MAN is 47 now, and gray-bearded. What's more, he's become a movie star of sorts. "I need the money," drawled John Osborne in his cool, lime-tart voice. "Being a writer living in England, you do need the Yankee dollar."

TRENTON, Sept. 15--Mario R. Roriguez of Camden resigned today from the State Parole Board with sharp criticism of Governor Byrne.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 15--More than five hours of hot-dice-roll yachting ended in frustration for Ted Turner today as Courageous failed to beat the time limit in the second race of the America's Cup defense.
GREENVALE, L.I., Sept. 15--The administration of C.W. Post Center of Long Island University today offered its striking faculty members a five-year contract.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 15 (UPI)-- Rioting in the slums of Bogota killed at least six more persons today, bringing the death toll in two days of violence and looting to 16. Thousands of troops in battle gear patrolled the city in jeeps and armored cars.

THE REGULAR SUBSCRIPTION season of the New York Philharmonic started in Avery Fisher Hall last night on a somber note. Erich Leinsdorf conducted Bach's "Kom, susser Tod" in memory of Leopold Stokowski, who died last Tuesday. The Stokowski transcription was of course used. After the piece, the audience and orchestra stood in a minute of silence.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15--The House of Representatives approved today an increase in the minimum wage in each of the next three years and, in a tense, dramatic roll-call, defeated by one vote a proposed subminimum wage for youths.

More than 150 people, many formerly addicted to drug, alchohol or gambling, passed the hat--a green vase--among themselves last night to collect enough money to bury a man who gave up a $30,000-a-year job three years ago to devote himself to helping addicts.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)--Con gress today voted final approval of a $458.3 billion budget for the fiscal year 1978. The budget includes a $61.3 billion deficit.

The new "morning man" at WNBCAM weighs 82 pounds, stands barely 5 feet tall, and has a soft, Georgia-accented voice very much on the order of Rosalynn Carter's. The new morning man is very obviously not a man, and her name is Ellie Dylan.

New York State health officials yesterday rescinded the freeze on Medicaid rates they had imposed last spring and approved increases of $160 million in public funds for hospitals and residential health-care facilities in the state.

OXFORD, Pa., Sept. 13--A rancorous dispute has erupted between the racially mixed faculty and the black president on the usually calm sylvan campus of Lincoln University, the nation's oldest black liberal arts college.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15--The Senate Finance Committee made it clear today that it would not accept President Carter's proposed rebate to consumers of revenues from a new tax on domestically produced crude oil.
Stock prices advanced slightly yesterday, bolstered by expectations that the Federal Reserve Board would not cause short-term interest rates to rise any higher for the present.
An extremely nervous cocoa futures market broke out on the downside yesterday, completely erasing the strong gains posted Wednesday.
The dollar was steady to slightly lower against most major world currencies in quiet foreign exchange trading yesterday. The price of gold declined, according to The Associated Press.

BETHESDA, Md., Sept. 15--A group of experts recommended today that the controversial nationwide screening for breast cancer be continued, but with a tightening of Federal guidelines for the cases of women under the age of 40.
The Whitney Museum's New American Filmmakers Series begins its eighth year tomorrow with the premiere not of a film but a videotape.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15--For Bert Lance, today's Senate hearing was the long-awaited opportunity to clear his name and reputation of the welter of charges against him.

ALBANY, Sept. 15--Security was tightened at Governor Carey's news conference today after the state police received a threat on the Governor's life this morning and a bomb scare emptied the Executive Mansion last night.
Bernie Carbo walks into the lobby of the New York Sheridan Hotel early in the afternoon, carrying a potted plant in his hands, and explains: "A little something to brighten up my room."

TORONTO, Sept. 15 (UPI)--Rather than risk injury to one of his players, Manager Earl Weaver of the Baltimore Orioles forfeited a game to the Toronto Blue Jays last night. He pulled his club off the field in a protest over a tarpaulin covering the pitcher's mound in the Toronto bull pen.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 15--In his first seven months as chief United States delegate, Andrew Young has spread the gospel of the Carter Administration far and wide in the third world during three swings around Africa and two trips to Latin America. He is also deeply engaged in negotiations aimed at a peaceful turnover of power to the black majorities in Rhodesia and in South-West Africa.

By the age of 5, Bruce Kimmel was hooked on movies. He saw his favorite, "The Court Jester," a spoof of swashhucklers that starred Danny Kaye, 25 times. By the age of 20, Mr. Kimmel had decided to make his own movie, "The First Nudie Musical," which is now at the 68th Street Playhouse. And it is his own movie--he acts, he writes, he directs, he does lyrics.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 15--The Security Council today adopted a resolution calling for the resumption as soon as possible of the stalemated Greek-Turkish talks on Cyprus. Prospects were considered bleak.

Massenet's "Manon" is firmly established in the operatic repertory, and is indeed being given this fall by the New York City Opera, with one performance taking place Sunday afternoon. Puccini's "Manon Lescaut" is possibly less popular, but is seldom long out of the repertory of major companies. The Abbe Prevost novel that inspired these two works has even provided the basis of a 20th-century opera, Henze's "Boulevard Solitude."

"The Door of Good and Evil," a 12ton bronze door for St. Peter's Basilica, has been completed in time for presentation to Pope Paul VI as an 80th birthday gift. TOWSON, Md., Sept. 15-If life is absurd for Eugene Ionesco, it is also alluring. His capacity for delight in the details of human existence struggles with his conviction of its futility; it lends depth and verve to his despair. Ionesco's pessimism, in fact, is exuberant, and sometimes not far removed from joy.
