An allocation of almost $2 million for the installation of fire-fighting equipment in the tunnels of the Long Island Rail Road will be voted on today by Amtrak's board of directors after a nearly 12-yearold controversy over the equipment.

FT. THOMAS, Ky., Sept. 18 (AP) The Beverly Hills Supper Club was an "electrician's nightmare" and this was overlooked by the club's owners as well as local and state officials, according to a state report on the fire last May 28 that killed 164 persons.
George W. Palmer, a partner in the law firm of Davis Polk Wardwell, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a heart attack. He was 77 years old and lived in New York City.

Six judges yesterday won the support of a "reform" Democratic caucus for nominations for the State Supreme Court in Manhattan and the Bronx. The judges received the backing at a caucus of delegates, to tomorrow's Democratic judicial convention from Manhattan's New Democratic Coalition and the Bronx's Committee for Democratic Voters.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 18 The world's diplomats are gathering for Tuesday's opening of the 32d General Assembly, which seems certain to be dominated by fractious Arab-Israeli disputes and the unsettled situation in southern Africa.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 18(Reuters) Cambodia indicated today that its troops had been in action on the border with Vietnam, and warned "all enemies, near or far, big or small" that it would not tolerate aggression.

SAN DIEGO, Sept. 18 (UPI) A representative of the conservationist Sierra Club has criticized a new plan to allow construction of a terminal in Long Beach, Calif., to receive Alaskan oil in exchange for $100 million worth of air pollution cleanup.

DOVER, Del., Sept. 18 (UPI) Benny Parsons kept his Chevrolet close to the early pace, then seized the lead midway through the $126,375 Delaware 500 Grand National stock car race today and held off a late challenge by David Pearson to win by three-fourths of a lap

Courageous defeated the yacht Australia for the fourth straight time yesterday off Newport, R.I., to successfully conclude the 23d defense of the America's Cup. Courageous, skippered by Ted Turner, won by 2 minutes 25 seconds in completing a four-race sweep. The 126-year-old New York Yacht Club trophy is considered the world's most prestigious yachting prize.

TRENTON, Sept. 18 Governor Byrne will ask the Legislature to pay most of the $9.5 million a year spent by the Jersey City Medical Center the state's largest general hospital on treatment of the poor who have neither medical insurance nor Medicaid benefits, according to aides of the Governor.

Indian ragas are associated with particular times of day. Because most concerts take place in the evening, that means either that some ragas are heard detached from their temporal moorings (a severe dislocation if you're serious about your musical mysticism) or that evening ragas are heard disproportionately often.
SOUTH ORANGE, Sept. 18 Archbishop Peter L. Gerety, in an official statement of direction for the 1.4 million Roman Catholics in the Archdiocese of Newark, yesterday called for unity.
DETROIT, Sept. 18 "You can't get gay out on the field you have to wait until you get in the clubhouse to be gay."
WOODBURY, L.I., Sept. 18 (UPI) A Nassau County policeman was credited with arousing five persons living in apart ments over a group of Woodbury stores that caught fire this morning, the police said.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 18 "When I see a pretty girl walking toward me, I sort of block her path and say, 'How lovely you are, you please me,'" Roberto Gomez explained shyly. "Sometimes she smiles and stops to chat. Other times, she swings at me with her handbag."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Undisclosed and unprosecuted by the Environmental Protection Agency, hundreds of facilities of the Federal Government across the country are violating the antipollution requirements of the Clean Water Act.

JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 18 A newspaper editor who viewed the body of Steven Biko in a mortuary last night said today that he had observed injuries that could have occurred during a beating. He cautioned however, that he could not be certain that the injuries had not been caused during the autopsy on the black leader's body five days ago.
Shortly after 1 P.M. yesterday, Amy Adelman, who was standing at Lexington Avenue and 86th Street distributing "Ed Koch For Mayor" leaflets, was approached by a passer-by.
BOSTON, Sept. 18 Watching Bert Lance perform with those Senators hour after hour, one saw why Jimmy Cater wanted him in Washington. He was smart, cool, resilient and recognizably human.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (AP) Atlanta tallied four runs in the seventh inning and held off Los Angeles, 9-8, preventing the Dodgers from wrapping up the National League West title today.

ROME, Sept. 18 Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti today demoted his Defense Minister and close personal and political friend, Vito Lattanzio, in a gesture intended to placate the leadership of the Communist Party, with which the governing Christian Democrats reached a basic agreement two months ago.

BONN, Sept. 18 Within hours after urban guerrillas kidnapped Hanns-Martin Schleyer, West Germany's leading industrialist, in Cologne on Sept. 5, police officers in Bavaria set up roadblocks to catch any terrorists who might try to flee abroad.

Fidelity Mortgage Investors, a Jacksonville, Fla., real estate investment trust that filed bankruptcy under Chapter XI on Jan. 30, 1975 in New York announced over the weekend that it had reached an agreement with creditors.

MOGADISHU, Somalia, Sept. 18 The capture of Jijiga, a strategic town at the base of the Ethiopian highlands, appears to have swung the initiative in the twomonth war in eastern Ethiopia to the Somalis.
CAIRO, Sept. 18 Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt said today that he would urge President Carter to invite the Palestine Liberation Organization to participate in future Middle East peace talks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) Palestinian sympathizers today released three Central Intelligence Agency documents that they said showed that the Israeli Foreign Minister, Moshe Dayan, deliberately ordered an attack on a United States Navy ship during the 1967 Middle East war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 After a faltering start, the Carter Administration is beginning to shape an urban policy based mainly on promoting the economic development of the nation's ailing big cities rather than on starting ambitious new social programs.

When mention was made here of the name Lady Curzon when used in con nection with a curry-flavored turtle soup, it was remarked that the most interesting thing about the lady in question was that she was Mary Leiter, the daughter of a Chicago millionaire who was married to Lord George Curzon, a viceroy of India. It was also noted that Lady Curzon soup appears on almost every important menu in Germany, according to friends.

Joao Gilberto, the Brazilian singer and guitarist who helped introduce bossa nova to North America with his hit recording of "Desafinado" during the early 60's, was at the Bottom Line on Friday and Saturday.

Puccini's "Manon Lescaut" and Massenet's "Manon" are probably the only two operas in the standard repertory based on the same source that coexist on equal terms. Other versions do exist and the Bel Canto Opera, which specializes in reviving out-of-the-way fare in its headquarters at the Madison...
SAN DIEGO, Sept. 18 The voters of San Diego will decide Tuesday whether the country's first city-sanctioned nude beach keeps its sanction.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 18 There was more action in the dockside celebration than there had been on the race course today when Courageous defeated the yacht Australia for a four-race sweep and a 23d successful defense of the America's Cup.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 18 Dr. Irving S. Cooper, a noted neurosurgeon who developed cryosurgery, the electronic brain Pacemaker and a host of other surgical procedures, will move his research and practice into Westchester County's new $61 million Medical Center.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 18 Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, the head of Ethiopia's ruling military Government, said today that there could be no peace in the Ogaden region until all Somali forces had left the region. He predicted a long war "to throw out the invaders."
ATLANTA, Sept. 18 In the quiet of the Los Angeles Rams' locker room today, Joe Namath was unwrapping the elastic bandage from his right knee when he was asked to assess his performance.

If you are a New York City Democrat, vote. What is called the runoff of a primary could well be conclusive, not only nominating the party's candidates for Mayor and City Council President but virtually electing them. That is not a happy circumstance. One-party bailiwicks are rightly going out of style, and a worthy Republican challenger for City Hall waits in the wings.

LEYDEN, The Netherlands, Sept. 18 (UPI) A 28-year-old woman who had taken fertility drugs gave birth today to sextuplets and doctors reported all six babies were in "very good condition," a University Hospital spokesman said.

Bridge has never been considered suitable for inclusion in the Olympic Games, which are confined to activities requiring more physical effort than tossing cards on to a table. But Israel rates intellectual activities more highly, and recently included bridge in the Maccabiah games which might be called a Jewish Olympics.

David Dudley Levenson, senior partner in the clothing firm of W. Weber Company and an amateur painter of landscapes, portraits and still-lifes, died yesterday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Westport, Conn., and in New York City.
BUCHLOE, West Germany Jet fighter-bombers screamed through the hazy late summer skies, while helicopters skimmed above onion shaped church domes and turreted castles.
The 17th annual I.B.M. International Tournament in Amsterdam was won this year by Grandmaster Anthony Miles of England, who posted a 10 4 score in the 16-player round-robin.
The J. Ray McDermott Company's stunning victory in the three-cornered fight for the Babcock Wilcox Company has shaken the conventional wisdom on Wall Street.

STANFORD, Calif. For anyone familiar with the history of women's suffrage, the slow progress of the Equal Rights Amendment to ratification must seem like a historical rerun. For as Carrie Chapman Catt, the 20thcentury suffrage leader, wrote, it took over half a century of agitation, with some 480 legislative campaigns and 277 party campaigns to remove the word "male" from the Constitution.

A report by the State Comptroller's office asserts that there are persisting shortcomings in the collection of back taxes in New York City because the Finance Department's compliance and collection division has failed to implement most of the recommendations made in a 1974 audit report.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-The Justice Department has quietly dropped a seven-year investigation of the United States Labor Party, a small left-wing splinter group that developed from the student protest movement of the 1960's.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 18 Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan's abrupt return to Israel last night in the midst of an overseas mission and his late-night meeting with Prime Minister Menahem Begin has fueled Israel's rumor mills.

"Get out the block, the shul, the sisterhood" was the campaign cry yesterday as Paul O'Dwyer, the incumbent in the Democratic runoff primary for City Council President, toured the heavily Jewish section of Borough Park and Williamsburg in the last day of campaigning before the runoff.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 18 The Baltimore Orioles and Boston Red Sox spent an exhausting weekend here pounding one another around the baseball field, and when it was over this evening it seemed as if all their struggle had only gone to help the Yankees.

Marian Amy Gruber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan R. Gruber, was married yesterday at the Harmonie Club to Walter George Montgomery, son of Mrs. Charles Spiegel of Pompano Beach, Fla., and E.H. Montgomery of Avoca. N.Y. Family Court Judge Louis Otten performed the ceremony.

Five contractors have submitted bids ranging from $1.17 million to $1.38 million for rail-welding work to reduce noise on a two-mile leg of the IND A line, according to New York City Transit Authority officials.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 18 The accounting industry, smarting from harsh criticism by Congress, has adopted a self-regulation program that includes a controversial reorganization plan for membership in its professional body, the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 19 The America's Cup races are revived every three years much to the astonishment of those who see the challenger beaten decisively time after time.
HACKENSACK, Sept. 19 A 13year-old schoolboy who was struck by a police car three years ago as he got off a school bus in Englewood was awarded $540,000 today in an out-of-court settlement.

VALPARAISO, Ind., Sept. 19 (UPI) A woman whose doctor put her on a rice and fruit diet during her last two months of pregnancy in 1954 has won $50,000 in damages on behalf of her mentally retarded daughter.
A throng of ceatively dressed New Yorkers turned out last night to view Andy Warhol's latest artistic achievement. A collection of Pop Art? No. An underground movie? No. Well, what then?

The chief judge of the Federal appeals court in Manhattan rebuked the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday for delaying for the last 18 months a decisoin on noise standards the Concorde supersonic airliner would have to meet to operate at Kennedy International Airport.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 19 (AP) Mayor Frank Logue has been certified as the winner over former Police chief Biagio DiLieto in last Thursday's Democratic primary by 339 votes. The first officially reported plurality had been 187.

PALO ALTO, Calif. Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance returned from Peking without making visible progress toward resolving the China dilemma: how to normalize relations with China without "abandoning" Taiwan or generating a domestic outcry. Yet normalize we must. Shaped by strategic and other political forces, the issue for Washington no longer is whether to do so, but how.

SEATTLE, Sept. 19 Fifteen mayoral candidates are skirmishing for two spots on the November ballot in tomorrow's nonpartisan primary here, and the seven leading contenders are working furiously to win votes from a largely undecided and disinterested electorate.

Like most disciplined, dedicated men, Edward I. Koch worries that he is really neither. "I took up jogging," he said the other day, "so I bought myself a pair of good track shoes $29.95. I knew if I paid that kind of money I'd have to use them. With $8 shoes, forget it."

TORONTO, Sept. 19-The projected new home of the Toronto Symphony Orchestra and Mendelssohn Choir, the focus of classical music in this commercial capital of Canada, will be a glittering, $34 million glass-enclosed creation, limned by shiny office towers and a spacious park in what is now just another section of the inner city bordering the financial and business district.

The Sony Corporation reported yesterday a drop of 28.1 percent in net income for the third fiscal quarter ended July 31, to $20.3 million, or 14 cents a share, from $40.7 million, or 19 cents a share on fewer shares outstanding, in the similar three months of last year.

New York City was set back yesterday in its plans for a long-awaited public offering of short-term notes this year with the disclosure that the safeguards that it had wanted to accompany the note sale would require action by the Legislature in Albany.
Citing import competition and environmental restraints, the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company announced yesterday a major cutback in its steel operations at Youngstown, Ohio, at a cost of 5,000 jobs.
Railroads, buoyed in part by the prospect of carrying more coal for the nation's power plants and industries, are steadily increasing orders for new equipment.

HONG KONG, Sept. 19 A Chinese military leader has disclosed that factional conflict in recent years has given rise to a discipline problem in the army, with some officers and men disobeying orders for supposed political reasons or bargaining over how far to carry them out.

GENEVA, Sept. 19 (Reuters)-Russell Means, an American Indian leader, said today that Indians "plan to ram the human rights issue down President Carter's throat" by telling East European leaders of "the horrendous genocide" being carried out against his people.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The unusual appearance of four staff members to testify under oath today before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee provides a glimpse into the pivotal but usually anonymous role that the staff plays in the way Congress works.

BRASILIA, Sept. 19 (AP) Brazil canceled four military agreements with the United States today in a move that the American ambassador said ends "all formal structure of military cooperation between the two countries."

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 (AP) Franco Harris rushed for 100 yards and a pair of touchdowns, and a totally dominant Pittsburgh defense yielded just 101 net yards to lead the Steelers to a 27-0 victory over the San Francisco 49ers tonight.

The New York City Opera will broadcast live five evening performances this season over WNCN, the classical-music radio station here owned and operated by the GAF Broadcasting Company. As of now, 12 other stations, from Boston to San Diego, will carry the broadcasts, live or on tape.

Dr. Charles A. Bliss, a professor emeritus of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, where he was the first to hold the Royal Little chair, died Saturday at his home in Angwin, Calif. He had retired in 1970. He was 73 years old.

ATHENS, Sept. 19 Jacqueline Onassis, has negotiated what her friends here call "an astounding settlement" with her late husband's daughter under which the shipowner's widow will receive $20 million in return for abandoning all further claims to his estate.

Factions within the Democratic Party were striving yesterday to dislodge the package of six nominations for Supreme Court judgeships in Manhattan and the Bronx devised by the antiorganization New Democratic Coalition on Sunday.

If additional reasons are still needed for accepting nofault automobile insurance, there is now one more: It would better serve the poor. Such is the conclusion of a new report, done by the Library of Congress at the behest of Representative Metcalfe of Illinois, co-sponsor of a bill that would require every state to adopt no-fault.
R.H. Macy Company, New York's largest retailer, plans to close its large branch store in the Jamaica section of Queens when the current lease expires on Nov. 1, a company spokesman said yesterday.

In the hurry-up tempo of our society, the pace of everything we do has quickened, and this is especially true of sports. The most conspicuous example, attributable largely to the influence of television, is the policy of the suddendeath playoff to break a tie in football, basketball and Stanley Cup hockey, among others. One team scores a point and it's all over.

Representative Edward I. Koch, who was virtually discounted as a serious candidate three months ago, defeated Mario M. Cuomo in the Democratic mayoral runoff primary yesterday by a 55-to-45 margin to become a strong favorite to be New York City's next Mayor.
VICTOR, Colo. Up here in the Rockies, in a valley 9,200 feet in the sky, Chuck Bradley seemed almost immune to problems of a sea-level world.

Fifteen of the chic boutiques that dot Madison Avenue from 64th Street through 77th Street got together yesterday morning to show highspots from their fall fashion collections in the main auction room of Sotheby Parke Bernet.

EUGENE, Ore., Sept. 19 (UPI) Robert B. Frazier, editorial page editor of The Eugene Register-Guard and a 1977 Pulitzer Prize judge, died yesterday of an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound, the police reported.
Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State came to New York yesterday to deliver "a major appraisal of U.S. foreign policy" at New York University's Graduate School of Business Administration.
For most people, having their tax returns audited is so intimidating that they don't even think of protesting further, should the I.R.S. auditor's conclusions be unfavorable.
Manny Wolf's, the East Side restaurant that is undergoing renovations, was extensively damaged yesterday by a group of men in what the police suspect was a union dispute.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 19 The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has made substantial modifications in Federal District Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr.'s comprehensive order of prison reform in Alabama, saying that he had exceeded his judicial authority in several areas.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The Carter Administration moved closer today to gaining Congressional approval of the proposed sale of radar planes to Iran.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Congressional staff members testified today that Bert Lance misled them before his confirmation about financial problems at the Georgia bank he once headed.

Outside North America the prowess of countries in international competition tends to oscillate in accordance with the supply of top-class young experts. Sweden has recently been in the ascendancy for this reason, while France and Britain, by contrast, seem to be suffering from hardening of the arteries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-William E. Simon, the former Secretary of the Treasury, said today that a group that has been raising funds for a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent recently indicted in New York would also raise funds for Richard Helms if the former Director of Central Intelligence was indicted.

ABC-TV has beaten CBS in the race-tothe-draw with a made-for-television movie on Lee Harvey Oswald, the accused assassin of President Kennedy who himself was killed by Jack Ruby in 1963 before he could be brought to trial.
The dollar slipped against most major currencies except the British pound in light world foreign-exchange trading yesterday. The Associated Press reported.

PARIS, Sept. 19-A new daily began publication here today, bringing the number of general-circulation French-language dailies in Paris to 11. The newspaper is called J'Informe--I Inform--a title as unusual in French as it would be in English.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Congressional staff members testified today that Bert Lance misled them before his confirmation about financial problems at the Georgia bank he once headed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (Reuters) The United States said today it was concerned at the recent increase in fighting in southern Lebanon and was continuing its efforts to stabilize the situation.
If Edward I. Koch ever needed any official seal on his runoff victory, it may have come when Jimmy Carter called.
Yields declined on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities.
Carol Bellamy, a little-known State Senator when she began a lonely, illfinanced campaign for New York City Council President, won the Democratic nomination yesterday.

BOSTON, Sept. 19 Dave Kingman, the Yankees' new home-run-a-game kid, hit one of his patented towering home runs in his first time at bat at Fenway Park tonight and set himself and the Yankees wondering what might have been.

New York City was set back yesterday in its plans for a long-awaited public offering of short-term notes this year with the disclosure that the safeguards that it had wanted to accompany the note sale would require action by the Legislature in Albany.

To say that a theatrical production is well intentioned is to speak well of the dead. The Jean Cocteau Repertory's version of the Jacobean play "A New Way to Pay Old Debts" has all the features of an unsuccessful resuscitation: good motives, lots of activity and no life.

ROME, Sept, 19 (AP) Robbers broke into the home of the Italian Fashion designer Aldo Gucci today, tied up his wife and two servants and got away with an undetermined amount of money, jewels and furs, the police said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Two months after President Carter's decision to block production of the B-1 strategic bomber, Pentagon officials and members of Congress are pressing for development of a mixed force of another manned penetrating bomber and the cruise missile.

If Representative Edward I. Koch, the winner of yesterday's Democratic mayoral runoff primary, is elected mayor in November, he would resign his seat in the House of Representatives at the beginning of the new year and his seat would be filled at a special election in January or February.
For a select group of Wall Streeters, the game with the highest stakes in town is risk arbitrage. Yesterday, a big decline in Gerber Products stock caused steel-nerved arbitragers to drop a bundle.

NEWARK, Sept. 19 George H. Barbour, president of the Board of Public Utilities Commissioners, said today he would meet with representatives of a group of South Jersey residents who have been withholding portions of their payments on gas and electric bills to protest against increasing fuel-adjustment charges in their bills.
YONKERS, Sept. 19 "I think the kids are losing out," Jane O'Brien said today, reflecting a growing impatience by many parents with the city's teacher strike, which is entering its third week.

The levels of pesticides in the breast milk of 50 women following vegetarian diets were one-third to one-half those found in a 1976 national sample taken of women eating a conventional diet, according to tests just completed for the Federal Government and a private environmental group.

Helene Montgomery-Moore, a civic leader of Higganum, Conn., died Sunday in Middlesex Memorial Hospital, Middletown, Conn. She was 77 years old and lived on Landing Road, Higganum, and at Treloyne, Paget, Bermuda.
LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP) The Lancet, Britiain's authoritative medical journal, says in an editorial that it doubts a purported link between saccharin and bladder cancer in humans.

Stanley Harwood, a Westbury, L.I., lawyer and Democratic elections commissioner of Nassau County, was elected last night to a third full term as Democratic county chairman at a Nassau party convention.

FAMAGUSTA, Cyprus The two young Turkish waitress-trainees, oblivious to the fact that their work is an issue of debate at the United Nations in New York, moved briskly on a veranda of the nearly deserted Constantia Hotel here and emptied the ashtrays of two unexpected visitors.

MANILA, Sept. 15 Now that southern Vietnam has become virtually impenetrable by foreigners and only the Hanoi Government's picture of life in the reunited country is presented to the world, the thousands of Vietnamese who have fled in small boats are the principal source of critical first-hand information about their country.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 19 A Congressional subcommittee holding hearings today on the Beverly Hills Supper Club fire in which 164 persons died, heard Kentucky Gov. Julian M. Carroll condemn the club's owners and several state officials for collectively setting the stage for such a disaster by ignoring state fire codes since at least 1971.

TRENTON, Sept. 19 (AP) The State Supreme Court upheld today a lowercourt judge's ruling that a 3-year-old girl should not be returned to her natural parents because it would cause the child too much damage to be taken from her foster parents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) Civil rights leaders representing the Civil Rights Commission's state advisory committees said today that an Administration plan to eliminate the committees would dismantle the civil rights movement across the country.
PARIS, Sept. 19 (UPI) Pablo Picasso's widow has accepted a plan to share the $205 million Picasso estate, ending four years of fighting among the six heirs, the estate lawyer said today.

ANDES HANDIWORK A new exhibition of pre-Columbian and modern fabrics from South America goes on view today through Nov. 13 at the Center for Inter-American Relations, 680 Park Avenue, at 68th Street. Included are intricate, vintage textiles from Peru and present-day items such as belts, bags, tunics, ponchos, tapestries and hammocks. Most of the items are from the Textiles Museum in Washington ...

The Israeli revue "Shalom '77," which opened a two-night stand at Radio City Music Hall last night, tends toward the secretive. It offered no printed program, and the announcement of its songs, sung understandably enough in Hebrew, was sparse in its information. Luckily I had a few names supplied to me by the theater's press office, but background material was at a premium.

ALBANY, Sept. 19 "I want the same opportunity as everybody else, no more," Luis Velez of Delancey Street in New York City said today shortly after he and 155 other recruits were sworn in to the state police force.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 18 The excitement is over now for Caro and Blushing Groom, two of Europe's leading thoroughbred sires, as they frolic in the bluegrass here. But for a while they were part of a spectacular race against time.

BONN, Sept. 19 President Walter Scheel said today that proposals for solving West Germany's terrorism problem were compatible with the rule of law in a free democracy. He rejected what he termed "irresponsible criticism" from abroad alleging that fascist trends were developing in West Germany.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Sept 19 After having spent the summer in thorny business sessions deciding to reject a merger with the rival league, the National Hockey League came out from under the paperwork today and returned to the game of hockey as training camp opened for 18 teams in Canada and the United States.

As a youngster studying trumpet with the New York Philharmonic's William Vacchiano, Gerard Schwarz dreamed of following in his teacher's footsteps. Then the dream came true: Four years ago, at the age of 26, Mr. Schwarz joined the Philharmonic as a coprincipal.

Dr. Benjamin Nelson, professor of sociology and history at the New School for Social Research, died Saturday of a heart attack aboard a train in West Germny. He was 65 years old and a resident of Stony Brook, L.I.

HARTFORD, Sept. 19 (AP) Connecticut's system of holding people in mental hospitals in unconstitutional because patients face the burden of proving they have become sane to win their freedom, the State Supreme Court ruled today.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 19 Gary Jeter has broken into the Giants' starting lineup, the most sobering thought for a team still celebrating its comeback 20-17 opening-game victory over the Washington Redskins.
Long Island's sewage may be dumped into the Atlantic Ocean until techniques are developed to return it to the soil, a judge in Federal District Court in Brooklyn ruled yesterday.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 19 (AP) Former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has said that she suspects that "outside forces" had a hand in the election defeats of herself and Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike of Sri Lanka and in the military coup that ousted Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan.

Senators Edward Kennedy and Frank Church have made public a letter to Senator Birch Bayh in which they recommend that a new charter for the Federal Bureau of Investigation should limit it to the investigation of crimes and rule out intelligence operations for "domestic security" purposes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)-James T. Housewright, president of the 700,000 member Retail Clerks International Union and an A.F.L.-C.I.O. vice president, died today of cancer. He was 55 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 President Carter has still not decided on the future of Bert Lance, an Administration spokesman said today after the two old friends had discussed their problems in a private early-morning meeting at the White House.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) The House passed legislation today to shift black lung payments from the Federal Treasury to the coal industry and to ease requirements for coal miners to qualify fo rbenefits.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim ex pressed doubts today about the so-called Dayan plan for giving Arab inhabitants in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River greater autonomy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) President Carter announced today that he had nominated Federal Judge Hugh H. Bownes to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit in Boston, covering Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Puerto Rico.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-The Carter administration strongly endorsed today the argument that disadvantaged members of minority groups may constitutionally be given special consideration in university admissions, but it avoided the question of whether specific racial quotas may be used to achieve that end.

OAKDALE, L.I., Sept. 19 The first face-to-face talks in almost three weeks between negotiators for Dowling College and its striking faculty members broke down last night, with both sides remaining far apart. The college announcement said that no new talks had been scheduled.
Time Inc. has announced that Henry A. Grunwald, managing editor of Time magazine since 1968, has been named to the position of corporate editor and that Ray Cave will succeed him.

ROME, Sept. 19 A "mushroom war" has broken out between France and Italy. The French have accused the Italians of having crossed into their territory to gather mushrooms in French woods and then sell them at "astronomical" prices in France and other countries.
There were more nervous traders in the lumber futures market than calm ones yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as both groups awaited the Federal report on housing starts.
Standard Oil of California, marketers of Chevron brand gasoline, after a summer-long search for a new ad agency, has chosen the J. Walter Thompson Company to handle its $10 million account.
Citing import competition and environmental restraints, the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company announced yesterday a major cutback in its steel operations at Youngstown, Ohio, at a cost of 5,000 jobs.

Manny E. Duell, president of Morgan Holding Company, a real estate concern that owned many properties in Greenwich Village and other sections of Manhattan, died Saturday of an apparent heart attack at his suburban home in Weston, Conn., at the age of 66.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 A Senate subcommittee reportedly has concluded that of the scores of scientific projects undertaken by the Central Intelligence Agency in its 25-year quest for control of the human mind, none represented a greater potential abuse of governmental authority or medical ethics than the agency's testing of LSD-25 and other psychochemicals on unsuspecting subjects.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) Housing starts in August were at an annual rate of 2.02 million, showing that the housing industry remains strong even though other segments of the economy have been cooling down in recent months, Government figures showed today.
The stock market lurched downward yesterday in a broad setback that sent it to its lowest level in 20 months.

MANCHESTER, England, Sept. 19 (UPI) Manchester United will appeal the Union of European Football Association's suspension of the soccer team from the European Cup Winners' Cup, a club spokesman, Les Olive, said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) The House today rejected, by a vote of 201 to 180, a move to raise the ceiling on the national debt by $75 billion to a new level of $775 billion.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 19 (AP) Help from government sources, private corporations and individuals continued to pour in today as estimates of damage from one of this area's worst disasters edged toward $140 million.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 19 Two Arabs were shot and killed by Israeli soldiers today in the shopping area of the occupied Gaza Strip, according to an official Israeli announcement.
MILFORD, Conn., Sept. 19 (AP)-Two men in a dinghy were rescued from Long Island Sound today about seven hours after their 27-foot sloop capsized, a Coast Guard spokesman said.

Film footage of great stage actors of the past among them George Arliss, Tallulah Bankhead, John Barry more, Noel Coward, Leslie Howard, Walter Huston, Charles Laughton, Pauline Lord, Helen Morgan and Laurette Taylor will be a highlight of a gala evening to raise funds for the American Place Theater's 1977-78 season.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 19 A controversial Self-regulation plan adopted over the weekend by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, the accountants national professional body, received a strong vote of confidence yesterday from members attending the group's annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 President Carter, opening a new and perhaps decisive round of Middle East diplomacy, told Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel today that it was important for Israel and the Arab states to show "courageous leadership" and to make compromises if there was to be a lasting settlement in the region.

After five months of court wrangling by both sides, the Gerber Products Company, the nation's leading baby foods maker, succeeded yesterday in fighting off an unwanted takeover by Anderson, Clayton Company, the big Texas food producer.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 19 Ninety-nine Vietnamese who fled from their country in fishing vessels boarded a jumbo jet today for the last leg of their adventurous escapes, turning into reality President Carter's program to admit 7,000 "boat people" to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19-Perhaps the Supreme Court will take the Government's advice in the Bakke case and avoid for the time being the question whether racial quotas in college admissions and other fields are constitutional.
VICTOR, Colo. Up here in the Rockies, in a valley 9,200 feet in the sky, Chuck Bradley seemed almost immune to problems of a sea-level world.

An official of the United Brands Company testified yesterday that he delivered cash payments of almost $50,000 to a top officer of the International Longshoremen's Association to insure that the company's banana boats would be unloaded during strikes in 1968 and 1971.

State Senator Roy M. Goodman, Republican candidate for Mayor of New York City, received a 13 percent rating for his 1977 legislative voting record in a Conservative Party scorecard listing him lowest of the New York Legislature's Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The Justice Department has created a special threemember panel to review all questions in the department concerning Bert Lance and to make recommendations for future action, Deputy Attorney General Peter F. Flaherty said today.
LONDON, Sept. 19 (UPI) The strike by British bakers ended tonight with an agreement by that union to return to work by Wednesday.

The Bert Lance confusion has now reached the status that Richard Nixon would have classified as a "crisis." That much was apparent when the networks moved it onto television and Clark Clifford took the chair just behind Lance on the right of the screen.

The credit markets were buoyed modestly yesterday by news that housing starts had declined in August, and fixed-income security prices rose slightly. During the afternoon, bond trading quieted as the markets searched for a sense of direction.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 A Senate subcommittee reportedly has concluded that of the scores of scientific projects undertaken by the Central Intelligence Agency in its 25-year quest for control of the human mind none represented a greater potential abuse of governmental authority or medical ethics than the agency's testing of LSD-25 and other psychochemicals on unsuspecting subjects.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 Richard A. De Santis, a local private attorney, called for John J. Flynt's resignation from the House ethics committee today because of remarks made in early August regarding the then-pending lawsuits against Tongsun Park.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 When things go wrong for the San Francisco Opera, which is rare, local audiences are still appreciative. So powerful is the appetite for opera here that the 12-week season is almost always sold out before it starts.

Representatinve Edward I. Koch, who was virtually discounted as a serious mayoral candidate three months ago, defeated Mario M. Cuomo in the Democratic mayoral runoff primary yesterday and became a strong favorite to be New York City's next Mayor.

HOUSTON, Sept. 19 (AP)-Pickets went up last night at the Hughes Tool Company plant here as a union local representing 2,500 workers rejected a contract proposal that it contended did not include a big enough wage increase. Company officials said the strike would affect about 3,500 employees.
After more than a year of fruitless negotiations, Kuwait yesterday nationalized operations of the American Independent Oil Company, The Associated Press reported.

A funeral service for Addison Verrill, movie-industry reporter for Variety, was held on Saturday in Hamden, Conn. Mr. Verrill was found stabbed to death last Wednesday in his apartment at 2 Horatio Street. He was 36 years old. A Variety spokesman said that the writer's apartment had been ransacked and that the police suspected robbery as the motive for the killing.
The Federal Reserve, at a swift stroke, ought to erase the $4 billion summer bulge in the money supply.

CAMDENTON, Mo., Sept. 19 (AP) Roy E. Richardson Jr. pleaded not guilty today to four counts of capital murder in the shooting of four children near this Lake of the Ozarks community last week. Memorial services were held yesterday for the four children, Steven Swift, 14 years old; Gregory Swift, 12; Tanya Swift, 3, and Stacy Swift, 18 months.

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 19 South Korean officials hinted today, through a variety of news leaks, that they might indict and then demand the repatriation from the United States of Kim Hyung Wook, the exiled former intelligence chief whose testimony before the United States Congress linked a South Korean Government agency to alleged multimillion-dollar attempts to influence American policy favorably toward South Korea.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) President Carter was told today that the Senate would reject, by at least a four-vote margin, his natural gas pricing proposal and vote to deregulate gas prices.

In a letter written from his hospital cell, David R. Berkowitz, the man accused of being the .44-caliber killer, says he killed six young people over the last year.

Frederick N. Melius Jr., president of the Transway International Corporation from 1966 to his retirement in 1972 and a leader in the development of intermodal transportation of freight, died Saturday at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., eight hours after the death there of his wife, the former Coralie Harper. His age was 72 and hers was 71.

ROME, Sept. 19 A "mushroom war" has broken out between France and Italy. The French have accused the Italians of having crossed into their territory to gather mushrooms in French woods and then self them at "astronomical" prices in France and other countries.

William J. Greene, who retired last year as chief clerk of Family Court in Manhattan while continuing to serve as president of the Mid-Manhattan chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, died Friday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 549 West 123d Street.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 19 If it weren't for a 5-foot-8-inch, virtually unknown player from Kutztown State, the Jets' offense couldn't get off the blackboard.
A Federal judge has ruled in favor of Barron's, a weekly financial newspaper, in a decision that is likely to make it harder for corporations to sue for libel.

Caesar B. Pattarini, who was suspended Sept. 2 as director of aviation of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, was reinstated yesterday in his $61,386-ayear job after repaying the agency about $2,000 in improper expenditures and expense-account billings he admitted submitting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Senator Adlai E. Stevenson 3d, chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Ethics, today coupled a widening of the Senate's Korea inquiry with a warning that noncooperation by South Korea with the investigations here would be considered "provocative" and an "act of ingratitutde."

TRENTON, Sept. 19 State Senator Anthony Imperiale, independent of Newark, withdrew today from the governorship race and said he would support the Republican candidate, State Senator Raymond H. Bateman of Somerville.
Tensions are beginning to build in business and financial circles as the nation's economy apparently is entering a period of slower growth after two and a half years of rather rapid expansion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The Carter administration strongly endorsed today the argument that disadvantaged members of minority groups may constitutionally be given special consideration in university admissions, but it avoided the question of whether specific racial quotas may be used to achieve that end.

The Reynaldo Alejandro Dance Theater combines the materials of Philippine folk traditions with modern dance in an effort to find the best of both possible dance worlds. Judging by "Rituals," which the company presented Sunday evening at the Vorpal Gallery, it is a synthesis that is still very much in the making.
A 29-year-old Queens woman shot an intruder in the stomach with his own gun early yesterday morning, moments after he had allegedly raped her 28-yearold roommate in their home in South Ozone Park.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) The Republicans, happy to oblige President Carter by keeping tabs on his 1976 campaign promises, said today that 121 of 674 had been kept and that 77 had been broken in the first seven months of the new Administration.

When Senator Hubert H. Humphrey made his first public appearance yesterday since leaving a hospital Sept. 2, it became an emotional occasion. Addressing the convention of the Minnesota A.F.L.-C.I.O. in St. Paul, Mr. Humphrey said: "I'm not about ready to have somebody cover me up. Back from a European tour, the Sarah Lawrence Chorus appeared in Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday night for a concert directed by the group's conductor, Harold Aks. The program was a generous one and covered material from the English and Italian Renaissance through the Baroque, Romantic and contemporary eras.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP)-More than 100 passengers and the crew members of an Amtrak train were detained for questioning as the authorities investigated the death of a passenger, who jumped or fell yesterday from the speeding Lake Shore Limited.

JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 18 A week after the event, it is clear that the death of Steven Biko has shaken South Africa more than any single event since the police opened fire at Sharpeville in 1960, killing 72 black demonstrators.

BOSTON, Sept. 19 With eight games left to play in the tantalizing shadow of the Great Green Wall of Fenway Park, the Boston Red Sox refused to concede anything tonight as Manager Don Zimmer warned the New York Yankees: "We're not dead yet."
Carol Bellamy, a little-known state senator when she began a lonely, ill-financed campaign for New York City Council President, won the Democratic nomination yesterday.

It had been a long afternoon of handshaking. Young campaign workers piled into the rented car waiting at a Queens intersection. Crammed into one corner in the back seat, a woman hardly older than they, dressed in a cotton blouse and skirt and scuffed espadrilles, sat drumming her fingers against a huge metal campaign button that read: "Hi! I'm Carol Bellamy."

LONDON, Sept. 19 (Reuters) Bangladesh announced today that more than 100 people had died from cholera, while doctors in the Gilbert Islands in the Pacific said 17 persons had died from the disease there.

Heart operations generally require blood transfusions but it has now been demonstrated that they can be done successfully without them, according to a report published yesterday of 542 operations Jehovah's Witnesses at a hospital in Houston.

Saying that hypnotherapy treatments had enabled him "to get my mind to gether," Jerry Quarry yesterday announced that he would return to professional boxing after more than two years of retirement. Quarry, 32 years old and weighing 210 pounds, will launch his comeback on Nov. 5 against Lorenzo Zanon of Italy as part of the Ken Norton-Jimmy Young fight card in Las Vegas.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 19 Israeli military forces in the north have been placed on alert because of the intensified fighting in southern Lebanon between Palestinian guerrillas and Lebanese Christians.

GRAND JUNCTION, Iowa, Sept. 19 AP) The former G.O.P. national chairman, Mary Louise Smith, said today, the Republican Party was not "in tune with the tempo of the times" and must become more responsive to people's problems.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) Lay teachers in Roman Catholic parochial schools can unionize, but they must bear in mind the "unique characteristics" of the schools as communities of faith, a report by a subcommittee of the United States Catholic Conference said today.

An employee of a midtown jewelry manufacturer was robbed of two boxes containing uncut diamonds worth $168,000 in a West Fourth Street station of the IND in Greenwich Village by two youths, but two nearby transit policemen captured a suspect and recovered one of the boxes with $56,000 of the gems.

Dr. George D. Langdon Jr., deputy provost and lecturer in history at Yale University, has been named president of Colgate University in Hamilton, N.Y., it was announced yesterday by Frankin B. Lincoln Jr., the chairman of Colgate's board of trustees.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 19 Palestinian guerrillas and Israeli-supported Christian forces fought pitched battles in southern Lebanon today for the control of strategic positions on the Litani River and made conflicting claims on the progress of the fighting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)-The Senate Intelligence Committee said today that it had found no evidence that Panamanian officials blackmailed the United States into concessions in the Panama Canal treaty negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Diesel-powered automobiles led three of five categories in fuel economy ratings for 1978 models, released today by the Environmental Protection Agency. Among them were Oldsmobile's new diesel passenger cars, the first made in the United States, which topped the full-sized classification with 21 miles per gallon in the city and 30 on the highway.

ATHENS, Sept. 19-Jacqueline Onassis has negotiated what her friends here call "an astounding settlement" with her late husband's daughter under which the shipowner's widow will receive $20 million in return for abandoning all further claims to his estate.
MIAMI, Sept. 19-The discovery of a computer-tampering scheme to defraud bettors at the West Flagler Kennel Club here was disclosed today by State Attorney Richard E. Gerstein.

TRENTON, Sept. 19 The final two members of the Casino Control Commission, which will regulate gambling in Atlantic City, were approved today by the State Senate, but only after one of the nominees, Alice B. Corsey, balked for a time over financial disclosure.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 19 (AP) Jerry Garvin dealt Baltimore's pennant hopes a severe blow tonight, allowing nine hits while pitching the Toronto Blue Jays to a 3-1 victory over the Orioles.

DANBURY, Conn. Sept. 19 School administrators, community workers and residents of this northern Fairfield County city sought today to explain and deal with the causes of racial fighting that broke out at Danbury High School last week, causing classes to be halted temporarily and 32 students to be suspended.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 19 The Florida Public Service Commission denied today a petition by the Florida Power and Light Company for the reconsideration of a controversial rate formula designed to encourage conservation of electricity.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Michael T. Markel, a lawyer who was an international food and drug law expert, died Sept. 11 after an apparent heart attack while vacationing in Germany, He was 80 years old.

If Ma Bell and the staff of New York State's Public service Commission have their way, the price of a local pay phone call in the state will double to 20 cents. Carlino Jr., the 36-year-old son of the former Nassau County Republican chairman and former Assembly Speaker, and his 24-year-old wife, Cathy, have been missing since early last Saturday when their single-engine airplane disappeared while in a flight over eastern Long Island, officials said today.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 20 (AP) Hotel workers have struck the 100 hostelries on this mid-Atlantic resort island, forcing some visitors to carry their own bags but generally not disturbing essential services. THE Panamanian head of state, Gen. Omar Torrijos, said that he had received the unexpected backing of John Wayne for the Panama Canal treaties. President Torrijos told newsmen that the actor, usually associated with conservative viewpoints, had telephoned him to express support and had agreed to visit Panama to demonstrate his backing. Mr. Wayne "has an effect on the American public and we are happy to have his backing," General Torrijos said.

A well-known New York City architect who "laundered" his corporation's funds through a brothel operator in New York and a stock manipulator in Washington, D.C., pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday to evading more than $13,000 in income taxes for 1971.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Northeastern governors and a bipartisan coalition of 204 Congressmen from the Northeast and the Middle West charged today that Defense Department spending policies had aggravated economic problems in their regions while stimulating booms in the South and the West.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 After weeks of controversy about his past business and banking practices, Budget Director Bert Lance resigned from office today and President Carter said he accepted his friend's decision with "regret and sorrow."

OAKDALE, L.I., Sept. 21 Faculty members at Dowling College agreed today to end their strike under a settlement that reportedly lets them retain their authority over academic affairs, but concedes that the power to hire and discharge faculty members lies entirely with the college's board of trustees.

VISALIA, Calif., Sept. 21 (AP) A body found buried in a shallow grave near here has been identified as that of Vaclav Wally Uhlik, who escaped from Czechoslovakia in a homemade tank almost a quarter-century ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Chief Justice Warren E. Burger is taking steps to improve relations between Congress and the Federal judiciary relations that have been proper but distant.
WHY DO people travel all over the country for a week of Spartan activity eating skimpy, if tasty, meals at the Golden Door spa in Escondido, Calif? And pay $1,250 for the privilege?

After several years in which various observations seemed to indicate that the universe is infinite and destined to expand forever, two studies have revived the possibility that it is finite and predestined to collapse.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21 At this institution, where events habitually never get started on time, something in the nature of a minor record may have been established this morning when, precisely at the scheduled time of 10 minutes past 10, Secretary General Kurt Waldheim emerged from the General Assembly Building and strode toward the row of flags that stand like sentinels in front of the complex.
Federal statistical samplings indicate that New York City workers lost about $5 million in wages because of the July 13-14 electricity blackout.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 An intensive Federal investigation of charges of widespread brutality by officers of the Philadelphia Police Department has produced indictments of six policemen and is expected to lead to formal charges against a dozen others in the next few months.

James J. Dickman, president of the Council of North Atlantic Shipping Associations, said last night that he was "a little more optimistic" about resolving differences with the International Longshoremen's Association.

A six-man umpiring team that includes two arbiters working their first playoff series was picked yesterday by Charles Feeney, the National League president, for the circuit's championship series that opens in Los Angeles Oct. 4.

Marc Blitzstein's "Regina," the operatic version of Lillian Hellman's "The Little Foxes," will be given one of its infrequent revivals by the Michigan Opera Theater in Detroit, starting Sept. 30. The five performances will be conducted by John Yaffe, with staging by Francis Rizzo and designs by Franco Colavecchia and Carol Luiken.

Kings Point's football team has won both its games this season without the help of a passing attack. Coach Pete Carmichael and his players didn't exactly plan it that way. It just happened. The Mariners have beaten Coast Guard and New York Tech without completing a pass.

New York City faces a budget deficit next year of at least $350 million, four times greater than the $86 million that Mayor Beame has projected, but fiscal officials who disclosed the gap yesterday said they hoped it could be offset with additional revenue generated by an expanding economy.
Dr. Paul Z. Frisch, a psychologist, died last Sunday at his home, 44 Arleigh Road, Great Neck, L.I. He was 51 years old.

A muddy track at Belmont Park failed to prevent the handicappers from correctly choosing the top three finishers yesterday in the $86,725 Matron Stakes. The only mistake for the form players was that the one-two-three finish was the exact reverse.

There are people who take the A train in the dark, going down from Harlem and points south to the city's ocean coast so they can watch birds stirring about Jamaica Bay in the blue edge of dawn. These city bird watchers walk from the subway's Broad Channel station to the marshes, and they are as quiet and undemanding as the birds they stare at, and as adaptable.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Bert Lance went to work today with the decision to resign his office already made.

The Justice Department charged Nassau County yesterday with discriminating against blacks, Hispanic people and women in hiring and promoting members of the County Police Department.

Alan D. Allen, president and founder of the Tandy Allen Realty Corporation of Manhattan, died Tuesday in Pascack Hospital, Westwood, N.J., after an illness of six months. He was 60 years old and lived at 27 Pascack Road, Woodcliff, N.J.

Alternate-side-of-the-street parking regulations will be suspended today for the Jewish holiday of Yom Kippur. The city's public schools will be closed in its observance, as will some suburban schools. Banks and both stock exchanges will remain open as will most department stores and most government offices, including post offices. Mail deliveries will not be affected.
NEWTON, Mass., Sept. 21 (UPI) Dr. Maurice S. Raben, who first reported that human growth hormones could be used to correct some types of dwarfism, died at his home Monday. He was 62 years old.
LONDON, Sept. 21 James Pitt, a well educated young family man, worries these days about the kind of people moving into Islington, the increasingly attractive north London borough in which he lives.

A Circuit Court Judge in Miami order Telly Savalas, star of the "Kojak" detective series on television, to appear in court next Monday in the murder trial of a 15-year-old boy whose lawyer is using TV violence for his defense.

How interest is credited is almost as important as the rate itself. Many thrift institutions, for example, work on a daily compounding basis. MORRISTOWN, N.J. STYLE not substance, sustained the village of Morristown in the late 19th century when it was trying to be a southern New port. Even though it was and is a landlocked little town, more millionaires were said to spend their summers within four miles of its village green than within four miles of any other spot in the world.

PEKING, Sept. 21 (Reuters) The President of Equatorial Guinea, a former Spanish colony in Africa, has used a dinner speech here to accuse the Spanish Government of attempting to kill him and overthrow his Government.

Irma Duncan, a foster daughter of Isadora Duncan, who became the American dancer's best-known disciple in the United States, died Tuesday in Cottage Hospital, Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 80 years old.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 21 The State Board of Education has rejected Bridgeport's proposed school desegregation plan and has threatened to cut off about $9 million a year in state aid if an acceptable plan is not submitted by Oct. 17, it was announced today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21 Deputy Prime Minister Nguyen Duy Trinh of Vietnam, speaking a day after his country was admitted to the United Nations, told the General Assembly today that the Vietnamese Government wanted normal relations with the United States.

Thirty-five friends and members of the families of two of the victims of the .44caliber killer, known as "Son of Sam," yesterday stood outside the Kings County Psychiatric Hospital where David R. Berkowitz, the suspect in the killings, is being held, and called for revenge.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 A three-year battle over charges of employment discrimination was resolved today when Peggy S. Griffiths was named chairman of the appeals review board of the Civil Service Commission.

Sixto Lezcano of the Milwaukee Brewers hit the 3,430 homer of the year in the major leagues last night, breaking the single-season home run record. Lezcano's homer surpassed the record of 3,429 set in 1970.

Twenty canaries and parakeets were working for a policy ring in Queens that did about $2 million a year in business, the police disclosed yesterday after they raided an apartment and arrested three men and two women.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Mayor Beame got a friendly reception but no commitment today in a visit with the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., during which he sought support for an immediate increase in Federal spending on welfare to ease the load on localities.

MONTREAL, Sept. 21 Under normal circumstances, a child's entry into kindergarten is not a national event. But 5 yearold Mark Peter Bischoff and his parents have unwillingly become part of a conflict that is dividing Quebec and Canada and this has made his first contact with formal education almost a traumatic experience.

If you doubt the pernicious effect of airline regulation, consider this paradox: The six major airlines that fly between the United States and Britain traditionally oppose bargain fares, but now wish to lower them substantially on advance-purchase excursions. The Civil Aeronautics Board, whose members are dedicated to reducing the cost of international air travel, won't let them.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 21 When Jim McMillian joined the Knicks last season, he said he welcomed the opportunity to play with "some intelligent players" for a change. By the time the season ended, McMillian had changed his mind and was disillusioned.

DEER LAKE, Pa., Sept. 21 (AP) Muhammad Ali was knocked down twice today by Jimmy Ellis, the retired former World Boxing Association champion, during a training camp sparring session, a spokesman for Ali's camp reported.

Pairs of buttons to allow Consolidated Edison Company system operators to reduce wattage or disconnect customers virtually instantaneously are to be installed in the company's energy control center by the end of October, company officials disclosed yesterday at a state inquiry into the blackout of July 13.

Frank Lucchesi, the former manager of the Texas Rangers, filed a civil personal-injury suit yesterday against Lenny Randle, now with the New York Mets, Randle, frustrated at losing his starting job with the Rangers to Bump Wills, attacked Lucchesi at Tinkers Field in Orlando, Fla., last March 28.

THE SPECIAL QUALITY of Ger trude Stein's writing is that it is funny, sad and dignified in a wrold somewhere between a prison and a catastrophe. She is subversive, but it is the subversion of some one who pretends the bars are not there because she knows she can't get through them. She was too bulky, perhaps. The answer to desolation is an ingenious disorder: She is the last child, playing alone among ruins.

Nobody wins when the Federal Government regulates domestic airlines. Passengers pay more as much as $2 billion more each year, according to the General Accounting Office than they would if airlines set their own fares and routes. Most airlines barely turn a profit: High fares are offset by millions of unsold seats because travelers are priced out of the market. And the economy suffers: Fewer travelers means fewer jobs for airline employees to serve them.

The National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians said yesterday it had reached a tentative settlement with the American Broadcasting Companies of a strike of network employees that started May 17.

Perhaps fans of the New York Yankees are cautious, but the club reported yesterday there had been no telephone calls nor any mail orders for playoff tickets. SOPHIA LOREN turned 43 on Tuesday. The private sector's authority on accounting rules moved yesterday to scrap a requirement that companies disclose data on such things as major customers in their quarterly financial reports.

HOWELL, N.J. Route 9 in Monmouth County is the vehicular spine through what has been one of the most active home-building regions in the metropolitan area over the last 10 years. Monmouth itself is among New Jersey's fastest growing counties.

Dry weather had a dampening effect on soybean futures prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. To traders, good weather currently indicates more harvesting, which in turn means more beans moving from farms to grain elevators. A large number of grain elevator owners selling futures leads to lower prices.

THE DISASTER NOVEL has almost become a category of popular fiction, like mysteries, romances or Gothics. A term that can encompass "Jaws" and "The "Towering Inferno" probably is open to charges of imprecision; still, terms arise when there is a need for them and there have veen a lot of books focusing on some sort of central cataclysm, whether man-made or natural, that wipes out a sizable number of people.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept 22 Sister Janice McLaughlin, an American Roman Catholic nun who had been imprisoned for three weeks in Rhodesia on charges brought under the country's security laws, was deported today.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 (AP) Ivan I. Artobolevsky, a Soviet scientist, has died at the age of 71, Tass reported today. Dr. Artobolevsky was the originator and chief exponent of Soviet theory on machines and mechanisms. He published the first university textbook on the subject in 1940 and edited standard works on closely related topics.

Radioactive debris from the Chinese nuclear test conducted in the atmosphere last Saturday is expected to begin passing over the New York metropolitan area and other parts of the Northeastern coast at midnight tonight. Its passage is expected to continue for about 24 hours, according to the Brookhaven National Laboratory here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI) Pan American World Airways has received a multimillion-dollar Pentagon contract despite opposition from the Labor and Transportation Departments based on the airline's maternity policy for stewardesses.

LEXINGTON, Ky. Charles W. Colson, former aide to President Nixon and a convicted Watergate figure, stood before 200 attentive inmates at the Federal Correctional Institution here the other day and preached his "born again" message.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt said today that Arabs were "ready for the first time to accept Israel as a Middle Eastern country to live in peace in this area."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22 Egypt drew on President Carter's own words today to justify its request for a General Assembly debate on what it termed illegal measures by Israel to establish Jewish settlements on the West Bank of the Jordan.
The North American Publishing Company, has added a third consumer magazine to its titles (Cue and Audio) by acquiring New Dawn from the Montcalm Publishing Company.

Dr. Clilan B. Powell, editor and publisher emeritus of The New York Amsterdam News and the first black member of the New York State Athletic Commission, died yesterday at his home in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. He was 83 years old.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 22 About $1 million in Law Enforcement Assistance Administration funds will be withheld from Nassau County as a result of yesterday's Federal suit charging the county's Police Department with discrimination in its recruiting and promotion policies, a Justice Department spokesman said today.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 22 (AP) Bert Blyleven, the right-handed curveball specialist, hurled a no-hitter tonight in the Texas Rangers' 6-0 victory over the California Angels.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 22 (AP) Lee May cracked a three-run homer and Mike Flanagan pitched a six-hitter as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Toronto Blue Jays, 7-1, tonight and moved within 1 games of first-place New York in the American League East.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Sept. 22 (AP) Using rakes and grading machines, workers scraped the last traces of an 800-gallon Alaska crude oil spill from one of southern California's most popular beaches today.

ROME, Sept. 22 (UPI) Italy's state Institute for Industrial Reconstruction went ahead today with a controversial plan to sell its controlling interest in a construction giant to Italian and United States businessmen, including former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally.

DETROIT, Sept. 22 (UPI) Car and truck producers this week are planning the heaviest overtime schedule since the startup of 1978-model production during the summer as they prepare to introduce the new models.

Pamela Jean White, a legal assistant with the Denver law firm of James Lapin, was married yesterday to Harold Frederick Riebesell Jr., a partner in the Denver law firm of Mason, Reuler and Peek. The ceremony was performed in the First Presbyterian Church in Hilton Head, S.C., by the Rev. Dr. James Black.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The National Council of Churches of Korea, which has often criticized the South Korean Government, has urged Tongsun Park to return to the United States from Seoul to face an indictment for alleged bribery of American Congressmen.

TRENTON, Sept. 22 Governor Byrne today announced that checks totaling more than $136 million from the proceeds of the state income tax were ready to be mailed out to property owners in the form of homestead rebates, and he said that he did not rule out the possibility of attempting to amend the income-tax law to delete a provision that the income tax expire on June 30, 1978.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22 The arms race among the major industrialized nations is continuing at an alarming tempo and such developments as the talks on limiting strategic arms, the Helsinki Conference and detente have failed to make a discernible impact on the situation, according to a study made public here today.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Sept. 22 Marvin Beckman, a 24-year-old graduate engineering student at Rice University in Houston, led seven other skippers today after the first three races in the annual Clifford D. Mallory Cup regatta for the United States men's sailing championship.

My son and his wife are not married. They have lived together for seven years without benefit of license. Though occasionally marriage has been a subject of conjecture, it did not seem important until the day they announced, jubilantly, that they were going to have a child. It was happy news. I was ready and eager to become a grandmother. Now, I thought, they will take the final step and make their relationship legal.

THE COURT BATTLE that began last May over the canvases of Arnold Friedman (1872-1946), a painter praised by critics but ignored by art marketeers, has been won at least for the moment by heirs to his estate. Surrogate Louis D. Laurino of Queens County has decided that 305 Friedman works in the possession of Charles Egan, an art dealer, must be returned to the Friedman heirs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) Airline passengers now have 45 days to file claims for lost or damaged baggage under a rule adopted today by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

Govenor Carey has put forth Morton P. Hyman, a 41-year-old lawyer and shipping executive, as his candidate for the proposed post of Director and Coordinator of Health for New York City, a job that city and state officials have likened to a health "czar."

LONDON, Sept. 22 Sir Eric Miller, a prominent British realty operator and friend of Sir Harold Wilson, died early today from an apparently self-inflicted gunshot wound. He was 50 years old. Rising from poverty, Sir Eric built the Peachey Property Corp., Ltd., into the biggest residential property company in Britain and was knighted as Sir Harold left the prime ministry last year.

Michael Sedgwick is not the kind of singer one normally expects to find in a supper club. He has a well-developed, trained voice a strong, high tenor and a delivery that would be completely at home in operettas of the vintage of "The Student Prince" or "Naughty Marietta." In actuality, Mr. Sedgwick's background encompasses more contemporary musicals the London productions of "Oklahoma!" and "Brigadoon" but his basic style is of an older school.

Naomi Sorkin, who left her position as a soloist with American Ballet Theater to try her foot at other styles, returns to the local dance scene tonight at 8 with the modern Kazuko Hirabayashi Dance Theater at Marymount Manhattan Theater, 211 East 71st Street. WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera will visit Israel next week as the guest of Prime Minister Menahem Begin on one leg of a trip aimed at easing ratification of the new Panama Canal treaties in both Panama and the United States.

Paul Kolton, who in July disclosed that he would not be seeking a renewal of his present tour of duty as chairman and chief executive of the American Stock Exchange, has made his first offthe-floor corporate connection. Hoffman, the former State Labor and Industry Commissioner, who broke with Governor Byrne a year ago and ran unsuccessfully for the Democratic nomination for Governor this year, today endorsed the Republican gubernatorial candidate, Senator Raymond H. Bateman of Somerville.

PARIS, Friday, Sept. 23(AP) A meeting of France's leftist alliance broke up early today with Socialists and Communists still bitterly divided over the issue of nationalization. The parties are seeking to update their joint platform in time for national legislative elections next March.

ROME, Sept. 22 (Reuters) Italy had a record $1.03 billion balance-of-payments surplus in August, enabling it to repay some of its heavy foreign debts, the Bank of Italy announced today.

Mr. Lance should try to save his good name, the friend said, but not his job.

WASHINGTON A stockholder receives dividends. A songwriter collects royalties. Each pays Federal tax on the income from these valuable assets. A house owner also holds a valuable asset. If he rented it to someone else, he would have to pay taxes on the rental income. If he pays the rental income to himself, in effect, by living in the house, he incurs no tax liability.

EVANSTON, Ill., Sept. 23 A group of newspaper editors and minority journalists agreed today that, although the number of blacks and other minorities working on newspapers has more than doubled in the last five years, the problem of how to give adequate news coverage to minorities continues to perplex editors of newspapers with predominantly white readership.

Last Call Tardy gardeners who were fooled by the recent mild September weather delayed bringing their summering house plants indoors. They'd better be speedy about it now for early frost threatens anytime and it would surely damage the plants. Besides, pot plants need a bit of time under the house roof to readjust themselves to life indoors.

FALL FOLIAGE One of the best places in the East to see the countryside burst into color is the Pocono Mountains of northeastern Pennsylvania. These low-lying hills, amid 2,400 square miles of lake-studded woodland, are now coming aflame with the scarlet of oak and maple leaves, the gold of aspen and tulip trees and the reds and greens of sumac and hemlock.

Keith Hunter, a talented quarterback, tossed four touchdown passes yesterday as Barringer shut out Franklin Township, 36-0, at Franklin. Hunter completed touchdown bombs of 21, 43 and 80 yards to Byron McMillan, a wide receiver, and hooked up with Rich Alston from 7 yards out. Alston scored Barringer's other touchdown on a 40yard burst. Hunter hit on six of nine passes for 169 yards.
